webTitle: Sun-dried strip for masters of spin

fields.headline: Sun-dried strip for masters of spin
fields.standfirst: Pitch is primed for a Mushtaq attack, writes  Mike Selvey
fields.trailText: The pitch at the Gaddafi stadium is primed for a Mushtaq attack, writes Mike Selvey
fields.body:
With 48 hours to go before the start of the first Test, the pitch at the Gaddafi stadium yesterday morning was having the last residue of moisture sucked from it by the sun.

Normally, the locals tell you, top-flight surfaces are produced here that help the pace bowlers in the morning when the dew still lingers. It usually has an early clamminess to it that allows the batsmen their pound of flesh for a couple of days, and then the spinners come into play. Twirly men get their wickets in Lahore but so do the quickies.

But this pitch is already biscuit-dry, grassless and with a mosaic of cracks. Push with a finger and they move.

Javed Miandad, the Pakistan coach, had promised a turning pitch for England's batsmen in the same gleeful way that one might offer an agoraphobe a walk across the Gobi Desert. This looks like being no idle threat. The pitch will crumble and with it, many believe, England's chances of competing in this series, offered up on the altar to the mysteries, wiles and genius of Saqlain Mushtaq and Mushtaq Ahmed.

For years, ever since uncovered pitches disappeared from the game, English batsmen have been laid waste by class spin bowling in helpful conditions. Abdul Qadir, Shane Warne, Anil Kumble, Stuart MacGill and Muttiah Muralitharan have all, at times, exposed poor techniques, leaden footwork and frail confidence. This winter, first in Pakistan and then Sri Lanka, offers as stern a test as any for England.

Each on his own, Mushtaq or Saqlain would be a match winner. Together they represent the most formidable examination of batting skills that can be offered by spin today.

At 30 Mushtaq is the elder by six years and more experienced by 20 Tests. England first encountered him in Saiwal on Mike Gatting's tour when, as a teenager, he employed the Qadir strut in to bowl. He took wickets even then and has since claimed 32 victims in eight Tests against them.

Saqlain by contrast has never played a Test against England, although he is familiar with them from his exploits at Surrey which brought him 66 wickets at 15 runs apiece in 12 matches last season. Only Muralitharan challenges his spin supremacy today.

Saqlain and Mushtaq pose different sets of problems. The former spins from the finger and is deadly accurate, and his arm-ball, unique as far as anyone can remember, spins away from the right-hander and appears to be undetectable. The theory is that this is spun over the top of the hand in the manner of a finger-spun top-spinner, but with unusual flexibility the rotation is angled not down the pitch but towards first slip. It is to his armoury what a completely disguised googly is to Mushtaq's.

Indeed, Mushtaq employs all the tricks that a wrist spinner can muster: leg-break and googly, of course, but top-spinner, flipper and all the variations in between as well, all delivered from a high arm with enviable accuracy.

If they operate in tandem England will have no respite. Mike Atherton, for one, appreciates the difficulties inherent in each, although he has played only once against Saqlain. "The problem with him is the thing that turns, not just floats, away. You would be looking to play an orthodox off-spinner on a turning pitch to the leg-side with the spin and do the bulk of your scoring there. He is happy to see you do that because you would be hitting this mystery ball across the line.

"You simply have to learn to pick which way it is going either from the hand or in the air. Off the pitch is a last resort. The earlier the better and you need to be selective about the leg-side rather than hitting there willy-nilly."

Mushtaq can spin his leg-spinner hard, but bowls with a high arm in contrast to Warne or, say, Ian Salisbury, and gets less sideways movement but more bounce as a result. Of him, Atherton says that the key has to be looking at the hand and trying to pick the variations early.

"He does give it some air," he said, "so you might think about using your feet if you are comfortable with the prospect. In general, though, the key is to pick the length and use quick and precise footwork."

One of the compelling prospects of the next few weeks will be to watch how the England batsmen develop individual counter-measures. Alec Stewart, for example, now more confident against spin first up, will use his feet and hit down the ground, whereas Graeme Hick hits over the top more readily than most and made a century against Muralitharan at the Oval a couple of years ago. Nasser Hussain, on the other hand, likes to sweep the ball.

Perhaps the likeliest batsman to succeed will be the left-handed Graham Thorpe, a worker of the ball, who will more readily oppose Saqlain's variation and Mushtaq's more spun leg-break.

webTitle: The 15 most powerful people in the voluntary sector

fields.headline: The 15 most powerful people in the voluntary sector
fields.trailText:
1. Stuart Etherington
Chief executive, National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO)
NCVO
Described as "the sector' s politician and tactician". Etherington has ensured that the NCVO is at the heart of recent sector developments such as the Compact and Getting Britain Giving Campaign.
fields.body:
1. Stuart Etherington
Chief executive, National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO)
NCVO
Described as "the sector' s politician and tactician". Etherington has ensured that the NCVO is at the heart of recent sector developments such as the Compact and Getting Britain Giving Campaign.

2. Michael Brophy
Chief executive, Charities Aid Foundation
CAF Online
One panellist called him "the strategist and power-broker of the monied side of the sector, a visionary with two feet on the ground". Brophy has made CAF a powerful force in the international voluntary sector and one of the main drivers behind the Getting Britain Giving Campaign

3. Lord Joffe
Chair of Oxfam
Oxfam
The elder statesman of the voluntary sector, Joel Joffe carries immense authority based on his long, varied and successful experience.

4.Lord Melchett
Executive director, Greenpeace
Greenpeace
Peter Melchett has "grabbed the headlines like no other voluntary sector CEO." Although he has recently announced his intention to resign he continues to highlight the issues of GM food testing.

5. Baroness Pitkeathley
Chair of the New Opportunities Fund (NOF)
NOF
With the NOF set to become the largest distributor of funds to good causes, Jill Pitkeathley is hugely influential in the way the sector is developing.

6. Charles Secrett
Chief executive, Friends of the Earth
Friends of the Earth
Deserves credit for ensuring that Friends of the Earth remains a force to be reckoned with as it champions the public's right to a safer and healthier planet.

7. Giles Pegram
Director of appeals, National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children
NSPCC
Has headed one of the most ambitious fundraising campaigns of recent years, highlighting the issue of child abuse and campaigning for its eradication.

8. Gerald Oppenheim
Director, UK and corporate planning, National Lottery Charities Board
National Lottery Charities Board
"Very definitely the power behind the throne at the Lottery Board and beyond." Immensely influential throughout government and the grant-making world on public policy issues affecting the sector.

9. Nick Partridge
Chief executive, Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse
Terrence Higgins Trust
Has been very effective in promoting legislative change and a healthier and more realistic attitude to sexuality.

10. John Stoker
Chief Charity Commissioner
Charity Commission
Stoker took over the Commission in July 1999. He is responsible for overseeing the regulation of charities.

11. Ann Pettifor
Director of Jubilee 2000
Jubilee 2000 Coalition
"If I had to choose one person in the world who has been instrumental in focusing political and media attention on globalisation and debt cancellation it would be Ann," says one of the panellists.

12. Professor Ian Bruce
Chief executive, Royal National Institute for the Blind
RNIB
He has made RNIB one of the most powerful disability organisations in the country. Through his work with the Volprof initiative at the City University Business School, he has transformed the way that many charities think about marketing.

13. Mike Whitlam
Chief executive of the Mentor Foundation
Mentor Foundation
He was previously chief executive of the British Red Cross Society, saw it through a major reorganisation and was acknowledged for his outstanding influence on good practice during this time.

14. Esther Rantzen
Chair, Childline
Childline
"A truly effective charity campaigner with over twenty years of active commitment to the sector that is often masked by media hype," says one of our panellists.

15. James Strachan
Chief executive, Royal National Institute for Deaf People
Royal National Institute for Deaf People
A commissioner on the Disability Rights Commission, Strachan, is influential within the wider context of disability issues.

Feedback: what do you think of the Power 90 panel's choices? Please send your comments to editor@societytheguardian.com

webTitle: Police swoop on Dalmiya in corruption inquiry

fields.headline: Police swoop on Dalmiya in corruption inquiry
fields.trailText: India's nine-month probe into corruption focused on the murky world of television rights yesterday when detectives raided the home of the former chairman of the ICC Jagmohan Dalmiya.
fields.body:
Indian detectives yesterday raided the home of world cricket's former chairman Jagmohan Dalmiya as the focus of their nine-month probe into corruption shifted dramatically to the murky world of television rights.

Officers from India's Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) swooped on Dalmiya's Calcutta home in search of evidence relating to the sale of TV rights for five major sports tournaments. They included last year's cricket World Cup, the 1998 knockout trophy in Dhaka (Bangladesh), and the 1997 Independence Cup.

In five cities across India investigators made 25 other raids on the homes and offices of officials from the TV companies involved in the deals. They included senior executives from the state-run network Doordarshan, India's broadcasting authority and the Bangalore office of the sports promoter Mark Mascarenhas.

CBI prosecutors last night filed a case against Dalmiya, Mascarenhas and six former Doordarshan officials, accusing them of abusing their positions and engaging in a criminal conspiracy. The conspiracy involved three private TV companies, including Mascarenhas's sports management firm WorldTel, CBI sources alleged. It is customary for prosecutors to lodge a case in this way, setting out the scope of their investigations.

Prosecutors from the CBI were last night also examining the sale of Indian TV rights to two lucrative tennis tournaments, Wimbledon 1997 and the French Open the same year.

"A criminal investigation has been set in motion. We have registered five cases in connection with the televising of sports rights," the CBI sources confirmed.

Yesterday's move came 11 days after the CBI stunned international cricket with its report which accused Alec Stewart, England's former captain, of accepting £5,000 from an Indian bookmaker, Mukesh Gupta. The report also implicated West Indies, Pakistan, New Zealand and Sri Lanka players.

The first photos have emerged of Gupta, revealing him as a heavily built, seemingly respectable businessman with a faint scar on his forehead. He has been in hiding since his allegations, which formed the basis of the CBI's report, were made public. A separate investigation by India's cricket board of control is continuing.

Dalmiya, 54, who retired in June after three years as International Cricket Council chairman, denies any wrongdoing and he said that he told the CBI yesterday: "These papers are not with me. These papers are not here. Whatever papers you are looking for, you tell me."

Dalmiya was first accused in May of colluding with Mascarenhas and WorldTel over the sale at an unrealistically low price of the 1998 Dhaka rights. He allegedly persuaded Doordarshan to raise its bid for both Indian and non-Indian rights from $4m to $11m (£7.8m), far more than the network had intended to pay. But at the last minute the ICC changed the bidding rules and WorldTel, collaborating with a TV marketing firm, Stracon, won the world rights for a bargain $3m. The deal allegedly defrauded Doordarshan. The money was then paid into the ICC's offshore bank accounts in the Virgin Islands. Mascarenhas too has denied wrongdoing.

Tax investigators searched Dalmiya's home as part of a widespread operation in India for undeclared assets.

webTitle: Hampson furious at Flintoff recall

fields.headline: Hampson furious at Flintoff recall
fields.trailText: Andrew Flintoff has rejoined the England party as batting cover for Michael Vaughan, at the risk of serious long-term problems according to his fitness coach.
fields.body:
Andrew Flintoff, the England all-rounder who flew home after the one-day series against Pakistan, has rejoined the party as batting cover for Michael Vaughan before tomorrow's first Test. His fitness coach, however, is furious about the decision to recall him.

Steve Hampson, the former Great Britain rugby league international, said the selectors risked worsening the persistent problem with Flintoff's back. "They could have sent for someone else. For me, he wants to get his back sorted out as soon as possible as it could lead to very serious long-term problems."

The chairman of the Test selectors, David Graveney, said Flintoff's injury would not be aggravated because he was going out as a specialist batsman and would not be bowling. But Hampson disagreed. "If you're 6ft 5 and you're bent over at the crease, for whatever length of time, it's definitely going to hurt."

Flintoff, chosen ahead of the standby batsmen Mark Ramprakash and John Crawley because he is acclimatised, arrived in Pakistan in the early hours of this morning and will practise today. With the news on Vaughan not promising, he has a moderate chance of playing tomorrow.

The England physiotherapist Dean Conway said Vaughan was "very doubtful" after straining a calf muscle while fielding in Peshawar on Saturday. The injury did not appear serious then and he was able to bat, but the flight down to Lahore that evening caused the muscle to stiffen. A final assessment will be made today.

However, it looks as if Flintoff will play only if England choose seven batsmen and only one spin bowler. The odds are shifting away from that now, especially after the Pakistan captain Moin Khan suggested his side might play four spinners, depending on the state of the wicket. And if Vaughan recovers quickly and the rest stay fit, Flintoff may be home again before the tour finishes.

Meanwhile Dominic Cork has been ruled out of the Test with a side strain and may not play again on the tour. His absence from the bowling attack makes it essential that Craig White plays to give the side balance; there is cautious optimism that White's damaged hamstring can stand the strain of a five-day Test.

The captain Nasser Hussain will almost certainly be declared fit after a recurrence of a back niggle that has bothered him at times over the past couple of years.

 Bangladesh's first ever Test ended in a nine-wicket defeat by India in Dhaka. The 10th and newest side in the Test arena were dismissed for 91 in their second innings, setting India only 62 to win, which they achieved for the loss of one wicket on the fourth day.

Bangladesh started the match encouragingly with 400 exactly in their first innings but were undone when they batted again by the pace of Javagal Srinath and the left-arm spin of Sunil Joshi, who both took three wickets. Joshi, the man of the match, also batted well for 92 out of India's 429.

Bangladesh's first-innings total was the second highest by a team in their maiden Test, behind Zimbabwe's 456 against India in Harare in 1992-93, but in their second innings only two players reached double figures and their last seven wickets went for 38 runs.

India now have a Test series at home against Zimbabwe starting on Saturday.

webTitle: The 15 most powerful people in regeneration

fields.headline: The 15 most powerful people in regeneration
fields.trailText:
1. Moira Wallace
Head, Social Exclusion Unit
Social Exclusion Unit
Former Treasury high-flyer, has played a leading role in developing the government's regeneration policy. In charge of Tony Blair's grand instrument of social justice, the Social Exclusion Unit, aimed at improving the lives of the marginalised.
fields.body:
1. Moira Wallace
Head, Social Exclusion Unit
Social Exclusion Unit
Former Treasury high-flyer, has played a leading role in developing the government's regeneration policy. In charge of Tony Blair's grand instrument of social justice, the Social Exclusion Unit, aimed at improving the lives of the marginalised.

A career civil servant, Wallace joined the Treasury in 1985 and quickly worked her way up to become the chancellor's private secretary in 1987, and the prime minister's economic affairs private secretary in 1995. She joined the SEU in 1997.

Its solutions, set out in the draft neighbourhood renewal strategy (NRS), tend towards the localist, rubbishing attempts to impose solutions from the centre and instead calling for much greater integration at the grassroots level. The NRS has raised high hopes of giving communities real power over their own regeneration projects, and the government is committed to many of its aims. Local government minister Hilary Armstrong is said to see the renewal agenda as her key role now that her programme of local government reform is being implemented.

Wallace and the rest of the government still face a serious challenge to convince community groups of their strategy's worth. But social exclusion is Blair's baby and Wallace is the more than capable midwife.

2. Ed Balls
Chief economic advisor to the Treasury
HM Treasury
Known jocularly as "the deputy chancellor", Balls is the chancellor's most trusted advisor with a major influence on all areas of financial policy. Said to be an important figure in Labour's drive towards a new urban policy.

3. Paul Evans
Director of regeneration, Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR)
DETR Regeneration site
Respected civil servant spearheading regeneration policy. Has crucial overview of the government's bafflingly wide range of initiatives.

4. Michael Bichard
Permanent secretary, Department for Education and Employment (DfEE)
DfEE
Education is vital to successful regeneration, but the DfEE is often seen as working against joined-up government. Bichard, with his reputation as a trusted moderniser at the top table of the mandarinate, could play a role in changing that.

5. Lord Rogers of Riverside
Chair of the Urban Task Force
DETR Urban Task Force site
The famous architect Richard Rogers of Millenium dome fame, whose report is helping to shape the urban white paper and, by extension, regeneration policy. Said to be a favourite advisor of both Blair and John Prescott.

6. Graham Hall
Chairman, Yorkshire Forward
Yorkshire Forward
Arguably the most influential of the eight English regional development agency chiefs. Also chief executive of the Yorkshire Electricity Group.

7. Nigel Crisp
Chief executive, NHS
NHS
Health is a vital part of regeneration policy. If Mr Crisp's NHS takes its eye off the ball of joined-up regeneration efforts, it will make redevelopment much more difficult.

8. Graham Hawker

webTitle: England bet big on futures market

fields.headline: England bet big on futures market
fields.standfirst:
As Peter Taylor starts again, Richard Williams asks whether the academy system will deliver a new era of heroes
Loss of Owen narrows England options
fields.trailText: As England prepare to launch a new generation of footballers on to the international scene, how well-equipped is the academy system to produce young players fit for the demands of the modern game.
fields.body:
One afternoon last month, barely a week before his sudden death at the age of 56, George Armstrong was leaning on a rail at Arsenal's training ground, watching the under-19s. On their way to a comfortable win over Watford, the junior Gunners were looking impressive. But Armstrong, the club's reserve team coach, was taking a longer view.

"If they get rid of the transfer system," he said, pausing to applaud a fine pass from Moritz Volz, the tall German boy in midfield, "the wages will go mad. There'll be some 20-year-olds on 30 grand a week. And then how on earth are you going to persuade them to come back and train in the afternoons?"

As England prepare to launch a new generation of footballers on to the international scene in Turin tomorrow night, the future training and education of young players within the domestic game may be an even more important consideration than the identity of the next national coach. Arsenal are one of 38 English clubs participating in the FA Premier League academy system, now in its third year, and using it as a means of raising the level of locally produced players to match the standard of the young talent also being recruited from around the world.

George Armstrong was part of that process. Thirty years ago, when Arsenal won their first league and cup double, the little Geordie winger missed not a single match all season. Raised in the deepest traditions of the English game, he nevertheless recognised the benefits that came with the arrival of Arsène Wenger. Running the reserves in the Wenger era meant not just grooming young players for the first team squad but helping them cope with the radical changes to the environment in which professional footballers grow up. If it all went according to plan, one or two of those boys on the training pitch would find themselves earning 30 grand a week before their 21st birthdays.

"Some of the clubs we play," Armstrong continued, "fill their reserve sides with senior players who can't get a game in the first team. But the manager here likes me to play the kids." A couple of nights later his team travelled to Chelsea and, featuring barely a name familiar to the average Premier League fan, lost by the only goal to a team stuffed with internationally known figures.

The players selected by Armstrong for what was to be his last side were almost all the products of Arsenal's youth scheme, which is run by another great figure from Highbury's recent past. From his office within the club's new training headquarters at London Colney, just inside the M25, Liam Brady supervises the progress of a group of around 130 boys aged between eight and 19, all of whom, under academy rules, live no further than 90 minutes' travel away.

During their first five years with the club, Brady explained, the boys train for six to eight hours a week at evenings and weekends. From the age of 13, roughly 10 boys a year are sent to Higham Park School in Walthamstow where, in return for grants that have helped provide the school with a performing arts centre, the academic timetable is adjusted to allow the boys more time with club coaches at a special facility close to the school. "It's been good for them, as far as we can tell," Steve Riches, the school's deputy head, said last week. "We try to give them as normal a programme as possible, to help them keep their options open."

This is the way things are being done at the de luxe end of the academy system, which was designed by Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director, to provide the same quality of coaching as France's centres de formation , the platform for success set up by Gérard Houllier, Aimé Jacquet and their fellow visionaries. "The idea is to give the clubs greater access to the boys," Wilkinson said. "By starting at nine rather than 13, the clubs have more of an opportunity to influence their technical, social, intellectual and emotional development. Everything is intensified. You get not only a better footballer, but a person who can deal with the problems that come with being a top-class athlete."

Another advantage of getting them four years earlier, Liam Brady pointed out, is a reduction of the influence of boys clubs and schools teams, those good-hearted incubators of the sort of crash-bang football that became the curse of the English game. Now all the early coaching is directed at developing skills, with the object of "getting them to fall in love with the game", in Brady's words.

"You wouldn't be getting a boy of that age to run half-laps in 28 seconds," he said. "That comes later. And as they get older, you're also teaching them about their responsibilities to their team-mates. We're encouraging them to be confident in their own ability, and to try things, but we're also telling them that essentially teams are what win matches and trophies."

Although academy status is given only to clubs capable of fulfilling a set of strict conditions concerning personnel, facilities and procedures, some critics of the scheme express doubts that, in all but a handful of clubs, the development of the coaching side is keeping pace. In France, for instance, where "coaching the coaches" is the keystone of the national football philosophy, the coaches are called together once a year for a week's compulsory intensive training at one of the regional centres. In England, by contrast, the annual requirement is 36 hours of in-service training.

"It's like producing school teachers," Wilkinson, himself a former teacher, said. "You hope they'll feel they have a vocation, and that they'll want to enthuse the kids and get them to aspire to better things. So we have a continuous professional development programme, which people are not always enthusiastic about."

But in purely footballing terms the FA's technical director has no intention of imposing any sort of national tactical formula. "We want to educate the coaches better and then encourage them to add their own thoughts and imagination to the mix," he said. "It would be totally wrong to turn out clones. It's not about giving them an A-to-Z of football practices."

Instead the tactical philosophy must come from within each club. "We play 4-4-2," Brady said, "because that's the way Arsenal play, and I think it's important to have that kind of continuity. The manager has never insisted on it, but it's obvious that if we want to get our players into the first team, they've got to feel at home with the system when they make the step up."

Although Brady's bunch includes boys from Germany, Brazil, France and Zaire, many of the brightest prospects are English, such as the Peterborough-born David Bentley, a 16-year-old whose uncommon vision and technique make him appear the natural heir to Dennis Bergkamp's No10 shirt. The benefits are reciprocal. The foreign players learn to cope with the pace of the English game while the English boys are exposed to ideas from other footballing cultures. Brady mentioned watching the 19-year-old left-back Ashley Cole, a member of England's Under-21 squad for tonight's match against Italy in Monza, making his Arsenal first-team debut. "The first thing he's looking for is to get the ball to Bergkamp's feet or Henry's feet. Now that's a drastic change. Down the years, he'd have been told to belt it into the channels."

At a club such as Arsenal, the quality of coaching is not in question. But for men like Brady, the frustration comes when their managers solve a short-term problem by picking up a foreign telephone directory and reaching for the chequebook. Wenger has used the less significant cup ties to blood some of his youngsters, but Brady, who established himself in the Arsenal first team at 18, knows that such a swift transition is much harder now that the stakes are so high.

"If even one or two from each year make it into the first team squad, we'll have done our job," he said over a bowl of soup in the training centre's restaurant, where the under-17s and under-19s were mingling between matches. "The boys have to come to terms with that. Whoever you are, you're not going to have a smooth ride all the way through your career. If you can't handle disappointment, you're not going to make it."

The young players receive a degree of pastoral care that would have been inconceivable a few years ago. "You try to show a boy that he has to live a certain lifestyle if he's going to achieve his aims, and you show him that this lifestyle goes hand in hand with being a caring individual, with respecting authority, and with respecting team discipline. If he can learn all that, it's a lesson that will help him to succeed in his life beyond football."

His eyes swivelled to the queue of boys waiting for their lunch. "Michael! Take that off and put it in your pocket!" A young man in a club tracksuit swiftly removed the large gold medallion from around his neck. "John! What are you doing, eating that? You've got a match kicking off in an hour and a half!" And another boy sheepishly replaced the lid of the soup tureen before putting his bread roll back into a basket.

Small things. Small lessons. All part of a footballer's education, nowadays designed not merely to win matches and trophies and international caps but, as George Armstrong recognised, to confront perhaps the most testing opponent of all, the unimaginable impact on a young life of 30 grand a week. On its success, far more than on tomorrow night's result, England's footballing future rests.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Tord Grip, Ker Plunk and other safe bets for success

fields.headline: Tord Grip, Ker Plunk and other safe bets for success
fields.trailText: Given the protracted debate since the "Starting gate" scandal blew up, it's odds-on Sven-Goran Eriksson will make off-the field games a priority when he takes over.
fields.body:
All last week players, managers and pundits felt moved to speak about the allegations of heavy gambling in the England camp, or "Starting gate" as the affair has become known.

Paul Merson wondered why the players looked so tired at the European championships, Peter Taylor said he would limit the amount of time spent on cards, and Paul Ince wisely observed that "brag and poker can be examinations of a person's bottle" (one minute the Guv'nor is talking of a "coward" in the dressing room, the next of the life lessons to be learnt from Texas Hold 'Em. Anyone would think the Boro midfielder was turning into Kenny Rogers). Things entered a new phase at the weekend when the FA confirmed that it would be backing Kevin Keegan's legal action against the News of the World. Though whether Adam Crozier and his colleagues have spent time weighing up the odds before deciding to take a punt on it is not recorded.

Naturally some experts have denounced the furore. According to them it is all a media-generated fuss which serves only to distract attention from important matters such as coaching and technique. Nothing could be further from the truth, of course, because off-the-field pastimes are as integral to the English footballer's professional life as the phrase "to be fair" is to the conversation of Peter Beardsley. They could not function without them. Coaching and technique are the peripheral issues here.

A keen student of football's past, Sven-Goran Eriksson will be well aware of the situation that prevailed when England truly was a world footballing power. During the inter-war years players in this country rarely saw a football from one Saturday to the next. The leading managers of the time knew only too well that prolonged sessions kicking a ball about are likely to leave your salt-of-the-earth English lad feeling drained and listless. Instead from Monday to Friday the players honed their mental and physical skills with hopscotch, leap-frog and British bulldog. In 1939 when the national team travelled to Milan and secured a 2-2 draw with the world champions Italy their preparation consisted of nothing more than a marathon beetle drive on the train journey.

It is my belief that the first thing Eriksson will address when he takes over as England boss will be the games situation. Most modern players are unlikely to know the rules of battleships, never mind the intricacies of elastic skips or battledore and shuttlecock, so the Swede will be looking to update the system much as Don Revie did when he created a Leeds United side that sent a shudder through Europe thanks to a combination of skill, ruthlessness, carpet bowls and bingo.

Eriksson, his assistant Tord Grip and the Scandinavian psychologist Dr Willi Railo will have been looking at methods of combining the best of England's old ways with styles more in keeping with the modern age. Some games are clearly not suitable. Pokémon is too addictive and everyone knows the effect Nintendo had on David James. Monopoly likewise can be easily dismissed: today's players will simply not be able to come to terms with the tiny sums of money involved. Others, though, will come under closer scrutiny.

The trio might, for example, have spent a day of two assessing the potential of Buckaroo as a replacement for Montana Red Dog. Certainly the saddle-stacking game with the moody mule provides an even more thorough test of a player's nerves than five-card stud. But would the sheer tension of attempting to place the banjo on the kicking quadruped's back when he's already weighed down with a lasso, a frying pan and a bunch of dynamite prove too enervating for Martin Keown and company?

Ker Plunk also offers a ferocious examination of mental strength. The presence of so many pointy sticks, however, may be seen as a liability. Many footballers are afflicted with the rare medical condition Stupid Injury Syndrome, or Beasant's Disease as it is sometimes known, and are likely to get them painfully wedged under their toenails. And although Mousetrap involves the players working together to construct the complex rodent entrapment device (a great team-building element) experience shows that it often ends with an almighty row over who gets to release the ball bearing.

A complicated intellectual problem for the thoughtful Eriksson, then, the outcome of which is hard to predict. Though the rumour is that a certain well placed international defender has got 50 grand riding on a Pictionary and Twister double.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

A complicated intellectual problem for the thoughtful Eriksson, then, the outcome of which is hard to predict. webTitle: Leeds rule out Viduka, Australia call him in

fields.headline: Leeds rule out Viduka, Australia call him in
fields.trailText: Despite David O'Leary's assertion that Mark Viduka is unfit, Australia manager Frank Farina has called the striker for a medical ahead of the country's friendly against Scotland on Wednesday.
fields.body:
Mark Viduka, who angered the Leeds manager David O'Leary by insisting on playing for his country in the Sydney Olympics, was embroiled last night in another club versus country struggle.

Although O'Leary said his £6m leading scorer was unfit after suffering an ankle injury at Chelsea on Sunday, Australia called Viduka to their training camp in Glasgow for an examination before tomorrow's friendly with Scotland.

The Socceroos' coach Frank Farina said last night: "We'll have a look at him, have a consultation with the club and a decision will most probably be made tomorrow or the day of the game.

"I spoke with David O'Leary this morning. For a player who has scored the team's last nine goals in the Premiership he would be a bit concerned.

"We had a good chat. David asked us to have a look at him, he was very concerned. He felt Viduka wasn't ready. But he added of the striker: "It's always good to see players who are very keen and want to play for their country."

Beset by injuries since summer, Leeds have been without another Australian forward, Harry Kewell, this season and on Sunday O'Leary pulled Alan Smith out of England's squad for Italy, though the manager admitted the risk of tiredness rather than an ankle problem prompted his action. His club play West Ham on Saturday before a European Champions League tie with the title-holders Real Madrid the following Wednesday.

Arsenal's Thierry Henry is out of France's friendly against Turkey in Istanbul. The striker travelled home but was sent back after national team doctors examined his groin strain, sustained in the 0-0 draw with Derby.

In Italy, Napoli sacked their Czech coach Zdenek Zeman yesterday and have approached Emiliano Mondonico, formerly in charge of Torino, to steer the club away from the bottom of Serie A. Zeman, Sven-Goran Eriksson's predecessor at Lazio, took over the newly promoted club in summer but Napoli failed to win any of their opening six games and have just two points.

He is the second coach to be dismissed in Serie A this season following Internazionale's sacking of Marcello Lippi after only one game.

Napoli want Mondonico as soon as possible but there are problems. He was replaced as Torino's coach after their relegation to Serie B last season but remains technically under contract to the club.

 Phil Babb and Mark Kennedy were effectively shown a legal yellow card yesterday by a Dublin judge after damaging a policewoman's car during drunken "wild horseplay". The Republic of Ireland players both pleaded guilty to being drunk and disorderly, breaching the peace, and criminal damage after the early-hours incident in August. They were dealt with under the Irish Probation Act which means that, though they have no criminal record, the matter can be raised again if they commit another offence. They had apologised to the policewoman and paid the £510 car damage.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Ferguson in war of hearts and minds

fields.headline: Ferguson in war of hearts and minds
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson believes the cushy lifestyles of today's young players has turned them into softies.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson believes today's young players need to develop their minds, not their skills, to cope with their cushy lifestyles.

The life of today's young players, says the Manchester United manager, is far different to when he was a lad. "People's lifestyles have changed," he says. "Nobody walks anywhere any more - everyone goes by car.

"This has softened them up not just physically but, far more importantly, mentally. People don't want to suffer pain - in fact they don't know what it is. These days you need to develop the minds of young players far more than their skills."

When Ryan Giggs and David Beckham burst into the first team he made a point of restricting their public appearances until they were of an age to cope with the pressures.

"You need to strike a balance between treating players like children or responsible adults," says Ferguson. "I've kept quite strict control over the likes of Ryan Giggs and Beckham.

"But once they are older, and you see them coping with the media and all the pressure, you have to admit they have matured. At that point the only thing to do is take a step back and accept they are out of my hands."

Ferguson also reckons United have benefited from having a squad liberally laced with home-grown players rather than packed full of foreigners.

"One reason for our strength is that nobody wants to leave us. We have created an atmosphere in which all the players, including the ones who are not regular first-teamers, feel happy all the time.

"David Beckham doesn't feel he needs to move to a club in Spain. He plays in front of 60,000 adoring fans every home game."

webTitle: Loss of Owen narrows England options

fields.headline: Loss of Owen narrows England options
fields.trailText: David Lacey reports as England caretaker-coach Peter Taylor experiment in youth faces up to the loss of valuable experience in the form of Michael Owen and Paul Scholes.
fields.body:
The wand of youth which Peter Taylor, England's caretaker-coach, will wield over the team for tomorrow night's friendly against Italy in the Stadio Delle Alpi is in danger of smacking less of the Magic Circle than Tommy Cooper at his zaniest.

Taylor will not be short of international rabbits to pull out of the hat but yesterday's withdrawal of Manchester United's Paul Scholes and Liverpool's Michael Owen has narrowed his options in creating a relatively experienced framework for his experiment. "This will not change the shape of the side I had intended to play," he said last night, "but it's a little bit of a blow."

Scholes and Owen were sent home yesterday morning when both reported injuries during England's final training session before the party left for Turin. Scholes has a thigh injury and Owen a back problem which had been worrying him for a week.

With another Old Trafford man, Wes Brown, dropping out on Sunday because of a knee injury and David O'Leary, the Leeds manager, withdrawing Alan Smith after their game at Chelsea through a combination of exhaustion and a sore ankle, Taylor has suffered the sort of problem with withdrawals that beset his predecessors.

Yet as he originally announced a squad of 26 he still has 22 players to work with.

Certainly he is determined to look on the bright side. "I don't think losing four out of 26 is too terrible at all."

Nevertheless, having deliberately confined his selections to players aged 30 and under, losing Scholes will further expose tomorrow's raw England team to the experience of an Italian side which, if Giovanni Trappatoni chooses, could include eight of the players who appeared in this summer's Euro 2000 final.

Either way it looks as if one of the principal points of Taylor's exercise will be to see if Emile Heskey might be capable of leading the England attack towards the 2002 World Cup. The 22-year-old Liverpool striker, enjoying prolific form in the Premiership, looks certain to be in the side Taylor will announce today, and presumably his club-mate Robbie Fowler has a better chance than Kevin Phillips of partnering him.

Last night Taylor positively glowed about Heskey's prowess since he was picking him for the England Under-21 team. "He's looking very good," said the England coach. "His back-to-goal game has improved and he's scoring regularly."

The absence of Scholes may mean another international opportunity for Frank Lampard, who shares the Manchester United man's propensity for moving into scoring positions from midfield. And if Taylor adheres to the 3-5-2 formation he employed with the Under-21s and now uses at Leicester City, the defensive place in midfield could go to Liverpool's Steven Gerrard.

The make-up and balance of Taylor's midfield will be crucial to his chances of seeing a quality of performance to justify his revolutionary approach to this game. If Kieron Dyer or Darren Anderton plays on the right, David Beckham will captain the team from a central position having made a decent though inconclusive stab at the role when England held France to 1-1 in Paris in September.

The role of Gareth Barry, at 19 the youngest player in the squad, will also determine what sort of evening England experience. For Villa, Barry normally plays on the left side of a back three but, as the France game showed, he is not averse to operating as a left-wing-back, which could see him preferred there to Derby County's Seth Johnson.

This would probably mean Gary Neville and Rio Ferdinand joining Southgate in a defence which already looks shorn of international clout without Martin Keown as well as the injured Tony Adams and Sol Campbell. But whoever plays at the back will rely on the midfield not giving the ball away, and against one of the most possession-conscious teams in the world this will hardly be easy.

England (possible, 3-5-2): James; G Neville, Ferdinand, Southgate; Dyer, Beckham, Gerrard, Lampard, Barry; Heskey, Fowler.

webTitle: Fundraising at the edge of the world

fields.headline: Fundraising at the edge of the world
fields.trailText: From dog sledding in the Arctic to quad biking in Namibia - are there any limits to a fundraiser's capacity? Not according to international charity Children's Aid Direct, which has launched a series of expeditions in extreme conditions to take place early next year.
fields.body:
From dog sledding in the Arctic to quad biking in Namibia - are there any limits to a fundraiser's capacity? Not according to international charity Children's Aid Direct, which has launched a series of expeditions in extreme conditions to take place early next year.

Mark Davey, expedition organiser at Children's Aid Direct, says: "The growth in adventure tourism has been highlighted in the charity sector by the success of overseas fundraising events. Most of these are based on trekking or cycling. But there is a growing trend to seek out more adventurous activities, and more exciting locations."

Fundraising from overseas events is a new departure for the charity, which has so far concentrated on challenge events in the UK, raising £1.3m this year. However, they are venturing into an area that has received criticism recently. Charity challenges have had a bad press this year for asking people to sponsor participants who use the money to pay for the holiday. However Children's Aid Direct insists on the cost being met by the participant and for fundraising to be a separate enterprise.

"We chose this method of funding the events in response to our research, which showed that 62% of people would prefer to pay all of their expedition costs and fundraise separately," says Davey.

The Arctic expedition, taking place towards the end of February 2001, allows adventurers to travel more than 150 miles by dog sled, snowmobile and snowshoe, and venture 260 miles into the Arctic Circle. The Skeleton Coast expedition in April will take people through highland desert wilderness in one of Africa's largest countries, Namibia, using 4x4 vehicles.

webTitle: Encouraging community finance initiatives

fields.headline: Encouraging community finance initiatives
fields.standfirst: The Charity Commission is to issue guidelines on how charities can make the most out of community investment
fields.trailText: The Charity Commission is to issue guidelines on how charities can make the most out of community investment.
fields.body:
The recommendations of a social investment taskforce in October were taken up by the Treasury in the chancellor's pre-budget statement and will also result in new guidance from the Charity Commission.

One of the main aims of the taskforce recommendations and the planned Charity Commission guidance is to encourage charitable trusts and other voluntary organisations to get more involved in community finance initiatives by investing in such schemes and helping to build their capacity.

Community development finance involves providing loans or equity to individuals or enterprises in under-invested communities. Unlike mainstream finance, these funds have a social objective rather than a purely financial aim.

One problem with developing charitable support for community development has been uncertainty about when community development finance is charitable and when it is not.

Not all regeneration activity is charitable, says the taskforce, because the balance between the public and private benefits of any initiative have to be considered. In other words, any private benefit generated by, for example, supporting small businesses must be outweighed by a wider public benefit for the scheme to count as charitable.

A number of community finance funds have been launched in recent years with the involvement of the public, private and voluntary sectors. They include the Aston Reinvestment Trust in Birmingham, Charities Aid Foundation's Investors in Society loan fund and the charity Local Investment Fund.

The social investment taskforce was chaired by venture capitalist Ronald Cohen but also included voluntary sector and community regeneration experts. It reported that more private capital should be channelled into deprived communities to invest in not-for-profit and for-profit enterprises. The government has agreed to consult on introducing a tax credit for private investment in community development institutions, one of the taskforce's main recommendations. It has also agreed to help set up the first community venture capital fund, which will invest in small businesses in under-invested communities.

One of the obstacles to the development of community finance in the UK, the taskforce found, has been the uncertainty many charities feel about their powers in this area. For example, charities were not always aware of the extent to which they could undertake "programme-related investment": activities with the primary purpose of accomplishing their charitable objectives by providing equity or loans.

Geraldine Peacock, chief executive of Guide Dogs for the Blind and a taskforce member, said charities have felt inhibited about getting involved in community development finance and that a "change in mindset" was required. "The voluntary sector has a key role to play in facilitating the release of private sector funds into community finance initiatives," she says.

The ability of charities to support programme-related investment will be encouraged further if the Charity Commission adopts the "total return" approach to charity investment on which it is currently consulting. This would allow charities with a permanent endowment to have programme-related investments as part of their overall investment portfolio.

The Charity Commission announced it would be issuing new guidance in mid-December on community capacity-building as a charitable purpose. It will issue guidance early next year to emphasise the flexibility that many charities have to use their funds to provide equity finance and loans, as well as making grants to further their charitable objectives. There will also be guidance next year, in conjunction with charities and other interested parties, on the important role charities can play in community development finance.

webTitle: The 15 most powerful people in social care

fields.headline: The 15 most powerful people in social care
fields.trailText:
1. Denise Platt
Chief inspector, Social Services Inspectorate, Department of Health
Social Services Inspectorate
A figure held in high regard in local and central government, with access to political power, Platt "operates effectively to promote not just social work but the whole of social care at the centre and to the public," said a panellist. "She's dangerous - when she wants to be," said another.
fields.body:
1. Denise Platt
Chief inspector, Social Services Inspectorate, Department of Health
Social Services Inspectorate
A figure held in high regard in local and central government, with access to political power, Platt "operates effectively to promote not just social work but the whole of social care at the centre and to the public," said a panellist. "She's dangerous - when she wants to be," said another.

Platt has held many of the top posts in social services, after starting out as a hospital social worker. She was the first head of social services at the Local Government Association. She has been a president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, while social services director at Hammersmith and Fulham council in west London. When she became social services chief inspector in 1998, she was the first woman to hold the post for a generation.

"She's a well established figure in social care and she's now in a powerful role in the Department of Health, delivering government's social care agenda," said one panel expert.

Spearheading an "increasingly interventionist" inspectorate, Platt might be expected to have a fascination for targets and indicators. But her main concern appears to be the qualitative experience of social care clients, rather than ticking check boxes.

2. Robert Hill
No 10 policy unit policy adviser
Number 10 Downing Street
Former binman and union official turned social care and health policy guru. Ultra-moderniser. Track record of key influence on regulation and public service issues for more than a decade. One commentator said: "Civil servants recognise his hand behind No 10 responses - but search and you will not find much about him." His modernising approach is admired and loathed in equal measures by those in the know.

3. Lord Warner of Brockley
Chairman of the Youth Justice Board
Youth Justice Board
Norman Warner is a former Kent social services director (from 1985 to 1991), a former senior policy adviser to the home secretary, author of the influential 1992 Warner Report on staff in children's homes. Has the ear of ministers - most importantly, home secretary Jack Straw.

4. Chai Patel
Chief executive, Westminster Healthcare
Heads one of the biggest private sector care home providers. Labour Party donor. Involved in advising government on elderly care and member of the Cabinet Office better regulation task force. Said to be responsible for government plans to use private care homes to provide intermediate care for elderly patients leaving hospital. His recent CBE shows the esteem in which Blair's government holds him.

5. Angus Skinner
Chief inspector, Social Work Services Inspectorate, Scottish Executive
Scottish Executive
Intelligent and politically astute player among Scotland's civil service. His work on developing centres of excellence has ramifications for social care good practice elsewhere. Some see him as having betrayed Scottish social work departments but few, if any, doubt his commitment to service users and the quality of their lives.

6. Naomi Eisenstadt
Head of Sure Start unit at the Department for Education and Employment
Sure Start
Long history of working on children's issues, particularly in the voluntary sector, including establishing a pioneering Milton Keynes family centre seen as a national model of good practice. Ex-chief executive of the Family Services Units charity before joining Sure Start in early 1999. Key player in drive to end child poverty.

7. Andrew Foster
Controller, Audit Commission
The Audit Commission
Former social worker and senior NHS manager. Head of the most influential regulatory body in the public sector. Does most of his talking behind the scenes in Whitehall. Audit Commission reports are influential at a national political and local service level.

8. John Ransford
Head of social affairs, health and housing at the Local Government Association
LGAnet
Seen as an effective backroom lobbyist. Former chief executive and social services director of North Yorkshire council. One-time honorary secretary of the Association of Directors of Social Services.

9. Inez McCormack
President of the Irish Congress of Trade Unions
Irish Congress of Trade Unions
Also regional secretary of public sector union Unison and member of the Northern Ireland civic forum (a body set up by the Good Friday agreement to act as an advisory body on economic, social and cultural matters). Committed fighter for human rights and working-class people, and a role model for women in senior positions. She proves that you can play with power and retain your integrity and your sense of humour.

10. Catriona Williams
Director, Children in Wales
A highly influential figure in the development of new Welsh child care strategies after the Waterhouse report on abuse in north Wales residential children's homes. A possible contender for post of Welsh children's commissioner.

11. Wendy Thomson
Head of best value inspection at the Audit Commission
The Audit Commission
Her team will review every social services department in England and Wales, so she cannot fail but to influence thinking at a local level. A smart and highly regarded former chief executive of Newham council. Said to be tough to work with.

12. Sandy Cameron
Director of social work, South Lanarkshire Council
South Lanarkshire Council
A lobbyist for social services and for people who use them. Influential in Scotland on the issues of social care, health, criminal justice and local government. One panel member said that Cameron was interested in "power and management" - and added that he would make a good head of the new Scottish commission for the regulation of care.

13. Mary Marshall

webTitle: 'Ain't No Mountain High Enough...but I'll pass on the valleys'

fields.headline: 'Ain't No Mountain High Enough...but I'll pass on the valleys'
fields.standfirst: Simon Reid-Henry tackles the highs and lows of adventure tourism in New Zealand.
fields.trailText: Simon Reid-Henry tackles the highs and lows of adventure tourism in New Zealand.
fields.body:
"What do you mean, wear shorts? It's freezing up there" I protested.

"Naah! Don't be such a great galaaah, you'll be fine mate!" replied the guide. He lied. Climbing New Zealand's Franz Josef Glacier in shorts is a palpably bad idea. It's freezing up there.

The Franz Josef is found plum in the middle of the Southern Alps, the backbone of the South Island and metamorphic heart of the nation's outdoor sports obsession. True, its not one of the most demanding activities you can do in this antipodean island. But the scenery has something wild and dark about it, that takes away more breath than the climb, and unlike when you're extreming it on the 'North Face', here you can actually appreciate the view on your way up. It's not without its pitfalls though, quite literally, and they'll rope you up on the trickier bits to make sure no one takes an icy tumble.

Once at the top it's out with the thermos of hot tea. In the time it takes to have one cup the weather can cloak you in fog, blind you with the sun and hurl you with sleet. All of which leaves you longing for the hot sauna that awaits you back at the lodge and not a little annoyed that you're wearing shorts.

Of course, those looking for a little more adrenalin in their afternoon tea, or who are even happy to miss it altogether, can find plenty of more outlandish activities in nearby Queenstown. Whether it's skiing, Bungee jumping, riding 'The Luge', or even paragliding its all there to be done, and you will probably get talked in to doing it.

Something that seems to figure highly in the many subsequent tales of derring-do in the land of sheep and lambs are the thrills and spills to be had in a Shotover jet. Shotover jets are 15 seater speedboats that hurl you along mountain gorges at upwards of a squillion miles an hour. But let the Guardian here bring you an exclusive, because few seem to know about a similar 'treat' offered by the ever-competitive North Island.

North Islanders are renowned for having their feet a little more on the ground than their Southern brethren, but not in the case of one Taupo farmer. This entrepreneurial individual who lives next door to a well-frequented coach stopover, has built in his backyard what can only be described as a cross between a pond and a racetrack. About a foot deep at best, and featuring chicanes, flats and the works, he floats upon this aquatic Brands Hatch a boat of his own fashioning. Essentially a modified bathtub, it sports an engine of a former aircraft that rotates on its axel, allowing him to turn on a button.

The acceleration of the 'boat' heaps petrol-spitting scorn on the space shuttle, and as the driver takes you - one at a time - towards the first dead end (he hasn't told you he can turn on a button yet) he turns to look right at you, and asks, almost as if making polite conversation, when precisely you would like him to turn.

"Now!!" you might well venture.

"I'm sorry" he says, endearingly leaning forward like a patient grandfather used to mishearing what year of school you are now in.

'"Now!!!" You scream, willingly accepting the loss in bravura if only he'll turn the damn boat before you crash.

"Right'O" he beams in a well-practised (and fortunately well-timed) manoeuvre, and swings you round to hurtle back towards your friends, who up until they see where you are heading, and the size of the bow wave they are about to be drowned under, were laughing heartily at your expense.

Somehow, he manages to fit all this into the 15 minutes of your coach stop, taking you from travel-weary slumber to near heart attack quicker than you can realise he's charging you fifteen bucks for the privelege. Next time it'll be the relatively languid pace of the shotover jet for me, either that or I'll stick to the mountains where it's safe!

So, New Zealand...dontcha wanna?

webTitle: Painful start to town hall revolution

fields.headline: Painful start to town hall revolution
fields.standfirst: Councils face testing times in their quest for increased openness and accountability
fields.trailText: Councils face testing times in their quest for increased openness and accountability.
fields.body:
It's make or break time for town hall modernisers. With the Local Government Act rapidly coming into force, ministers and campaigners face the first test of the new political structures they have created to make town halls more open, efficient and accountable.

Failure to make cabinet-style council leadership and directly elected city mayors work will dent the credibility of the government as a whole and seriously damage the reputations of Tony Blair and local government minister Hilary Armstrong.

Fortunately for them, the voters seem to like the idea of change. A recent ICM poll showed that more than half of respondents thought mayors would improve council accountability, and there has been an explosion in the number of campaign groups working to collect the 5% of local voter signatures needed to force a referendum for a mayor. Berwick-upon-Tweed borough council showed just how easy this could be when independent councillor Brian Douglas launched a one-man referendum campaign and quickly collected the 1,100 signatures he needed.

Many in local government speak of a domino effect, arguing that once one city puts a mayor in place, others will be persuaded to follow. And this is already happening. Ministers are working to organise a democracy day of mayoral referendums across the country, which could take place late next year. The key to persuading campaigners and councillors from as far afield as Liverpool and Lewisham to come on board was Birmingham city council's decision to ballot on a mayor.

This is despite widespread resistance to the idea of mayors from local politicians. Research from the Local Government Association earlier this year showed that just 1% of councils wanted a mayor, and that the vast majority favoured cabinet-style local government. But while this may be the less radical option, it could prove just as difficult to implement.

The media has given the new structures associated with the modernisers a rough ride because of plans for cabinet councillors to take decisions in private. The regional press, opposition politicians and freedom of information campaigners have persuaded the government to make concessions on openness. Ministers now insist councils take key decisions in public, but concerns remain about how authorities will define which decisions are "key".

More worryingly, research on the new structures has not been positive. A government report on six councils that were piloting the new arrangements expressed concern that the scrutiny of cabinet decisions was poorly developed. This scrutiny function is crucial to the government's new structures, and is designed to give backbench councillors a chance to hold their executive colleagues to account. The findings point to a long period of upheaval and confusion in local government before the new structures bed down.

The lack of enthusiasm for modernisation among many councillors could prolong and complicate that process. More than a third of those who stood down at this year's local elections gave political modernisation as a reason. Conservatives in particular feel cabinets and mayors are an unwanted Whitehall imposition, and politicians of all parties fear their role will decline as day-to-day executive power is concentrated in the hands of a small number of local councillors.

The changes will also affect local government officials, who will have to reassess their position in relation to these more powerful politicians. Senior officers who are used to having an important policy-making role could find themselves becoming simple administrators under a city mayor, and Birmingham's chief executive Sir Michael Lyons recently announced his resignation for just this reason.

The concerns are understandable. Officers, councillors, ministers and campaigners are now exposed to the electorate in a way they never have been before. Local voters have the power to directly effect a revolution in their town and city halls, and to make or break political careers in the process. If they topple one domino, the chances are that more will follow.

webTitle: Japan's ruling party split on bid to oust leader

fields.headline: Japan's ruling party split on bid to oust leader
fields.standfirst: Party diehards are rallying round the unpopular prime minister, but the country's economic crisis could set the seal on his fate, reports Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: Party diehards are rallying round the unpopular prime minister, but the country's economic crisis could set the seal on his fate, Jonathan Watts reports.
fields.body:
At the dusty headquarters of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party the air is thick with the talk of rebellion, betrayal and upheaval.

The building in Tokyo's Nagatacho district is usually the calm control centre of one of the world's most effective political machines, which has held power for all but one of the past 45 years.

But it has plunged into a chaos of accusation and counter-accusation since Friday, when LDP heavyweight Koichi Kato made a blatant grab for power by calling for the resignation of his party boss, the prime minister Yoshiro Mori.

This revolt has stirred up the Japanese political world like few other events in recent years and prompted pundits to suggest that the country could at last be witnessing the beginning of the end of Mr Mori and, possibly, the LDP.

But in many respects the revolt resembles nothing more than a rerun of the change of government in 1993 that promised so much and delivered so little.

As was the case seven years ago, the nation's leader is spectacularly unpopular and there is widespread distrust of politics. In 1993, it was prime minister Kiichi MIyazawa, who bore the brunt of public anger over bribery scandals and economic decline, with approval ratings of less than 10 per cent according to some polls.

Today, the target of abuse is the gaffe-prone prime minister Yoshiro Mori, who is disliked by more than 70% of voters. His support is shrinking fast. According to a survey released on Monday by NHK, the state-run broadcaster, Mr Mori's approval rating has declined by seven points in the past month to 17%.

As in 1993, the economic outlook is also uncertain. Last week, the government downgraded its assessment of the nation's growth prospects for the first time in two years. There are also parallels in the recent series of sex and bribery scandals that forced the resignation of several government ministers and weakened the standing of the the prime minister.

In such circumstances it is easy for challengers to follow the golden rule for getting ahead in politics: always kick a man when he is down.

Mr Ozawa did his stomping by leaving the LDP. By contrast, Mr Kato is putting the boot in from within by saying that he needs to take the helm of a party that is currently sinking like the Titanic and dragging the nation down with it.

"If we continue on this way, Japan's economy, its vision of the future and its status in Asia and the world will decline rapidly," he said in a television interview.

He has threatened to vote against Mr Mori in a no-confidence vote that the opposition are expected to submit later this month.

With the support of his own 45-member faction and another group of 19 MPs lead by an ally, Mr Kato could help the opposition to overturn the government's majority in the 480-seat lower house of parliament. If the no-confidence vote is passed, Mr Mori would either have to resign or to call a general election.

It is still far from certain that Mr Kato will win the numbers game. LDP elders have been working feverishly behind the scenes to break up his support. They have also encouraged Kato faction members in the cabinet - such as Kiichi Miyazawa, who is now finance minister - to criticise his disloyalty. But if neither side blinks in the next two or three weeks, the outcome of the vote is likely to depend on how many urban-based LDP politicians feel that Mr Kato offers them the best chance of electoral survival.

Even if Mr Kato is successful in ousting Mr Mori, there are doubts as to whether he is the right man to change the course of Japanese government, which has run up a public debt worth 120% of GDP in a vain 10-year attempt to revitalise the economy .

Like Mr Ozawa, Mr Kato projects himself as a moderniser. He is in favour of small government, deregulation and fiscal rectitude. A Harvard-educated former diplomat who is fluent in Chinese, he can also claim to offer far more of a global perspective than Mr Mori, whose views are widely criticised as insular and anachronistic.

But Mr Kato, who is not known for his charisma or leadership qualities, would not be the choice of most Japanese people for prime minister. He is seen as a product of the status-quo that he claims to want to change. He is a former bureaucrat, a master of LDP backroom deals and no stranger to political funding scandals.

When Ozawa left the party in 1993, Kato played a central role in bringing it back into power a year later by helping to negotiate a coalition government.

At that time, he dismissed Ozawa and his supporters as being nothing more than an alliance of anti-LDP opportunists. The criticism stuck: the government of prime minister Morihiro Hosokawa, which started amid such high hopes for reform, soon disintegrated without a shared and coherent vision.

The danger is that Kato will suffer the same fate unless he can distinguish himself from the current administration. He has promised to do this by producing a policy platform by the end of the week. It is likely to include tax increases, which are favoured by the opposition. This would signal a tightening of fiscal policy - one of three possible fault lines in Japanese politics along with a growing rural-urban split and a long-standing divide between supporters and opponents of reforming the nation's peace-advocating constitution.

Unless Mr Kato can draw clear battle lines on one or all of these issues, he will be labeled a negative candidate who is merely capitalising ing on the unpopularity of the prime minister. Voters need a lot of persuading that they have not seen it all before.

At that time, he dismissed Ozawa and his supporters as being nothing more than an alliance of anti-LDP opportunists. The criticism stuck: the government of prime minister Morihiro Hosokawa, which started amid such high hopes for reform, soon disintegrated without a shared and coherent vision. The danger is that Kato will suffer the same fate unless he can distinguish himself from the current administration. He has promised to do this by producing a policy platform by the end of the week. It is likely to include tax increases, which are favoured by the opposition. This would signal a tightening of fiscal policy - one of three possible fault lines in Japanese politics along with a growing rural-urban split and a long-standing divide between supporters and opponents of reforming the nation's peace-advocating constitution. Unless Mr Kato can draw clear battle lines on one or all of these issues, he will be labeled a negative candidate who is merely capitalising ing on the unpopularity of the prime minister. Voters need a lot of persuading that they have not seen it all before. webTitle: Cancer charity puts clinical trials details on the web

fields.headline: Cancer charity puts clinical trials details on the web
fields.trailText: The Cancer Research Campaign has launched a web service that gives cancer patients information about clinical trials.
fields.body:
The Cancer Research Campaign has launched a web service that gives cancer patients information about clinical trials.

Patients are able to check whether they are eligible for a particular trial, print off the details and then discuss with their doctor whether they could be included in the trial.

The publication of the details on the CancerHelp UK website represents the first time this information has been directly available to the public in Britain.

Professor Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said: "In the US, this sort of information is already available to patients and they demand to be put on trials because it ensures they get the very best available treatment. We want to give patients far more control of their own destiny. That's what this website is all about."

The charity says trials are important because they can give patients the chance of receiving cutting-edge treatment.

Dr Nick James, a CRC-funded scientist and senior lecturer in clinical oncology at the University of Birmingham, said: "Trials will shift forward knowledge about treatment and empower patients to take control of things."

The clinical trials section is one of several new features on the revamped CancerHelp UK website, which was set up by the University of Birmingham and the CRC four years ago.

webTitle: Osman gets top job at BBC

fields.headline: Osman gets top job at BBC
fields.trailText: 6.45pm The BBC's head of press Sally Osman was tonight confirmed as the new head of communications for the corporation.
fields.body:
Two of the BBC's most senior PR women have strengthened their grip on the corporation's publicity machine.

The BBC's head of press Sally Osman was tonight confirmed as the new head of communications for the corporation.

And Vanda Rumney, head of TV publicity, has been promoted to take responsibility for publicity across all media.

Ms Osman, decided not to apply for the marketing director's job which has been made vacant by the resignation of Matthew Bannister.

In a memo to staff tonight Mr Bannister said: "Having looked both externally and internally, it was quite clear that she was the outstanding figure in the industry with the qualities we need to lead this important area."

Donald Steel, currently the chief press officer, will head up the new "rapid response" team, which is already earning a reputation as a rapid rebuttal unit.

webTitle: Hackney is much too PC

fields.headline: Hackney is much too PC
fields.standfirst: In Hackney, PC stands for privatisation and cuts
fields.trailText: Hackney council's humiliation goes deeper than incompetence. It goes back to Baroness Thatcher's assault on local democracy, argues Paul Foot.
fields.body:
My local council, Hackney, is bust. Why? Huge articles in the Guardian and Observer concentrated on the incompetence of councillors and officials. The Guardian traced the Hackney horror back to 1982 when "the hard left took over".

Well, the hard left, if it ever existed, vanished without trace from Hackney council years ago. So did the entire left. The council is now run by a Labour rump in coalition with a Tory rump helped out by Liberal Democrats who are always eager to take part in anything PC. PC used to stand for "politically correct" but now it stands for the two remedies to which all three major parties aspire: privatisation and cuts.

How has a once vibrant local Labour party been so humiliated? The answer goes much deeper than incompetence. It goes back to Thatcher's assault on local democracy. Her government abolished the large councils which raised some of their rates from the rich to help the poor (GLC, Ilea and the metropolitan boroughs), and stifled the rest by capping their ability to raise rates. This put a stop to the process of municipal reform that sustained so many Labour councillors when they were elected (including rightwing Labour politicians like Herbert Morrison, the first Labour mayor of Hackney).

In reply to Thatcher, there was none of the defiance shown by another Labour mayor, George Lansbury, at Poplar in 1921. He went to prison rather than implement government policies against the poor. "The workers must be given tangible proof that Labour administration means something different from capitalist administration," he said.

No such proof was available to local electors during Thatcher's attack on them. So the problem became not the power of local councils but their impotence. If you can't do anything about poverty in your area, why bother being a councillor at all? In areas like Hackney, pretty well everyone with any reformist inclination has dropped out of the council, leaving the spineless residue with nothing but PC - privatisation and cuts.

The government meanwhile treats elected local councils as springboards for their vacuous public relations offensives. I cite a press release issued by Hackney Council on March 18 1998 entitled "Top government official helps launch Hackney's anti-poverty strategy". The "top government official" was Guy Gardiner from the cabinet office's social exclusion unit who visited Hackney the following day for the launch of the council's "ground-breaking anti-poverty strategy". The ground was broken with Hackney's two MPs over appropriately proletarian fish and chips in a local pensioners' club. The strategy, said the press release, "is closely linked to Prime Minister Tony Blair's work on social exclusion". A foreword to the strategy was written by Professor Peter Townsend, the veteran anti-poverty campaigner. The strategy, wrote Townsend, needed "decently paid jobs and more of them in local public services".

What happened to that strategy? It vanished as fast as the fish and chips. A cabinet office spokeswoman told me nothing more was said on the matter. Guy Gardiner, who turns out to be an assistant chief constable in Kent, was an "external adviser" to the cabinet office. And now, as Hackney disappears under mountains of rubbish bags, the strategy of providing more jobs in the public services has been replaced by, well, you've guessed it, privatisation and cuts (and the sacking of hundreds of public service workers). Blair's great campaign against social exclusion turns out to be devoted in Hackney to social exclusion on an unimaginable scale.
