webTitle: The state of the Florida recount

fields.headline: Vote count could be cut off tonight
fields.trailText: A Florida judge ruled today that Florida officials may cut off the vote count in the fiercely  contested US presidential election at 5pm (2200 GMT) but must give consideration to late revised counts.
fields.body:
A Florida judge ruled today that Florida officials may cut off the vote count in the fiercely contested US presidential election at 5pm (2200 GMT) but must give consideration to late revised counts.

Judge Terry Lewis ruled that counties may file supplemental or corrected totals after the deadline, and Florida's Republican secretary of state, Katherine Harris, may consider them if she employs "the sound exercise of discretion".

It is a blow for Al Gore whose lawyers are expected to appeal against the decision in Tallahassee to Florida's supreme court.They have less than four hours to do so.

Earlier, Mr Gore's campaign team swiftly rejected "out of hand" a suggestion by George W Bush's team of a way to resolve Florida's contested election.

The Bush team had pledged to accept the results of manual recounts in scattered counties if Mr Gore would agree to a halt in the counting at the disputed 5pm (2200GMT) deadline set by state election officials.

"If the Gore campaign accepts this proposal and drops its litigation, we will dismiss our lawsuits," the Republican former secretary of state, James A Baker III, said at a news conference in Tallahassee.

Otherwise, Mr Baker said, "when is it going to end? I ask you, when is it going to end?"

William Daley, the Gore campaign manager, rejected the offer, saying Democrats would await the then impending court decision.

But as important as the Lewis ruling is, it is only one of a mushrooming series of events popping up around the state that stands to pick the next president. Mr Bush held a 388-vote in an unofficial tally by the Associated Press, although the vote totals will change with the recounts as well as with the tally of overseas absentee ballots set for Friday night.

Florida offers 25 electoral vote and the candidate who wins them stands to become the nation's 43rd president after one of the closest elections in history.

Meanwhile, Mr Bush's lead in New Mexico disappeared when officials in Dona Ana County found 500 votes that had not been counted for Mr Gore. That gave Gore a 374-vote lead in the state, which has five electoral votes.

A Gore victory in New Mexico would not affect the fact that Florida's equally close vote determines the outcome of the presidential election. But it would make any Gore victory more decisive and a Bush victory even narrower, with just two electoral votes to spare.

Representatives for Mr Bush and Mr Gore have been clashing all day over the deadline aimed at shutting down all vote counting in Florida except for overseas ballots.

Heavily Democratic Palm Beach county delayed its recount while the legal battle played out.

Earlier today, representing Mr Gore, the former secretary of state, Warren Christopher, accused Ms Harris, the chief elections official in Florida and a Bush supporter, of taking a "move in the direction of partisan politics" by sticking with the 5pm deadline for certifying the county-by-county results.

However, Karen Hughes, a spokeswoman for Mr Bush, responded: "The vice president essentially said we should ignore the law so that he can overturn the results of this election." The Republicans are still considering whether to take their fight to block a manual count to an appeals court, and perhaps the supreme court.

The Gore campaign won a federal court ruling yesterday that permitted hand recounts to continue in a few Democratic areas of the state. Officials in Palm Beach County, a Democratic bastion, said they cannot finish their hand count in time to meet the deadline, and they opted today to delay action until they see whether they have the authority to proceed.

A hand count was proceeding in Volusia County while officials in Miami-Dade County were deciding today whether to take the same step.

Even as Bush representatives intensified their efforts to get the counting wrapped up quickly, except for overseas ballots that must be received by midnight on Friday, Mr Christopher said he wouldn't rule out the idea of broadening the hand recount to cover the entire state if that suggestion were put in play.

"It's certainly something we'd want to look at," he said. "Anything that would bring this to a fair result is one that I think we would have to look at very carefully."

But both Mr Christopher and William Daley, Gore's campaign chief, said no such deal had been discussed with Mr Bush's officials.

The Los Angeles Times reported today that some officials in both campaigns are intrigued by the idea of a state-wide recount to break the deadlock, but the two sides have not discussed it with each other yet.

Meanwhile today, Mr Bush's lead in New Mexico disappeared today when officials in Dona Ana County found 500 votes that had not been counted for Gore. That gave Mr Gore a 374-vote lead in the state, which has five electoral votes.

A Gore victory in New Mexico would not affect the fact that Florida's equally close vote determines the outcome of the presidential election. But it would make any Gore victory more decisive and a Bush victory even narrower, with just two electoral votes to spare.

Mr Gore went before cameras outside the White House yesterday and said: "I would not want to win the presidency by a few votes cast in error or misinterpreted or not counted, and I don't think Governor Bush wants that either."

One week after the nation voted, neither contender has an electoral college majority, and both need the 25 electoral votes offered by Florida to fashion one.

Mr Bush holds a 388-vote lead in an unofficial state wide recount tally maintained by the Associated Press, not including the unknown number of overseas absentee ballots.

Mr Gore leads in the national vote by about 200,000. However, the US presidency is not decided on the popular vote but by the electoral college. Under this arcane system, each state has as many electoral votes as congress members, with all electors usually going to whoever gets most votes statewide.

The contested election played out in far-flung portions of the state on Monday. County workers sifted through thousands of ballots in Volusia County, where a complete Gore-requested hand recount was in progress. In the area around Fort Lauderdale, a check of a few precincts turned up only a few changes, and local officials voted 2-1 against a recount of all of Broward County that Mr Gore had sought.

The partial recount, covering 3,892 votes in three precincts, turned up four additional votes for the vice president. Democrats promptly planned an appeal. Officials in Miami-Dade county were considering whether to yield to a Gore campaign request and conduct a manual recount in their area.

In the south Florida district court yesterday, Judge Donald Middlebrooks listened to conflicting arguments about the relative powers of the federal and state governments, before rejecting a Republican attempt to stop the hand count in Florida on constitutional grounds. "While I share a desire for finality, I do not believe it is served by involving a federal court," he said.

Today, new polls suggested that Americans are intensely interested in the struggle to settle the presidential election, but a majority say they are not extremely worried about it. Two-thirds of Americans in an ABC News-Washington Post poll said the current struggle is "just the kind of thing that can happen in a very close election".

webTitle: On being short

fields.headline: That extra inch or two
fields.standfirst: On being short
fields.trailText: On being short
fields.body:
Schoolgirl Emma Richards had both her legs broken and stretched on a metal frame in the hope she would "grow" from a worthless 4ft 9ins to a more respectable 5ft 3ins and so meet the minimum height requirement to become an air hostess. The painful process has left Richards, now 16, at a lowly 5ft 2ins - an inch short of her dreams; so for that all-important final inch she is taking growth hormones.

As a fellow shortie - although I prefer the word petite - and as someone who is at least a couple of inches below the minimum requirement, I can sympathise, to an extent. I wish I were taller virtually every morning, just before I wish I were thinner, just after I've wished for a bigger chest.

There are outfits I will not wear without certain shoes for fear of looking "stumpy". I am paranoid about being patronised and quick to accuse if I think I am being talked down to because of my height, or lack of it. I am fully aware that some people, men more often than women, equate short with incapable and worse still, "cute". I have no shame in admitting I'd love an extra inch or two. I kid myself and anyone who asks that I'm 5ft something, when it's probably closer to nothing (or less).

But would I resort to having six five-inch metal pins screwed into my freshly broken legs and turned four times a day, for four months, to stretch the bone? Grow up. In fact I can't imagine any sane adult choosing to through such a painful process. Worse still, enduring a six-hour operation not because I have a medical problem, but to become an air hostess? For the pleasure of being at the beck and call of hundreds of drunken passengers. For the honour of cleaning up other people's vomit and pushing a tea trolley endlessly up and down the aisle of a 747?

But Richards isn't a sane adult at all, she's a child - a schoolgirl lacking in confidence. If it wasn't her height she was unhappy with it would probably be her weight, skin or lack of a boyfriend. Given the chance and enough love and encouragement from those close to her, Richards might have grown out of her height-related low self-esteem.

But alas, her parents were fully behind the project. "We hope people will understand how important this has been to Emma," pleads her mother, Irene. "We are now hoping the growth hormones will kick in... you never know, she might keep growing and reach 5ft 9ins."

Richards, who was bedridden for four months and lost three stone after her legs became infected as a result of the operation, may not know better, but her parents, short of stature themselves, certainly should. Mother Irene (4ft 11ins) and father John (5ft), presumably know what it's like to feel insecure about their height. Yet, instead of telling their daughter they love her no matter what, they are sending out signals that actually, a few more inches would make the world love her more.

And as for the dream of being an air hostess, the best cure for Richards would be to take a long- haul flight, preferably a charter, during peak season. A few hours of turbulence later - not to mention the smugness of actually being able to fit into the seat - and being under the height restriction wouldn't seem so bad.

 Sarah Boseley is away

webTitle: Témoin

fields.headline: Témoin: animal fears
fields.standfirst: Cécile Jeanne describes what it's like to share a house with children and scorpions
fields.trailText: C*cile Jeanne describes what it's like to share a house with children and scorpions
fields.body:
Moi qui ai peur des araignées et des insectes en général, je suis gâtée: des scorpions partagent ma vie depuis deux ans! J'en ai trouvé quatre au total. La première fois, on a été très étonnés. Ça prend les tripes car ce n'est pas un animal que l'on s'attend à découvrir dans sa maison. Instinctivement, on pense que c'est dangereux, et que leur piqûre est mortelle. En fait, c'est le deuxième, celui que j'ai trouvé cet été dans la chambre des enfants, qui m'a fait le plus peur. webTitle: Stopping the cheats

fields.headline: Stopping the cheats
fields.standfirst: Stephanie Tunmore, Climate Campaigner for Greenpeace, suggests that the key issue of the Hague is preventing countries from creating loopholes to evade their responsibilities
fields.trailText: The international climate negotiations resume in the Hague from 13th -24th November and governments will have to take decisions on crucial issues. How these issues are decided will determine whether the Kyoto Protocol becomes a first step towards climate protection or a 'Cheat's Charter' that will allow industrialised countries to increase rather than reduce emissions.
fields.body:
The international climate negotiations resume in the Hague from 13th -24th November and governments will have to take decisions on crucial issues. How these issues are decided will determine whether the Kyoto Protocol becomes a first step towards climate protection or a 'Cheat's Charter' that will allow industrialised countries to increase rather than reduce emissions.

Since Kyoto in 1997, when thirty-eight industrialised countries agreed to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions by an overall 5.2%, the talks have made very little progress. The meeting in the Hague this week is the culmination of three years of wrangling and, in theory, is where cards must be laid on the table and agreement reached about how the developed world will achieve their individual targets.

But, as the prospect of legally binding targets gets nearer, concerted efforts are being made to insert loopholes into the Kyoto Protocol. If accepted these loopholes could result in an environmentally ineffective Treaty that could actually legitimise an increase in CO2 emissions.

Fossil fuels are at the core of the current climate crisis. Burning oil, coal and gas for energy releases carbon dioxide (CO2) into the atmosphere, creating a thick 'blanket' of gases around the earth and trapping the sun's heat. As global temperatures rise the planet's climate system is being thrown into disarray.

In theory the solution is quite simple: substantially reduce the use of fossil fuels by replacing them rapidly with clean renewable energy sources. One of the loopholes being suggested by a number of industrialised countries is counting the amount of CO2 stored in carbon 'sinks' - especially forests - against their fossil fuel emissions. This would effectively allow them to carry on business as usual and still nominally achieve their targets.

The danger inherent in this approach is that forests and other vegetation only store CO2 temporarily and it can be released back into the atmosphere rapidly at any time.

Through photosynthesis, trees take CO2 out of the atmosphere and store it as wood carbon. Carbon is also stored in plants on the forest floor, in leaf and forest debris and in forest soils. But much of this carbon is constantly moving.

Young trees absorb large amounts of CO2 as they grow but a mature forest can reach an 'equilibrium' where it emits as much as it takes up. Branches and leaves fall to the forest floor and release CO2 as they decay and drought and wildfires can cause a forest to die and release so much CO2 back into the atmosphere that it becomes a 'source' rather than a sink. Drought and wildfires are expected to increase as a result of climate change.

This makes accounting for the amount of carbon stored in forests difficult and imprecise.

By contrast, subterranean carbon buried underground in the form of fossil fuels is locked out of the atmosphere and leaving it underground guarantees that it will not be a burden on the atmosphere.

Under Kyoto Protocol rules, every tonne of CO2 stored in forests would allow a corresponding tonne of fossil fuel CO2 to be released into the atmosphere. Given the difficulties of calculating the exact uptake of CO2 by forests and the impermanent nature of the storage, these proposals could result in emissions to the atmosphere increasing substantially rather than reducing.

The only way that a tonne of carbon stored in forests could have the same impact on the atmosphere as a tonne of 'avoided' fossil fuel carbon is if the forest carbon is permanent. None of the stored carbon could ever be allowed back into the atmosphere, so the forest could not be allowed to decay, burn down or be harvested. If the trees are harvested, the resulting paper or wood products would have to be tracked in perpetuity to make sure they were never destroyed.

There would also need to be certainty that the CO2 stored in the forest is additional. A lot of forest management practices would happen anyway because they are 'good practice' but it is now being proposed that many of these should be eligible for emissions credits. If this is allowed it will be difficult to differentiate between what would have happened anyway and what is truly additional.

The recent floods in the UK have delivered a timely reminder of what we can expect in the future if we fail to address climate change and it is to be hoped that politicians gathering in the Hague will pay attention.

We have to urgently reduce the amount of CO2 we are putting into the sky if we are to avoid the worst impacts of climate change. The only way to do that is through domestic action to phase out fossil fuels and switch to clean renewable energy sources. Creative 'carbon accounting' with sinks might be a clever trick but it won't save the climate.

webTitle: Letsbuyit makes a tentative comeback

fields.headline: Letsbuyit makes a tentative comeback
fields.trailText: Beleaguered online auctioneer Letsbuyit.com has defied its critics to post narrowing losses, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Beleaguered online auctioneer Letsbuyit.com has defied its critics to post narrowing losses.

The Amsterdam-based company has been dogged by reports of financial and internal problems ever since its much-delayed stockmarket debut in July.

Letsbuyit reported a third-quarter operating loss of E25.8m (£15.4m), against E42.2m (£25.2) for the same period last year, on a 28% leap in sales to E9.3m (£5.5m).

The key to Letsbuyit's recovery was a E20m (£11.9m) cut in marketing costs, as the group keeps its powder dry for the all-important Christmas period.

Martin Coles, chief executive of Letsbuyit, said: "The financial market environment in which we operate is tough right now, but the consensus of the forecasts for the B2C market over the next five years is for exponential growth."

The Frankfurt-listed shares climbed 7% to E1.53 (91p) by late afternoon, nearly half their flotation price.

Letsbuyit arranges for consumers to pool their buying power for goods such as TVs and personal stereos.

The company fired 80 of its 400 staff in August, after research showed that only 17% of its 850,000 registered users had bought something from the site.

Letsbuyit is still fighting a German lawsuit which claims the company is violating retail laws.

webTitle: November 13 ratings

fields.headline: One Foot in the Grave audience slips
fields.trailText: Ratings for last night's penultimate episode of One Foot in the Grave failed to match those of the previous four on BBC1, declining to 8.5m, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Ratings for the penultimate episode of One Foot in the Grave failed to match those of the previous four on BBC1, declining to 8.5m (32% of audience share).

The BBC1 hit, leading into the Royle family, is still packing a respectable punch in the ratings but is 1.7mn down from its debut.

The combination of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? leading straight into Frank Skinner on ITV, however, proved to be a killer combination.

Millionaire? handed Skinner an inheritance of nearly 11m and 40% share, of which Skinner held onto more than 7m.

The debut of Rob Brydon and Julia Davis's dark comedy, Human Remains, on BBC2 got 1.7m, (8% of share), losing out to movie Sex Lies and Videotape over on Channel 4, which pulled in 1.5m and 11% of share.

Meanwhile, viewers are showing no signs of news fatigue, with the fiasco that is US politics presumably helping to push the BBC's Six O'Clock News to 7.2m, comfortably beating ITV's early evening news, which attracted 6.3m.

webTitle: Vodafone boss hits out at BT over legal wrangle

fields.headline: Vodafone boss hits out at BT over legal wrangle
fields.trailText:
Vodafone's chief executive has lashed out at BT after the telecoms giant began legal proceedings against Vodafone's Vizzavi internet service, writes Dan Milmo.
Vodafone rings up strong rise in profitability
fields.body:
Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent has lashed out at BT after the telecoms giant began legal proceedings against his company's Vizzavi internet service.

But Mr Gent said Vizzavi, a joint-venture with Vivendi, had not been affected by BT's renewed claims that the the venture was breaking an agreement with the French media giant.

The Paris-based company is a partner of BT in French phone company Cegetel.

This week, the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) ruled against BT's claim that Vizzavi breaks a shareholder pact between the two companies.

Mr Gent said he was confused by BT's behaviour, given that the company had made heavy hints about selling its 26% stake in Cegetel.

"I am not sure what BT's game is, but if they are potential sellers maybe this suing game is to get a better price. I sometimes think BT's legal department is out of control," he said.

BT's dispute grows more complicated by the day - it is using a separate ruling made by the ICC to demand up to £1bn in compensation.

The ICC ruled that Vivendi had breached a different shareholder agreement by signing a deal between Cegetel's SFR mobile phone arm and Vizzavi.

BT declined to comment on the situation, saying it is against the rules of the ICC tribunal.

Mr Gent added that Vodafone might sell its 15% holding in Cegetel to Vivendi and will discuss the matter with Vivendi chairman Jean-Marie Messier.

Vizzavi will operate on the combined companies' mobile, fixed and cable television networks in Europe and has been launched as a brand in the UK, the Netherlands and France.

Plans are underway to make Vizzavi an international service available anywhere in the world, tailored to meet local needs and interests.

Vivendi expects Vizzavi to break even within three years, following an initial investment of up to £950m.

webTitle: Nasdaq dives as investors flee

fields.headline: Nasdaq dives as investors flee
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The Nasdaq composite index fell through 3,000 for the first time in a year yesterday as disappointing earnings from the world's second biggest computer manufacturer increased concerns that the US economy was slowing down.
fields.body:
The Nasdaq composite index fell through 3,000 for the first time in a year yesterday as disappointing earnings from the world's second biggest computer manufacturer increased concerns that the US economy was slowing down.

Investors fled the US stock market as soon as it opened yesterday morning after the announcement from Hewlett Packard added to fears raised by the continuing uncertainty over the US presidential elections.

Within 10 minutes of the opening bell, the technology-driven Nasdaq index fell 3% to 2936. The warning from HP, a constituent of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, also hurt confidence in blue-chip shares. The Dow was down 181 points, or almost 2%, at 10419 by mid-morning.

Technology companies that had led the bull market of the past two years were among those hardest hit. Shares in HP fell 15% following the pre-opening announcement that its earnings would be well below expectations. The Nasdaq closed at its lowest level in a year on Friday after losing 12% in a week. It has not fallen below 3000 since November 2.

Dell, the former stock market darling and computer manufacturer, had added to last week's fears when it warned of lower than expected revenues next year.

Few investors believe that the Federal Reserve, the US central bank, will further increase interest rates when it meets on Wednesday. However, few expect the markets to rally until after the meeting.

webTitle: Web lines

fields.headline: Web lines
fields.trailText: While the US electorate waits for the final word on who will be their next president, websites across the Atlantic have been analysing the fight so far. According to women's portal www.oxygen.com, 54% of women backed Al Gore in last week's election, compared to 43% voting for George W Bush. Yet an online poll by the portal found that two-thirds of women thought Laura Bush would make a better first lady than Tipper Gore, who only attracted a third of women's votes. Susan Medalie, of the Women's Campaign Fund, which promotes political action by women, suggests that women had been more sophisticated voters when it came to considering election issues like education, abortion and gun control: "Women went for a lot of these issues and men went for a guy they could go out and have a beer with."

Commenting on an investigation by news service ZDNet UK, Childnet International and NCH Action for Children expressed concerns over Yahoo!'s policy of not censoring a chatroom unless it breaks, or incites the breaking of, the law. Childnet has set up a new site www.chatdanger.com to encourage safe use of chatrooms by children.

These entertaining shopping experiences will be "much like the Tupperware parties of the 70s", he says. Hold that excitement.

webTitle: Taylor names his team

fields.headline: Taylor names his team
fields.trailText: Emile Heskey will lead England's forward line during tomorrow's friendly against Italy, with Nick Barmby playing in a floating role just behind him, caretaker coach Peter Taylor announced today.
fields.body:
Emile Heskey will lead England's forward line during tomorrow's friendly against Italy, with Nick Barmby playing in a floating role just behind him, caretaker coach Peter Taylor announced today.

Rio Ferdinand, Ray Parlour and Nicky Butt have also been named in a flexible-looking England team, which could line up in either a 4-4-1-1 or 3-5-1-1 formation.

"Italy are a very good side and are very strong. We have to match them," Taylor admitted. "I have selected a young team which is full of promise but they have to make sure they get selected again. It is up to the players. I hope they take their opportunity."

In particular, Taylor is hoping that Heskey, who has scored nine goals in his last eight matches for Liverpool, will be able to transfer his club form onto the international stage. "He has been scoring goals, and should score more," said Taylor, "In the past he has sometimes been guilty of looking to pass more than score, but he is looking a very good target man.

"I might ask Nick Barmby for a freer role. It will be two up but in different places," he continued.

Earlier today, Taylor suffered another injury blow when Steven Gerrard was forced to pull out of the squad after suffering a recurrence of the back problem that has dogged him for most of the year. But despite the loss of Gerrard, Alan Smith, Wes Brown, Michael Owen and Paul Scholes, Taylor insisted that he had been able to pick his side from a strong squad.

"The hard thing about the job is selecting a team because there are so many good players," he said. "If you're in the squad, it is because you are a good player and you have ability. I have named the team now and it is hard leaving 10 players out but that is the strength of our game."

England team to face Italy in Turin tomorrow: James (Aston Villa), G Neville (Man Utd), Ferdinand (West Ham), Southgate (Aston Villa), Barry (Aston Villa), Parlour (Arsenal), Beckham (Man Utd, captain), Butt (Man Utd), Dyer (Newcastle), Heskey (Liverpool), Barmby (Liverpool).

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

"I might ask Nick Barmby for a freer role. It will be two up but in different places," he continued. Earlier today, Taylor suffered another injury blow when Steven Gerrard was forced to pull out of the squad after suffering a recurrence of the back problem that has dogged him for most of the year. But despite the loss of Gerrard, Alan Smith, Wes Brown, Michael Owen and Paul Scholes, Taylor insisted that he had been able to pick his side from a strong squad. "The hard thing about the job is selecting a team because there are so many good players," he said. "If you're in the squad, it is because you are a good player and you have ability. I have named the team now and it is hard leaving 10 players out but that is the strength of our game." webTitle: George Harrison attacker pleads insanity

fields.headline: George Harrison attacker pleads insanity
fields.trailText: Jurors in the trial of the man accused of trying to kill the former Beatle, George Harrison, and his wife Olivia were today told they would have to decide if the couple's attacker was insane.
fields.body:
Jurors in the trial of the man accused of trying to kill the former Beatle, George Harrison, and his wife Olivia were today told they would have to decide if the couple's attacker was insane.

Michael Abram, 34, of Woolfall Heights, Huyton, Merseyside, denies two counts of attempted murder, by reason of insanity, at the star's home on December 30 last year.

Simon Mayo, prosecuting, at Oxford crown court, told the jury: "During the course of the attack Mr Harrison was repeatedly stabbed with a knife and severely beaten."

Abram allegedly stabbed the 57-year-old guitarist after breaking into his 30-acre Friar Park estate home in Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire, in the middle of the night. He is also accused of injuring 52-year-old Olivia, which he also denies.

Mr Harrison is not expected to give evidence in person. The trial continues.

webTitle: Far right casts shadow in Betty's backyard

fields.headline: Far right casts shadow in Betty's backyard
fields.standfirst:
In the second of a three-part series on next week's byelections we look at the former Speaker's West Bromwich West seat
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: In the second of a three-part series on next week's byelections we look at the former Speaker's West Bromwich West seat
fields.body:
The racist shadow of the British National Party is hanging over the battle to succeed Betty Boothroyd in West Bromwich West. Nick Griffin, the 41-year-old leader of the far right group, is standing and intends to exploit whatever prejudices he can stir up on council estates and narrow streets in a constituency where one in five people are from ethnic minorities.

"Anti-white discrimination and resentment it causes is a major issue with people in the area and we will certainly address that," says Mr Griffin, betraying the fact the BNP has essentially not changed despite attempts to present it as a more moderate force.

Next week's byelection, triggered by Ms Boothroyd's decision to hang up her wig and quit the Commons and Speaker's chair, will see the first real contest in the seat since 1992 when, after calculating for subsequent boundary changes, Labour enjoyed a 6,174 majority over the Tories. Barring a catastrophe for the people's party, Labour will hold the constituency on November 23 but on an expected low turnout the BNP could do uncomfortably well in an area where the far right has a long record.

The National Front chairman, Martin Webster, polled 5,500 votes against Ms Boothroyd in the 1973 byelection that propelled her into parliament. At the last general election, as the Tories and Liberal Democrats respected tradition and declined to challenge the Speaker, NF candidate Steve Edwards - standing under that racist party's National Democrat colours - secured 4,181 or 11.4% of the votes.

More recently at May's local elections the BNP secured 23.6% in Tipton Green, one of the constituency's seven wards, and the 230 complaints from racist graffiti and hate mail to disputes with neighbours, employers and police being handled by Sandwell racial harassment unit suggest the BNP has had some success in raising tensions. The unit covers four constituencies including West Bromwich West, and Maxie Hayles, its chair, says: "The BNP are trying to make themselves look decent when in fact they are encouraging racial terrorism."

Local police maintain race relations are improving. Sandwell council, covering West Bromwich West, is led by Tarsem King, the first Sikh to enter the House of Lords after being made a peer in June last year. Mahboob Hussaine, a Labour councillor with Pakistani roots, believes the tide is turning against the far right: "The communities band together more strongly than before. People will vote for the best candidate and on their merits rather than the colour of their skin."

The West Bromwich West constituency is one of those quirks of boundary commission changes, a seat that does not include the town it is named after. It is instead a collection of gritty metal bashing towns including Tipton, Wednesbury and Oldbury that merged into one sprawling conurbation during the industrial revolution. At the heart of the Black Country in the middle of England near the M5-M6 junction, it has no significant middle class or executive estates. Nearly half the workforce are employed in manufacturing (particularly car components with Longbridge 12 miles down the road) and construction, with almost half the electorate living in council houses.

A quarter of voters are retired, few have post-16 qualifications, and very high levels of strokes, heart disease and osteoporosis have seen the government declare Sandwell a health action zone.

Ms Boothroyd is remembered with affection but the lack of a proper election in 1997 has left the local machines of the main parties rusty and there are some complaints that, as Speaker, she grew remote.

The Tories and Liberal Democrats accuse Labour of trying to hide the election, even claiming it wanted a truce on lamppost placards. Millbank resisted the temptation to parachute in a New Labour clone, leaving the local party to select bearded Adrian Bailey, Sandwell council's deputy leader, a former librarian and walking encyclopaedia of lower levels football after a lifetime supporting Cheltenham Town. Despite the Birmingham Post's description of Mr Bailey, 54, as about as inspiring as a vandalised bus shelter, he will be heading to Westminster on November 23.

Canvassing with Urdu and Punjabi speakers, Mr Bailey enjoys a warm welcome on most doorsteps. The problem will be getting his vote out because most people appear to take it for granted Labour will win. Labour's own Mondeo man - he has had two car radios stolen in the past five years - is making fighting crime a big issue. "I take nothing for granted but we are working hard for the constituency," says Mr Bailey. He is relieved no discontented Labour figure is standing to draw votes away from his campaign after a "Labour Change" candidate in 1997 gained more than 8,500 votes.

Tory hopes are pinned on a recently elected councillor who her critics claim is a political novice. Karen Bissell, a 35-year-old legal executive, will be lent a hand by William Hague later this week and seems to make most headway in local markets when she campaigns on issues such as pressure from local trading standards officers to list weights in kilograms not pounds. She too is trying to make crime an issue, though claims that the local police station shuts at 6pm because of staff shortages have been contradicted by senior officers.

Ms Bissell is also making much of the jailing of 75-year-old Mary Rooney for refusing to pay her council tax over a planning dispute. "How on the one hand can Labour run Sandwell imprison a pensioner for a £360 debt and on the other propose to its members that we should write off £300,000 worth of upaid debt, which incidentally includes non-payment of council tax?" she asks.

If Sadie Smith fails to clean up at the polls for the Liberal Democrats, she will at least have left part of the constituency a little tidier after donning rubber gloves to collect litter. Refusing to divulge her age - though her more garrulous aides wagered she is about 60 - she proved her devotion to pavement politics to show that if Mr Bailey's council could not be trusted to keep the streets clean, she could. Ms Smith is leader of Sandwell council's official opposition, a 10-strong Liberal Democrat group, though unfortunately for her poll prospects not one of the 10 are in West Bromwich West. "All we hear are complaints about the council," she says. "Adrian Bailey is deputy leader so he must take responsibility." The fifth candidate is the UK Independence Party's Jonathan Oakton, 52.

Mr Bailey watched the chancellor's pre-budget statement in the home of acouple who recently received a free TV licence for the over-75s. They welcomed the extra £8 a week and £50 on fuel allowance. The sign of votes to come was more evident later when, calling the bingo numbers in Wednesbury rugby club, a female pensioner kissed him and said: "Send our love to Gordon when you get to London."

webTitle: Chancellor thinks creatively about urban regeneration

fields.headline: Chancellor thinks creatively about urban regeneration
fields.standfirst: The pre-budget report includes a number of measures which will energise local regeneration initiatives, says Neil McInroy, of the Centre for Local Economic Strategies
fields.trailText: In recent years, the government has been increasingly responsive to calls for the right incentives for regeneration and greater flexibility in the rules covering local approaches. The package of initiatives offered by the chancellor in his pre-budget report represents a continuation of this approach, and offers some useful and timely measures which should assist local efforts to reverse urban decline.
fields.body:
In recent years, the government has been increasingly responsive to calls for the right incentives for regeneration and greater flexibility in the rules covering local approaches. The package of initiatives offered by the chancellor in his pre-budget report represents a continuation of this approach, and offers some useful and timely measures which should assist local efforts to reverse urban decline.

At best, these measures could energise a number of existing regeneration programmes, making both their uptake and delivery easier and more successful. The initiatives - which include a reduction on VAT to 5% for house conversions, and the provision of tax credits to encourage community investment - indicate that the government is prepared to think creatively about regeneration and provide a favourable local financial context for urban change. Questions of scale remain, along with the matter of defining which areas are to be considered "deprived" - the index of local deprivation operates as too blunt an instrument, in some instances.

The possibility of business rate relief has long been an issue for small businesses in deprived areas. Existing interventions, such as equipment grants, marketing grants or start-up grants offered by local agencies, and regeneration schemes, such as the single regeneration budget, have proved useful. However, rate relief - included in this package - raises the opportunity for local businesses to increase their long-term competitiveness.

Working in tandem with this proposal, banks are to be encouraged to reveal their lending activities in under-invested areas. Small businesses, particularly those owned and run by ethnic minorities and those with alternative or innovative views of business culture - or just the wrong postcode - are frequently refused loans, overdrafts and even business accounts.

This pernicious practice undermines both investment and local business confidence. Whether banks can be "encouraged" to invest without specific legislation is another matter, but it is a positive move and one which the banks should ultimately embrace, given their pivotal role in providing investment in local economies. The report does not appear to address a similar problem with insurance practices, where businesses in certain "problem" postcodes face high property and contents insurance premiums, resulting in reduced available local capital and restricted potential investment. This will need to be looked at in the future.

The proposals for a reduction in the rate of VAT on conversions of empty residential properties and tax relief for property owners converting redundant spaces over shops into flats are welcome. The issue of vacant properties in Britain's urban areas is an ongoing issue, particularly where there has been considerable restructuring and change in town centres.

At present, building on green-belt land is almost always exempt from VAT, so any reduction in the cost of renovating properties will serve to narrow this disparity in opportunity. It will also serve to energise the regeneration of empty properties in inner cities and other urban areas. In many instances, renovators are small-business owners or individuals with restricted budgets, who, for whatever reason, have allowed a property to decline. These measures present an opportunity to reduce costs. Given the small margins involved, this may be the crucial factor in seeing a property renovated or left to decline.

At present, grants are available to landlords and potential renovators to assist the renovation of empty properties. For instance, there are empty property initiatives, and commercial premises conversions via regeneration initiatives such as the single regeneration budget or the Housing Corporation's social housing grant. Take up of these schemes has been scatter-gun, due to either potential renovator apathy, or lack of funds. These measures may allow for more comprehensive redevelopment in some problem locations and bring new life to a number of properties in blighted streets and closes.

Another of the key measures proposed is an increased budget - £1.2bn this year, rising to £1.7bn in 2003-04 - and an increase in budgetary freedom and flexibility for regional development agencies. This flexibility allows for more targeted responses to fit the local context. However, this flexibility may bring problems with it, especially for sectors that have the security of ring-fenced funding - particularly those with less political muscle, such as the community and voluntary sector.

The issue of local sensitivity raises an overarching concern about these measures and how they relate to local flexibility. The need for local solutions to tackle local needs has been emphasised in this pre-budget report and appears to reflect a trend in government thinking. Some issues are still outstanding, including the relaxation of planning control in some blighted areas and a more flexible social security system, which would allow for innovation that is rooted in the local context and sensitive to local needs.

webTitle: Cosgrove Hall to bring back Andy Pandy

fields.headline: Cosgrove Hall to resurrect Andy Pandy
fields.trailText: 5pm; Animation company Cosgrove Hall is developing new versions of Andy Pandy and The Woodentops for our screens. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
TV favourites Andy Pandy and The Woodentops are set to return to our screens after animation company Cosgrove Hall revealed it is developing new versions of the shows.

The news came as the BBC unveiled its winter schedule, which includes a new series of Bill and Ben.

The much-loved flowerpot men are making their comeback in a new format after a 30-year absence.

The two central characters will still communicate in their incomprehensible language, but they will be joined by a range of new characters including Whimsey the spider and Whoops the Worm.

The development of Andy Pandy and The Woodentops is at a much earlier stage and the BBC has not commissioned either series.

But a BBC spokesman said such a move was being considered.

webTitle: Catherwood leaves Channel 5 to return to ITV news

fields.headline: Catherwood makes comeback to ITV news
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Channel 5 has parted company with Andrea Catherwood after a year. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
She was Channel 5's great hope after Kirsty Young defected to ITV.

But today it was confirmed that Andrea Catherwood has been axed and is returning to ITV's news team a year after joining the station as its main newsanchor.

Sources say Ms Catherwood had another year to run on her contract with Channel 5, but both sides agreed her future lay elsewhere.

"She wanted to return to the road. She missed reporting on the big breaking stories. In the end we came to a mutual agreement," said a source at the station.

Another said her hard news background meant she was also more suited to the ITV bulletins.

Channel 5 had huge difficulty finding anyone who could match Kirsty Young's on-screen allure when the Scottish presenter quit last year.

But they had huge hopes for Ms Catherwood and even modelled a new TV character, Vandrea the virtual newsreader on the 32 year old presenter.

Channel 5 has realised it can never recapture the excitement of the early days when the sight of Ms Young pulled in up to a million viewers.

Recent ratings have dropped as low as 400,000 and the station is considering relaunching its bulletin.

Current newsreaders Rob Butler and Charlie Stayt are likely to take over from Ms Catherwood when she signs off at the end of the year.

As predicted by MediaGuardian.co.uk, Ms Catherwood is to go back to being a correspondent at ITV's bulletins although she will do some presenting shifts.

"Andrea leaves us after successfully relaunching the new-look five news earlier this year, as well as bringing her proven journalistic ability to some of the year's biggest news stories," said Channel 5 News editor Gary Rogers.

Nigel Dacre, head of ITN news on ITV, said in a statement that Ms Catherwood was a "highly talented and experienced journalist".

webTitle: Selection, Speculation, and Segregation

fields.headline: Selection, Speculation, and Segregation
fields.trailText: TELL TAYL
fields.body:
TELL TAYL

Say what you like about Peter Taylor, but he's not frightened of taking risks. The head Fox, currently keeping an eye on team England, shocked the world (or El Tel at least) by picking not one man over the age of 30 in his 26-man squad to face Italy. Today, he spooked them again by allowing Nicky Butt onto the pitch from the very start of the game. That Pete, he crazy like a Fox.

Yes, the inclusion of the Manchester United clogger is the main surprise in the XI to turn out in Turin tomorrow. He will play alongside Arsenal's Butt-a-like Ray Parlour and Cap'n Dave Beckham in what is expected to be a three-man midfield. Emile Heskey will start as predicted, with Nick Barmby in support - Kevin Phillips is believed this afternoon to have joined the Foreign Legion - while Kieron Dyer and Gareth Barry are expected to act as wing-backs. David James is in goal, and Gary Neville, Gareth Southgate and Rio Ferdinand will be charged with the responsibility of looking bewildered for 90 minutes.

webTitle: 'I'll move Panorama if it flops' says BBC chief

fields.headline: 'I'll move Panorama if it flops' says BBC chief
fields.trailText: 9.45am: BBC director of television Mark Thompson has said he will move Panorama from Sunday nights if it flops in the ratings. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
BBC director of television Mark Thompson has said he will move Panorama from Sunday nights if it flops in the ratings.

He said: "It is a critical programme for BBC1. It is does not work out in that slot, we'll have to consider an alternative."

Mr Thompson's remarks, made at last night's Royal Television Society dinner, came just 24 hours after Mariella Frostrup made her controversial debut on the programme.

Her investigation into reality TV led to criticism that Panorama was "dumbing down" in a bid to win viewers in a tough Sunday night slot.

In the event, Sunday night's programme did not capture the imagination and was branded a flop in many newspapers. It drew just 2.7m viewers, the second worst performance for Panorama in the five weeks since it moved to Sunday nights.

Last night Mr Thompson refused to condemn the show's performance and said he would give it at least six months to settle down.

"Panorama is famous for bombing up and down in the ratings," he said.

Hinting that reality TV such as Big Brother may not have been a suitable matter for a current affairs show, Mr Thompson added: "I don't know if reality TV was a strong subject for BBC1, or whether it was a Channel 4 or BBC subject which we in the media are interested in.

"We have got to judge it on 20, 25, 30 editions. But we have never said if it does not perform in that slot, it will have to stay there."

webTitle: Losing weight

fields.headline: 'I was hiding behind the fat'
fields.standfirst: As an unhappy, abused child, she was overweight. By 24, she had ballooned to 35 stone. But for Christie Martin, losing the weight was just the start of a painful struggle.  Moira Petty reports
fields.trailText: As an unhappy, abused child, she was overweight. By 24, she had ballooned to 35 stone. But for Christie Martin, losing the weight was just the start of a painful struggle. Moira Petty reports
fields.body:
Three years ago, Christie Martin was 24 years old and weighed 35 and a half stone. She collected her groceries in the middle of the night from 24-hour stores; she never lingered at the school gates, in case it embarrassed her daughter: she was a complete outsider.

Then she was warned that she could be dead within six months, and with a sense of resignation, she decided to undergo a stomach bypass operation, a procedure which could have been fatal for someone of her bulk. There were post-operative complications and a month of painful convalescence but the weight dropped off at the rate of more than a stone a month for the first year and today, Christie, from Arkansas, USA, is, at 12 stone, a third of her former size and is still, slowly, shedding the pounds. She has yet to relinquish the self-loathing of the seriously obese, but life is finally moving on and, on the surface at least, Christie's story is a personal triumph.

So how did Christie get so fat in the first place? She says that she came from a destitute and broken family and was abused, mentally and physically. By the age of eight, she was nearly 12 stone. "Every night, I prayed I wouldn't wake up in the morning, but I had to act like it didn't bother me.

"At 15, I went to live with my father and he didn't buy groceries but made us live on Slimfast. Then I'd go round to my mother's house and eat supper there and she'd say: 'Slow down.' Everyone made me feel uncomfortable about eating so I'd try to eat the way they wanted me to, but when they weren't looking I'd eat anything that was available. I did most of my eating secretly. When I was made to clear the table and put the leftovers away, I would take them into the kitchen and stand and eat it all real quick. I felt hungry and ashamed."

As she grew up, Christie's relationships with men were often abusive: her weight made her feel she deserved nothing better. "I think obese people settle for the leftovers." At 19, she gave birth to her daughter Olivia, by her first husband. They split up when Olivia was two. A year later she met Robert, who was to be her second husband. (She admits she stayed with him so that the £16,000 cost of her surgery would be met under his medical insurance.)

Christie's weight severely limited her life with her daughter. "Other people had to take her out. I tried taking her places. I couldn't get into the car at the fairground but I could push her on the swing until I got out of breath and every part of my body started hurting." There was also the problem of shielding Olivia from other people. "People would stare at me or chase me in their car and shout: 'Why don't you die, you big fat fuck?' As I took a step, teenagers would should: 'Ba-boom, ba-boom.' Olivia said once: 'Mummy, that's mean. Why are they doing that?' I began going out less and less."

Finally Christie was referred to Professor George Khan at the Baptist Memorial Hospital, Memphis, Tennessee, who believes that extreme obesity can be cured only by surgery. Christie was suffering from sleep apnoea, in which the tongue slips down the throat, threatening suffocation and causing the sleeper to wake continually, gasping for breath. To allow her to rest, she was sent home with her windpipe cut open for three weeks before the stomach bypass.

Tonight an ITV documentary will chart her struggles during and after her operation. In the film, Christie is seen saying goodbye to her daughter before the operation. "I'd have done anything for Olivia and without the operation our days together were definitely numbered. It was scary but I knew she would be taken care of if anything happened to me," she says.

In surgery, Christie's stomach and intestine were divided so that all food must pass through a half inch pouch. After a minute portion of food she feels full. "I still pile it all on my plate but have to throw it away."

After she had lost 19 stone, she had 15lbs of loose skin cut away, giving her waist definition for the first time. "I felt attractive to men but I had such low self esteem I had to get a buzz going first, by getting a few beers down me." She also turned to drugs, including marijuana and cocaine. "I had a new body but I didn't know who I was anymore. The weight came off so quickly I couldn't deal with it. Losing weight made me feel better for a while. Wo! It was wonderful. But then I realised I was still sad and miserable and wanted to die. I had been hiding behind the fat. It had been an excuse for not going out and not dealing with my problems."

Christie is currently living in a shelter for the homeless since leaving another abusive boyfriend. She has been offered a three-bed, two-bath flat on a government assistance plan and hopes to find work soon. Tragically, Christie's problems are being replicated in Olivia, now eight, who, in the Carlton film, is seen gaining weight. "It's getting hard to buy clothes for her. I tell my family not to goad her. If they make an issue of it, it'll make her want to go and eat. I'm trying to keep her active. We go walking and play in the park.

"She was passed around my family so much and now I'm trying to rebuild our relationship. I was mentally abused and sometimes I say mean things to her. I get mad and say: 'God! You're so slow' or 'Go ahead, get fat. Be like I was', then I ask her to please forgive me. It is a long road for both of us."

 Christie's Story is on ITV tonight at 10pm.

webTitle: Dr Ann Robinson

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.standfirst: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.trailText: Dr Ann Robinson
fields.body:
Too much radiation?

Q Our daughter has scoliosis in the lumbar region, to an extent which puts her on the borderline for surgery. She has had a lot of x-rays, not all of which were necessary in our view. The consultant assured us that the amount of radiation would be equivalent to (and no worse than) "for a passenger on a transatlantic flight". Can this be correct? Our daughter wants children, and we are worried about the x-ray exposure

A You are quite right that the radiation for lumbar spine x- rays is significant. A chest x-ray is a relatively insignificant amount of radiation; equivalent to three days of background radiation and half as much as flying to Spain. The excess risk of developing cancer from a chest x-ray is about the same as smoking one cigarette. But x-rays of the pelvis and lumbar spine are equivalent to about six months of background radiation. Having said that, even repeated lumbar spine x- rays cause an excess cancer risk of less than 1%. If your daughter is careful to avoid all x-rays that are not strictly necessary for the rest of her life, she will minimise her risk. And if she eschews the risk factors for cancer such as smoking, she could end up at less risk than most of the population.

Foot sore

Q Over the past few months I have found that if I walk for any length of time I get a burning (sort of ripping) sensation in the balls of my feet. This is very painful and has inhibited my being able to drive. I'm 50 years of age and used to jog regularly (I finished a marathon some years ago) although I'm much less active nowadays (due to sloth rather than sickness). I'd welcome your advice.

A This is such a common complaint but no less painful for that! The pulpy part of your foot has become inflamed from taking your weight over the years on unforgiving, hard surfaces. This has the grand name of plantar fasciitis.The trick is to put padding between yourself and the ground. Bouncy trainers with thick rubber soles, cushioned insoles, avoiding walking barefoot or on thin-soled shoes and walking or jogging on grass or treadmills rather than tarmac are the key to a pain-free life. Losing excess weight obviously helps. Podiatrists can fashion wonderful, but expensive, custom-made insoles for your shoes but expect to pay up to £200. I only have this problem when I'm out at college or when I'm nervous.

Or perhaps you're not able to wear a clean top every day and they are becoming a little stale smelling. webTitle: Health: Gum disease

fields.headline: With your heart inyour mouth
fields.standfirst: Gum disease has been linked to everything from premature births to pneumonia. It may also cause heart attacks, reports  Oliver Burkeman
fields.trailText: Gum disease has been linked to everything from premature births to pneumonia. It may also cause heart attacks, reports Oliver Burkeman
fields.body:
Parents faced with the hair-tearing task of instilling in their children the importance of regular toothbrushing could probably do with a house call from Dr Efthymios Deliargyris. Where previously they would have had to resort to dark mutterings about the perils of dental neglect - scare tactics along the lines of "all your teeth will fall out" - Deliargyris, a cardiologist at the University of North Carolina, has come up with a rather more convincing threat. According to a study he presented to the American Heart Association's annual meeting at the weekend, gum disease could be a significant contributory factor in a large proportion of heart attacks.

The most common afflictions always seem the most baffling to medical researchers: just look at the common cold. In the case of heart attacks, one third of all instances of the country's biggest killer remain unexplained by the conventional risk factors of high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes and smoking.

Deliargyris may be edging towards a solution to the mystery. In his study, periodontal disease - the official term for advanced gum disease, as opposed to the less serious gingivitis - was found in 85% of subjects who had suffered heart attacks, compared with 29% of those who had not. The 85% in question also displayed abnormally high levels in their bloodstream of a protein, CRP, which is associated with both conditions.

Alarming stuff. And yet the finding is only a small part of a growing body of evidence suggesting that this most common of ailments - gum disease affects around 10% of the population to a serious degree, and many others less acutely - could be implicated in a wide range of conditions, from pneumonia to premature birth.

The mouth is awash with bacteria at the best of times, but most of them are beneficial. Problems only arise when destructive bacteria - plaque - are allowed to build up, leading to sore and bleeding gums, bad breath and loose teeth. Swollen and torn gums provide the bacteria with an easy entry point into the bloodstream, where they can trigger an inflammatory response in the arteries associated with heart attacks.

"The one thing we know about [gum disease and heart attacks] is that they tend to initiate an immune response, also called an inflammatory response, in the body. We believe that patients with a heart attack and periodontal disease have an exaggerated inflammatory response . . . that might put them at risk of future heart attacks," says Deliargyris, whose findings have particular significance for those who have already suffered a heart attack and want to reduce the risk of a repeat occurrence. "This work also raises the possibility that by treating severe gum disease in people with heart attacks, we might be able to reduce their CRP levels and their risk of another heart attack."

To probe the links between the mouth and the heart is to enter the murky world of epidemiological correlation - where the prevalence of one condition in a population suffering from another cannot be taken as proof of causation, and few experts are willing to say for certain what they think is going on. But the evidence, in study after study, is growing more convincing. One such investigation found that gum disease was a stronger predictor of heart disease in the American subject group than any of the conventional risk factors.

"We know that bacteria get from the mouth to the bloodstream very regularly - if you have a tooth extracted, for example, it will happen to a minor degree," says Newell Johnson, professor of oral medicine and pathology at King's College, London. "Most people clear it from their bloodstream quickly, but if you have advanced periodontal disease, you already have a deep-seated infection in pockets around the teeth."

Once the plaque bacteria have entered the bloodstream, it may not just be coronary problems that ensue. A study published in September found that women with severe gum disease were more than seven times more likely to give birth to a premature, low-weight baby than those with healthy gums, possibly because the bacteria in plaque can have an inflammatory effect on the placenta. "The results of the trial indicate that the effect of gum disease in pregnancy seems to be as harmful as other well-established risk factors such as smoking," the report's author, Professor Steven Offenbacher, said at the time.

Dental professionals are understandably unwilling to say so, but overvigorous flossing or brushing can also contribute to the problem once gum disease has taken hold, further damaging tissue in the mouth and sending more bacteria into the bloodstream. But it's not that simple, of course: underzealous brushing is one of the surest ways to contract the disease in the first place. Another is a deficiency in levels of saliva, which contains antibodies that fight infection: a dry mouth - brought on, for example, by many prescription drugs - can increase the risk of gum disease considerably.

There are those who dispute the link entirely. Two months ago, the world's medical media fixated briefly on a study from the University of Washington suggesting that there was no clear connection between gum disease and heart attacks - or if there was, it was "very small or very hard to reliably detect", according to Philippe Hujoel, the lead researcher. (Critics of the study, including Johnson, point to the historical data on gum disease on which it relied, collected at a time when the measurement of the prevalence of diseases in the population was still in a fairly primitive state.)

Even if gum disease correlates strongly with a range of health problems, a significant part of the explanation may be due to other causes with social roots. "People who neglect their health neglect other parts of their bodies as well, so we have to be careful," says Robin Seymour, of Newcastle University's dental school, who has conducted research into the links between gum disease and heart attacks. Nevertheless, he adds, "With heart disease the evidence shows a strong association. And it appears to be like a dose response: the worse the gum disease, the greater the risk of coronary heart disease.

"What we still haven't established, though, is the impact of intervention: whether, if you treat gum disease successfully, you actually reduce the risk of coronary events." While the jury is out, the British Heart Foundation recommends that anybody with a heart condition should take particularly good care of their mouth and teeth: the same advice, of course, that we have all been receiving since we were toddlers - only this time with an even better incentive for compliance.

webTitle: Asylum law could face human rights challenge

fields.headline: Asylum law could face human rights challenge
fields.standfirst: One group of asylum seekers is falling foul of harsh immigration policies.Terry Bamford looks at the background
fields.trailText: Refugees face little support under the Home Office's harsh immigration policies.
fields.body:
Every country in Europe has been affected by the dramatic increase in refugees and asylum seekers. The collapse of the Soviet Union and the subsequent economic turmoil, together with the hundreds of thousands of households displaced by the Balkan conflicts has placed unprecedented pressure on receiving countries.

Social workers help asylum seekers rebuild their lives after trauma. They work against a rising tide of xenophobia affecting many European countries.

Belatedly, the UK government has made positive noises about the contribution some refugees can make to British society and has strengthened resettlement support services. However, some of the restrictions already introduced by home secretary Jack Straw, under the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, leave a new group of asylum seekers out of any entitlement to help with accommodation costs. This may prompt a challenge under the Human Rights Act.

Conservative home secretary Michael Howard had previously introduced legislation drawing a distinction between asylum seekers who make their application in the country, usually after locating friends or family members, and those who make their application at the port of entry. The second group retained their entitlement to social security benefits and housing costs.

Many of the latter were placed in social housing by local authorities, pending a decision on their asylum application. Their rent was covered through their benefit entitlement. The huge backlog of applicants awaiting a decision (over 75,000) means that there is a long wait, during which families put down roots, place children in school and begin the process of settling in to a new life and new community.

Since September 25, if an application for asylum is rejected, this group of asylum seekers lose their social security benefits and have to apply to the national asylum support service (NASS). Under the scheme, asylum seekers receive vouchers and may be dispersed to any part of the country. Over 85% of applications for asylum are turned down at first (although roughly a fifth of all appeals are successful).

The consequences are severe. Although households with school age children are excluded from the scheme so that their education will not be disrupted, the impact on childless households and those with children under school age is immediate. They are unable to pay rent and face eviction. To receive any help, they have to move to an area where they know nobody. They have no income other than vouchers.

The backlog of in-country applicants is such that as many as 15,000 people may be in this position - although the slow pace of decisions means that few cases have yet come through to housing departments. The majority of asylum-seeking households are still in London.

The Association of London Government has negotiated with NASS to ensure that councils in the capital do not lose out in rental income from asylum seekers whose application fail. Mark Brangwyn, the association's policy adviser, says: "We are working with the national asylum support scheme to find a solution which is fair to local authorities and minimises the disruption."

One possibility is that NASS meets the rental costs of families and that only single or childless couples will be dispersed. However that could militate against the government's dispersal policy. And some authorities will be keen to see asylum seekers dispersed because of pressure to rehouse the indigenous homeless.

A challenge to the new rules may come through the Human Rights Act. Article 8 provides for the right to respect for private and family life. This can only be interfered with in the interest of national security, public safety and the economic well-being of the country, to prevent crime and disorder, and to protect health or morals. "In our view none of these conditions apply," says Ruth Stark of the British Association of Social Workers. "We would support any challenge under the Human Rights Act."

Legal challenges take many months. In the meantime, households face a "choice" of moving to a distant area, under the national support scheme, or relying on the charity of their friends for support and accommodation. The Home Office's approach to immigration was set out in the White Paper, Faster, Fairer, Firmer. Only "firmer" seems an accurate description of their treatment of asylum seekers.

webTitle: Wowgo shuts up shop after four months

fields.headline: Wowgo goes under after four months
fields.trailText: 12pm: Wowgo, the Unilever-backed teenage girls' website, has shut up shop just four months after launch, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Wowgo, the Unilever-backed teenage girls website, has shut up shop just four months after it launched its much-hyped community website.

A statement from Wowgo blamed its downfall on negative sentiments towards consumer-focused internet companies.

It said: "Having decided that it is unable to continue as an independent entity, Wowgo has ceased trading. In the current market conditions, the company has been unable to raise further funding to continue development of its operations."

Wowgo started its PR activity at the start of this year but hit a number of technical snags before it was due to launch in April. The site launched three months later.

The hype around the site focused mainly on the high-calibre staff that were brought in to run the venture.

Michael Gold, founder of GGT Advertising and French Gold Abbott, and David Peller, who has a strong background in fmcg marketing, interactive media and restaurants, were the two founding partners.

They brought in James Ginzler, formerly online development manager at Emap On Air, and more recently named Melinda Chandler, previously marketing manager at Publicis.

The problems at the company were exacerbated when its delay in launching opened the door to competition in the teen girl market from BSkyB, Freeserve-backed MyKindaplace and Procter & Gamble-backed Swizzle.com.

The closure will come as a blow to Durlacher, which will have to write off its 15.24% stake in Wowgo.

Earlier this year Durlacher had to write off its investment in NetImperative when it put the company into liquidation. Its investment in Talkcast hangs in the balance after a number of management departures and the shake up of its consumer business.

The irony is that Wowgo was not a flash-in-the-pan venture. It was set up following two years of extensive research and development, and received £6m in initial funding.

It is not clear why Unilever would not bail out Wowgo with further investment.

Unilever refused to comment.

Wowgo is now looking to sell off its assets and said it would make a further announcement in due course.

webTitle: Teenage Brit named as 'global leader for tomorrow'

fields.headline: Teenage Brit named as 'global leader for tomorrow'
fields.trailText: 2pm: An 18-year-old has become the youngest ever Brit to be picked as a 'global leader for tomorrow' by the World Economic Forum, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
A UK teenager has become the youngest ever Brit to be picked as a 'global leader for tomorrow' by the World Economic Forum.

Eighteen-year-old internet entrepreneur Tom Hadfield is one of 10 British business leaders recognised by the World Economic Forum in its annual list of 100 global leaders for tomorrow to be published in January.

Previous global business leaders have included Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, Yahoo Europe boss Fabiola Arredondo and Lachlan Murdoch.

Mr Hadfield has so far been involved in two successful websites.

He set up Soccernet at the age of 12 with help from his father, Greg Hadfield, a former education correspondent with the Sunday Times, and Associated New Media.

After a 60% stake in Soccernet was sold to Disney for £15m last year Mr Hadfield set up Schoolsnet, an education website aimed at teachers, parents and pupils.

Schoolsnet is now a £40m company and Mr Hadfield's personal wealth has been estimated at around £7.5m.

Mr Hadfield has only just turned 18 and divides his time between studying A levels and running Schoolsnet.

He hopes to study Politics, Philosophy & Economics at Oxford next year.

'Global leaders of tomorrow' are individuals under 40 who have been nominated by members of the World Economic Forum for their influence, position and responsibility, and who are considered 'global' in terms of their accomplishments and potential.

webTitle: Three dead as Israel blockades the West Bank

fields.headline: Three dead as Israel blockades the West Bank
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Audio: Suzanne Goldenberg on the West Bank
fields.trailText: Three Palestinians have died on the West Bank in clashes with the Israeli army that left 15 more injured.
fields.body:
Three Palestinians have died on the West Bank in clashes with the Israeli army that left 15 more injured.

Two of the three, a 13 and a 16-year-old boy, were shot after throwing rocks at troops in the area.

The Israeli army is blockading Palestinian towns on the West Bank in revenge for an attack yesterday that left four Israelis dead.

Food and medicine are allowed past the soldiers but military observers say the blockade may soon be taken outside the towns. Cars with Palestinian license plates will be banned from travelling on the West Bank roads.

Gaza, already circled by an electric fence, is now completely cut off.

The siege marks a return to the sanctions that Israel lifted last month after prime minister Ehud Barak agreed to a ceasefire at peace talks in Sharm el-Sheikh.

Mr Barak has cut short an overseas trip and scheduled an emergency meeting to discuss further retaliation for the killing of four Israelis - a teacher, a truck driver and two soldiers - by Palestinian gunmen.

"The minute the situation is bad for us, it will be very bad for them," said Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, who is acting prime minister until Mr Barak returns.

The Palestinians, meanwhile, say they will cut off roads to Jewish settlers and keep Israeli civilians and troops out of West Bank villages. This is contentious since all previous peace accords have granted Israel security control over the West Bank villages.

The closure has paralyzed life in the West Bank, with army roadblocks cutting off Palestinian communities from one another. The situation is already bad - trade has come to a virtual halt and unemployment, which was in the double digits even before the unrest, has risen sharply.

One sixth of the Palestinian workforce have jobs in Israel but since the fighting began seven weeks ago they have banned from crossing the border.

Mr Ben-Eliezer says the siege will be enforced "until further notice".

webTitle: Spectres of the Spectrum

fields.headline: Spectres of the Spectrum
fields.standfirst: London film festival  ****
fields.trailText: London film festival ****
fields.body:
American film-maker Craig Baldwin is the Ancient Mariner of American underground cinema, button-holing the unwary with rambling, hair-raising narratives of doom and perdition. His stories, in which no less than the entire history of Western culture is at stake, are paranoid epics of warfare and psychological combat. Baldwin's speciality is sampled cinema - he slowly, painstakingly builds mosaics of TV and film footage, sometimes only a couple of seconds long, and transforms them, with the addition of breathless voice-overs, into paranoid narratives of conspiracy and mind control.

Spectres of the Spectrum is only marginally less delirious than Baldwin's Tribulation 99: Alien Anomalies Under America, a mock-reactionary sci-fi story that satirically presented Kissinger, Pinochet and the Contras as intrepid hunters of extra-terrestrial vampires.

Where Tribulation 99 laid itself open to incomprehension by masquerading as a crypto-fascist rant, Spectres positions itself on the revolutionary margins of the near future. Its heroes, seen in live-action footage, are a young telepathic woman, Boo Boo, and her father Yogi, agit-prop broadcasters in the people's Resistance to the New Electromagnetic Order.

The narrative key to all this is a 1950s popular science TV show, in which Boo Boo's grandmother has concealed a message which will aid the future revolutionaries. As Boo Boo travels back in time to unlock granny's secret, Yogi scans the history of the electro-magnetic power struggle, from Benjamin Franklin's kite, through electrical pioneer Nikola Tesla, to the age of the internet and its "corporate colonisation of the imagination".

Disorienting as the film is, you can always trace a passionate conviction - the opposition to the ownership of images. Baldwin's sampling style wrests found images away from copyright and any official meanings they may once have had. Innocuous moments of family entertainment yield worrying new meanings, dark warnings of a future world under the surveillance of "Disney spy satellites".

Baldwin's work draws on a history of underground film-making from Joseph Cornell to 1980s scratch video as well as today's climate of anti-corporate culture-jamming. Spectres of the Spectrum (SOS for short) is radical pop art, and head-spinningly entertaining storytelling, if you manage to keep up with it.

At the National Film Theatre, London SE1 (020-7928 3232), tonight.

webTitle: Mayor offers government way out of tube sell-off

fields.headline: Mayor offers government way out of tube sell-off
fields.standfirst: Minister refuses to drop plans for part privatisation
fields.trailText: The London mayor Ken Livingstone yesterday offered the government "a face saving formula" to withdraw from its plans for part privatisation of London Underground.
fields.body:
The London mayor Ken Livingstone yesterday offered the government "a face saving formula" to withdraw from its plans for part privatisation of London Underground when he asked ministers to let Bob Kiley, the new tube boss, decide if the scheme made sense.

Mr Livingstone promised he would drop his opposition if Mr Kiley backed the plans.

Speaking in the Commons Mr Livingstone added that Mr Kiley, the foremost expert in mass transit, would be unable to make a proper judgement unless ministers gave him details of contractors' rival bids, as well as an update of comparisons with a public sector service produced last March.

The environment minister Chris Mullin refused to drop plans for part privatisation, but promised that tube management would let Mr Kiley see the public sector figures.

Mr Livingstone released a poll showing 42% of Londoners thought safety would be jeopardised by privatisation.
