webTitle: Enter Mayor Ken, signalling trouble ahead

fields.headline: Enter Mayor Ken, signalling trouble ahead
fields.standfirst: Lingstone goes for his strategy of last resort: statesmanship
fields.trailText: Mayor of London Ken Livingstone hit the Commons yesterday determined to tackle the Government over tube privatisation. Sketch by Simon Hoggart
fields.body:
The Mayor of London made a rare visit to the Commons yesterday, in order to denounce the new system for funding the tube.

This is the public-private partnership, a bizarre new arrangement modelled on the way the Tories privatised the railways, only more complicated. It's been operating as a "shadow" system since April, since when the tube has got much worse.

The PPP splits the responsibility for running trains away from tracks and signals, the same plan which gave us Hatfield and other disasters. The tough new American tube boss, Bob Kiley, will only run half the system.

Imagine that New Labour had been fighting El Alamein. "Now, look, Monty," John Prescott would have said, "we want you to run the tanks, but we're going to be in charge of the chaps inside them. Oh, and we've brought in a contractor to look after ammo, which he'll get from a sub-contractor. In Germany. I'm sure it'll all work out!"

This was a vital issue for Mr Prescott's department, so as usual he wasn't there for the debate. Tories pretended to be enraged. Mr Eric Forth demanded of the Speaker how the deputy prime minister could be persuaded to come to the House.

"The important thing," replied Mr Martin runically, "is that I am here and the honourable gentleman is here." The odd thing about the new speaker is that even when you can make out what he is saying, you have no idea what he means.

Dale Campbell-Savours said that all these late arrivals were the fault of rail privatisation. "But he's got two Jags! Two Jags!" bellowed the Tories.

Bernard Jenkin wondered where Mr Prescott was, and surmised he was skulking in his den. "If I raise my eyes towards the camera, I am probably looking at the secretary of state in his office," he said, lifting his head but resisting the temptation to wave and shout "hello, John!" This is very modernistic Commons behaviour, acknowledging you're being watched, like Craig on Big Brother.

"He has lost his grip, lost his nerve, and soon he will lose his office, his salary, his grace and favour houses, and his chauffeur-driven cars as well!" Mr Jenkin concluded with lip-smacking relish.

Keith Hill, the minister for London, is a sensible fellow and so cannot possibly support the PPP. But he has to pretend he does. So he resorted to sounding like the late Frankie Howerd. As Mr Jenkin tried to make him give way, Mr Hill camped at him. "I want to make progress, but if you behave yourself, I might look favourably on you later," he said, sadly failing to add: "Oooh, missus!" The unspoken message was, "this isn't the real me talking, it's a fictional comedy me!".

Finally it was the mayor's turn. He knows very well that one reason Mr Prescott is obsessed with ramming through the PPP is that he hates Ken. So Ken went for his strategy of last resort: statesmanship. Every reputable report on the PPP condemned it. However, if Mr Kiley decided it would work, he, Ken, would take his word for it. Would the government do the same if Mr Kiley thought the whole thing was a disaster? Fat chance, as Mr Livingstone well knows.

As for the present bosses, or "dullards... Bob Kiley will cut through the senior management of the tube like a scythe through butter!" he said, but you knew it was Mr Prescott's neck he really had in mind.

"I honestly have to say that I fear this system will bring about a major loss of life. This is something we cannot blame on the previous administration. It will be our fault. I beg the government to step back!"

Of course Mr Prescott still wasn't there to listen. He very rarely is.

webTitle: What happens if neither candidate wins US election?

fields.headline: US constitution heads for meltdown
fields.standfirst: If the Florida recount fails to produce a clear winner, Americans could face a long legal quest for a president. Derek Brown finds there are several intriguing possibilities
fields.trailText: If the Florida recount fails to produce a clear winner, Americans could face a long legal quest for a US president. Derek Brown finds there are several intriguing possibilities.
fields.body:
Unravelling the knots in the legal web now enveloping the US presidential race is a lucrative business for the lawyers, and a fascinating exercise for constitutional authorities. For US voters and for those peering into the murk from outside, it is a nightmare.

At the centre of the quagmire is the ongoing struggle to decide exactly how the citizens of Florida voted. In the increasingly unlikely event of a clear and uncontested outcome, then it's all over: Vice president Al Gore or George W. Bush will be heading for the White House.

If, as seems more and more probable, Florida has no clear winner by December 18 - the day on which the Electoral College is due to meet - there are two intriguing legal possibilities.

One is that the courts will direct the governor of the state - Jeb Bush - not to appoint any college electors. In that case Mr Gore, who already has a slender majority in the college, will become president.

But the courts could direct Governor Bush to appoint the electors, in accordance with the constitution - and instruct them not to vote in the college election because of the lack of clarity in the popular polls. And without the Florida votes, neither candidate could gain the 270 votes necessary to carry the college.

Florida could ask for an extension of the December 18 deadline. But that could delay the decision until uncomfortably close to noon on January 20, the instant when, whatever happens, William Jefferson Clinton will cease to be the president of the United States. To muddy the waters still further, the Republican majority in Congress would willingly postpone the meeting of the electoral college if a Gore victory seemed imminent - but Clinton could veto that postponement.

Assuming that Florida does not participate in the electoral college, the result of the slimmed-down election will be announced to Congress on January 6. Traditionally, the announcement is made by the vice-president, raising the intriguing prospect of Al Gore declaring that he himself has won, even without a clear majority in the college.

There are two more interesting possibilities. One is a tie in the electoral college (where voters are not legally obliged to follow their party mandate). Another is that Congress refuses to accept the college vote, as it is entitled to do.

In either case, the decision will pass to Congress. The House of Representatives will decide who becomes president, and the Senate will pick his vice-president.

Again there is a fascinating possibility of a candidate voting himself the winner. With Washington state yet to declare the winner of its November 7 senatorial election, there is a chance that the upper chamber will be split 50-50. In that case Al Gore, in his capacity as president of the Senate, could break the deadlock to declare his running mate Joe Lieberman - also a senator, fully entitled to cast a vote - as vice-president of the nation. And if the House of Representatives is unable to choose a president, Lieberman would then automatically step up to the White House.

The ultimate meltdown scenario is that the courts, the electoral college, and the Congress will be unable to decide on a president by January 20. In that case the law is quite clear: the speaker of the House, Republican. Denny Hastert, will be catapulted from relative obscurity to the Oval Office.

webTitle: Book trade news

fields.headline: Warring Waterstone's
fields.standfirst: Birthday buy-out for John Smith | Bertelsmann's not caught napping | Booker-bashing continues apace
fields.trailText: As small publishers fight back against Waterstone's, John Smith & Son celebrates 249 years of independence, Bertelsmann looks to a filesharing future, and the Booker fails to inspire readers
fields.body:
The spirit of popular revolt, perhaps inspired by the fuel protesters, has hit the book business. Small publishers across the country are starting to fight back against what they see as a threat to their livelihoods from Waterstone's, the nation's largest dedicated bookseller. The latest spat between the big W and its suppliers came in response to a letter sent out by Waterstone's to smaller publishers stating that, from this week, it would be buying in their titles at a new standard discount of 50% - an increase in some cases from 35%. Waterstone's said the new terms would be used regardless of whether publishers replied to its letter or not.

Smaller publishers, many of whom already feel ill-disposed to the ailing retail chain, reacted as small publishers are wont to do when such demands are issued in this way: they threatened to withhold their books. Tiverton-based local publisher Halsgrove went a step further and issued a press release stating its reasons for suspending dealings with the bookseller and calling on its customers to support its stance. Accusing Waterstone's of the "worst case of commercial arrogance" it had come across, the publisher argued that the bookseller was "attempting to dig themselves out of trouble" by imposing the new terms and thereby making "regional publishing unviable". It is not the first time that Waterstone's has raised the ire of publishers and risked the loss of their titles and no doubt it will not be the last.

Waterstone's defended itself in the trade press by arguing that it was losing money on these books and needed to "professionalise" its relationships with smaller publishers. Quite how Waterstone's interprets the word "professionalise" is anyone's guess but more puzzling still, given the level of accounting sophistication it would take to calculate the real cost of selling individual books, was the assertion that the bookseller was actually losing money on these titles. Still, if Waterstone's believes it can arrest the decline in the performance of its business by offering fewer books to its customers and going to war with its suppliers, who in the trade can argue?

Birthday buy-out for John Smith

Better news from across the border where bookseller John Smith & Son celebrated its 249th year of independence by announcing that its present managing director, Willie Anderson, was to buy the business from its current chairman, Robert Clow and his family.

The deal is something of a personal triumph for Anderson, one-time president of the Booksellers Association and a vociferous supporter of all things independent. Mr Anderson, who has been managing director of the chain since 1994, has overseen the business during a period of much needed retrenchment thanks to the expansion of the US chain Borders and Waterstone's into its territories.

The fact that John Smith has survived in what Mr Anderson calls a "volatile and uncertain" market speaks volumes about the loyalty of its customers and the flexibility of its staff. The management buy-out will also be welcomed by those publishers who fear more power being placed in the hands of the large bookselling chains.

Bertelsmann's not caught napping

Meanwhile, in a galaxy far away, Bertelsmann has struck up a deal with Napster, the online peer-to-peer music-sharing renegade. Under the terms of the deal Bertelsmann will fund Napster's development into a legal (ie profitable) model and suspend its legal assault on Napster's file-sharing operation.

Why should this be of interest to the book business? Bertelsmann owns Random House, the largest book publishing company in the UK and US. It also owns the UK's largest book club operator, Book Club Associates, and the (second largest) online bookseller, Bol.com.

Not only did the deal see Thomas Middelhoff, chairman of Bertelsmann, admit that "file-sharing technology will be used in the future, no matter what the outcome of the lawsuit against Napster may be", he added that the technology would open up "in the medium term, an additional distribution channel... for our other content businesses".

The fact that Middelhoff has, so far, declined to comment further on what he meant by this statement should not be taken as an indication that he does not yet know how the technology will be used by Bertelsmann's book publishing companies.

Booker-bashing continues apace

And, finally, what of the Booker? This year's award, won by Margaret Atwood, has drawn the usual criticism for failing to inspire book buyers. While Booker-bashing has become a favourite pastime of literary journalists in need of a safe story, there is some truth to the latest round of carping.

According to BookTrack, which records book sales in 4,600 outlets, only two titles - Atwood's The Blind Assassin and Azzopardi's The Hiding Place - have sold more than 1,000 copies since the shortlist was announced. Atwood has sold more than 6,000 and Azzopardi 1,007. Furthermore, despite the swathes of publicity devoted to the Booker shortlist, only one book is selling appreciably more copies now than it was in the week of the shortlist's announcement: Brian O'Doherty's The Desposition of Father McGreevy sold 363 copies last week, compared to 67 in the first week. Some in the book trade suggest that concentrating on sales figures is missing the point of the Booker, which is supposed to award merit not saleability. Undoubtedly true, but if the nation's most talked about literary prize fails to inspire book readers to actually read the books in question then, it might seem reasonable to ask, what is the point?

The fall-out from this year's slow sales could be interesting. Booksellers have complained of difficulties in getting hold of some of the titles on the list, while publishers have been disappointed by the promotion the shortlisted titles have received in some shops, not least from WH Smith which loudly announced earlier in the year that it was getting behind the Booker like never before. It seems too obvious to suggest that a lack of books will lead to a dearth in sales, but in a week in which entente cordiale between publishers and booksellers has been stretched to its limit, perhaps the trade should just enjoy the party and let others worry about the business of selling books.

The deal is something of a personal triumph for Anderson, one-time president of the Booksellers Association and a vociferous supporter of all things independent. Mr Anderson, who has been managing director of the chain since 1994, has overseen the business during a period of much needed retrenchment thanks to the expansion of the US chain Borders and Waterstone's into its territories. The fact that John Smith has survived in what Mr Anderson calls a "volatile and uncertain" market speaks volumes about the loyalty of its customers and the flexibility of its staff. The management buy-out will also be welcomed by those publishers who fear more power being placed in the hands of the large bookselling chains. Bertelsmann's not caught napping Meanwhile, in a galaxy far away, Bertelsmann has struck up a deal with Napster, the online peer-to-peer music-sharing renegade. Under the terms of the deal Bertelsmann will fund Napster's development into a legal (ie profitable) model and suspend its legal assault on Napster's file-sharing operation. Why should this be of interest to the book business? Bertelsmann owns Random House, the largest book publishing company in the UK and US. It also owns the UK's largest book club operator, Book Club Associates, and the (second largest) online bookseller, Bol.com. Not only did the deal see Thomas Middelhoff, chairman of Bertelsmann, admit that "file-sharing technology will be used in the future, no matter what the outcome of the lawsuit against Napster may be", he added that the technology would open up "in the medium term, an additional distribution channel... for our other content businesses". The fact that Middelhoff has, so far, declined to comment further on what he meant by this statement should not be taken as an indication that he does not yet know how the technology will be used by Bertelsmann's book publishing companies. Booker-bashing continues apace And, finally, what of the Booker? This year's award, won by Margaret Atwood, has drawn the usual criticism for failing to inspire book buyers. While Booker-bashing has become a favourite pastime of literary journalists in need of a safe story, there is some truth to the latest round of carping. According to BookTrack, which records book sales in 4,600 outlets, only two titles - Atwood's The Blind Assassin and Azzopardi's The Hiding Place - have sold more than 1,000 copies since the shortlist was announced. Atwood has sold more than 6,000 and Azzopardi 1,007. Furthermore, despite the swathes of publicity devoted to the Booker shortlist, only one book is selling appreciably more copies now than it was in the week of the shortlist's announcement: Brian O'Doherty's The Desposition of Father McGreevy sold 363 copies last week, compared to 67 in the first week. Some in the book trade suggest that concentrating on sales figures is missing the point of the Booker, which is supposed to award merit not saleability. Undoubtedly true, but if the nation's most talked about literary prize fails to inspire book readers to actually read the books in question then, it might seem reasonable to ask, what is the point? The fall-out from this year's slow sales could be interesting. Booksellers have complained of difficulties in getting hold of some of the titles on the list, while publishers have been disappointed by the promotion the shortlisted titles have received in some shops, not least from WH Smith which loudly announced earlier in the year that it was getting behind the Booker like never before. It seems too obvious to suggest that a lack of books will lead to a dearth in sales, but in a week in which entente cordiale between publishers and booksellers has been stretched to its limit, perhaps the trade should just enjoy the party and let others worry about the business of selling books.

webTitle: Sky News sets up investigative journalism unit

fields.headline: Sky News sets up investigative journalism unit
fields.standfirst: Nov 13: Sky in bid for ITV news contract
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: Sky News has created a new investigative journalism unit, designed to focus on special reports, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Nov 13: Sky boosts efforts to become ITV news supplier
fields.body:
Sky News has created a new investigative journalism unit designed to focus on special reports.

The unit, led by head of special reports Michael Wilson, will include award-winnig journalists David Chater, Andrew Simmons, Mark Saggers and Greg Milam.

Head of Sky News Nick Pollard said: "The calibre and experience of this new unit will provide viewers with in-depth analysis of current news and will set the news agenda by breaking exclusive stories."

The announcement follows reports that Mr Pollard has approached ITV chiefs to re-bid for the news contract for the channel, which is up for grabs at the end of this year.

Sky News has made a number of attempts to break ITN's stranglehold in the terrestrial television news marketplace.

Last year Sky was thought to have come very close to winning the contract to supply Channel 5, but lost out at the last minute in a counter-bid from ITN.

Sky is now seeking official news supplier status from the ITC in a further bid to position itself against ITN.

webTitle: Burger King makes global marketing deal with Nickelodeon

fields.headline: Burger King signs multimillion pound Rugrats deal
fields.trailText: 2pm: Burger King is hoping to cash in on the popularity of the new Rugrats movie with a multimillion pound global marketing deal. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Burger King is hoping to cash in on the popularity of Tommy, Chuckie, Phil and Anjelica with a multi-million pound global marketing deal to promote the new Rugrats movie.

The fast food giant has teamed up with Nickelodeon in what the two companies are claiming is one of the biggest ever promotional deals aimed at kids in the UK.

Rugrats in Paris: The Movie, the second Rugrats film, opens in the UK next spring.

Burger King is hoping to replicate its success with the first Rugrats movie, which sent burger sales soaring - up more than 30% - as it became the only non-Disney animated film to gross more than $100m at the box office.

The new movie opens in the US this month and stars Susan Sarandon and John Lithgow.

All Burger King's 645 UK branches will carry in-store promotions backed by television and internet advertising. Anyone who buys a Burger King children's meal will get a specially-designed Rugrats in Paris: The Movie collectable prize.

Rugrats fans in the UK can already buy themed toys, books, clothes and software as part of around 70 licensing agreements signed by Nickelodeon.

The company has already secured marketing agreements with the publisher Simon & Schuster and toymaker Mattel to promote the film.

webTitle: Alli 'told Carlton he was leaving in February'

fields.headline: Alli 'told Carlton he was leaving in February'
fields.standfirst:
12.15pm: Alli exits after shake-up
10.45am: Alli to leave Carlton
fields.trailText:
2pm update: Friends of Waheed Alli today claimed the Labour peer had told Carlton back in February he intended to resign to pursue his political career. By Jessica Hodgson and Lisa O'Carroll.>BR> 12.15pm: Carlton shake-up
10.45am: Alli to leave Carlton
fields.body:
Friends of Waheed Alli today claimed that the Labour peer had told Carlton Communications boss Michael Green back in February that he intended to resign to pursue his political career.

But less than a month ago, Lord Alli was talking to the Financial Times's Creative Business magazine about "team Carlton".

Cynical observers may suggest that "team Carlton" never meant much more to the maverick Labour peer and his partner Charlie Parsons than the cool £15m it netted them for the sale of their company, Planet 24.

Carlton paid a premium for Planet 24 just as it was beginning to realise the value of content if it wanted to play a major role in the future of ITV.

As well as giving Carlton one of the hottest independent companies around - responsible for The Big Breakfast and The Word - it gave the company access to one of the most powerful new media figures, equally at home in 10 Downing Street and medialand.

Officially everything went according to plan. Last spring, a year on from the Planet 24 acquisition, a spate of newspaper interviews saw Lord Alli singing from the Carlton song-sheet, pointing to larger numbers of ITV network commissions, and bigging up the value of its in-house production talent.

If Carlton thought it odd that all its new creative supremo had done in a year was to revive a limp seventies sitcom (Crossroads) and a kids' TV classic (The Railway Children), nobody said so at the time.

It was noticeable, however, that all the time Lord Alli and Charlie Parsons were mining another rich seam after holding on to the format rights to Survivor!, which went on to be the year's biggest network hit in the US.

They created a separate company, Castaway, to look after the property and stand to make £31m from international sales of the show.

As one friend of Lord Alli said today: "This is probably worth more than Michael Green has amassed in his career."

Allies of Lord Alli insist that he was planning to leave Carlton ever since it became clear that Labour was not going to breeze through the next election.

One said: "You don't get a peerage for nothing. And Waheed has ambitions to have a more active role in government, so he has got to spend more time on politics.

"He made a commitment to the government in February and spoke to Michael Green about this."

Others, however denied this, saying Lord Alli showed no signs of resigning in recent months.

When Planet 24 was sold to Carlton in March 1999, eyebrows were raised about how the creators of "yoof" TV would fare in Michael Green's conservative television empire.

After all, his appointment to a senior executive role overseeing production seemed to replicate the job of Steve Hewlett, who just six months earlier had been poached from Channel 4.

Lord Alli did nothing to dispel talk of clashes with Mr Hewlett. Notably, he failed to deny in an interview earlier in the year that he and Hewlett had "trod on each other's toes".

In an interview with the Guardian in April he also made it clear that he aspired to be one of Michael Green's right hand men and part of the key team who would manage a single ITV company.

Lord Alli said: '"I desperately want to be in there. I hope I will be involved in the managing of that process in one way or the other and part of whatever new company that comes about." His eyes twinkle: 'I think I have age on my side."'

Insiders at the company say Lord Alli had the ambition but not the temperament for corporate life. He never lost his small-company attitude and while his exuberance energised colleagues, it also infuriated them.

"He just couldn't manage people. He was an accident just waiting to happy," one recalled.

"If he said paint the room black one day and paint it white the next, he expected people to do it. He never had people say to him before that that was a waste of shareholders' money, or a waste of people's time."

But this morning's shock resignation and restructuring, will simply revive debate about the value of trying to bring small independents under a corporate yoke.

Lord Alli's departure is the second to hit the company in three months.

Steven Cain, who joined Carlton as chief executive in early 1999 aged only 34, collected over £1m in compensation when his job effectively disappeared after Carlton announced plans to merge with United News & Media.

Mr Cain, formerly marketing director at Asda, had been the UK's youngest chief executive.

webTitle: Alli to exit Carlton

fields.headline: Alli to exit Carlton
fields.trailText: 10.45am update: Waheed Alli will leave Carlton Communications today, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Waheed Alli will leave Carlton Communications today, it has been confirmed.

The Labour peer, who was brought into Carlton after it acquired his Planet 24 production outfit, is said to be the victim of a restructuring at the ITV company.

His departure, to be announced later today, was confirmed by a spokesman.

He will spend more time in politics as the government prepares for the general election.

Lord Alli joined Carlton's TV as the head of its production business just 18 months ago.

Many questioned how he fitted into a company that already had a de facto production boss in former BBC executive Steve Hewlett.

At the time many in the industry were surprised with the seniority of his position given that the company had only recently poached Hewlett from Channel 4.

However his position in the company seemed assured and many believed he would outlive Hewlett because of his links to the Labour party. Lord Alli, who set up Planet 24 with his partner Charlie Parsons and Bob Geldof, is best known as one of the masterminds behind Channel 4's The Big Breakfast.

He and Parsons also have the worldwide rights to Survive!, the reality game show that became a sensational hit in the US this summer.

webTitle: Time to scrap the term 'social housing'

fields.headline: Time to scrap the term 'social housing'
fields.standfirst: Chris Holmes wants to see a change in attitudes to rented accommodation, starting with scrapping the term 'social housing' because it is so stigmatised
fields.trailText: Chris Holmes wants to see a change in attitudes to rented accommodation, starting with scrapping the term 'social housing' because it is so stigmatised
fields.body:
While the government sets out its vision for the future in its long-awaited housing policy green paper, we must not lose sight of the need to plan communities.

The green paper vision is ambitious. At its heart is the aim of ensuring that everyone has the opportunity of a living in a decent home. It emphasises the need to reform the current crisis-driven legislation and to create policies and practice which seek to prevent homelessness arising in the first place. There are important proposals to extend the help given to vulnerable people leaving institutions and an outline of changes to make the homebuying process easier. The paper has a lot to say about choice, flexibility and inclusive communities. But, to give substance to these words, we need to jettison old thinking about housing - and with it some old language.

It is time to break down the divisive attitudes to housing tenure - the ingrained belief that owning your own home is intrinsically better than renting, and that rented "social housing" is the tenure of the last resort for those who have no other choice.

The term social housing should be abandoned. It is an artificial and increasingly stigmatised label. In its place we need to create new and more flexible forms of housing where people can choose between different tenure of equal status.

Polls shows that 90% of people would like to own their homes, but a significant minority cannot afford to do this. Some owners face serious problems as a result of taking on commitments they cannot sustain, while many single people in their 20s prefer the flexibility of renting.

Public subsidy should be available to people in all tenures, but only to assist those who cannot afford the full market cost of adequate housing.

For home owners, this help could include grants to lower income households - especially older people - to improve their property and mortgage benefit to home owners facing unexpected difficulties.

Rented homes could be made up of "private" and "not-for-profit" lettings - homes let by local councils, housing associations, housing co-operatives and local housing companies. Not-for-profit landlords would provide homes at subsidised rents for low income tenants and at-cost rents for those in work who can afford it.

A Mori poll last year found that two-thirds of people believe that local authority and housing association homes should be available to anyone who prefers to rent their home.

A new form of cost-rent tenancy will encourage this, but without giving public subsidy to people who do not need it.

More radically, not-for-profit landlords should have the freedom to decide the kind of homes they let. This will mean selling properties - for full or part ownership - on monolithic estates of rented housing. And, using the proceeds from sales, buying homes to rent in areas that are mostly privately owned.

Recent research by the Demos thinktank has shown the crucial link between the housing market and choice of schools. House prices are pushed upwards as better-off parents buy homes near to successful state schools.

A properly integrated social policy would set targets for the balance of incomes and tenure for schools' catchment areas. Current market forces are leading to greater segregation, and social action is essential to develop more inclusive communities.

We also need a new approach to the way homes are let by not-for-profit landlords. Most landlords give very little choice to people over where they live; the very name - "allocating" tenancies - reflects a deeply ingrained paternalism. The aim must be to offer people seeking somewhere to rent as much choice as possible, while giving priority to those in greatest need.

The internet could transform the process of letting rented homes, making it possible for people seeking accommodation - from any landlord anywhere in the country - to find out what is available.

The success of this radical new approach depends on an increase in investment in affordable homes. A major research project carried out for Shelter has shown a substantial shortfall in the investment needed to provide affordable homes for people on lower incomes.

Next month, Shelter will publish the final report from a three-year research project. It will set the scale of unmet need, how it can more effectively be met, and how much it will cost. Our proposals include linking private finance with public subsidy to provide homes at affordable rents; making better use of planning powers to secure more affordable homes and ensuring that both investment and public spending are targeted to where they are most needed.

But they also require an increase in public spending on housing. As the price of achieving the goal of a decent home for everybody, increasing choice, strengthening cohesive communities and raising achievements in schools, it is surely a price worth paying.

 Chris Holmes is director of Shelter.

webTitle: Improved housing will cut crime

fields.headline: Improved housing will cut crime
fields.standfirst: Living on the street before or after a prison sentence is a major cause of offending. Paul Cavadino argues that tackling homelessness will reduce crime
fields.trailText: Living on the street before or after a prison sentence is a major cause of offending. Paul Cavadino argues that tackling homelessness will reduce crime
fields.body:
"I was on the streets fending for myself from the age of nine. When I came out of prison after nine years inside, I was literally on the streets. I felt like the whole world was against me, like society wanted me to go back inside."

These words of a 34-year-old resident of a housing project run by the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders (Nacro) show the link between housing and crime more clearly than any set of research statistics.

While many homeless people are law-abiding, vulnerable people without a home are more likely to drift into crime - and prisoners are more likely to re-offend if they have no home to go to on release.

Over the last three decades, surveys and research studies have reinforced this message. Recent examples include a 1997 survey by the Prisons Inspectorate which found that a quarter of young prisoners were homeless on reception; a 1998 Nacro research study of juveniles in young offender institutions, 60% of whom had unstable living conditions; and the Social Exclusion Unit's finding in the same year that half of rough sleepers had at some time been in a prison or remand centre.

Young people leaving care are a particularly vulnerable group. Nearly two-thirds have moved to independent living by the age of 18 and most experience difficulties in coping. Up to 20% of young people leaving care experience homelessness within two years of leaving. Some 26% of all prisoners and 38% of those under 21 have been in care, compared with 2% of the general population.

Offenders who are imprisoned often lose their homes. A recent large scale resettlement survey by Nacro found that 13% of prisoners were homeless before their sentence and a further 34% had lost homes through being in prison. Nearly half the sample was therefore at risk of being homeless on release. When prisoners lose their accommodation, they often lose their possessions as well.

When women prisoners lose their homes, young children are often affected as women are more likely to be sole carers. If children are taken into care because their mother is imprisoned, the loss of accommodation makes it harder for her to get them back. Where children have been cared for by friends or relatives and return to their mother on release, the family has to start the housing process again in bed and breakfast or other unsatisfactory forms of accommodation.

Yet prisoners released homeless are much more likely to reoffend. One home office research study, which followed up nearly 600 men for two years after release, found that less than a third of those with homes to go to were reconvicted, compared with 69% of those with no home.

There are many obstacles to housing offenders and those at risk of offending. These include the serious shortage of affordable rented accommodation; changes in benefit arrangements which have made it harder for single people with low incomes to find housing; and delays in processing housing benefit claims so that people can wait months before getting their benefit.

Ex-offenders have also been affected by local authorities' greater powers to exclude potential tenants under the Housing Act 1996. Some authorities have used these powers to reduce ex-offenders' access to housing, in some cases taking a blanket approach to people with criminal records or to particular categories of offender. Few local authorities and housing associations will give a commitment to rehouse prisoners on release in return for terminating their tenancies: most local authorities require prisoners to re-apply as homeless persons.

The government is taking a number of steps which should help in tackling the problem. These include legislation to improve support arrangements for care leavers, guidance to discourage "blanket bans" on offenders in housing allocation policies and a new key performance indicator for the prison and probation services related to reducing offenders' homelessness.

We also need higher levels of housing investment to increase the stock of affordable rented housing; a statutory duty on local authorities to provide resettlement services (in addition to advice and assistance) for homeless people; national standards and monitoring to ensure that the housing needs of marginalised groups including ex-offenders are properly met in social housing; a speeding up of housing benefit payments; and a reversal of restrictions which have reduced benefit payments below real rent levels in many areas.

Prisons should routinely provide housing advice on reception, help prisoners make arrangements to keep their existing accommodation, develop contacts with housing providers and make systematic plans for housing on release.

And housing departments should nominate prison liaison personnel and begin homelessness assessments before the four-week period prior to release.

The message is clear: when housing and criminal justice agencies work together to cut homelessness, they are also working to cut crime.

fields.bodyText: "I was on the streets fending for myself from the age of nine. When I came out of prison after nine years inside, I was literally on the streets. I felt like the whole world was against me, like society wanted me to go back inside." These words of a 34-year-old resident of a housing project run by the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders (Nacro) show the link between housing and crime more clearly than any set of research statistics. While many homeless people are law-abiding, vulnerable people without a home are more likely to drift into crime - and prisoners are more likely to re-offend if they have no home to go to on release. Over the last three decades, surveys and research studies have reinforced this message. Recent examples include a 1997 survey by the Prisons Inspectorate which found that a quarter of young prisoners were homeless on reception; a 1998 Nacro research study of juveniles in young offender institutions, 60% of whom had unstable living conditions; and the Social Exclusion Unit's finding in the same year that half of rough sleepers had at some time been in a prison or remand centre. Young people leaving care are a particularly vulnerable group. Nearly two-thirds have moved to independent living by the age of 18 and most experience difficulties in coping. Up to 20% of young people leaving care experience homelessness within two years of leaving. Some 26% of all prisoners and 38% of those under 21 have been in care, compared with 2% of the general population. Offenders who are imprisoned often lose their homes. A recent large scale resettlement survey by Nacro found that 13% of prisoners were homeless before their sentence and a further 34% had lost homes through being in prison. Nearly half the sample was therefore at risk of being homeless on release. When prisoners lose their accommodation, they often lose their possessions as well. When women prisoners lose their homes, young children are often affected as women are more likely to be sole carers. If children are taken into care because their mother is imprisoned, the loss of accommodation makes it harder for her to get them back. Where children have been cared for by friends or relatives and return to their mother on release, the family has to start the housing process again in bed and breakfast or other unsatisfactory forms of accommodation. Yet prisoners released homeless are much more likely to reoffend. One home office research study, which followed up nearly 600 men for two years after release, found that less than a third of those with homes to go to were reconvicted, compared with 69% of those with no home. There are many obstacles to housing offenders and those at risk of offending. These include the serious shortage of affordable rented accommodation; changes in benefit arrangements which have made it harder for single people with low incomes to find housing; and delays in processing housing benefit claims so that people can wait months before getting their benefit. Ex-offenders have also been affected by local authorities' greater powers to exclude potential tenants under the Housing Act 1996. Some authorities have used these powers to reduce ex-offenders' access to housing, in some cases taking a blanket approach to people with criminal records or to particular categories of offender. Few local authorities and housing associations will give a commitment to rehouse prisoners on release in return for terminating their tenancies: most local authorities require prisoners to re-apply as homeless persons. The government is taking a number of steps which should help in tackling the problem. These include legislation to improve support arrangements for care leavers, guidance to discourage "blanket bans" on offenders in housing allocation policies and a new key performance indicator for the prison and probation services related to reducing offenders' homelessness. webTitle: Stuart Etherington: the state must pay for criminal record checks on charity workers

fields.headline: The state must pay for criminal record checks on charity workers
fields.standfirst: Compulsory criminal record checks will dissuade volunteers from working with children unless the government funds the cost, writes Stuart Etherington
fields.trailText: The introduction of compulsory criminal record checks will dissuade volunteers from working with children unless the government funds the cost, writes Stuart Etherington.
fields.body:
With parliament back in session, it's time for the voluntary sector to respond to government proposals which clearly have an impact on charities and voluntary organisations.

A key issue the sector is currently facing is the proposal for compulsory criminal record checks on all those who work with children. Until now volunteers for charities did not have to pay for checks. Now, the government rightly says that everybody working with young children must be subject to the checks. More controversially, they insist that everybody must pay for the checks themselves.

The National Council for Voluntary Organisations entirely supports the principle of criminal records checks which are designed to protect young people from unsuitable adults. By July 2001 a new Criminal Records Bureau will provide a one-stop shop for all organisations whose employees or volunteers come into contact with children or vulnerable adults.

The government has stated that each check will cost at least £10. There are some 120,000 active general charities of which 15% work with children and young people. This works out at around 18,000 organisations. There are also some 150,000 amateur sports clubs, the majority of which also involve young people.

Larger voluntary agencies will almost certainly shoulder the cost of the checks on their volunteers' behalf. For example, the Boys' Brigade has 5,000 new volunteers a year so at a a minimum the checks will cost them £50,000. The brigade estimates however, that the additional staff and administration costs means that the total cost to the organisation will be in the region of £94,000 every year.

Small organisations which rely even more heavily on volunteers may not be able to cover the cost of criminal records checks. In these instances it will be the volunteer who will have to pay for the check despite offering their time and skills for free.

Research carried out by ICM on behalf of NCVO asked different age groups whether they would be discouraged from volunteering if they had to pay for the checks. Around half of all those questioned said they would be put off by charges. The highest proportion was found among 19-21 year olds (60%). This research clearly shows the significant impact that charges on criminal record checks will have on the number of people who will volunteer.

So what will the total cost be? According to the NCVO's own research based on figures provided in recent parliamentary questions, the total cost will be around £16m a year. Despite the damage these charges could do to the voluntary sector this cost would be small change to the public purse.

In the run up to a general election, the NCVO has commissioned research looking at what charities and voluntary organisations are looking for in the political parties' election manifestos. The results showed that the vast majority want an increased role in delivering public services while receiving core funding from the government. It seems that charities are more ready than ever to work in equal and fair partnership with government and extend their responsibilities into areas that hitherto have been part of the state's sphere.

However, I firmly believe that in order to achieve this goal, the government must foster an environment in which charities can prosper. Its failure to provide free criminal records checks for volunteers is just the kind of policy that hinders this process. The NCVO will be working with other organisations to co-ordinate a sustained parliamentary campaign to put pressure on them to do so.

For more information on NCVO's parliamentary campaign for the introduction of free criminal record checks for volunteers, email Richard Hebditch on Richard.Hebditch@ncvo-vol.org.uk

 Stuart Etherington is chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations

webTitle: Rights campaign tainted by sex abuse case

fields.headline: Rights campaign tainted by sex abuse case
fields.standfirst:
The conviction on sex abuse charges of the head of the Northern Ireland Human Rights Bureau ends his lone campaign against former IRA comrades, reports Henry McDonald

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The conviction on sex abuse charges of the head of the Northern Ireland Human Rights Bureau ends his lone campaign against former IRA comrades, Henry McDonald reports.
fields.body:
The jailing of Vincent McKenna on 31 accounts of sexual abuse against his daughter marks the end of his one-man campaign against former comrades in the Provisional IRA.

McKenna, a former low-ranking member of the Provisionals' East Tyrone Brigade, was the Northern Ireland Human Rights Bureau, one of the groups highlighting republican and loyalist punishment attacks in the province.

His 18-year-old daughter Sorcha waived her rights to anonymity in Monaghan Circuit Court on Friday. She told the court she had suffered abuse including attempted anal sex, oral sex and fondling as well digital penetration.

The director of the Human Rights Bureau denied the allegations but admitted using his hands on occasion to punish his daughter by "slapping" her. After a three-day trial a jury of seven men and five women took two hours to reach their verdict. Judge Matt Deery remanded McKenna in custody for sentencing in Cavan on November 21.

McKenna turned his back on the IRA in 1990. He had been arrested on arson charges in 1981 but absconded across the border when out on bail. After his recapture in 1985, he was sentenced to nine months in Crumlin Road jail - the amount of time he had been on remand.

While a student at Queen's University McKenna formed a peace group, which supported all-party talks and subsequently the Good Friday Agreement. He stood for election to Belfast City Council in 1995 but his derisory vote in South Belfast did not get above double figures.

McKenna initially joined Families Against Intimidation and Terror (Fait), the oldest and most effective group to oppose paramilitary punishment beatings. But his presence in Fait provoked splits within the organisation with some of its founders, such as Sam Cushnahan, the brother of Fine Gael MEP John Cushnahan, accusing McKenna of being a fantasist and a megalomaniac.

Cushnahan now says McKenna played a divisive and ultimately disastrous role inside Fait, particularly his politicisation of the punishment attacks issue.

When McKenna broke with Fait he formed the Northern Ireland Human Rights Bureau. The organisation, effectively a solo effort by McKenna, constantly supplied updated figures on paramilitary activity to politicians and the media.

At times McKenna was a useful channel of information, particularly when he introduced young men forced to flee their homes after paramilitary threats to the media for interview.

However, many questioned the validity of his figures on punishment beatings and shootings. After the Good Friday Agreement was signed in 1998, McKenna gravitated to parties opposed to the accord. He addressed an annual conference of the UK Unionist Party and threatened to name those behind the Omagh bomb atrocity from the platform.

At that time the RUC and Gardai were totally opposed to any move to name and shame the Omagh bombers. He also stood on a platform with senior unionist figures like the former director of British Airways David Burnside at a Save-the-RUC conference in Belfast's Ulster Hall. Sam Cushanan said human rights campaigners struggling against republican and loyalist punishment shootings and beatings despaired that McKenna was dragging their campaign into the political arena.

McKenna also became alienated from David Trimble's pro-Agreement Ulster Unionists, many of whom were suspicious of his relationship with prominent anti-Agreement unionists.

Although his life was threatened and he was assaulted near his Ormeau Road home in South Belfast, there were also question marks over a number of alleged bomb alerts at his house. McKenna blamed the IRA for sending a number of crude devices to his Haypark Avenue home but senior RUC detectives cast doubt on this theory. They believe the devices were elaborate hoaxes, which they insist did not emanate from the IRA.

It is understood that McKenna will try to appeal against his conviction but, apart from the terrible trauma suffered by his daughter, there is another casualty in this sordid tale of sex abuse and naming and shaming. The campaign to defend the human rights of those at the sharp end of paramilitary shootings and beatings has been tarnished by the activities of Vincent McKenna stretching back 15 years.

webTitle: £70 million to tackle child poverty in Scotland

fields.headline: £70 million to tackle child poverty in Scotland
fields.trailText: A new £70 million fund to help the most disadvantaged and vulnerable children in Scotland has been unveiled by first minister Henry McLeish.
fields.body:
A new £70 million fund to help the most disadvantaged and vulnerable children in Scotland has been unveiled by first minister Henry McLeish.

The Children's Change Fund, which will be available from 2002, will target children most in need by supporting integrated services and innovative approaches to help the most vulnerable.

Ministers will consult the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities, health boards and the voluntary sector on how the fund should be administered and linked in with other initiatives.

McLeish said: "This Children's Change Fund is our new commitment to tackling child poverty and deprivation. Our aim is to promote inclusion and improve the life chances of children across Scotland."

The first minister was speaking on the publication of the first social justice annual report on 13 November. The report reveals that 70,000 children have been taken out of poverty since 1997. The number of children from homes where no one is in work fell from 19% to 16% this year.

He said: "Last year, we set out our strategy for tackling poverty and injustice and we committed ourselves to ambitious goals. This first annual report shows we are now moving from strategy to action - and action that is making a difference.

"We are measuring what matters - showing how our policies are working for the people of Scotland and where the extra effort is needed."

webTitle: Campaigning makes its mark on voluntary list

fields.headline: Campaigning makes its mark on voluntary list
fields.standfirst: Judging by their strong showing, campaigning organisations really are making a difference
fields.trailText: Judging by their strong showing, campaigning organisations really are making a difference.
fields.body:
Stuart Etherington of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations and Michael Brophy of the Charities Aid Foundation were the obvious choices for one and two as they run the two largest umbrella bodies in the sector. Representatives of campaigning organisations feature strongly in the list, suggesting that their activities have raised their profile and that they are perceived as powerful by achieving legislative change.

Although there are only three women in the top fifteen, others just failed to make the list: Angela Mason, director of Stonewall; Geraldine Peacock, chief executive of the Guide Dogs for the Blind Assocation; Marjorie Wallace, chief executive of SANE; Sally Greengross, former chief executive of Age Concern and Fiona Reynolds, director designate, the National Trust.

There are no power players from ethnic minority communities in this list, although a case could be made for two left out: Bharat Mhetia, clerk to the trustees, the City Parochial Foundation; and Kumar Murshid who established the National Assembly against Racism.

Several members of the commercial world also just missed out. Stephen Lloyd, a partner at, Bates, Wells and Braithwaite, lawyers to the voluntary sector; Stephen Serpell head of community partnerships, BT; and Ken Burnett who founded the direct marketing agency, Burnett Associates.

webTitle: Joining up government key to regeneration list

fields.headline: Joining up government key to regeneration list
fields.standfirst: The current trend of joining up local services dictates who holds power in regeneration
fields.trailText: The current trend of joining up local services dictates who holds power in regeneration.
fields.body:
This list powerfully reflects the orthodoxy of the moment, which has it that successful regeneration is all about joining up local services.

Moira Wallace makes it to the top because of the role her Social Exclusion Unit (SEU) has played in forging this attitude to regeneration work.

But the SEU's approach requires a willingness from government departments to engage in cross-sector cooperation, and some are not keen on sharing their toys.

The Department for Education and Employment, for instance, faces immense pressure to remove school finance from local government control - a move that would work directly against joining up.

As one of the key education civil servants, Michael Bichard has the power to resist this pressure and ensure that the issue of school funding does not eclipse the importance of lifelong learning to renewal projects.

Arguably, regeneration has slipped down the list of priorities at the NHS, and it will be interesting to see if its new chief executive Nigel Crisp decides to treat it as important.

Regional development agencies are key players in providing a strategic lead on regeneration, and in England they are beginning to gain credibility and have successfully fought for greater independence from the centre.

Most of the real work in any regeneration scheme is carried out at local level. This might explain the presence of council officers including regeneration chiefs in Manchester and Liverpool.

The community groups and local partnerships that carry through these policies do not get a mention on this list. No one group has enough power. But they are without doubt the unsung heroes of the regeneration sector.

webTitle: Top health power player answers only to Blair

fields.headline: Top health power player answers only to Blair
fields.standfirst: The most powerful person in health is hardly known outside Whitehall
fields.trailText: The most powerful person in health is hardly known outside Whitehall.
fields.body:
It is a sign of the political times that the single most powerful individual in health, ministers aside, is Downing Street policy adviser Robert Hill: not a health professional or a civil servant, but a "special adviser" accountable only to his boss, prime minister Tony Blair.

Mr Hill's writ runs large over health policy and yet he is virtually unknown outside Whitehall and Westminster. His influence will dramatically shape the future of the NHS, but neither he nor his employer is obliged to divulge anything about his work, his decisions or even himself.

Women make up 80% of the NHS workforce, but none wield any serious power over health policy. The service may be undergoing its most radical changes for 50 years, but the people who influence this reform are, as ever, predominantly white, male and middle aged.

The most influential woman in the NHS, the Royal College of Nursing general secretary Christine Hancock, has announced that she is to retire next summer - and there is no guarantee that her replacement will be a woman, let alone an individual with comparable stature and leverage.

And while patients are rhetorically central to the NHS plan, no individual representing consumer interests is connected to high-level NHS power networks; rather, power is concentrated in the hands of central government and producer interests - the trade unions and professional associations.

The presence of Paul Dacre, editor of the Daily Mail and tribune for middle England, is an indication of how powerful the media has become in directing the tone, timing and nature of government policy decisions and announcements. Health is no exception.

The only ethnic minority power player is Chai Patel, a private health sector businessman of Indian parentage. Incidentally, he is the only individual in the top 15 to have made a registered donation to the Labour Party - he gave at least £5,000 in 1999.

The list contains some individuals who are arguably ciphers for institutional power. It is no disrespect to Alastair Bridges to assert that his influence depends on his role as field commander of the Treasury tank battalion currently parked on Department of Health lawns. Others, such as Professor George Alberti, transcend institutional power. As president of the Royal College of Physicians, his influence rests not there but as a trusted ministerial adviser and fixer who has credibility with the medical establishment.

Analysis of the professional backgrounds of the NHS Power 15 reveals that medicine and NHS management supply most of the key players. Including Patel, there are five qualified doctors. Including Simon Stevens, and Hancock, there are five with NHS management experience. Of the 15, only Unison head of health Bob Abberley, who was a hospital operating theatre assistant, and Hancock, who was a nurse, have hands-on experience of the NHS outside medicine and management.

Notable omissions from the top 15 are anyone with specialist expertise and influence in mental health, cancer, and heart disease - the government's three principle priorities for investment.

The list is inevitably invidious. Powerful individuals who just missed the cut include: Sir Donald Irvine, chairman of the General Medical Council; Sir Richard Sykes, chairman of Glaxo Wellcome; and Dr Mac Armstrong, former British Medical Association secretary, now Scotland's chief medical officer. Not far behind comes Rabbi Julia Neuberger, director of the King's Fund health policy think tank; Ian Carruthers, chief executive of East Dorset health authority and doyen of NHS managers; Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services; and Mike Richards, NHS national cancer director.

Finally, no list of powerful people would be complete without a conspiracy theory. Although there is no evidence of an actual conspiracy, an astonishing proportion of influential doctors come from health secretary Alan Milburn's and Blair's north-east stamping ground: Messrs Alberti, Rawlins, Donaldson and Irvine.

Mr Hill's writ runs large over health policy and yet he is virtually unknown outside Whitehall and Westminster. His influence will dramatically shape the future of the NHS, but neither he nor his employer is obliged to divulge anything about his work, his decisions or even himself. Women make up 80% of the NHS workforce, but none wield any serious power over health policy. The service may be undergoing its most radical changes for 50 years, but the people who influence this reform are, as ever, predominantly white, male and middle aged. The most influential woman in the NHS, the Royal College of Nursing general secretary Christine Hancock, has announced that she is to retire next summer - and there is no guarantee that her replacement will be a woman, let alone an individual with comparable stature and leverage. And while patients are rhetorically central to the NHS plan, no individual representing consumer interests is connected to high-level NHS power networks; rather, power is concentrated in the hands of central government and producer interests - the trade unions and professional associations. The presence of Paul Dacre, editor of the Daily Mail and tribune for middle England, is an indication of how powerful the media has become in directing the tone, timing and nature of government policy decisions and announcements. Health is no exception. The only ethnic minority power player is Chai Patel, a private health sector businessman of Indian parentage. Incidentally, he is the only individual in the top 15 to have made a registered donation to the Labour Party - he gave at least £5,000 in 1999. The list contains some individuals who are arguably ciphers for institutional power. It is no disrespect to Alastair Bridges to assert that his influence depends on his role as field commander of the Treasury tank battalion currently parked on Department of Health lawns. Others, such as Professor George Alberti, transcend institutional power. As president of the Royal College of Physicians, his influence rests not there but as a trusted ministerial adviser and fixer who has credibility with the medical establishment. Analysis of the professional backgrounds of the NHS Power 15 reveals that medicine and NHS management supply most of the key players. Including Patel, there are five qualified doctors. Including Simon Stevens, and Hancock, there are five with NHS management experience. Of the 15, only Unison head of health Bob Abberley, who was a hospital operating theatre assistant, and Hancock, who was a nurse, have hands-on experience of the NHS outside medicine and management. Notable omissions from the top 15 are anyone with specialist expertise and influence in mental health, cancer, and heart disease - the government's three principle priorities for investment. The list is inevitably invidious. Powerful individuals who just missed the cut include: Sir Donald Irvine, chairman of the General Medical Council; Sir Richard Sykes, chairman of Glaxo Wellcome; and Dr Mac Armstrong, former British Medical Association secretary, now Scotland's chief medical officer. Not far behind comes Rabbi Julia Neuberger, director of the King's Fund health policy think tank; Ian Carruthers, chief executive of East Dorset health authority and doyen of NHS managers; Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services; and Mike Richards, NHS national cancer director. Finally, no list of powerful people would be complete without a conspiracy theory. Although there is no evidence of an actual conspiracy, an astonishing proportion of influential doctors come from health secretary Alan Milburn's and Blair's north-east stamping ground: Messrs Alberti, Rawlins, Donaldson and Irvine. webTitle: Capital Gold to receive image face-lift

fields.headline: Capital Gold to receive image face-lift
fields.trailText: 12pm: Capital Gold is to undergo a major image revamp, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Capital Gold, the favourite radio station of London's baby-boomer generation, is to undergo a major image revamp.

Owner Capital Radio has unveiled a new logo for its Gold brand and has recruited a raft of older rock acts to star in a marketing campaign for the new-look radio station.

From the end of this week, the faces of David Bowie, Mick Jagger, Debbie Harry and Sting will appear on 850 London buses beside the new logo to promote Capital Gold and remind consumers of the quality of its playlist.

But die-hard Capital Gold fans worried about their station becoming too modern have little to fear.

The station's new autumn schedule shows that Capital Gold will remain true to its sixties and seventies roots with a new Saturday show called Cream of the 60s and forthcoming specials including a Tom Jones night on November 20 and a Queen chart on November 24.

Glam rock legend Noddy Holder will also host two new shows, Noddy's Saturday Night Fever and Noddy's Seventies Sunday Show.

Capital Gold programme controller Andy Turner said: "The music from these artists is as timeless and relevant today as ever. It's simply great music, whether you are hearing the songs for the first time or celebrating a great song from your past.

"You only need to look at the massive anticipation for the new Beatles album "1" or the recent press interest in the sale of John Lennon's piano to bear this out."

Capital Gold marketing manager Paula Gunn added: "The new logo design and marketing campaign will challenge long-outdated perceptions of Capital Gold and encourage new trial.

"Capital Gold is all about great music and the images reflect the passion of the station."

webTitle: Blairs win latest privacy battle

fields.headline: Blairs win latest privacy battle
fields.trailText: Cherie Blair yesterday won another round in her continuing battle to prevent the publication of confidential information about her family.
fields.body:
Cherie Blair yesterday won another round in her continuing battle to prevent the publication of confidential information about her family.

An injunction was obtained against Nel Lister, a friend of the Blairs' former nanny Ros Mark, who is writing a book about the Blair family. It was to have included claims the prime ministerial couple lacked parental control and proper personal security.

Mrs Blair wanted to stop Mrs Lister revealing information she had learned from Ms Mark, who had signed a privacy agreement when she was employed.

It is the latest step in the Blairs' battle to keep their domestic life private in a year when it has repeatedly been publicised. In July son Euan, 16, was found drunk in central London and in August was accused of rowdy behaviour in an Italian hotel. The Blairs were also criticised for trying to stop pictures of new baby Leo being published.

At the beginning of the year Ms Mark, nanny for four years to Euan, Nicky and Kathryn, tried to publish her memoirs but was prevented by a court injunction.

Mrs Lister, a 49-year-old friend of Ms Mark's family, yesterday gave a legal undertaking at the high court in London to hand over three computer disks containing material relating to the Blairs.

But Mrs Lister was not willing to pass on her own research relating to Mrs Blair's response to the threat to her privacy, which Mrs Lister described as "heavy-handed".

She refuted suggestions of trying to blackmail Mrs Blair after asking for £40,000 in return for not publishing and to cover her expenses.

The judge ruled that the material Mrs Lister had obtained from Ms Mark - which included references to the Blairs' "alarming disregard to parental control" and "lack of personal security" - fell within the confidentiality agreement which Ms Mark and her brother Thomas signed with the Blairs.

The judge warned Mrs Lister that she would be in contempt if she did not comply with the order and would be at risk of going to prison.

Gore 262

Needed 270

Today November 14

Florida
5pm Deadline for all 67 Florida counties to submit recount figures. The results of some hand counts may be left out of the total if they fail to meet the deadline. Despite this, Palm Beach County vows to go ahead with a hand recount which could last for six more days.

Legal
Florida counties with hand counts may ask for more time. The Democrats have argued that the deadline is arbitrary and incomplete figures would disenfranchise voters.

Washington
The "lame-duck" Congress reassembles to complete unfinished legislative business. It can change the schedule date for the meeting of the electoral college.

November 17/18

Florida
Overseas ballot papers in by midnight of 17th. Counted by 18th. With the result so close, these few thousands ballot papers could tip the result either way. The Republicans are confident that the postal vote from overseas military and businessmen would go in their favour. After this result is declared, the loser will come under intense pressure to concede defeat, irrespective of any future challenges.

Legal
Democrats may challenge Florida result on the grounds that they were unable to cast votes as they intended, notably in Palm Beach county.

Electoral
17th Deadline for recount calls in Wisconsin.
17th Deadline for recount calls in Iowa.

Late November/early December

Legal
Appeals against lower courts would be heard in Florida - possibly more in federal courts, leading to Supreme Court.

Electoral
28th Deadline for recount calls in New Mexico.
First week of December Any Oregon count would be held.

December 12

Florida
If the results are still in dispute or subject to court action the state may lose the right to take part in the electoral process.

Electoral
Each state must choose members of its electoral college. If they cannot, Congress takes is asked to rule on which candidate the state voted for.

December 18

Electoral
Electoral college meets in all 50 states. Members could switch votes.

January 6

Washington
Congress meets to count results from electoral college. If no winner, House of Representatives choose new president, voting by states. The Senate votes for the vice-president.

January 20

Washington
Inauguration day The new president is sworn by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court at the Inauguration ceremony on Capitol Hill. If no president or vice-president is confirmed, Speaker Dennis Hastert becomes acting president.

webTitle: The 15 most powerful people in health

fields.headline: The 15 most powerful people in health
fields.trailText:
1. Robert Hill
Number 10 policy unit adviser on health
10 Downing Street
"We don't release information about Number 10 staff." The government is not required to tell us anything about the most powerful individual in the NHS.
fields.body:
1. Robert Hill
Number 10 policy unit adviser on health
10 Downing Street
"We don't release information about Number 10 staff." The government is not required to tell us anything about the most powerful individual in the NHS.

What we know is that he is a former theology student, one-time binman, National Union of Public Employees officer (he was active in the 1982 NHS strike, the longest in health service history), and Labour Party official. Joined the Downing Street policy unit team in May 1997. He is Tony Blair's trusted advisor on health. "Blair and Hill share the same core beliefs on health," says one insider.

Credited with coming up with initiatives such as NHS Direct and walk-in centres, and establishing a Daily Mail-friendly "safety first" approach to mental health policy, to the horror of the clinical establishment.

He is Blair's emissary to the Department of Health (DoH), where he delivers high-voltage news of his master's dissatisfaction, and reputedly has the power to make or break ministerial careers.

Quiet, intelligent, and regarded by some as aloof and pompous. "When I knew him he was called Bob, and now its Robert," says one former union colleague. But no one questions his power. "If it (a health policy idea) doesn't fit in his world view, it's unlikely to happen," claims one observer.

2. Nigel Crisp
NHS chief executive
NHS.uk
Chief executive of both the NHS Executive and the DoH. The first NHS chief to combine the two posts, and therefore the first NHS chief with a seat among the power brokers at the civil service top table. Widely respected in the NHS management community, he arrived in his present job after the launch of the NHS plan, but responsibility for its implementation lies in his hands.

3. Sir George Alberti
President, Royal College of Physicians
Royal College of Physicians
Blair's modernising representative on Planet Consultant. Plugged into the higher level medical power networks, although his influence stretches further afield: he helped draw up the national health framework on coronary heart disease, sits on the NHS modernisation board, and advised ministers on the appointment of Nigel Crisp as NHS chief executive.

4. Simon Stevens
Head of the strategic policy unit, Department of Health
Department of Health
Career NHS manager turned policy advisor to both former health secretary Frank Dobson and incumbent Alan Milburn. The latter created a strategic policy unit in the DoH (possibly to counterbalance the influence of Number 10 and the Treasury), and made Stevens head of it. Worked closely on the NHS plan, now looking at health policy options for a second term of Labour government.

5. Professor Liam Donaldson
Chief medical officer for England and Wales
DoH Chief Medical Officer
As the holder of the top doctor's post in England and Wales he is the clinical face of the DoH, and has immense influence on key public health issues (as the recent Phillips' report on the BSE crisis, which examined the role of his predecessors, made clear). As chief medical officer to the government, not just the DoH, he has serious reach across Whitehall, while his experience as a senior NHS manager gives him credibility in the NHS.

6. Professor Mike Rawlins
Chair, National Institute for Clinical Excellence
National Institute for Clinical Excellence
Respected pharmacologist who brings clinical credibility to the job of deciding which drugs and treatments are cost-effective enough to be made available on the NHS. If he can withstand furious counter-attacks from an outraged pharmaceutical industry lobby and the right-wing press (witness the furore over flu drug Relenza), he will have immense power to shape NHS clinical practice and investment decisions.

7. Alastair Bridges
Head of Treasury health team
HM Treasury
The Treasury is increasingly influential on health policy, imposing the financial and performance framework in which the NHS operates, and - according to its critics - micro-managing the NHS in an unprecedented way. It holds the purse strings, and has a major say in the development of new hospitals and GP health centres. As head of the health team, Bridges is a key figure, visiting trusts and health authorities as the Treasury's very own NHS productivity inspector.

8. Chai Patel
Chief executive, Westminster Health Care Holdings plc
Labour party donor, Blair favourite, and head of one of the UK's biggest private healthcare providers. Persuaded the government to use private care homes to provide intermediate care for NHS patients. Influence also over long term care and social care policy through his many government committee appointments, including the NHS older people task force and the Cabinet Office better regulation task force.

9. Ian Bogle
Chair, British Medical Association
BMA Online
Experienced medico-politician. Although he has signed up the BMA to the principles of the NHS plan, and sits on the NHS modernisation board, his organisation's commitment to NHS reform is always conditional and self-interested. Bogle's position gives him the power to stall the government's ambitious project should his members revolt over plans to tighten regulation of doctors, or limit consultants' private earnings.

10. Paul Dacre
Editor, Daily Mail
Daily Mail
The Mail's tales of impending NHS collapse are read and possibly believed by the millions who reside in that virtual geographical space known as middle England. Not the obvious newspaper of choice for NHS policy makers but its sallies into the healthcare arena cause tremors in the corridors of the DoH in a way that no other national media outlet can.

11. Peter Homa
Chief executive, Commission for Health Improvement (CHI)
Commission for Health Improvement
Respected career manager and former head of government waiting list taskforce, now in charge of the nascent regulatory body aimed at driving up standards of NHS care. Initially likely to adopt a "softly-softly" approach to inspections in a bid to shrug off CHI's "Ofsted of the NHS" reputation, but its wide powers to investigate failing hospitals and monitor quality gives CHI real muscle.

12. Stephen Thornton
Chief executive, NHS Confederation
NHS Confederation
Articulate spokesman for NHS management with a high media profile. Has turned the confederation into a highly effective lobbying machine. An influential contributor to the NHS plan. He sits on the NHS modernisation board, while his key managers colleagues sit on modernisation task forces.

13. Professor Chris Ham
Advisor, strategic policy unit, DoH
Health Services Management Centre
Health policy heavyweight who has influenced DoH thinking under this government and its predecessor. Currently a member of the DoH strategic policy unit set up to advise Milburn on the NHS plan and the direction of the NHS under a second term. Also director of the health services management centre at Birmingham University.

14. Christine Hancock
General secretary, Royal College of Nursing
RCN site
Head of what is potentially Britain's most powerful health lobby, with around 260,000 of the public's favourite health workers in membership. Any NHS reforms must get the RCN on side - Hancock was a key figure in helping Milburn firm up the NHS plan. Opinion is divided on whether Hancock has exploited nurses' leverage to the full, particularly over pay.

15. Bob Abberley
Head of health, Unison
Unison
Experienced trade unionist who helped ease Unison's access back to the corridors of power after years of being frozen out under the Conservatives. Milburn's link to the NHS rank and file. Influential on NHS human resources policy, but has failed to break Labour's love affair with the private finance initiative.

Feedback: what do you think of the Power 90 panel's choices? Please send your comments to editor@societytheguardian.com
