webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours brought to you in just 9.5 seconds.
fields.trailText: Zinedine Zidane could join Arsenal in a "sensational swap deal" that would see Patrick Vieira move to Juventus, according to Football 365's "Highbury insider". The website back up their story with speculation in the Gazzetta dello Sport which suggests that the French legend may be looking for a "change of scenery" after Juve's exit from Europe. However Zidane has since denied the rumours, saying it is "out of the question" that he will leave Turin.
fields.body:
Zinedine Zidane could join Arsenal in a "sensational swap deal" that would see Patrick Vieira move to Juventus, according to Football 365's "Highbury insider". The website back up their story with speculation in the Gazzetta dello Sport which suggests that the French legend may be looking for a "change of scenery" after Juve's exit from Europe. However Zidane has since denied the rumours, saying it is "out of the question" that he will leave Turin.

Kevin Keegan, Jim Jefferies and Howard Kendall are the three names on the shortlist for the vacant manager's job at Bradford, reports Teamtalk. However, Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond has refused to comment on what seems like yet another Teamtalk guessing game.

"I decided at the beginning that I was going to be consistent and not comment on any of the rumours or speculation," he said. "Despite reports, no offer has been made to any individual and no interviews have commenced. I have a shortlist of three people and I wouldn't exclude the possibility of a new manager being appointed by the end of this week."

But FA technical director Howard Wilkinson will not be on the shortlist, despite speculation linking him with vacant position. "As far as I'm aware, Bradford have an active manager and I have a job. I have no thoughts of changing that situation," said Wilkinson.

Croatian international Igor Biscan will join Liverpool on December 1 - two weeks earlier than planned - after being granted a work permit.

Sheffield Wednesday are hoping to sign Terry Cooke for a cut-price £500,000. The Manchester City winger, currently on loan at Hillsborough, cost Joe Royle £1m from Manchester United.

Charlton have taken 21-year-old Haugesund goalkeeper Kenneth Hoie on trial.

Preston are set to sign Fulham's versatile midfielder Wayne Collins.

"Despite reports, no offer has been made to any individual and no interviews have commenced. But FA technical director Howard Wilkinson will not be on the shortlist, despite speculation linking him with vacant position. "As far as I'm aware, Bradford have an active manager and I have a job. Croatian international Igor Biscan will join Liverpool on December 1 - two weeks earlier than planned - after being granted a work permit. Sheffield Wednesday are hoping to sign Terry Cooke for a cut-price £500,000. The Manchester City winger, currently on loan at Hillsborough, cost Joe Royle £1m from Manchester United. Charlton have taken 21-year-old Haugesund goalkeeper Kenneth Hoie on trial. Preston are set to sign Fulham's versatile midfielder Wayne Collins.

webTitle: Alli exits after Carlton shake-up

fields.headline: Alli exits after Carlton shake-up
fields.standfirst: 10.45am: Alli to leave Carlton
fields.trailText:
12.15pm update: Waheed Alli's departure from Carlton follows a shake-up designed to streamline the ITV company's TV and media operations, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
10.45am: Alli to leave Carlton
fields.body:
Waheed Alli's departure from Carlton Communications follows a shake-up designed to streamline the ITV company's TV and media operations.

It is believed the Labour peer decided to leave Carlton because he was not offered a new boardroom position overseeing production for ITV, as well as satellite and digital TV and online services.

Lord Alli, who is managing director of Carlton Productions, hit the headlines recently after he masterminded the £10m return to ITV of seventies motel soap Crossroads.

The Crossroads revival was seen as a major triumph for Lord Alli who, like other executives before him, was determined to rid Carlton of its reputation for second-rate programming.

In a restructuring to be announced later today a new executive board will be created, bringing together the cream of executives at Carlton Communications and Carlton TV.

It is believed that Carlton will now redefine itself with a new management structure for content and channels.

The new board will be headed up by Gerry Murphy, the recently installed chief executive of Carlton Communications, while Nigel Walmsley, chairman of Carlton TV and executive director of Carlton Communications, will be named deputy chief executive.

Clive Jones, chief executive of Carlton TV will get a new role as chief executive of Carlton channels.

Carlton TV director of programming Steve Hewlett is to continue with his current job.

In an interview Lord Alli gave to the Financial Times three weeks ago, it was clear that he believed his future was intimately linked with that of the company.

In words that have come back to haunt him, he told the paper of his long term plans.

He said: "I am a big enough character and confident enough to stop the corporate jobsworths destroying the culture of the company. There are stacks of corporate jobsworth people willing to strangle the creative culture out of companies - 'You may not have coloured walls. You have to have grey carpets. You must have clear desks' - But Carlton is not like that any more.

"I have not made any acquisitions in my first year quite deliberately," Lord Alli added, but he suggested that he would be shopping for companies in his second year.

"If we are going to be making deals in the next year, they are going to be deals we can leverage in the US."

According to a source, "there were aspects of Carlton as an organisation that were dysfunctional. The plc structure worked for a conglomerate but not for a company that works as a core media business."

webTitle: Tales to inspire children

fields.headline: Inspiring tales
fields.trailText: From Martin Luther King to the monarchy and the consequences of illiteracy, a selection of tales to inspire children
fields.body:
I Have a Dream by Neil Tonge (Hodder Wayland, £8.50, 7-11 years) presents a chance encounter between a little boy and Martin Luther King. The illustrated narrative concentrates on the motivation behind his commitment to racial equality, and on the famous Montgomery bus boycott that triggered reform in the USA. This was not a man fighting for himself, but on behalf of all those segregated or discriminated against. Although specific in its remit, there is a distinct resonance with racial iniquity both at home and abroad.

I Was a Rat! ... or The Scarlet Slippers by Philip Pullman (Corgi £3.99, 10+ yrs) is a chameleon of a story, shifting with every re-reading. As storytellers go, Pullman is among the best, and, although renowned for the deservedly feted His Dark Materials trilogy, this slimmer volume is no less ingenious. Plundering the world of traditional fairytale and adding some trenchant references to the unpalatable way in which the press can manipulate their readers, this story works on several levels and poses any number of conundrums about perceptions of ourselves and those around us.

Warlands by Rachel Anderson (OUP, £5.99, 9-15 yrs) Accident of birth fascinates Anderson, whose books often look at how a quirk of nature dictates the direction of a life. Using experience of her own adopted son, Sang, the author tells a series of stories about Ho, a Vietnamese orphan whose history is unknown. A whole narrative and emotional framework must be created so he can take his place among the family. His abysmal behaviour strains their commitment, but through the stories they slowly provide a haven in which he thrives, secure in himself and with others.

Falling Awake by Vivian French (Barrington Stoke £4.50, 11-16 yrs) Vivian French tackles the horrors of drug addiction head on, starting with a ghastly drug-induced nightmare. And it continues, even as reality and consciousness kicks in. The negative side-effects of drug-taking are made very clear, but the over-riding impression is of the drugs economy which, even on this local scale, targets the weakest.

The Monarchy by Emily Moore (What's the Big Idea? series, Hodder, £3.99, 11-15yrs). Emily Moore gets her teeth into The Monarchy, subtitled 'National Treasure or a Right Royal Disgrace?' It is fairly clear in which direction she leans, but she avoids diatribe or blue-rinse defence. Historically and socially fascinating and entertainingly illustrated, there is fodder here for spirited debate about the nature of power and the accident of inherited status within a much broader context than simply the beleaguered Windsors.

Tommy Trouble by Stephen Potts (Mammoth £3.99, 9-12 yrs) Theresa Breslin's Carnegie-winning Whispers in the Graveyard was ground-breaking in its exposure of the consequences of illiteracy - this book explores similar territory for a younger readership. Tommy is ridiculed by his teacher, bullied by his peers and largely ignored by his weary, lonely mother. A friendship with the old man he meets at the war memorial provides the incentive and support he needs to begin to explore the world of words. His journey is not neatly complete by the time this gentle story closes. Life will never be easy for Tommy.

webTitle: 'Every vote counts: sometimes three or four times'

fields.headline: 'Every vote counts: sometimes three or four times'
fields.standfirst: Yesterday's ruling by Florida's secretary of state has earned her 15 minutes of fame, reports Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Yesterday's ruling by Florida's secretary of state has earned her 15 minutes of fame, reports Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The Florida press is having a field day, guiding readers through the dense legal fog now enveloping the presidential poll. Most of the papers lead on the declaration by the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, that the recount must end at 5pm local time today - and point out that the ruling isn't worth a fig.

As the Miami Heraldputs it, the Republican secretary of state has tried to draw a line in the sand. But, the front page report tautly adds, "the sands kept shifting". Morin, the paper's sardonically inclined cartoonist, contributes an acid viewof the voting farce.

The Orlando Sentinal delves into the increasingingly squalid legal tangle, reporting that today's legal judgment on the deadline is sure to go to yet another appeal. The paper reports: "As of Monday, Florida's unofficial recount figure from all 67 counties except Palm Beach put Bush ahead by 961 votes with 2,910,078 against Gore`s 2,909,117. An Associated Press count of all counties had Bush`s lead shaved to 388 votes."

At the epicentre of the electoral storm, the Palm Beach Postcarries a lively bulletin board of predictably partisan posts. Many express faith in the constitution, but posters are sharply divided on the propriety of the electoral recount. The paper also carries some guilt-ridden comments by the voters who might have made all the difference - by not turning out on November 7. One young wag comments that "every vote does count, sometimes three or four times".

In the state capital, the Tallahassee Democrat offers soothing advice to its readers: "Amid this historic, rancorous confusion in the wake of 'Indecision 2000,' it's important that Americans of all political persuasions take a deep breath and remember a couple of things.

One: Nothing fundamental has changed in Washington since last Tuesday. Our national government is stable, and the same man who was in office one week ago will remain in office until January, when, presumably, either George W Bush or Al Gore will assume the presidency.

Two: Before television and radio, and long before the internet, Americans frequently didn't know who their next president would be until many days, even weeks after an election was held. Despite our history of passionately partisan politics, America didn't then collapse under the weight of not knowing right away. It's preposterous to think we will now - even in this information age of immediate gratification."

The Fort Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel offers a clever interactive ballot, based on the controversial punched-hole system used in Palm Beach. The implication is that if readers can use the form correctly, they must be a shade brighter than their east coast neighbours. The paper also carries a wry report on the bonanza the recount has brought to Palm Beach hoteliers and other traders. A manager of one five-star hotel notes that the media pack has offered little additional business. Most are on per-diem restrictions, and couldn't afford the rooms. "What we have are the attorneys," he added. "They're never on per diem."

The Sarasota Herald-Tribune focuses on a local woman made good - or bad, depending on your politics: "Katherine Harris' job was considered so insignificant that the voters decided to eliminate it. Now, the Florida secretary of state may end up deciding who will be the leader of the free world.

Harris, a 43-year-old former state senator from Sarasota, yields the least amount of power and influence among the six statewide elected cabinet members. The Republican is in charge of state corporate records, issuing concealed weapons permits and promoting the arts. But she also oversees the normally mundane state elections system, and her once-in-a-lifetime power became clear Monday..."

webTitle: Gerrard pulls out of England squad

fields.headline: Gerrard pulls out of England squad
fields.trailText: England coach Peter Taylor suffered another injury blow today when Steven Gerrard was forced to pull out of tomorrow's friendly against Italy with a back problem.
fields.body:
England coach Peter Taylor suffered another injury blow today when Steven Gerrard was forced to pull out of tomorrow's friendly against Italy with a back problem.

The Liverpool midfielder, who was expected to be handed a holding role in midfield, is flying back to England this afternoon after suffering a recurrence of the back problem which has dogged him for most of this year.

Gerrard was also included in the squads for the World Cup qualifiers against Germany and Finland as well as the friendly international in France but on each occasion had to withdraw.

He becomes the fifth player to drop out of Taylor's original squad of 26, after Wes Brown, Alan Smith, Paul Scholes and Michael Owen pulled out earlier this week.

webTitle: Blue Peter to air all year round

fields.headline: Blue Peter to air all year round
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Children's flagship Blue Peter is proving so popular that the BBC has decided to broadcast it all year round, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
In the age of Pokemon and the playstation, Blue Peter's sticky-backed plastic appears to be something of an anachronism.

But the programme's popularity is so strong that the BBC has decided to run it all year round.

At the moment, the show - which currently runs on three nights a week - takes a break for the summer.

But today, the BBC's new head of children's programmes, Nigel Pickard, will announce that it is to run 52 weeks a year.

The BBC's award-winning children's news programme, Newsround, is to move from 5pm to 5.30pm - just before Neighbours - as part of a reorganisation of the children's TV schedules.

The show picked up a gong at the Bafta children's awards on Monday.

Mr Pickard, who has been poached from ITV, will tell a press conference today that he aims to revitalise the ailing Live and Kicking, which despite a relaunch is performing poorly against ITV's SM:TV Live.

He will also give more details of the corporation's plans to launch two new children's channels, one of which is provisionally titled Playbox.

webTitle: Luton Airport takes on RPM3 for relaunch campaign

fields.headline: Luton Airport hires RPM3 for relaunch campaign
fields.trailText: Luton Airport, immortalised by Lorraine Chase in the 70s Campari ads, has hired a new advertising agency. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Luton Airport, immortalised by Lorraine Chase in the 70s Campari ads, has hired a new advertising agency.

In a final bid to ditch its 70s image, the airport is launching a London-wide press and outdoor campaign with RPM3 to relaunch the brand.

"Luton Airport is a new place," said Marcus Balmforth, the company's commercial director. "What we have to do is convince people to try us.

"Our research has shown that people have very long held preconceptions about the brand and that's what we will be battling against."

Mr Balmforth added that since the last ad campaign five years ago, the airport had benefited from a new terminal building, a railway line linking it to London's King's Cross, new catering and more space in the departure lounge.

The number of passengers using the airport during that time has also soared from 1.9m to 6.2m. This figure is expected to rise again to 10m by 2004.

Mark Brandis, managing director at RPM3, said: "This is a classic case of getting your product right and then telling people about it."

webTitle: View from Hong Kong: 'Angry' Chinese leader leans on Hong Kong press

fields.headline: 'Angry' Chinese leader leans on Hong Kong press
fields.standfirst: Beijing has started to meddle with a leading paper in the province, raising fears that press freedom is under threat, reports John Gittings
fields.trailText: View from Hong Kong: Beijing has started to meddle with a leading paper in the province, raising fears that press freedom could now be under threat, John Gittings reports.
fields.body:
The reports of the demise of press freedom in Hong Kong after the 1997 handover were greatly exaggerated - but there is now a new concern that Beijing may have started to lean more heavily.

The most obvious sign of heavy-handedness came from the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, who blew his top recently at some persistent questioning from young Hong Kong reporters. "I'm angry", he shouted, accusing them of being "too simple and naive".

Now Mr Jiang appears to have punished the Hong Kong media by barring access for them to a high profile event today across the border. Hong Kong's chief executive Tung Chee-hwa will attend a ceremony to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone.

Mr Tung will see Mr Jiang unveil a bronze statue to the former leader Deng Xiaoping, architect of the "open-door policy" under which Shenzhen has flourished.

But journalists from Hong Kong are not invited, and there will not even be an official photographer to accompany Mr Tung. Mr Jiang, observers are suggesting, is "still angry".

More serious worries have been raised by the resignation of Willy Wo-lap Lam, China editor of Hong Kong's main English-language newspaper, the South China Morning Post. The Post's China coverage has been seen as a litmus test of press freedom and so far has proved a good advertisement for official tolerance.

Its Beijing-based correspondents regularly expose Chinese corruption in high places, while Mr Lam's commentaries have explored the inside story of top-level intrigue and contention within the Beijing leadership. Mr Lam has resigned after a staff reorganisation which gave his formal title to a former mainland Chinese journalist while inviting him to stay on as associate editor.

This move, although justified in terms of expanding the Post's China coverage, came only a few months after Mr Lam had been publicly criticised by the paper's controlling shareholder, Malaysian tycoon Robert Kuok Hock Nien.

Mr Kuok was a member of a group of Hong Kong tycoons feted in Beijing by Mr Jiang. Mr Lam wrote a cutting commentary suggesting that they had been pressed to support Chief Executive Tung in return for economic favours.

Mr Kuok denounced Mr Lam's commentary in a letter to his newspaper, backed a couple of days later by fellow-tycoons. Journalists from other countries acknowledge that a proprietor criticised in his own paper would have taken offence elsewhere too. It is the China connection which makes the affair especially sensitive.

More than half the Post's editorial staff - 115 reporters and editors - have now signed a letter expressing their concern, and affirming their own commitment to editorial freedom.

They say they deplore the way that Mr Lam was given the impression that he was being sidelined, "especially in sensitive circumstances just a few months after the unprecedented public criticism of him by Mr Kuok;."

Mr Lam believes that this is part of a move to "depoliticise" the Post's China coverage. Former Post editor Jonathan Fenby says that during his tenure he came under pressure from the Post proprietor to remove Mr Kuok.

Tales of newspaper upheavals are rarely completely straightforward. Mr Lam was an incisive writer rather than an editorial manager and his replacement has wider responsibilities. The Post's current editor Robert Keatley admits that the organisational changes "could have been carried out with greater care and sensitivity".

The Post printed its own journalists' protest and a number of critical letters. It had allowed Mr Lam to stand by his original story after it was attacked by Mr Kuok.

Yet in Hong Kong's very specific context of "one country two systems", such episodes are bound to be widely interpreted as threatening to undermine a very important feature of its own "system". Understandably, Mr Lam feels hard done by, and public opinion will only be re-assured if the Post's China coverage as a whole remains unaffected.

And, of course, if President Jiang Zemin stops being angry....

Mr Lam believes that this is part of a move to "depoliticise" the Post's China coverage. Former Post editor Jonathan Fenby says that during his tenure he came under pressure from the Post proprietor to remove Mr Kuok. Tales of newspaper upheavals are rarely completely straightforward. Mr Lam was an incisive writer rather than an editorial manager and his replacement has wider responsibilities. The Post's current editor Robert Keatley admits that the organisational changes "could have been carried out with greater care and sensitivity". The Post printed its own journalists' protest and a number of critical letters. It had allowed Mr Lam to stand by his original story after it was attacked by Mr Kuok. Yet in Hong Kong's very specific context of "one country two systems", such episodes are bound to be widely interpreted as threatening to undermine a very important feature of its own "system". Understandably, Mr Lam feels hard done by, and public opinion will only be re-assured if the Post's China coverage as a whole remains unaffected. And, of course, if President Jiang Zemin stops being angry.... webTitle: Tories ready to axe 'patronising' women's unit

fields.headline: Tories ready to axe 'patronising' women's unit
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Tories stood accused of marginalising women last night after admitting that in power they might scrap both the post of minister for women, and the women's unit.
fields.body:
The Tories stood accused of marginalising women last night after admitting that in power they might scrap both the post of minister for women, and the women's unit.

The shadow secretary of state for education and employment, Theresa May, cast doubt on the relevance of the post, which, at present, is held by Tessa Jowell, and, in the Lords, by Lady Jay.

"We haven't finalised the structure yet, that is for William to decide," Ms May said. "But I question what women's ministers have done."

Ms May speaks on women's issues for the Conservatives, and, with Ann Widdecombe and Angela Browning, is one of only three women in the shadow cabinet. She has also indicated that the future of the women's unit - which was set up immediately after the last election and is part of the Cabinet Office - would be in doubt if the Tories gained power.

"We don't want to ghettoise women's issues," Ms May said. "But I think in some sense what the government is doing is patronising, saying 'here's a unit that is just looking after you'."

In private, the unit has been derided by the Tories for doing "little but produce glossy magazines and hold the odd summit". In particular this criticism refers to the unit's body image summit held this July to draw attention to the media's glorification of superwaif figures, and to Voices, a magazine produced with the publication Good Housekeeping, which offered practical advice on issues such as returning to work or setting up in business.

But the 35-strong unit has achieved more than this. It has worked across government departments to ensure the needs of women are taken into account in forming policy, and produced research, such as the finding earlier this year that women earn £250,000 less in their lifetime than men.

The Conservatives' lack of enthusiasm for retaining the unit and the job of women's minister tallies with their opposition to positive discrimination, widely seen as the cause of their failure to select many women to fight the election in safe seats.

Only 66 of the Tories' chosen candidates are women, and only 24 are expected to reach parliament if the Tories win the election. At present, the Conservatives have 14 women MPs in contrast to Labour's 100.

A Labour spokeswoman said the Opposition's resistance to providing women with a "voice in government" meant female voters would desert them at the election. "Women make up 51% of the population. They deserve to be represented in government at the highest level," she said. "With so few women Tory MPs and so few women on their frontbenches, you can be sure that if the Tories were re-elected, there would be no voice for women in government."

fields.trailText: David Beckham, Patrick Vieira and Marcel Desailly are among eleven Premiership-based players named in the 50-man shortlist for the European Footballer of the Year award today.
fields.body:
David Beckham, Patrick Vieira and Marcel Desailly are among eleven Premiership-based players named in the 50-man shortlist for the European Footballer of the Year award today.

Other English based contenders for the prestigious Ballon d'Or include Fabien Barthez, Roy Keane, Ryan Giggs, Jaap Stam, Paul Scholes, Dennis Bergkamp, Thierry Henry and Sylvian Wiltord.

Although most of the big names of European football - including Andrei Shevchenko, Luis Figo, Zinidine Zidane and Alesandro Nesta - have made the shortlist, there are a few notable exceptions, including Gianluigi Buffon and Christian Vieri.

Last year Beckham was beaten into second place by Rivaldo, who polled 219 votes to Beckham's 154.

webTitle: Leader: Whatever happened to conservatism?

fields.headline: Scots out!
fields.standfirst:
Whatever happened to conservatism?

Special report: Tories in opposition
Devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Whatever happened to conservatism?
fields.body:
Once, Conservatives could generally be relied upon to be just that, conservative. If you wanted a defence, say, of flummery or anachronism you sent for a Tory; they would turn up the relevant page in Burke and the ancien regime would be saved. But Maggie Thatcher put a stop to all that. The word "constitution" rarely passed her lips but she still gave it a fair old battering. It seems her protege, William Hague, would like to follow the lady's lead.

After devolution, a period of quiet might be useful, to bed down the new arrangements and strengthen working relations between Cardiff, Edinburgh, Belfast/Dublin and London. But Mr Hague, indefatigable in his pursuit of populist points, is now saying he wants to re-weight voting in the Commons or, to put it in his usual subtle way, send the Scots packing when it comes to "our" schools and hospitals.

Now if Mr Hague genuinely cared about the representativeness of the Commons or the logic of the UK constitution he would not begin in West Lothian. He would, instead, be worrying about proportionality. Or the mystery of the monarchy and the use and abuse of "prerogative" powers by the executive. A sincere constitutional reformer, if that is what he wants to be, would put a lot more distance between his party and the Ulster unionists - who (without a note of Tory demur) vote happily on the domestic affairs of the British mainland.

No, Mr Hague is motivated only by malice. Perhaps we should welcome the honest admission that the Tories are no longer concerned about the integrity of the UK. They certainly play straight into the hands of the nationalists. All MPs representing seats in Scotland in the Westminster parliament are, in Tory eyes, merely "Scottish MPs" with no concern for the UK as a whole. So they do not belong at Westminster at all, the nationalists said yesterday. Is this what Mr Hague is aiming at?

webTitle: Hague's nationalist warning

fields.headline: Hague's nationalist warning
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: William Hague took a first step towards tapping into English nationalism yesterday by unveiling plans to strip Scottish MPs of their rights to vote on matters south of the border.
fields.body:
William Hague took a first step towards tapping into English nationalism yesterday by unveiling plans to strip Scottish MPs of their rights to vote on matters south of the border.

In a speech in Oxford, which has been widely condemned, the Tory leader promised to change House of Commons procedures to guarantee "English votes on English laws".

Mr Hague warned that there was a danger of political instability unless the "West Lothian question" was tackled.

The question was first posed by the Labour MP Tam Dalyell who warned devolution would create an anomaly in which Scottish MPs could vote on matters in England, while English MPs would have no vote on matters in Scotland.

Mr Hague said the anomaly had already arisen after Scottish Labour MSPs voted for one form of tuition fees north of the border, while voting, as Westminster MPs for a different system in England.

He said: "We saw what happened when the Scottish people felt the poll tax had been imposed on them by an English majority. Reverse the situation and add the West Lothian dimension and you have an explosive situation. Ignore English consciousness, or bottle it up, and it could turn into dangerous nationalism."

Mr Hague, who also pledged to reduce the number of Scottish MPs at Westminster, cast his speech as a constructive attempt to stem growing English nationalism since the establishment of the Scottish parliament. His remarks show the Tories believe there are votes to be had south of the border from those who think England got a raw deal over devolution.

The Tory leader also said Britain could face a constitutional crisis if Labour were beaten in England, but won a majority at Westminster on the basis of Scottish and Welsh MPs.

Mr Hague's speech was condemned last night by the Liberal Democrats as "a petty attempt to seek revenge on the voters who rejected them".

Alasdair Morgan, the SNP's Westminster group leader, described the move as "typical Tory anti-Scottishness".

webTitle: Coca-Cola to keep Universal McCann as UK media agency

fields.headline: Coca-Cola to stay with Universal McCann
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Coca-Cola is to keep Universal McCann as its UK media buying agency in a move that may end speculation over its roster of agency partners, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is to retain Universal McCann as its UK media buying agency.

This morning's announcement may signal an end to months of speculation surrounding the future of the drink giant's entire roster of agency partners, including media, creative and PR.

In June, Coke asked its three European creative agencies to pitch for a Europe-wide branding campaign for its brands, which include Coca-Cola, Dr Pepper, Fanta and Lilt.

It will be the first time in recent history that its brands' European advertising will be created locally rather than imported from the US.

Senior players at each agency are still awaiting a decision from Coke, with many beginning to doubt that the company itself knows the best way forward.

A media review was announced a few months later. Further question marks hung over its UK roster of agencies as Coke began to appoint work to non-roster companies. PR was then said to be under the microscope.

Recent US campaigns to be imported to the UK include "Coca Cola. Enjoy" and "Always Coca Cola". But senior executives at Coke have increasingly called for a more local approach and greater freedom for marketing executives to do what's right for their own markets.

BBJ's associated companies, Carat Insight and Carat Interactive, have now been appointed to handle media planning.

Charlotte Oades, Coca-Cola's UK and Ireland marketing director, said: "Universal McCann will now be working with BBJ/Carat and together they will give us an even greater depth of consumer and media insight and more innovative and creative media planning.

"Given the dramatic expansion of our media mix and the new technologies we are exploring, this configuration will serve our needs best."

Meanwhile, Coke has also retained Wieden & Kennedy to handle its diet Coke business.

Ms Oades added: "We are renewing our commitment to their London office in order to create local advertising that truly engages British adults and dramatizes the playful and flirtatious spirit of diet Coke."

webTitle: Look no further

fields.headline: Look no further
fields.standfirst: If you want to be a film star, you're reading the right paper. Or are you? Roman Polanski advertised in the Guardian for the star of his new film - and then cast a pro. Was it just a ploy to get some publicity? By  Mark Morris
fields.trailText: If you want to be a film star, you're reading the right paper. Or are you? Roman Polanski advertised in the Guardian for the star of his new film - and then cast a pro. Was it just a ploy to get some publicity? By Mark Morris
fields.body:
Maybe you were flipping through the Guardian job pages recently and saw the ad. You probably wondered whether it was a hoax. Was Roman Polanski really advertising for the star of his next film? "Acting experience is not essential." It could be you. "Sensitive, vulnerable and charismatic." It was you! Chances are you thought about it for a bit and then forgot it. But you could have been one of the thousands who actually tramped down to London's Covent Garden.

Because everyone had an equal shot, right? Polanski really wanted an outsider to play Polish composer Wladyslaw Szpilman in Pianist. Casting agent Alex Johnson explained at the time that because the story was "so close to Polanski's own experience, he has a very clear idea of what he wants. He feels there is someone out there, and not necessarily an actor, who embodies what he feels about Szpilman." But if you're still waiting for them to call you back, it is time to stop checking your messages. That someone they were looking for, it turns out, was Adrien Brody. Brody was not one of the dreamers who turned up at the Actor's Centre, but rather the star of Spike Lee's Summer Of Sam. A man with acting experience, an agent and a name.

Perhaps the Covent Garden disappointed should form a support group with people who fancied their chances of appearing in Blair Witch 2. The producers, The Hollywood Reporter announced, were looking for fresh faces, in keeping with the "is it real?" tradition of the previous film. Well, they may have looked for the untried, but what they found were a group of admittedly little known but definitely shopworn actors. Kim Director, for instance, has appeared in the last three Spike Lee movies - including Summer Of Sam, with Adrien Brody.

And the group should have no problem recruiting from the 22,000 Latinas who turned up in Miami, Chicago, San Antonio and LA in 1996 for the opening calls for Selena, the 1997 biopic of the murdered Mexican-American pop star.

Director Gregory Nava says his crew patiently looked at each and every one of them. In the end, of course, Nava chose Jennifer Lopez, whom he had worked with before - and who, the resentful howled, isn't even Mexican.

Another disgruntled bunch will be the Tank Girl hopefuls who turned up in big numbers to an open call in New York City, only to be ignored in favour of the hapless but allegedly professional Lori Petty - although they might just be grateful they weren't in the film in the end. And imagine the excitement that went around boho New York when it was announced in 1995 that Francis Ford Coppola - no less - was holding open auditions for On The Road. At least the prospective Deans and Sals never had the bitter experience of seeing, say, Johnny Depp in the movie, since it never got made at all.

Makes you wonder why they bother. That is apart from the fact that open casting calls are very cheap publicity for a film at the pre- production stage when the money is still being raised. And if you're Roman Polanski, whose last few films have hardly set the world on fire, then re-establishing yourself as someone who is talked about for something other than Sharon Tate or the rape can only be a good thing. Because when you think about it calmly, it seems unlikely that anyone would really chance several million dollars on the performance of a complete novice.

There are odd stories of the open audition working out. The wettest leading man of the 80s, Andrew McCarthy, was plucked from a crowd of hopefuls to play the boy who makes love in an elevator with Jacqueline Bisset in Class. And on a rather more august note, Akira Kurosawa found the very great Toshiro Mifune at an open audition in 1946. So it can work. And there are filmmakers who regularly use people plucked off the street: the likes of Ken Loach and John Sayles. The problem is that these directors really do want people who look and sound ordinary, not those with dreams of celluloid glory. Appearing in an ultra-realist drama is unlikely to set you up to star alongside Cameron Diaz.

Still, as all those people who turned up at the Pianist and Selena auditions reasoned to themselves, all that separates you from Jennifer Lopez or Tom Cruise is luck. And perseverance is all. You've just missed the official deadline to win a place as an extra in American Pie 2, but you never know - if you have a terminally optimistic nature, plus the requisite amount of natural beauty, and are eighteen or a couple of years older, then you can email your CV and photo to www.hypnotic.com. Alternatively, they're holding open casting for the Muhammad Ali movie out in LA, providing you've got your own period costume. You'd just be lurking in the background to start with, of course, but once Michael Mann spotted you, how could he resist, right? After all, some of us are just destined to be stars.

That is apart from the fact that open casting calls are very cheap publicity for a film at the pre- production stage when the money is still being raised. And if you're Roman Polanski, whose last few films have hardly set the world on fire, then re-establishing yourself as someone who is talked about for something other than Sharon Tate or the rape can only be a good thing. Because when you think about it calmly, it seems unlikely that anyone would really chance several million dollars on the performance of a complete novice. There are odd stories of the open audition working out. The wettest leading man of the 80s, Andrew McCarthy, was plucked from a crowd of hopefuls to play the boy who makes love in an elevator with Jacqueline Bisset in Class. And on a rather more august note, Akira Kurosawa found the very great Toshiro Mifune at an open audition in 1946. So it can work. And there are filmmakers who regularly use people plucked off the street: the likes of Ken Loach and John Sayles. The problem is that these directors really do want people who look and sound ordinary, not those with dreams of celluloid glory. Appearing in an ultra-realist drama is unlikely to set you up to star alongside Cameron Diaz. Still, as all those people who turned up at the Pianist and Selena auditions reasoned to themselves, all that separates you from Jennifer Lopez or Tom Cruise is luck. And perseverance is all. You've just missed the official deadline to win a place as an extra in American Pie 2, but you never know - if you have a terminally optimistic nature, plus the requisite amount of natural beauty, and are eighteen or a couple of years older, then you can email your CV and photo to www.hypnotic.com. Alternatively, they're holding open casting for the Muhammad Ali movie out in LA, providing you've got your own period costume. You'd just be lurking in the background to start with, of course, but once Michael Mann spotted you, how could he resist, right? After all, some of us are just destined to be stars.

webTitle: German resource: Harry und die Lesewut

fields.headline: Harry und die Lesewut
fields.standfirst: German children can't get enough of Harry Potter.  Nicole Prestle finds out what effect he is having on their reading habits
fields.trailText: German children can't get enough of Harry Potter. Nicole Prestle finds out what effect he is having on their reading habits
fields.body:
Harry Potter hat es geschafft. Hunderte von Kindern holt er weg vom Computer. Lesen ist wieder in. Lesen und über Literatur diskutieren. Als jetzt der vierte Band auf den Markt kam, öffneten viele Buchläden in Deutschland bereits um Mitternacht. Zauberpartys wurden gefeiert, Lesungen gehalten, Potter-Snacks serviert.

Kinder und Jugendliche sind die größten Fans des kleinen Zauberers. Doch auch Erwachsene schlägt er in seinen Bann. Eltern, Söhne und Töchter beim gemeinsamen Leseabend vereint. Wann hat es das zuletzt schon gegeben?

Lesen war und ist ein beliebter Zeitvertreib. 300000 Besucher und mehr als 6500 Aussteller bestritten in diesem Jahr die Frankfurter Buchmesse. Neue Bücher wurden vorgestellt. Romane auf Papier gedruckt, aber auch elektronische Bücher. Wir haben uns bei Jugendlichen nach ihrem Leseverhalten erkundigt. Ist Lesen so populär wie früher? Werden wir bald kein Buch mehr aufschlagen, sondern statt dessen den Computer anschalten und uns die Schriftstücke auf den Bildschirm laden?

Was haltet Ihr [ihr] von Harry Potter?

Nicola (12): Ich finde ihn einfach genial. Er weiß immer eine Lösung, ist witzig und sieht auch noch nett aus. Den würde ich gerne mal in Wirklichkeit kennenlernen.

Frank (15): Ich habe alle vier Bände gelesen. Jeder war so spannend wie der andere. Ich konnte die Bücher nicht mehr weglegen. Und das ist schon was, denn normalerweise lese ich nicht so gerne.

Peter (13): Ich war vor kurzem auf einer Harry-Potter-Party im Buchladen. Das war, als der neue Band veröffentlicht wurde. Ich fand es total gut, mit den anderen Fans zu reden. Wir haben uns ausgedacht, wie es weitergehen könnte.

Lest Ihr [ihr] oft? Und welche Bücher gefallen Euch [euch] am besten?

Luca (18): Ich habe früher oft gelesen. Jetzt muß [muss] ich gerade mehr für die Schule lernen. Da bleibt leider kaum Zeit.

Ariane (14): Was mir gefällt, ändert sich ständig. Früher waren es Tiergeschichten. Jetzt lese ich gerne Zukunftsromane. Das ist witzig, weil man sich vorstellen kann, was davon einmal wahr wird.

Nicola: Nun ja, Phantasiegeschichten wie die von Harry Potter mag ich am liebsten. In diesen Büchern kommen immer ganz besondere Wesen vor. Jetzt soll es ja auch einen Harry-Potter-Film geben. Ich bin neugierig, wie diese Tiere und Menschen dann im Kino aussehen.

Von vielen Büchern gibt es Leseproben im Internet. Lest Ihr [ihr] sie manchmal?

Ariane: Nein. Das ist mir zu umständlich . Lieber höre ich mich bei Freundinnen um, was sie gerade lesen. Und wenn sie ein Buch gut finden, leihe oder kaufe ich es mir. Bis ich die Internet-Seiten aufgerufen habe, das dauert mir viel zu lange.

Peter: Den neuen Harry-Potter habe ich mir über das Internet bestellt. Ich habe aber keine einzige Zeile vorher gelesen. Es hätte mich dann nur geärgert , daß [dass] ich am Ende der Leseprobe nicht gewußt [gewusst] hätte, wie es weitergeht.

Luca: Das habe ich ehrlich gesagt noch nie getan. Entweder ich will lesen oder im Internet surfen. Ich habe auch noch nie ein Buch über das Internet gekauft. In einen Laden zu gehen und dort zwischen den Regalen zu stöbern - dieses Gefühl kann das Internet nie ersetzen.

Also haben elektronische Bücher auch keine Chance?

Ariane: Das kann man so nicht sagen. Wenn ich in meiner Freizeit lese, möchte ich das nicht vor dem Computer tun. Das ist ungemütlich. Aber Fachliteratur für die Schule oder den Beruf würde ich schon am PC lesen.

Frank: Doch, haben sie schon. Wenn ich daran denke, wieviel elektronische Bücher man auf einem Laptop speichern kann. Und diese Bücher kann man überall mitnehmen. Und das, ohne viel zu schleppen .

Luca: Elektronik wird in unserem Leben eine immer größere Rolle spielen. Und wahrscheinlich macht diese Entwicklung vor dem Buch nicht halt [Halt]. Es tut mir leid [Leid], aber ich kann es nicht ändern.

Ist Lesen unpopulär geworden, weil es zu viele andere Dinge gibt, die man in seiner Freizeit tun kann?

Nicola: Kinder finden Lesen immer noch toll. Und Erwachsene auch, glaube ich. Man braucht niemanden dazu, man lernt dabei und man kann abschalten .

Peter: Natürlich gehe ich auch mal ins Kino, spiele am Computer oder schaue Fernsehen. Dann habe ich eben einfach keine Lust zum Lesen. Das liegt aber nicht daran, daß [dass] es zu viele andere Freizeit beschäftigungen gibt. Man hat eben nicht immer Bock auf das gleiche.

Luca: Wenn man an ganz früher denkt, an unsere Großeltern: die hatten auch nicht mehr Zeit als wir. Nur lag das nicht daran, daß [dass] es so viele Dinge gab, die man tun konnte. Es lag daran, daß [dass] sie so viel arbeiten mußten [mussten].

Glossar/Glossary

abschalten: to switch off (mentally and physically)

sich ärgern to be annoyed

Bock haben (coll.) to like to do sth.

genial ingenious

haltmachen [Halt machen] to stop

die Lesewut reading mania

normalerweise normally, generally

schleppen (coll.) to carry a heavy weight

umständlich tedious, ineffective

der Zauberer wizard

webTitle: Di Canio: Rio 'not ready for England'

fields.headline: Di Canio: Rio 'not ready for England'
fields.trailText: Paolo Di Canio has continued his recent string of outspoken remarks by declaring that Rio Ferdinand is not yet ready to play for England, 24 hours before Peter Taylor is set to give the West Ham youngster a central role against Italy in the friendly in Turin.
fields.body:
Paolo Di Canio has continued his recent string of outspoken remarks by declaring that Rio Ferdinand is not yet ready to play for England, 24 hours before Peter Taylor is set to give the West Ham youngster a central role against Italy in the friendly in Turin.

"Rio is a very talented young player," Di Canio told the Mirror this morning. "But if I'm going to be honest then I must say that, along with Joe Cole, I don't think they are ready for England just yet.

"It's too easy just to say they are talented and ready. They must prove themselves, match after match, for a long time, not just a few games."

Di Canio made similar remarks about Ferdinand in his eponymous autobiography claiming that the 22-year-old could be the best defender in the world, but "he needs to go to the next level. He needs to develop that hunger, that drive, that personality which great players have.

"Maybe he thinks he's good enough already, maybe he thinks he's the best English defender around. He may well be, but is that enough?"

Such controversial remarks have become the Italian's stock in trade of late, but will only add to the recent criticism of Ferdinand and his inconsistent form for the Hammers. It will also do nothing to dispel the rumours that Ferdinand is set to leave the East End for a bigger club, such as long-term suitors Leeds United.

webTitle: Energis expansion results in huge losses

fields.headline: Energis expansion results in huge losses
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Energis has more than doubled its losses after expanding its UK and European operations. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Energis, the company which forms the backbone of the UK's internet network, has more than doubled its losses after expanding its UK and European operations.

The company has sunk money into buying equipment in readiness for local loop unbundling in the UK, which will send voice and data signals down telephone lines at greater speed.

The company said first half pre-tax losses were £45.2m, a massive increase from last year's deficit of £18.2m, though group turnover soared from £202.1m to £365.3m.

Mike Grabiner, chief executive of Energis, said: "In the UK, our critical mass, our network reach, our service portfolio and our reputation for quality and service and traffic volumes, position extremely well to benefit from the changes in the market as the local loop unbundles."

Mr Grabiner added that loop unbundling, which is already underway, will expand the company's UK reach.

Energis raised £400m in a share placing last month and will use it to continue its expansion programme.

webTitle: Jeffrey Masson on the paternal devotion of penguins

fields.headline: What every father should know about penguins
fields.standfirst: As a psychoanalyst, he scandalised his profession by condemning Freud. Then his book on the emotional life of dogs had critics questioning his sanity. So what chance his latest, on the paternal devotion of penguins? Jeffrey Masson talks to  Marcia Russell
fields.trailText: As a psychoanalyst, he scandalised his profession by condemning Freud. Then his book on the emotional life of dogs had critics questioning his sanity. So what chance his latest, on the paternal devotion of penguins? Jeffrey Masson talks to Marcia Russell
fields.body:
Doctor Jeffrey Masson, enfant terrible of the psychoanalytic establishment, believes the disputes that have dogged him for the past 15 years probably won't ever go away. His response is to abandon the troubled human mind, and delve into the animal world instead.

As director of the Sigmund Freud archives, Masson denounced the father of psychoanalysis for what he claimed was a deliberate suppression of cases of incest and child abuse to support his theory of female infantile fantasy (Assault on Truth: Freud and Child Sexual Abuse), then went on to condemn psychoanalytic practice and most of its practitioners (Against Therapy: Emotional Tyranny and the Myth of Psychological Healing and Final Analysis: The Making and Unmaking of a psychoanalyst).

During all this, the onetime professor of Sanskrit famously sued the New Yorker Magazine for $10m over a savage 48,000-word article by journalist Janet Malcolm which portrayed Masson as an irredeemable womaniser and an insufferable egomaniac who wanted to turn the holy shrine of Freud's life and work at Maresfield Gardens, Hampstead, into some kind of bordello.

The case became a celebrated examination of journalistic practice, mainly about the sacredness or otherwise of direct quotes, and the trials and appeals bounced around the US courts for nearly 10 years before Masson won a ruling that he had been misquoted. But the controversy released an avalanche of words and raised issues that are still being discussed by academics and journalists. Masson himself, though, has left it all behind. As something of an antidote to all this, he has turned his attention to animals - with considerable success. "To some extent I got sick of people," he says. "You know, I'd been a psychoanalyst and I'd had a very unpleasant experience, to put it mildly, with the world of established psychoanalysis. And it really made me question that if these are the people who are supposed to be our mentors, the people who are treating people who are not mentally well, then there is something seriously wrong either with the criteria of mental health and the training or with our species. Yes... to some extent turning to animals was a result of being somewhat disillusioned."

So from being a succès de scandale in the intellectual salons of Europe and New York, Masson moved along to become a box office bestseller with When Elephants Weep: the Emotional Lives of Animals, written with Susan McCarthy, which got on the New York Times bestseller list and sold half a million copies. It was quickly followed by Dogs Never Lie About Love: Reflections on the Emotional Lives of Dogs, which was equally successful. His latest book, just published in Britain, is The Emperor's Embrace: Fatherhood in Evolution.

The title derives from the paternal devotion of the emperor penguin, an inhabitant of the bleakly hostile ice continent of Antarctica who takes guardianship of his mate's unhatched egg throughout the endless night and sub-zero temperatures of the deepest antarctic winter. The hatching rookeries are beyond the reach of all but the most intrepid. Masson, a dedicated Californian, didn't actually go to Antarctica to observe them: "Too cold, too forbidding". The embrace of these particular emperors is reserved for the times when the environment is at its most cruel. To describe how the birds protect their young in a collaborative and supportive shield would be, in a way, to reveal the narrative drive. But the story is a dramatic celebration of fatherhood and dads everywhere should be cheered by its heroism.

Masson says he wrote it because, at the age of 55, he was about to become a father for the second time. He'd read a lot of books about becoming a father the first time round and found them inadequate then. This time he wondered if things had improved. They hadn't.

It seemed like an opportunity to do something - and to do it rather differently by writing about animal fathers. "It is a topic never written about. There are a few scholarly books and articles but generally very little about what kind of fathers animals are."

What he did find on the subject seemed to endorse a generally held belief that male animals have no interest in children. He set out to test the hypothesis. "One of the questions I thought I might be able to answer, but I haven't, is whether there's a tremendous variation within a species as there is within us. We run the whole gamut from wonderful fathers to terrible fathers. I wondered if animal species do too."

What he found was that most scientists didn't even like the question. "I have to say all of my books have been badly reviewed by the scientific community. They don't like them."

Masson concedes that some of the criticism is valid. He's not a scientist. Much of what he writes is speculative and he readily admits he is "simply regurgitating what other people have said and putting another slant on it". But he insists that the questions he asks about the emotional life of animals are legitimate and deserve scientific investigation.

"I think it is hard," he says, "for some people to give up the idea that we are the pinnacle of creation. Underlying it [the criticism] is 'how dare he, or anyone, compare us humans to these mere animals'. And I think people who do painful things to some other creature do not want to be told that that creature is their superior."

When Masson wrote his second bestseller it was to "make a really strong case for a most outrageous thesis, namely that dogs feel more profoundly than we do". He believes it, even if some critics think he is insane.

To make the point he does a creditable imitation of the reception he gets when he meets his German shepherd, Sasha - now living with his ex-wife Terri and daughter, Simone, in Oakland, California - after six month's absence. The urgent crying and howling noises accompanied by ecstatic wriggling and rolling around is familiar to most dog owners. "It doesn't take a scientist to see that she's having a deeply emotional response to seeing me again," says Masson. "So for anyone to say there's nothing going on in her mind at that point is insane. We don't know exactly what, that's true. But then I don't know exactly what is going through your mind as you listen to me either."

That's true, too. What I'm thinking is that New Zealand is closer to the Antarctic and the emperor penguin than anywhere else in the world, excepting the barren wastes of Tierra del Fuego and Cape Horn. It is tempting to speculate that Masson's admiration of the giant bird has drawn him to this group of small islands in the South Pacific.

But the reasons are more emotional than scientific. He and his German-born wife, paediatrician Leila Siller and their four-year- old son, Ilan, simply fell in love with New Zealand. They went there to escape London in December - where Siller was studying tropical medicine - and a few weeks later bought a house, by telephone, at a secluded bay on the shores of Auckland's Waitemata harbour. Masson plans to build a new "eco-friendly" home with a grass roof and solar panels for heat and energy. "It's paradise," he says. And maybe it's also a haven of peace, after the embattled years.

 The Emperor's Embrace: Fatherhood in Evolution is published by Vintage Random House.

But he insists that the questions he asks about the emotional life of animals are legitimate and deserve scientific investigation. "I think it is hard," he says, "for some people to give up the idea that we are the pinnacle of creation. Underlying it [the criticism] is 'how dare he, or anyone, compare us humans to these mere animals'. And I think people who do painful things to some other creature do not want to be told that that creature is their superior." When Masson wrote his second bestseller it was to "make a really strong case for a most outrageous thesis, namely that dogs feel more profoundly than we do". He believes it, even if some critics think he is insane. To make the point he does a creditable imitation of the reception he gets when he meets his German shepherd, Sasha - now living with his ex-wife Terri and daughter, Simone, in Oakland, California - after six month's absence. The urgent crying and howling noises accompanied by ecstatic wriggling and rolling around is familiar to most dog owners. "It doesn't take a scientist to see that she's having a deeply emotional response to seeing me again," says Masson. "So for anyone to say there's nothing going on in her mind at that point is insane. We don't know exactly what, that's true. But then I don't know exactly what is going through your mind as you listen to me either." That's true, too. What I'm thinking is that New Zealand is closer to the Antarctic and the emperor penguin than anywhere else in the world, excepting the barren wastes of Tierra del Fuego and Cape Horn. It is tempting to speculate that Masson's admiration of the giant bird has drawn him to this group of small islands in the South Pacific. But the reasons are more emotional than scientific. He and his German-born wife, paediatrician Leila Siller and their four-year- old son, Ilan, simply fell in love with New Zealand. They went there to escape London in December - where Siller was studying tropical medicine - and a few weeks later bought a house, by telephone, at a secluded bay on the shores of Auckland's Waitemata harbour. Masson plans to build a new "eco-friendly" home with a grass roof and solar panels for heat and energy. "It's paradise," he says. And maybe it's also a haven of peace, after the embattled years.  The Emperor's Embrace: Fatherhood in Evolution is published by Vintage Random House.

webTitle: Jenny Colgan on addiction to checking books sales on Amazon

fields.headline: Look, I've sold one more copy!
fields.standfirst: What do authors do when inspiration runs out and Richard & Judy has finished? Visit their own book page at amazon, of course, to check on the latest sales of their works. But, warns novelist  Jenny Colgan, it can get addictive
fields.trailText: What do authors do when inspiration runs out and Richard & Judy has finished? Visit their own book page at amazon, of course, to check on the latest sales of their works. But, warns novelist Jenny Colgan , it can get addictive
fields.body:
Only 3% of British books are bought online but one thing is for sure - 100% of British authors with an internet connection keep a very close eye on it indeed.

It's not easy working at home in front of a computer. Richard & Judy only takes you up to lunchtime, and those two friends of the homeworker, Freecell and Minesweeper, will cramp your writing hand sooner or later. So, what better than to keep an eye on your children - and at the same time, those of your competitors? Checking your book page on amazon almost feels like working.

Why is it so compulsive? Well, for starters it updates your chart position every hour, on the hour. Not only that, but the "people who bought this book also bought_ xxx" section connects you to your nearest rivals for comparative purposes. Even people like my good friend Andrew Mueller, whose Rock and Hard Places rarely budges from its hotly contested position at 37,692, have to constantly take a look. Just in case in the last half hour there's been a flurry and you're outselling Harry P. It could happen - if everyone in the world died except your closest relatives.

Of course, what one would never do is order lots of copies to influence the chart position because "you can always cancel it later".

But the chart is only the first half of the story. Next stop is the comments section. Oh my God! Normally people read books and forget about them. If anyone can be bothered to pick up pen and paper to approach the author, the more green crayonish letters are filtered out by publishing staff before they reach you. But amazon has changed all that. Now it takes about 16 seconds to ruin somebody's day. Don't believe me? Look at the review page for Honeymoon by Amy Jenkins. Would you please leave that poor girl alone?

Just as there are guidelines for writing reviews, there ought to be guidelines for reading them. At a rough estimate, discount the bottom six. They will all be from an unnamed "reader from London", will grant five stars and have a short message along the lines "this is the best book ever".

If you'd just read a book so great that you had to go to a website and make public your thoughts, don't you think your emotion, love and excitement might spill over into more than just a short paragraph? These are, in fact, hastily assembled friends and family members and, occasionally for the very desperate, publishers. Think of them as greetings cards.

Also, be wary of anything over the top - literary chums Richard Mason and Jamie Holland were caught out when Mason wrote reviews comparing Jamie's book, One Thing Leads to Another, to Tchaikovsky, using hotmail pseudonyms compiled from his own characters.

One-star reviews, if well argued, are fair enough, but if they say things like "this book is trite and pointless and its author always left her washing-up in the sink", then they are probably best avoided.

There is also the double-edged review of your book with the sting in its tail: eg, "I really hated this nonsense and much preferred XXX". XXX will always be the massively successful tome of your nearest rival. (Don't forget, you can find out who this is by checking the "customers who bought this book also bought..." box). If you're really in the mood to piss off an author, this is an excellent way to do it.

Four stars is the acceptable average star level. Five is like getting a first-class degree: you're trying too hard; or you're a crazy sci-fi saga writer, your fans draw geneaology charts for your characters and have never had sex. Three can be OK if you've got a case like Adele Parks' merciless morality tale, Playing Away, where readers either think this is the best thing ever, or that it is the devil's work, best burned.

The "I am the author" button always had me hopelessly intrigued before I could legitimately press it. Being a well-behaved girl, I never did, but apparently some nutter pretended to be Phillip Pullman, the genius behind His Dark Materials, and filled a whole page with craziness. A friend of mine is constantly dithering about whether to press it for Mein Kampf or The Bible.

As a long-time amazon contributor, I stopped writing negative reviews the first time a newspaper remarked that I looked like Gail Tilsley, but the few I did do seem set to haunt the web pages for ever. Now, I only write wholehearted endorsements of things I love. Except for AA Gill books, but he is asking for it. Well, I say books in plural - nobody who has read one would dream of picking up the other.

My father was grumbling recently about not receiving a response to a letter that he sent a famous author. "Don't worry," I said. "Whatever you want to get across, amazon.co is the place to do it. And not only will the author see it, but all her peers and rivals will see it too. Probably in the next half-hour."

 The best antidote for amazon addiction I can find - which is also conveniently time consuming - is at Brains4zombies.com

webTitle: Deborah Bee   on men and presents

fields.headline: Gentlemen: read this before Christmas
fields.standfirst: Deborah Bee   on men and presents
fields.trailText: Deborah Bee on men and presents
fields.body:
Gentlemen. There are 41 shopping days left to Christmas - that's including Sundays, which, unless you live on Oxford Street, don't really count because we don't want anything from Woolworths or Halfords. Lose Sundays, and you only have 35 days.

Now, you think that's a lot don't you? You're secretly rather thrilled, in fact, that despite the reappearance of plastic reindeer on your nearest high street, Christmas is still well over a month away. Which means you don't have to think about it yet.

Wrong. Why not break the habits of a lifetime? While you're at it, why not break the habits of the brotherhood of man? Stop being so entirely crap and get your partner/spouse/girlfriend a decent Christmas present for a change.

You think I'm making a sweeping generalisation, don't you? That you can't judge all men by the mistakes of a few. Wrong again. Even among the random selection of friends that happened to be on the end of a phone at 4.30pm yesterday, I can deliver an impressive list of totally undesirable gifts.

Last year, Bun got two (really horrible) fleeces from a farming supplies shop; Jane, a concrete mixer complete with red satin bow ("he thought it would be useful"); Stef, a bunch of flowers from a petrol station (she dumped him); Ciara, a ceiling mobile that had previously belonged to her boyfriend and was stuck to the ceiling of the flat that they shared; Elaine received earrings (when she doesn't have pierced ears); Jacqui, a boxed set of Van Morrison CDs (I would definitely have left him for that); and my personal best was membership of the AA.

As Lisa put it: "I don't need the Christians' festive reminder to 'put Christ back into Christmas'. Each year when I open the present from my boyfriend - it's right there on the tip of my tongue - 'Gardening gloves? Christ!' "

But all of this doesn't apply to you, right? You're a shrewd shopper who has developed a keen intuition for what your partner would really like for Christmas. The deep-fat fryer/cashmere lookalike sweater/black-and-red peephole bra that she got last year was just what she wanted. She said so.

The trouble with women though, is that they probably wouldn't tell you even if they didn't like it. In the first flush of a new relationship she'll want to protect your feelings. In the second or third flush of an old relationship she'll be saving up her post-Christmas-gift-anticlimax to use in a row at a later date. Around about July time, you'll be midway through an argument when she'll say: "No I haven't lost the car keys again. And another thing. Your Christmas present was shit."

You can avoid all this, once you've admitted to yourself that you have no clue how a woman's mind works when it comes to presents. You may have a perfectly legitimate reason for choosing a particular gift, but women may not see things in the same way. You buy her a fabulous candle, a superfast car, some silk underwear, or a Magimix juice extractor - what more could she possibly want? But for women, these gifts fall into four revealing categories which are:

1. The impersonal gift - any number of meaningless objects whose proximity to the front doors of many department stores means they smack of indifference. A candle isn't a present, it's the means by which you'll find the bottle opener during next winter's power cut. Related gifts: potpourri, miniature soaps, wooden carvings, silk scarves, perfume.

2. The vicarious gift. The 25-piece DIY set you've had on your wish list for years isn't really for her is it? Nor is the sports car. Nor is the boxed set of Men Behaving Badly videos or the weekend away in the Black Forest at a classic car show.

3. The innuendo gift. Here's the trickiest one for men to get their heads around. If you buy your partner sexy underwear, she'll decide that you think she's a slut or that you wished that she was a slut. Buy her a dress that's too big and she'll decide you think she's fatter than she is or that you wish she was. Choose diamond earrings and she'll be certain you think she's either flash trash or a gold digger. Clothes, jewellery, underwear - don't touch it.

4. The housewifey gift. Anything for the kitchen is just plain naff. Women don't want what they need, they want what they don't need. A set of 16 kitchen knives may well be used against you at a later date. Also see bathroom accessories, cookery books, shoe trees and clothes dryers.

So how is a bloke supposed to get his partner a present that she really, really wants? Unless you can persuade her to drop Father Christmas a line, the answer to your Christmas present dilemma lies with your partner's best mate. Give her a call, set aside an afternoon and have a wee shop. Don't leave it until the last minute and make sure that you give her plenty of time to have a conversation with your partner first.

In the meantime, ladies - start dreaming up your list.

webTitle: Retailers on riot alert after launch of text message ad service

fields.headline: Retailers on riot alert after launch of text message ad service
fields.standfirst: Nov 8: Lakeside hosts text message ads trial
fields.trailText:
10am: Retailers at an Essex shopping centre are on riot alert after mini-stampedes caused by the popularity of a new text message promotions service, writes Amy Vickers.
Nov 8: Lakeside hosts text message ads trial
fields.body:
Retailers at Essex shopping centre Lakeside have been put on riot alert after the unprecedented popularity of a new text message promotions service called ZagMe.

"It's a lot of fun," said Bill Green, chief executive officer of ZagMe, who said users had been racing around Lakeside to make the most of the free promotions.

The service, which went on trial at the shopping centre last weekend, allowed retailers to message consumers via mobile phones as soon as they arrived in the shopping centre.

According to Mr Green, there were mini-stampedes after one store offered free gifts to anyone who arrived in the shop within half-an-hour.

"I'm blown away by the response. It's way ahead of our expectations. People love it and retailers are enjoying it as they've already seen it's a powerful mechanism to channel people into stores with simple loss-leaders," he added.

Mr Green said that one promotion involving a text message offering free CDs to the first 10 people to make it to the ZagMe stand created something of a riot.

He said ZagMe was signing up 500 users a day and after just four days already had more than 2,000 people using the service.

"We haven't even had the viral effect kick in yet. Once people start telling friends, we expect to take off exponentially."

webTitle: Figleaves raises £3.6m to fund further expansion

fields.headline: Figleaves raises £3.6m for further expansion
fields.trailText: 10.15am:Online underwear retailer Figleaves has raised £3.6m to fund further expansion and take the company into Europe. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Online underwear retailer Figleaves has raised £3.6m to fund further expansion and take the company into Europe.

Hiding up Figleaves' sleeve is a new product called Global Bra Sizing, which it claims will revolutionise the global bra industry.

The Global Bra Sizing product allows customers to self-measure and then to be offered a selection of the best-fitting products, either online, by mail order or through selected retail outlets.

Figleaves chief executive officer Mike Ross said the company was already in talks to licence its GBS product to major bra manufacturers and retailers.

He said: "We are entering an exciting period of expansion. Prospects for our home retailing business are strong and our new Global Bra Sizing product tackles a real need in the market," said Mr Ross.

"Much of the raised capital will be used to create a number of multilingual, multi-currency websites."

Mr Ross refused to say who the fresh funding came from, other than it was led by venture capital firm Lynch Talbot.

Figleaves grew out of Easyshop.co.uk, which rebranded in May this year to distance itself from Stelios Haji-Ioannou's Easy empire.

webTitle: Vodafone reports strong increases in profitability

fields.headline: Vodafone rings up strong rise in profitability
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Vodafone brought much-needed relief to the stock market this morning with impressive half-year results, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Vodafone brought some much-needed relief to the stock market this morning with half-year results at the top end of analysts' expectations.

The world's largest mobile phone company said pre-tax profits for the first half of the year were £2.3bn, against £1.9bn for the same period last year.

The company racked up £10.2bn in revenues, up 32% on last year's £7.7bn.

Customer numbers increased by 1.4m in the UK to 10.2m, and by 31% in continental Europe to 37.4m.

Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone, said: "These figures clearly demonstrate that, even with the better-than-expected growth in customer numbers, the group continues to report strong increases in profitability in all its operating regions."

But the City will be concerned by the pressure on Vodafone's margins, caused by the cost of acquiring customers in a saturated mobile phone market.

Vodafone's German operations were the hit hard, with margins tumbling from 45% to 30%, and from 33% to 30% in the UK.

Nonetheless, the market reacted positively to the results, maintaining the company's role as a bellwether for technology stocks. The shares rose 6%, or 14.5p, to 252.75p.

Vodafone has avoided the fate of many European telecoms companies by keeping its debts down, following its £11bn outlay on European mobile phone licences.

Today's figures exclude the £27bn sale of its Orange mobile phone subsidiary to France Telecom in May, which was triggered by the need to pay for licences in the UK, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain.

webTitle: MPs warn post offices rescue plan is threatened

fields.headline: MPs warn post offices rescue plan is threatened
fields.standfirst: Plans for post office-based cash machines in 'serious danger'
fields.trailText: Ministers may be unable to prevent a rising rate of post office closures, threatening banking plans for socially excluded, MPs warn.
fields.byline: By Patrick Wintour, chief political correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
Ministers may be unable to prevent a rising rate of post office closures unless they review plans to give them a new role, MPs warn today.

In a report on the future of the post office network the trade and industry select committee cast doubt over the cornerstone of the government's plans to give the post offices new income, because of hostility from high street banks and unrealistic costings.

The government has tried to defuse a politically explosive collapse in the network of 18,000 post offices by negotiating new markets for them, including proposals that they become a universal bank for the socially excluded.

The government has proposed that banks be obliged to make their basic accounts accessible through post offices and pay for the privilege. The system would also ensure that social security benefit payments could still be paid in cash through post offices.

But confidential information given to the select committee by the post office has led the MPs to warn that the banks "will be unwilling to pay for the service unless the post office comes up with a cheaper and fairer system".

The committee concluded: "There remains a substantial gap between the post office's aspirations to provide financial services and its ability to do so at present."

The MPs point out that retail banks do not want a large number of their customers to switch to a new post office bank, nor will they want the rate of take-up of basic accounts to swamp their systems with non-profitable business.

Each "socially excluded" account would need an average daily balance of £1,300 to cover the annual costs of the system. As a result, the £150m widely quoted cost of the universal bank is seen as on "the low side" by the select committee. webTitle: Act of chivalry that killed Briton

fields.headline: Act of chivalry that killed Briton
fields.standfirst: More about the tunnel tragedy
fields.trailText:
Kevin Challis, a ski instructor who had lived and
worked in Austria for a decade, died in the
Kitzsteinhorn tunnel after giving up his place on
an earlier train that carried his daughter Siobhan
to the summit.
fields.body:
Kevin Challis, a ski instructor who had lived and worked in Austria for a decade, died in the Kitzsteinhorn tunnel after giving up his place on an earlier train that carried his daughter Siobhan to the summit.

Mr Challis, 40, who came from Bridport in Dorset, gave up his seat next to his eight-year-old daughter to an elderly man, saying he would wait for the next one. He is understood to have escaped from the blazing train through a window but was overcome by the poisonous fumes that filled the 11/2 mile tunnel.

"Apparently he let an old person go in front of him into the train where Siobhan was, and he was behind, the last one who didn't go on," said Mr Challis's Austrian wife Christl, 39, also a ski instructor.

"She [Siobhan] was at the top. She saw the steam coming out and was worried that something was wrong. She was worried that she left her dad alone.

"He was out of the train and ran up the slope to get away from it.

"If anybody could have escaped it would have been him. He was very fit. I'm sure he did not mess around. He would have got out and tried to get away."

Mr Challis moved to Europe in the early 1990s after catching the skiing bug. He worked in France for a year before moving to Austria where he met Christl.

"He found true contentment and love," said his father, Roy Challis, from the family home in Bridport. "Kevin and Christl would be ski instructors in the winter, and he would do all sorts of odd jobs in the summer to make ends meet."

Mr Challis said he learned of his son's death on Saturday when his eldest son, John - a partner in the family building firm - phoned him after seeing news footage of the disaster.

"At first I thought it wouldn't affect Kevin. The news was mentioning Kitzsteinhorn, and I knew Kevin was working at Kaprun," Roy said.

"But then Christl phoned us and said he had been on the train. He really was a shooting star who burned very brightly. Tragically, it was for a short period of time."
