webTitle: Top woman advertising exec blames laddish culture

fields.headline: How to get ahead in advertising - be a man
fields.standfirst: Advertising branded sexist, ageist and laddish
fields.trailText: 8am: A top woman advertising executive claims that the industry will always be hell for women, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
One of the three women who have made it to the top in advertising claims that the industry will always be hell for mothers.

"Men like to have it all," said Christine Walker of Walker Media. "In the final analysis women will not get away from the issue of juggling career and children.

"It's tough as hell and you have to be prepared to work bloody long hours. I've succeeded because I am totally insensitive. It never occurs to me that I can't achieve something. I am deeply ambitious.

"I can see why women may not want to work in media agencies - media owners are dominated by men. There is a very laddish culture where people are expected to work hard and play hard."

Success, said Ms Walker, can be measured by women's level of commitment to the business.

"In order to be successful you have to network. You have to be out every night and for most women the priorities lie elsewhere."

But women interviewed by the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising believe that a glass ceiling still exists, no matter how hard you work.

"I find it depressing beyond belief that whether we like it or not, the glassy bit is still there," one female executive told the surveyors.

webTitle: Advertising branded sexist, ageist and laddish

fields.headline: Advertising branded sexist, ageist and laddish
fields.standfirst: How to get ahead in advertising - be a man
fields.trailText: 8am: Women are "under-represented in the extreme" in advertising, claims a report which brands the industry as sexist, ageist and overly laddish. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Women are "under-represented in the extreme" in advertising, claims a report which brands the industry as sexist, ageist and overly laddish.

According to the damning report, which is published later this month, the industry is failing to attract enough high-calibre women and runs the risk of losing what female talent it has.

Findings from the latest Women in Advertising study from the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising will reveal that while women make up half of the number of employees in advertising, only 9% make it into senior management.

Only three women out of thousands have made it to the very top.

Christine Walker of Walker Media, MT Rainey of Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R and Amanda Walsh of Walsh Trott Chick Smith are the only women who have their names above the door of a top 50 advertising or media agency.

The IPA survey found that attitudes towards women in the sector have improved little over the past 10 years.

Four in 10 women say they felt they were discriminated against with 18% of those citing lack of family-friendly employee policies.

A common complaint was offensive language - being referred to as a girl or being subjected to comments about dress.

Women also complained that men made assumptions about them having children and that they were often not invited to agency outings because they involved sport.

"If we lived in the States, there'd be lawsuits all over the place. Men wouldn't be allowed to get away with their comments there," said one female media planner.

Creative departments remain the last bastion of male domination. Women account for just 17% of the industry's copywriters while only 14% of art directors are female - an all-time low.

The number of women creatives is minuscule despite the fact that women make up more than half of the students doing the courses that feed creative departments.

While the IPA hopes its findings will provide a wake-up call to the industry, senior male management were dismissive of its findings.

"This is just the way it is," said a partner at one leading media agency. "I'm not a believer in tokenism. Women in middle management roles do meet rich men and jack in their jobs. I don't think you'll find that many men are prepared to do that - it doesn't mean women have less opportunities."

This view was supported by the survey, which showed that 44% of women and only 10% of men said they were concerned about the low proportion of women in senior management positions.

The report also warned of advertising's inability to rely on its sexy image to attract talent as dot.com and broadcasting companies challenge for the best people.

Findings were based on research with 500 people across 30 advertising agencies throughout the UK.

webTitle: £500m drugs fund to tackle killer diseases

fields.headline: £500m drugs fund to tackle killer diseases
fields.standfirst: Funds to meet cost of new drugs, cancer and heart treatment
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will today announce a £500m increase in NHS spending over the coming year to tackle cancer and coronary heart disease, the biggest killers.
fields.byline: By John Carvel, social affairs editor, The Guardian
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will today announce a £500m increase in NHS spending over the coming year to tackle cancer and coronary heart disease, the biggest killers.

Allocations for health authorities and NHS trusts in England for 2001-02 will unlock funds to buy new drugs that are expected be approved shortly by the national institute for clinical excellence.

Mr Milburn is expected to say that expansion of cancer and heart treatment will take almost a quarter of the growth in NHS spending next year.

The extra money will be accompanied by the acceleration of targets to reduce waiting times between GP referral and treatment to a maximum of a month. NHS managers will be told to reach this standard next year for all cases of children's cancer, testicular cancer and leukemia.

Today's announcement is not intended to pre-empt decisions on the effectiveness of 13 new cancer drugs. Chemotherapy drugs being investigated by Nice include Irinotecan for colorectal cancer, Paclitaxel (lung), Gemcitabine (pancreatic) and Popotecan (ovarian).

The government is allocating £255m extra for cancer treatment, of which £170m will be reserved for drugs.

There will be £150m more for tackling coronary heart disease, including £50m for statins, betablockers and other drugs for patients recovering from heart attacks. By 2002, 80-90% of discharged heart patients should be taking these drugs.

Other allocations will include £32.5m to reduce smoking. The £500m package does not include capital investment in equipment and buildings, announced previously.

"This is a big increase in resources and we must now see it accompanied by a big improvement for patients," a Department of Health source said.

The allocations will for the first time give health authorities an indication of their budgets over three years instead of just one. They will include £120m targeted at areas with above average premature deaths.

webTitle: NHS waiting times 'progress' disputed

fields.headline: NHS waiting times 'progress' disputed
fields.standfirst: Average wait for inpatient treatment rises
fields.trailText: The government's claim to be making progress in reducing waiting times was disputed last night by an independent healthcare company which claimed the wait for NHS inpatient treatment had increased.
fields.byline: By John Carvel, social affairs editor, The Guardian
fields.body:
The government's claim to be making progress in reducing waiting times was disputed last night by Health Care Navigator, an independent healthcare company.

It said the average wait for NHS inpatient treatment after referral by a GP increased from 201.2 days in June to 203.8 days in September.

Roger Hymas, its chairman, said: "It is surprising to see that waiting times have increased since June, as the summer is a period in which one would have expected to see some catching up."

Government figures last week showed the number of people waiting for NHS treatment fell by 5,800 to 1,031,800 over the same period. But analysis showed the average wait was lengthening in all regions except London and in all specialities bar general surgery and gynaecology.

Later, a spokesman for Mr Milburn added that across July, August and September patients waiting for longer than 13 weeks for an outpatient appointment fell by 8,700. In-patient waiting times also fell, and the total waiting for an operation was down more than 126,000 since March 1997, the spokesman added.

webTitle: Girl 'stretched' in £12,000 operation

fields.headline: Girl 'stretched' in £12,000 operation
fields.standfirst: Operation carried out to give teenager 'normal life'
fields.trailText: The surgeon who helped to "stretch" a teenager who was too short to achieve her ambition of becoming an air hostess has defended the £12,000 NHS surgery.
fields.body:
The surgeon who helped to "stretch" a teenager who was too short to achieve her ambition of becoming an air hostess has defended the £12,000 NHS surgery.

Emma Richards, 16, of Wadebridge, Cornwall, is back in hospital for the fourth time after an operation in January which has lengthened her legs by 5in so far. Before surgery she measured just 4ft 9in.

But yesterday the consultant orthopaedic surgeon, Darren Fern, of the Royal Cornwall hospital, Treliske, Truro, said the operation had not been done for cosmetic or career reasons but so that Emma could live a normal life.

"Emma was not just a little bit short, she was very short," he said. "When she first came to see me I thought she was a nine-year-old. She is entering adulthood but everybody thinks she is a child.

"She wasn't sure if she would be able to drive a car because she couldn't see over the dashboard. She couldn't turn on a tap, she couldn't reach things in the kitchen."

Around 150 children have undergone the surgery, although Emma is the tallest person he has operated on. "Each case is taken on its individual merits," he said. "Somebody else who is 4ft 9in may be fine, but Emma was not fine about being that height."

The operation would have cost around £4,000, with each day in hospital costing around £180, without complications.

Both Emma's femurs were broken in the six-hour operation and pins used to attach the bones to a metal frame. This was screwed increasingly tightly to stretch her legs, which grew about 1mm a day.

But Emma's left leg broke within two hours of her discharge. She is now in hospital with her third fracture.

Her mother, Irene, said: "We would have tried to do the operation privately if the NHS had not been able to do it."

webTitle: Foetus store triggers new row at Alder Hey hospital

fields.headline: Foetus store triggers new row at Alder Hey hospital
fields.standfirst: Collection linked to controversial pathologist
fields.trailText: Four hundred foetuses which were miscarried, stillborn or aborted have been discovered stored without their parents' consent at Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool, it has emerged.
fields.body:
Four hundred foetuses which were miscarried, stillborn or aborted have been discovered stored without their parents' consent at Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool, it has emerged..

All but 80 of the foetuses originated from two maternity hospitals in the city, which merged five years ago to form the Liverpool women's hospital. The others are from other hospitals around the north west.

The foetuses, which range in development from early pregnancy to almost full term, were sent to Alder Hey for post mortem examinations between 1988 and 1995, because it provided a pathology service.

Alder Hey hospital is already the subject of an independent inquiry into the issue of the organ retention of 893 babies and children. It was ordered by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, last year. Ministers received a copy last week of the inquiry report from Michael Redfern QC.

Dick van Velzen, the pathologist at the centre of the organ retention scandal, is believed to have been responsible for storing the foetuses. The families were not told that they had been retained.

Ian Cohen, a solicitor representing many of the families affected by organ retention, said they had been making discreet inquiries about the foetuses over the past four weeks.

"It now transpires that there is in fact a collection and, more worryingly, it seems to be directly connected to the period when Professor van Velzen was in charge of postmortems at Alder Hey," he said.

His colleague, Raymond Goodman, said: "We have for some time been requesting full information as to exactly what has gone on in relation to these foetuses, upon what authority they have been retained and what research has been carried out."

But the NHS executive in the north west accused Pity II, the parents' support group, of another attempt to put the boot into Alder Hey.

"There is nothing new or newsworthy about this story," said its spokesman, Hugh Lamont. "It has been looked at by the inquiry - it is not a secret."

He said the revelation formed part of the terms of reference of Alder Hey's special incident project board, set up this year, which includes members of Pity II. It was discussed at a meeting in July.

Kate Jackson, the project director of Alder Hey's serious incident team, said the hospital was aware that a number of foetuses had been retained. "We do not contact families proactively," she said. "Many families will not want to be reminded. We do rely on parents to contact the hospital."

She said any families who had been affected would be offered the same support and counselling as other families whose children's organs were retained following their death at Alder Hey.

webTitle: Peers challenge ministers to insist on gay law

fields.headline: Peers challenge ministers to insist on gay law
fields.standfirst: Ministers will invoke Parliament act to override Lords
fields.trailText: Ministers insisted they would force through measures to lower the age of consent for gay sex to 16 despite it being thrown out by peers for the third time.
fields.byline: By Sarah Hall, political correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
Ministers insisted they would force through measures to lower the age of consent for gay sex to 16 despite it being thrown out by peers for the third time.

The government plans to invoke the rarely used Parliament Act - which allows it to override the Lords if it defeats a bill - if peers do not back down before the end of this month.

While there is still time for the Lords' amendment to be overturned in the Commons and then returned to peers, the government privately anticipates the act being invoked for only the third time in a decade. It would also mean the bill would have to be rubber stamped by the new Speaker Michael Martin, one of just six Labour MPs who opposed the lowering of the age of consent.

The move follows the government's defeat last night by 205 to 144 over plans to reduce the age of consent for homosexuals from 18 to 16. A second defeat by 139 to 124 followed as peers voted to extend the number of categories of people who could be prosecuted for abusing positions of trust.

Lady Young, the Tory peer who has crusaded against the change, successfully put forward an amendment which would keep the age of consent for anal sex for both boys and girls at 18 but allow any other homosexual acts to be committed at 16.

She said it would also prevent buggery of girls at 16 being legalised for the first time. "Our concern is to protect children," she said. "Sixteen-year-olds are children in law. By keeping the age of buggery at 18, we protect young 16-year-olds from the most dangerous of sexual practices."

The Liberal Democrat peer, Lord Russell, said students and young people favoured a change in the law, and older people opposed it. He told peers: "I believe this issue has done more damage to the reputation of this house in those quarters in which I move than anything else since Irish home rule (in 1911)." The debate also revealed divisions among clerics, with the Bishop of Birm ingham supporting the bill, and the Bishop of Chelmsford opposing it.

Lord Alli, the Labour millionaire and gay peer, likened Lady Young to a concerned grandparent who should leave a younger generation to "live our own lives.

"We are not asking for you to approve of homosexuality or homosexual acts. I am not even asking for you to understand why they happen," he said. "What I am asking you to do is to remove the penalty and weight of the law from those young men aged 16 and 17 who consent to have sex with other men. Surely there can be nobody, except those on the very extreme of this debate, who believe that we should criminalise 16 and 17 year olds for having sex by consent."

The cabinet office minister Lord Falconer, for the government, argued that the issue was one of equality, adding "far from providing the protection that the baroness claims that they (the amendments) will, the view of many people involved in that process appears to say they would have the reverse effect".

fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN

THE GUARDIAN

Were he not dead, Inspector Morse would have demanded an explanation as to why Australian viewers got to see the final episode of Inspector Morse before viewers in the UK. P7
Jack Straw is setting up a cybercop crime force to tackle internet crime. P9
Prosecutors have raided World Online's Rotterdam offices after allegations of insider trading. P26
Future Network shares tumbled after a profits warning yesterday. P29
Oftel yesterday ordered BT to change the way it bills operators for using its network. P29
Emap has cut its spending for web-based services from £250m to £120m over the next three years. P29

THE INDEPENDENT

World Online's headquarters were raided yesterday in connection with allegations of insider trading. P18
Future Network saw its shares almost half after a profit warning. P18
Oftel has warned that limits must be imposed on unmetered traffic to ensure that BT's network doesn't collapse. P19
Emap has cut its online investment by half, to about £120m. p19
Emap shares should be left on the shelf. P21

Reprint of a speech by Mark Thompson, BBC director of television, to the Royal Television Society. "If you thought moving the news was radical, you ain't seen nothing yet," he says. P8
Could Piers Morgan be the first editor to be brought down by new technology? How Piers is discovering there is no such thing as deleted email. P8
Robert Fisk looks at biased reporting from war-torn countries. P9

Channel 4 may turn to the City to raise future funding, according to chief executive Michael Jackson in an interview with the FT. Privatisation would be a bad idea but we may want to raise some money beyond our budget, said Jackson, citing BBC Worldwide's deal with Flextech. P4
Emap slashes new media investment plans by half. P25
TV producer and labour peer Waheed Alli is expected to announce he is leaving Carlton Communications today, as new chief executive Gerry Murphy announces plans to restructure the TV business into two broad divisions: production and broadcasting. P25
Freeserve shares drop to new low of 132p, driven by widespread falls on Nasdaq. P26
Future Network shares tumbled as it warned of a profits shortfall yesterday. P26
Financial magazine publisher Incisive Media is to raise £40m in an IPO. P26
Internet investor Durlacher has received a £30m cash injection from three institutions. P26
Prosecutors raid World Online's offices in Rotterdam after allegations of insider trading. P32

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

Oftel has told BT to extend its Friaco service from February. P26
Emap has posted flat pre-tax profits but is on track to meet expectations. P30

Unmetered access moved a step closer yesterday after BT was ordered to change its pricing structure. P5
Mariella Frostrup has caused Panorama to lose 1m viewers. P12
New evidence about Piers Morgan's share dealing scandal is to be sent to the Press Complaints Commission. P15
Emap retreats as dot.com revenues drop. P35

Piers Morgan's future is in doubt again after the DTI widened its investigation into the share tipping scandal. P2
The BBC has asked the commercial TV regulator to back out of its deal with ITV to bring back News at Ten. P2
The Teletubbies have arrived in Russia and will be shown nationwide on RTR. P20
World Online's headquarters were raided yesterday by Dutch police. P27
Emap cuts back on web spending. P28
New Oftel ruling boosts free internet access. P32
Warning wipes £300m off value of Future Network. P32

It's Mariella Flop-strup. Sunday's Panorama pulled in its second lowest audience since it moved from Monday night five weeks ago. P6
Coronation Street's Curly weds his girlie in special festive episode. It's a tear-jerker, says the Sun. P15
TV joker Keith Chegwin has secretly tied the knot with his long-term girlfriend, 34-year-old Maria Felden. P23.
Countdown to the end of Inspector Morse. Exclusive interview with Kevin Whately. P28/29

THE MIRROR

The stars of Budweiser's 'Whassup' ads have landed their own TV show, playing similar characters in a US sitcom. P8
Corrie's Curly was filmed marrying his lover yesterday for the dramatic Christmas Eve episode. P17

The Mail blows yesterday's Oftel announcement about improvements to BT's Friaco service out of all proportion, and spins it into a larger than life front page story. It's a "massive boost to the internet revolution" says the Mail. P1
The kiss from Sergeant Lewis that says case closed and end of the show for Inspector Morse. P17
Anne Diamond poses in her 'party gems' to show she's not bothered about being overweight. P21
Annabel Heseltine and Mariella Frostrup are interviewed about relationships. P28
Frostrup's Panorama is failing to grab viewer's imagination. P38
Mirror editor faces fresh share probe. Anil Bhoyrul wants to case reopened. P63

Cybercops are to fight internet crime. P10
Panorama is proving a ratings flop for the BBC. P11
How the stars of children's TV have finally come of age. P20
Curly gets hitched. P23
Millions to get 24-hour internet deal for £10 per month. P23
Future Network loses half of its value. P60

Corrie's Curly get a surprise at his wedding as his daughter turns up. P7
Funnyman Frank Skinner causes a hoot by impersonating Anne Robinson. P15

Spare a thought for Matt Peacock, director of corporate communications at AOL who was today the most quoted man in the press. Problem was that Associated's Metro somehow managed to get his name wrong, calling him Adam of all things.

webTitle: Psychiatric patients feel unsafe on wards

fields.headline: Psychiatric patients feel unsafe on wards
fields.standfirst: Melba Wilson, policy director of the mental health charity Mind, challenges mental health staff to respond to service users who say they are unsafe and unheard
fields.trailText: Melba Wilson, policy director of the mental health charity Mind, challenges mental health staff to respond to service users who say they are unsafe and unheard
fields.body:
The government has said that policy and practice development should revolve around the needs of patients and services users. There is no greater need for this than in mental health services.

But a new Mind survey on patients' views of conditions in psychiatric wards, titled Environmentally Friendly?, highlights patients' dissatisfaction with their treatment.

The national service framework for mental health emphasises meeting people's needs with safe, sound and supportive services. It promotes ten core principles focusing on service users including:

 Principle 3, which calls for services that respond to the needs of different groups and individuals and challenges discrimination on the grounds of age, gender, ethnicity, religion, disability and sexuality. It encourages NHS staff to treat patients as individuals and with dignity.

 Principle 8, which states that the health and social care system must be shaped around the needs of patients or service users - not the other way around. It calls for the health service to develop partnerships and co-operation at all levels of care. That means developing partnerships between patients, their carers and families and NHS staff; between the health and social care sectors; between government departments; between the public sector and between voluntary organisations and private providers.

The NHS plan shows that the government is committed to enhance patient care. For those who deliver the services, the challenge is translating this policy into real improvements in care and treatment.

Environmentally Friendly? does not leave out the positive experiences of mental health service users, and these cases are worth noting, given the stretch of most hard-pressed and dedicated staff in meeting a growing need.

However, for many mental health service users, the government's rhetoric is a long way from the reality. The report highlights an unacceptable incidence of non-therapeutic environments in psychiatric wards. Service users report feeling unsafe, unheard and unaffected by the plethora of well intended legislation.

Mind welcomes the government's emphasis on outcome-focused change, for example, its guidance recently issued to health authorities and trusts on Cleanliness in Hospitals (NHSE, July 2000).

But if user services are to improve, mental health staff need to make changes in the way they monitor and report interaction with their clients. Clinical governance development plans, which are meant to reflect improvement, should make a stronger impact in the services. And it is crucial that patients spell out their requirements for quality services.

For providers, it is a challenge, but one which is well worth the engagement, because - as many mental health service users will tell you - the stakes are high.

webTitle: Leader: Free speech v privacy

fields.headline: Free speech v privacy
fields.standfirst:
Protecting the public - and young killers

MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Protecting the public - and young killers
fields.body:
Four newspaper groups have joined forces in the high court this week to resist a further infringement of free speech. The Guardian declined to join them. We yield to no one in our commitment to campaign for a more open society. Few newspapers in democratic countries face the extended legal tentacles that curb British media - the laws of contempt, official secrets and confidentiality. But even a free press has its limits, as that great defender of free speech, Oliver Wendell Holmes, noted in 1919: no one has the right falsely to cry fire in a crowded theatre. And that is precisely why we are resisting this week's moves.

The tabloid press is eager to protect their right to follow every step of the two young men who, as deeply troubled 10-year-olds, killed toddler James Bulger eight years ago. They are due to be released next year. The tabloids, alas, have a notorious history of whipping up false fears and unnecessary alarms by their hysterical coverage of crime.

At the moment the British press has been restrained by an injunction, imposed when the juveniles were convicted, from disclosing details about their development. But now they are adults. Mary Bell, who killed two toddlers at the age of 11, did get protection on her release as a 23-year-old. But this was to protect her daughter, not herself.

There are three arguments for extending the ban on reporting. Protecting the public - there will be little hope of rehabilitation if the two young men are hounded day by day by the tabloids. Second, protecting the young men - and equally seriously their lookalikes - from revenge attacks. The reason a criminal justice system was introduced was to end lynch law. And third, their right to privacy, as enshrined in the new Human Rights Act.

Tabloid lawyers yesterday pointed to the danger of a dangerous precedent being set: "If juveniles who commit serious crimes and are not released till they are adults are given anonymity, why shouldn't everyone have it?" That can be easily answered. It's because they were only 10 when they committed the crime - an age they would not have even been prosecuted in many European countries - that they should have protection.

The tabloids showed in 1998 what little restraint they are prepared to exercise when they broke the injunction protecting Mary Bell's 14-year-old daughter. Protection must not just be extended, but draconian sanctions set for any breach.

webTitle: Guinness to return to TV screens with four new ads

fields.headline: Guinness to return to TV screens with four new ads
fields.trailText: 8am Guinness is returning to TV this month with four new ads telling punters to 'live life to the power of Guinness', writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Guinness is making its return to TV this month with four new commercials telling punters to "live life to the power of Guinness".

The latest campaign, from HHCL & Partners, is a million miles from the surfers film that secured the honour of "best TV ad of all time" earlier this year with its "Good things come to those who wait" tagline.

'Laughter', one of the new ads, opens on a run-down council estate in Ireland. As the camera pans around to reveal the poverty stricken area, viewers see two friends sitting on a wall laughing hysterically.

Another three 40-second spots will break in Ireland shortly and will be backed by cinema advertising later in the year.

They will feature a couple fighting in the rain, fire-eaters and a man roaring at the sea. The total £7m campaign also includes outdoor advertising which works around the same theme.

Steve Henry, founding partner and creative director at HHCL and Partners, confirmed that the ads may run in the UK at a later date.

The campaign was shot in Dublin and directed by Ringin Ledwidge, one of the world's hottest young directors, whose show-reel includes Adidas, VW and Nike.

Steve Langan, marketing director of Guinness, said: "'Laughter' celebrates living life to the full, living life to the power of Guinness.

"By featuring a young couple laughing hysterically, the advertisement illustrates just how central Guinness is to bringing people together to have a great time. All the ads focus on the release of different emotions which drinking Guinness evokes."

webTitle: Cook calls for more positive reporting of Europe

fields.headline: Cook calls for more positive reporting of Europe
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, yesterday singled out the Guardian for failing to report the positive case for Europe and succumbing to "the ideological Euroscepticism" of newspapers such as the Daily Mail.
fields.body:
Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, yesterday singled out the Guardian for failing to report the positive case for Europe and succumbing to "the ideological Euroscepticism" of newspapers such as the Daily Mail.

Mr Cook, who insisted that only the Financial Times had "a consistently objective narrative" about Europe, took task with the Guardian for its report on an "important" speech by Romano Prodi, president of the European Commission, to the CBI national conference last week.

The foreign secretary said Mr Prodi had "exploded the myth of the European superstate and stressed the primacy of national identities in Europe. He praised what Tony Blair had said about the future of Europe last month in Warsaw. But how was he reported the following morning? 'Britain rejected calls yesterday from Romano Prodi to abandon its veto on key areas of policy'."

Mr Cook said the opening line of this report in the Guardian presented Mr Prodi, who had agreed with the prime minister, as challenging Mr Blair. "Note how Britain is being portrayed on the defensive - rejecting pressure on it from Europe. Note how it assumes that any reduction in unanimous decision-making is a threat to the British national interest. And note also that this intro is not culled from the Daily Mail, where it belongs, but from the Guardian," Mr Cook said. "How can we hope to convince the public of the case for Europe if even those papers which profess to support Europe consistently present it to their readers as a threat...?"

However, the Guardian report on November 7 did not assume that any reduction in unanimous decision-making was a threat to the British national interest but said the UK wanted to retain its veto on areas of tax and immigration policy, including the single market and fraud.

This was based on an extensive talk with Keith Vaz, minister for Europe, by the Guardian's two correspondents and a handful of other journalists. The report quoted the minister, a member of Mr Cook's foreign office team, as saying other countries saw scrapping the veto to be off limits in some areas.

"We have made it clear that on tax, social security, border controls and immigration we will not con sider qualified majority voting or the removal of the veto," said Mr Vaz.

The report also drew on a 30-minute briefing given by Mr Prodi to scores of journalists at the CBI conference in Birmingham. This amplified the commission president's remarks in his speech about qualified majority voting and was attended by Emma Udwin, a Prodi aide, who later offered more advice.

webTitle: Business leaders put trust in global brands

fields.headline: Business leaders put trust in global brands
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Business leaders are more likely to trust American Express than the government, according to research published today. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Britain's business leaders are more likely to put their trust in American Express or Yellow Pages than in the government, according to research published today.

The Business Superbrands Survey, conducted by Mintel, shows that business leaders consider global brands such as Siemens and United Airlines to be more reliable than the government or royal family.

And when it comes to governing the country, the business community's love affair with the Conservative party appears to be over.

The survey found that UK business leaders have more faith in the German government's ability to govern the country than in our own Conservative party.

Mintel questioned 47 managing directors and marketing managers from top UK companies about their attitudes to 53 different business brands, all of which have been voted business superbrands by the Superbrands Council.

The council, which is made up of senior executives from the marketing and advertising industries, publishes an annual report on Britain's top consumer brands. This is the first time it has published research into business-to-business brands.

Marcel Knobil, chairman of the Business Superbrands Council, said: "Superbrands is all about promoting the discipline of branding. We genuinely believe that prudent branding elevates a company."

Sony emerged as the company business leaders would most would like to work for, closely followed by Nokia, American Express, Easyjet and Microsoft.

BT was the highest-scoring brand in the telecoms category, in spite of its recent troubles. And Easyjet was found to be the brand most successful at exploiting the internet to service customers.

webTitle: Poptones signs Sony licensing deal in Japan

fields.headline: Poptones signs Sony licensing deal in Japan
fields.trailText: 8am: Music maestro Alan McGee has struck a breakthrough deal in Japan for his internet-friendly Poptones label. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Music maestro Alan McGee has struck a breakthrough deal for his internet-friendly Poptones label.

The entire Poptones catalogue will be distributed in Japan after the company signed a licensing deal with Sony.

Mr McGee's stripped-down label harks back to his early days at Creation, the record company he founded in the early 1980s which went on to launch Oasis.

Poptones signs its acts onto small contracts in a deliberate attempt to move away from the style of bigger labels, which often sign artists on six-album deals.

Mr McGee also aims to capitalise on music sales over the internet, though the bulk of sales will still come from conventional retail channels.

Mr McGee said: "We had tremendous success in Japan with Creation, particularly with Oasis and Primal Scream. In some ways it has been a much bigger market for me than the UK."

Mr McGee said the AIM-listed company is taking a relaxed approach to the business and will licence individual acts to separate labels, with the Sony deal likely to be a one-off.

He added: "There are no rules to how we are approaching it. We are keeping it tight financially because the way the record industry has worked in the past has been so complacent and overblown."

The Poptones roster is made up of little-known bands, including Arnold and Cosmic Rough Riders, though Mr McGee added that he is negotiating deals with a further ten acts.

Despite its underground image, Poptones still attracts some high-flying backers, including the Queen who recently invested £50,000 in the company through her personal investor.

webTitle: November 14 Media Briefing

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

Were he not dead, Inspector Morse would have demanded an explanation as to why Australian viewers got to see the final episode of Inspector Morse before viewers in the UK. P7

Jack Straw is setting up a cybercop crime force to tackle internet crime. P9

Prosecutors have raided World Online's Rotterdam offices after allegations of insider trading. P26

Future Network shares tumbled after a profits warning yesterday. P29

Oftel yesterday ordered BT to change the way it bills operators for using its network. P29

Emap has cut its spending for web-based services from £250m to £120m over the next three years. P29

THE INDEPENDENT

World Online's headquarters were raided yesterday in connection with allegations of insider trading. P18

Future Network saw its shares almost half after a profit warning. P18

Oftel has warned that limits must be imposed on unmetered traffic to ensure that BT's network doesn't collapse. P19

Emap has cut its online investment by half, to about £120m. p19

Emap shares should be left on the shelf. P21

MEDIA

Reprint of a speech by Mark Thompson, BBC director of television, to the Royal Television Society. "If you thought moving the news was radical, you ain't seen nothing yet," he says. P8

Could Piers Morgan be the first editor to be brought down by new technology? How Piers is discovering there is no such thing as deleted email. P8

Robert Fisk looks at biased reporting from war-torn countries. P9

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

Channel 4 may turn to the City to raise future funding, according to chief executive Michael Jackson in an interview with the FT. Privatisation would be a bad idea but we may want to raise some money beyond our budget, said Jackson, citing BBC Worldwide's deal with Flextech. P4

Emap slashes new media investment plans by half. P25

TV producer and labour peer Waheed Alli is expected to announce he is leaving Carlton Communications today, as new chief executive Gerry Murphy announces plans to restructure the TV business into two broad divisions: production and broadcasting. P25

Freeserve shares drop to new low of 132p, driven by widespread falls on Nasdaq. P26

Future Network shares tumbled as it warned of a profits shortfall yesterday. P26

Financial magazine publisher Incisive Media is to raise £40m in an IPO. P26

Internet investor Durlacher has received a £30m cash injection from three institutions. P26

Prosecutors raid World Online's offices in Rotterdam after allegations of insider trading. P32

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

Oftel has told BT to extend its Friaco service from February. P26

Emap has posted flat pre-tax profits but is on track to meet expectations. P30

DAILY TELEGRAPH

Unmetered access moved a step closer yesterday after BT was ordered to change its pricing structure. P5

Mariella Frostrup has caused Panorama to lose 1m viewers. P12

New evidence about Piers Morgan's share dealing scandal is to be sent to the Press Complaints Commission. P15

Emap retreats as dot.com revenues drop. P35

THE TIMES

Piers Morgan's future is in doubt again after the DTI widened its investigation into the share tipping scandal. P2

The BBC has asked the commercial TV regulator to back out of its deal with ITV to bring back News at Ten. P2

The Teletubbies have arrived in Russia and will be shown nationwide on RTR. P20

World Online's headquarters were raided yesterday by Dutch police. P27

Emap cuts back on web spending. P28

New Oftel ruling boosts free internet access. P32

Warning wipes £300m off value of Future Network. P32

THE SUN

It's Mariella Flop-strup. Sunday's Panorama pulled in its second lowest audience since it moved from Monday night five weeks ago. P6

Coronation Street's Curly weds his girlie in special festive episode. It's a tear-jerker, says the Sun. P15

TV joker Keith Chegwin has secretly tied the knot with his long-term girlfriend, 34-year-old Maria Felden. P23.

Countdown to the end of Inspector Morse. Exclusive interview with Kevin Whately. P28/29

THE MIRROR

The stars of Budweiser's 'Whassup' ads have landed their own TV show, playing similar characters in a US sitcom. P8

Corrie's Curly was filmed marrying his lover yesterday for the dramatic Christmas Eve episode. P17

DAILY MAIL

The Mail blows yesterday's Oftel announcement about improvements to BT's Friaco service out of all proportion, and spins it into a larger than life front page story. It's a "massive boost to the internet revolution" says the Mail. P1

The kiss from Sergeant Lewis that says case closed and end of the show for Inspector Morse. P17

Anne Diamond poses in her 'party gems' to show she's not bothered about being overweight. P21

Annabel Heseltine and Mariella Frostrup are interviewed about relationships. P28

Frostrup's Panorama is failing to grab viewer's imagination. P38

Mirror editor faces fresh share probe. Anil Bhoyrul wants to case reopened. P63

DAILY EXPRESS

Cybercops are to fight internet crime. P10

Panorama is proving a ratings flop for the BBC. P11

How the stars of children's TV have finally come of age. P20

Curly gets hitched. P23

Millions to get 24-hour internet deal for £10 per month. P23

Future Network loses half of its value. P60

THE STAR

Corrie's Curly get a surprise at his wedding as his daughter turns up. P7

Funnyman Frank Skinner causes a hoot by impersonating Anne Robinson. P15

AND FINALLY...

Spare a thought for Matt Peacock, director of corporate communications at AOL who was today the most quoted man in the press. Problem was that Associated's Metro somehow managed to get his name wrong, calling him Adam of all things.

webTitle: How the tide turned against the fuel protesters

fields.headline: How the tide turned against the fuel protesters
fields.standfirst:
Julian Glover charts the fluctuating fortunes of petrol taxation, its advocates and enemies.

Special report: the petrol crisis
fields.trailText: Timeline: Julian Glover charts the fluctuating fortunes of petrol taxation, its advocates and enemies.
fields.body:
The Conservative legacy

Mid-1991: Unleaded petrol costs around 40p a litre in Britain. Tax makes up 68.5% of the total price.

March 1993: The Conservative chancellor, Norman Lamont, announces a 10% increase in road fuel duties. At the same time, he reveals plans to increase these duties by at least 3% above the rate of inflation every year from the next year - a formula that becomes known as the "fuel duty escalator".

November 1993: Chancellor Kenneth Clarke increases the escalator to at least 5% in real terms for each future budget.

Mid-1994: The price of unleaded petrol passes 50p a litre in the UK. Tax now makes up 76.5% of the price.

The approaching crisis

November 1997: In the first Labour budget for 18 years, Gordon Brown announces an immediate 9.3% rise in petrol duty and states that the escalator would in future be at least 6%.

Mid-1998: Unleaded petrol now costs around 65p a litre, with tax making up 81.9% of the price.

March 1999: In an effort to increase crude oil prices, which have remained low for the past three years, Opec cuts oil production.

November 1999: Mr Brown reveals that the escalator mechanism will be scrapped. This is welcomed by road users and organisations such as the AA and RAC, but infuriates Friends of the Earth and other environmental groups.

March 2000: In the budget, petrol duties are raised by just under 2p a litre. Rising crude oil prices lead to substantial increases in petrol prices - and government tax revenues.

August 2000: Petrol protests erupt across France, causing massive disruption. British commentators suggest that similar events "could never happen here". UK petrol prices pass 80p a litre, with tax making up around 72% of the total price. An attempt to persuade motorists to "boycott the pumps" in protest falls flat.

The September crisis

Early September: Crude oil prices reach $35 a barrel, pushing petrol prices well beyond 80p.

September 7: About 100 farmers and truckers block access to the Stanlow oil refinery in Cheshire.

September 10: Protests spread across the country and further refineries are closed. Despite limited media coverage of the protests, some motorists begin to buy extra supplies of fuel. This leads to queues at petrol stations and the first shortages.

September 11: Britain now faces widespread shortages of fuel. The government is granted emergency powers by the privy council to regulate fuel supplies, but tanker drivers refuse to leave their depots, citing intimidation by protesters.

September 12: Tony Blair promises to get fuel supplies moving again within 24 hours but says he will not give in to illegal protests.

September 13: There is little sign of the prime minister's demands being met.

September 14: The Daily Mail calls for the blockades to end. Most protesters call off their blockades in the face of the government's defiance of their demands, growing economic disruption and signs that the public mood is turning against them. Protesters set a 60-day deadline for government action.

The aftermath

September 20: The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, promises that the Tory party will cut petrol prices by 3p a litre if elected. The social security secretary, Alistair Darling, describes Mr Portillo's announcement as "opportunistic" and a "return to the worst of Tory boom and bust".

Late September: The government puts plans in place to cope with any future petrol protests. The home secretary, Jack Straw, takes charge of the government's "fuel taskforce". Oil companies agree to reinforce their distribution systems.

October: The government continues to attack the fuel protesters as dangerous supporters of illegal action. Fears grow that when the 60-day deadline expires protesters will attack the national grid.

October 29: Ahead of the government's pre-Budget report, Mr Blair says the government will not give in to calls for cuts in petrol taxation.

November: Shaun Woodward, the Labour MP for Witney who defected from the Conservatives, claims that there are links between the fuel protesters and the far-right British National party. By now the movement's credibility has been badly damaged by the government's campaign against them and polls suggest that public support for renewed action is slipping.

November 6: Divisions between petrol campaigners grow, with some now calling for only a token demonstration after the end of the 60-day deadline. Hauliers propose a slow-driving convoy from Jarrow to London, but the plan is attacked as tasteless by surviving Jarrow hunger marchers and police say they will dictate the truckers' route.

November 8: In his pre-Budget report, Gordon Brown offers a £1.5bn package to appease drivers. His plans include a 3p cut in tax on low-sulphur fuel and a "BritDisc" system to charge overseas trucks for using British roads. The chancellor says his tax cuts surpass those proposed by the Tories.

November 9: Divisions among protesters grow. Some welcome the chancellor's concessions, while others begin a go-slow convoy, aiming to reach London on November 13.

November 10: The convoy fails to impress, with few drivers taking part. The police disrupt its progress.

November 13: The 60-day deadline expires with minimal attention.

November 14: Truckers plan to gather in Hyde Park to renew their demand for a 26p cut in fuel tax, but the battle for public opinion seems to have been lost.

webTitle: Fuel protesters demand Blair meeting

fields.headline: Fuel protesters demand Blair meeting
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Fuel protesters today demanded to meet the prime minister, Tony Blair, as the first of their lorries arrived in London.
fields.body:
Fuel protesters today demanded to meet the prime minister, Tony Blair, as the first of their lorries arrived in London.

Around 50 lorries which had assembled at Thurrock Services, Essex, this morning were the first to arrive in the capital. They were stopped by police and parked on the A40 Westway in west London.

After some negotiations between police and the protesters' spokesman Andrew Spence, it was agreed that a tractor, a Land Rover, and one articulated lorry would be allowed to proceed to Downing Street.

The main body of protesters was assembling prior to setting off on foot to Hyde Park. They are expected to walk to Westminster after a rally and speeches.

The tractor making its way to Downing Street was draped with a banner reading "The Labour government are killing British farmers. More suicides this year than ever before."

The first vehicle in the convoy was driven by haulier, Andy Courtney, who said he was losing £10,000 worth of business by having 13 of his 14 lorries involved in the process.

Mr Courtney arrived driving a Toyota Land Cruiser with a sign saying: "Taxed Out Of Work" in the windscreen. Other trucks displayed placards in their windows including "Blair Out Now" and "Blair Stitch Up Project".

Mr Courtney said: "It's time the government came out and met us, not us come to meet them. They throw money around like confetti everywhere apart from where it is needed and expect us to pick up the bill for it."

However, a spokesman for Mr Blair said: "The government has never wanted to pick a fight with anybody. We have acknowledged repeatedly that the price of petrol is high and this causes particular problems, for example, for people in rural communities.

"We have done what we can, but to do more would be to start to jeopardise the extra investment the government is putting into public services, to possibly impact on interest rates and we are not prepared to put in jeopardy the hard-won economic stability."

The spokesman added ministers had said they were prepared to meet protesters, but there had been no request for a meeting today.

The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, at his meeting with members of the government's road haulage forum this afternoon, is expected to spell out some of the benefits outlined by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in his pre-budget report last week.

Lord Macdonald is expected to say that this year alone tax changes excise duty on lorries would be worth about £4,000 a truck for 250,000 vehicles.

Don Foster, the Liberal Democrat transport spokesman, said: "Public support for the fuel protest has clearly evaporated. Causing traffic chaos in London will only alienate the public further."

In Edinburgh, a slow-moving convoy of fuel protesters in more than 80 lorries, coaches and private vehicles sounded their horns as they drove into the city centre.

Earlier, police in London had relaxed their plans for a total exclusion zone preventing protest lorries driving into the centre of the capital because they now expect fewer vehicles to be taking part.

Last night, protesters had claimed the main truck convoy heading to London on the M1 was acting as a decoy, with many more vehicles heading directly to the capital.

Gateshead-based haulier Craig Eley said as many as 40 other trucks from north-east England had either already arrived in the capital or were planning to travel down last night or early today.

"There will be more protesters than people think," he said. "The plan has been to get as many people to London as possible without getting arrested.

"It is fair to say that Andrew [Spence, the convoy leader] has been a good decoy."

He claimed all the extra vehicles, travelling at normal speeds and not in convoy, would be carrying genuine loads for delivery in the capital and could not be stopped by police.

Yesterday was the 60-day deadline for tax concessions, set by protesters after they brought Britain to a standstill in September.

webTitle: Fuel protesters claim decoy ruse

fields.headline: Fuel protesters claim decoy ruse
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Fuel protesters claimed yesterday that the small scale convoy of hauliers and farmers descending on London had been a "decoy" to cloak the arrival in the capital of many more vehicles.
fields.body:
Fuel protesters claimed yesterday that the small scale convoy of hauliers and farmers descending on London had been a "decoy" to cloak the arrival in the capital of many more vehicles.

Smaller than anticipated numbers joined the convoy from the north-east of England, led by Andrew Spence of the People's Fuel Lobby. But he hinted at the weekend of "some surprises in store".

As the original 60 day deadline set by the fuel protesters for the chancellor Gordon Brown to come up with a big cut in the price of fuel expired last night, around 20 lorries stopped at Scratchwood service station in Hertfordshire in preparation for today's protest in Hyde Park, London.

Gateshead-based haulier Craig Eley said that up to 40 other trucks from the north-east had already arrived in the capital or were planning to travel down before the rally.

The convoy itself was being kept deliberately small to avoid confrontation with police, Mr Eley said."The plan has been to get as many people to London as possible without getting arrested. We did it this way after police said they would throw a ring of steel around London. Andrew has been a good decoy."

Police have relaxed their plans for an exclusion zone preventing protesters from driving into London. Leaders of the People's Fuel Lobby met with senior Metropolitan police officers on Sunday night to discuss policing of the protest.

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "After reviewing the situation and numbers of vehicles expected we have renegotiated the arrangements. But the precise details have still to be finalised."

A ban on lorries entering the very heart of the city, and a ban on vehicles more than 40ft in length will remain in place.

Stephen Alexander, solicitor for the People's Fuel Lobby, said he was pleased with the change of plan. "Since the agreement was reached, protesters have had several calls from hauliers saying they would join the convoy. People were put off by the language police were using, but that has now relaxed."

Scottish fuel demonstrators set off in convoy yesterday for a protest in Edinburgh today. Around 90 lorries, coaches, taxis and cars left Inverurie, in Aberdeenshire, and headed down the east coast.

One of the organisers, taxi operator Graham Wilson, of Dunecht, Aberdeenshire, said the aim was to bring "a stark message to the Scottish parliament that people are not appeased by the budget at all".

Eighteen demonstrators yesterday converged on the Stanlow oil refinery, on Merseyside, which saw the first of September's fuel blockades. A police spokeswoman said they were members of the public rather than farmers and hauliers. They dispersed after officials from the People's Fuel Lobby urged them to go home.

fields.headline: Life in the slow lane
fields.standfirst:
They were dubbed 'The Fat Blokes', told to go home by their leader and ridiculed for their dwindling numbers. As the fuel protesters arrive in London, Angelique Chrisafis, the only reporter who travelled with the convoy, reports on four strange days with the Big Boys and Jimmy the Drain

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: They were dubbed 'The Fat Blokes', told to go home by their leader and ridiculed for their dwindling numbers. As the fuel protesters arrive in London,  Angelique Chrisafis, the only reporter who travelled with the convoy, reports on four strange days with the Big Boys and Jimmy the Drain
fields.body:
Jesus Christ, who dropped a bomb on this place?" came the cry over CB radio, as the People's Fuel Lobby's go-slow convoy pulled into the Hollies truck stop at Cannock in Warwickshire. Velvet curtain tassels pinned to lorry windscreens shook as trucks heaved over potholes deep with mud. Freddie Mercury was singing I Want to Break Free on the local radio. It was dark, it was raining. We were three miles from the nearest pub. Men were jumping through puddles carrying their washbags to the prefab shower then drawing the blinds on their truck and climbing onto makeshift bunks for the night, next to pictures of their kids.

All there was for comfort on the second night of their convoy was an enormous truckers' caff serving huge helpings of custardish-like scrambled eggs. Outside the caff sat Gareth, an alternative documentary maker who was following the convoy in a camper van.

"What's wrong Gareth, like?"

"The plates are so big here I can't get them into the shot."

This is the story of the "Big Boys," six struggling Geordie hauliers, an unemployed couple living under a green duvet in an F-reg Fiesta, and "Jimmy the Drain," a Carlisle-based drain cleaner with a dog called Millie. These were the people who blockaded the oil refineries in September and brought the country to a halt. After Gordon Brown's pre-Budget statement they felt tax on fuels was still too high and they were driving for four days at 20mph down the country to make a stand.

Dubbed "The Fat Blokes" by Guardian cartoonist Steve Bell, told by their leader, Welsh farmer Brynle Williams, to piss off and go home three days ago, pulled apart by the press for their dwindling numbers, outnumbered by the police at every turn, called "pillocks" over the CB system by a small group of opposing hauliers in Birmingham, they are an unflagging hardcore of protesters, determined to march till the end.

Today, 400 miles from their starting point, they will rally in Hyde Park at midday and the original five will go to Downing Street to deliver a message to Tony Blair "on behalf of all the public, even lawnmowers users" that fuel taxes are crippling the country.

Most of these men are broke. They have put £1,000 into fuel for this journey. They are losing work in businesses that were already suffering. Tony Finlay, 28, and his wife Alison, 34, from the Less Tax of Fuel campaign had driven from Durham in their Fiesta in which they had slept for the duration. They have spent £51 on petrol and are down to their last fiver. "We're going to keep going until the fuel runs out. Then we'll just have to sit in a lay-by and wait for a week until Friday, the next date we can draw cash out of our account. We are unemployed, don't call us selfish for being here. We've made a huge sacrifice."

It is cold at night under their duvet, plus they have hardly any money for food. The chill air is giving Alison bladder trouble and she has to keep getting out of the car at 2am to sprint across the truck stop. "There is nowhere to squat with all these trucks parked here," she says. Behind the car there is only a field full of bemused sheep.

It all started on Friday morning at Birtley truck stop south of Gateshead with 20 tons of manure and an inflatable alien propped on top and tied to a stake. "Who's carrying the stink now", cried a banner on a tractor. But a 6.30am, as the sun rose over the potholed park, a handful of farmers searched in vain for the protesters. Suddenly a 20-ton hay-bale wagon drove into the stop, tooting.

"Aye, aye, it's Norman Nattress and his hay, he was at Stanlow, like." One by one the hauliers began to arrive.

Paul Stobbart, 32, rolled in on a seven-and-a-half ton truck with a caravan on the back for his wife Lesley and their 12-year-old daughter Samantha. "It's a 1986 reg caravan. I usually have it in the field with the horses, like. It's got a shower, a toilet and a gas fire, its like a home from home. When you've got a wife and bairn you've got to get a wash, like."

Two weeks before the convoy left, they were demanding a fee - to cover fuel costs - for the media to get on a lorry for the full ride to London. In the event, no one paid and the People's Fuel Lobby was more than generous about taking passengers. But there wasn't enough room on the 20 wagons for all the documentary makers and cameramen, let alone press. I had walked half a mile up the A1(M) at 6am to join the convoy, carrying a huge backpack and a bag of oranges (the press had a perverse idea they'd all get scurvy), but there were reporters in brand-new fleeces running through puddles, looking for what had been billed as 200 lorries.

Albert Storey, aka "The Wanderer", who had driven 70 miles from Carlisle in a 38-ton powder tanker, stepped in when he realised there was a lone woman hitchhiking with 20 angry hauliers. "Are you daft? We're not having that, get on."

We broke pies together at 25mph all the way to Lymm in Cheshire, past the Angel of the North. ("It would be alright with a bit of paint but it doesn't look like an angel.") The CB radio blared and morale was strong.

"Keep it together boys." "Drop your speed at the back and let this wagon in on your back door, breaker." "I've got Sky News on my front door, breaker." "Oh no, I've not combed my hair."

The media did not emerge as hate figures until Saturday morning when the press, confused by the numbers of vehicles on the convoy counted 20 vehicles pulling into a truck stop. This was the number also counted from bridges. Hauliers felt this did not do justice to trucks which had "joined" in the middle lane of the M6.

"I am very disappointed in you. I've got a 23-ton wagon full of shite waiting for us in London and I'm going to pour it all over your head if you don't report this fairly," said Andrew Spence of the People's Fuel Lobby.

I had already been thrown off Albert's truck for reporting that some lorries had got lost at the back of the convoy. "You're making us look like fools," he said.

John Coxon of the People's Fuel Lobby took a more lenient view, though: "You might be intensely annoying," he said. "But we can't leave you at the truck stop."

Farmer Bill Headley in a 40-ton trailer with two tractors on the back gave me a lift to Milton Keynes, even making his farmer passenger get out and hitch a ride in a TV van. By Saturday several mythical figures had emerged as patron saints of the convoy.

The first were the "barristers" who, protesters vowed, would deal with any hiccups from their offices "overlooking Hyde Park". The second was the "sandwich woman on the dole". She struck at night at the truckstop, handing out bags of ham sandwiches to protesters. Some said she had driven from North Wales, others said there were more than one, but each night unemployed women stood buttering bread in their kitchen in order to drive bootfuls of sustenance to the boys.

The last was "Bernadette from Milton Keynes" who joined the convoy in a white Ford Escort with a sheet tied to the front. She was a nor mal motorist, advising the protesters on their route and warning them of police cars and press on their tails.

"Watch out there's a cameraman up your jacksie," she cried.

Arnold Pennant, a farmer from North Wales and his spaniel Coco, added the last touch to the crowd of supporters who came to join the convoy at truckstops down the country and rushed on to bridges to count their numbers. His cut-glass accent sliced through the smoke of truckers cafes. "God, it's a fleapit in here," he said.

Pennant said the fact that farmers and hauliers had joined showed all kinds of classes were working together in this convoy. He was with them until the end in his sparkling Land Rover, staying at hotels or driving home at night.

Yesterday the truckers said they would travel to London in coaches if the convoy was stopped.

"Oh, I don't think I've ever travelled in a coach before," said Pennant over a mug of tea. "Farmers don't use public transport. They have their own means of getting around."

webTitle: Analysis: European integration

fields.headline: Never say never
fields.standfirst:
Most Britons are hostile to the euro, but they think we will be using it some time in the future. The battle to keep the pound is far from over

Special report: economic and monetary union
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: How high is the mountain of Euroscepticism Tony Blair and Robin Cook yesterday braced themselves to climb? They are keen to separate attitudes towards the euro and towards UK membership of the EU but they have a habit of mixing and matching.
fields.body:
How high is the mountain of Euroscepticism Tony Blair and Robin Cook yesterday braced themselves to climb? They are keen to separate attitudes towards the euro and towards UK membership of the EU but they have a habit of mixing and matching.

We know that in a referendum more than 70% would opt to keep the pound. An already sceptical electorate seems to have been swayed further by the Danish "No" vote, continuing news of the euro's weakness and Mr Blair's avowal that he too would vote No in an opinion poll. Indeed, since August the shift in opposition to the euro has been most marked among Labour supporters. In August Labour voters would have said No to the euro by a margin of only 3%, now a majority of 28% would follow Mr Blair's advice.

Danish voters rejected the euro at the end of a campaign in which virtually the whole political, business and media establishment urged them to take the plunge. This knocked the notion here in the UK that the euro is inevitable.

Continuing news of the euro's weakness on the foreign exchange markets had already worried voters. They feel that a currency they hear is "weakening" and going "down" must, by definition, mean trouble for all who use it. They see no disadvantages for those whose currency is "strong" and "rising". And if that were not enough, already sceptical voters have been fed, drip by drip, opinion polls that suggest those who oppose the euro are in a clear majority, creating a climate of opinion hostile to any chance the pro-euro camp may have of winning a referendum.

Since "Yes" prospects are poor it makes little sense for Blair to allow the impression that he is in favour of joining the euro to harm his election chances: far better to start the campaign after he has been re-elected when perhaps the euro will be in better shape.

In focus groups, people are deeply distrustful of other Europeans. Often they say that we beat them all in the second world war and they have been trying to get back at us ever since. They fear the continentals sneaking up on us under the cover of the EU. Beyond this, people are confused about what the euro will mean to them. Yet they are also fatalistic, saying we will have to accept it in the end anyway.

While anti-euro campaigners trumpet the fact that we are taxed less than people in euroland and have one of the largest economies in the world, few believe it. More common is the idea that we are a small country, anchored somewhere offshore and unable to ignore them, the Europeans, or even resist their long-term will. So while only 18% would vote for the euro in a referendum now, 52% think it will be the currency of Britain within a decade. Only 21% think we will never have the euro.

So Mr Blair still has some reason to be cheerful about long-term prospects. Voters are tribal, Labour supporters especially. No matter how many issues pollsters ask about, around three-quarters of Labour voters nominate their own party as having the best policies. But Labour supporters show only low levels of support for policies where the party line is distinctly different from their instincts or where the policy is confused or badly communicated.

We can compare the apparent clarity of William Hague's message with the confused smoke signals from Labour's high command. In an immediate referendum, 85% of Tory voters would vote No and only 10% would vote Yes. But among Labour voters, 60% would vote No and 29% Yes. For as long as the government seems confused, so will Labour supporters. But at any time when the perceived economic fortunes of euroland improved, a more forceful message from the top would encourage more Labour supporters to fall into line.

A risky gamble with a new-fangled currency is, for the moment, unlikely to appeal. But in time the euro will strengthen along with the perceived strength of euroland economies. And people will start to gain personal experience of euro notes and coins on trips across the Channel. The pound will at some point start to weaken relative to the euro. When that time comes, adopting the single currency will no longer seem like a dangerous adventure.

It is tempting but dangerous for No campaigners to look at the data in the chart and imagine the war is over when, in fact, it has yet to really start. Their problem is that public opposition is founded on nothing much more than inherited animosity to all things European. The pro-euro forces look as if they have been knocked out but No campaigners would be unwise to stop trying to find ways to carry on punching. The pro-euro lobby is not going to be killed off and the most the No campaign can hope for is that they will find it difficult to pick themselves up and resume the fight.

webTitle: View from Paris: Why French politicians keep mum on Europe

fields.headline: Why French politicians keep mum on Europe
fields.standfirst:
French politicians don't make many pro-European speeches because they are not as Europhile as we might think, argues Jon Henley

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: View from Paris: French politicians don't make many pro-European speeches because they are not as Europhile as we might think, argues Jon Henley.
fields.body:
France, in case anyone had forgotten, currently holds the rotating six-month presidency of the European Union. And next month, in Nice, a summit will be held which should, in theory and among other things, agree the major institutional changes needed to enlarge the EU to up to 30 members.

So it comes as something of a surprise to realise - as both Britain's foreign and prime ministers produce resoundingly pro-European (or at least, anti-Eurosceptic) speeches today, less than a month after Tony Blair's previous contribution to the European debate in Warsaw - that the last time a senior French figure said anything serious about Europe was back in June.

That was when President Jacques Chirac spoke to the Bundestag in Berlin. Seeking to make up ground on Germany, whose Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer had just made an altogether alarming federalist speech, Mr Chirac talked warmly, but confusingly of inner cores and more intensive integration, remaining vague as to the details so as to offend no one.

Since then, however, no leading French politician has made a proper pronouncement on Europe and France's place in it. Indeed the prime minister Lionel Jospin has, like the rest of his government, managed to avoid outlining exactly what kind of Europe France would like since he was elected, which is more than three years ago.

There is, of course, an important reason why Messrs Blair and Cook should feel obliged to deliver pro-European blasts from time to time, and that is that the majority of the British people - thanks largely to an often outrageously deceitful Eurosceptic press - remains worried about what Europe represents.

The corollary of that may, of course, hold true in France. Since opinion polls continue to show that nearly 60% of the French describe themselves as "enthusiastic" or "favourable" to the European project, while 70% would like even faster integration, it may be that Messrs Jospin and Chirac simply do not need to make any big European speeches.

But another possibility is equally, if not more, likely: France's leaders do not make any big European speeches because they do not actually have any big European ideas. And they do not have any big European ideas because they are not actually very pro-European.

In fact, the vision of a federal Europe painted by Mr Fischer inspires horror in most French politicians, many of whom are genuinely far closer to the British view of Europe than anyone in the Eurosceptic British press would like to admit. The very word "federal" is anathema in France, where power is by tradition centralised and not split between the capital and the regions.

And although a majority of French people do favour a more powerful or federal EU (without actually having thought much about what that might imply), important groups from both sides of the political divide - the Communists and radical Republicans on the left, and some Gaullists and Eurosceptic ex-Gaullists on the right - are fiercely opposed to any more power being transferred to Brussels.

Not for nothing is France the biggest offender when it comes to observing EU directives. Not for nothing does it refuse to accept some of the important constraints imposed by the single currency (the country's 2001 Budget, for example, is in clear violation of Paris' promise to Brussels to reduce its budget deficit).

France's leaders are reluctant to go very much further down the road to integration. They would be happy with something that offered just a few more social guarantees than the lowest common denominator, the free-trade bloc they suspect Britain wants, but absolutely not with the United States of Europe that they suspect Germany is after.

France's leaders would, in fact, be satisfied (indeed delighted) with something very close to Mr Blair's vision of a Europe based on the almost ad-hoc cooperation of sovereign governments - itself a vision very similar to Charles de Gaulle's famous "Europe des patries". But they can't really say so in public, for fear of losing face to Germany. So they say nothing at all.

webTitle: Emap cuts spending forecast on new media

fields.headline: Emap cuts spending forecast on new media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Emap, the magazine publishing and radio group, yesterday sharply cut its spending forecast for web-based services from £250m over the next three years to £120m.
fields.body:
Emap, the magazine publishing and radio group, yesterday sharply cut its spending forecast for web-based services from £250m over the next three years to £120m.

The eight targets for this investment will include online versions of men's magazine FHM, music monthly Q and construction trade titles.

Kevin Hand, chief executive, said the world had become a "little more realistic" about new media in the nine months since the company's first forecast. The new figure reflected a "rigorous examination" of the business.

Emap is forecasting break even by 2003 for the new media division and revenues of £100m within five years.

It reported a 3% increase in revenues to £567m for the first half year and flat pretax profits of £92m, slightly above expectations, before taking internet investment into account.

Centralising advertising sales across radio and magazines had made the business lose focus slightly, said Mr Hand, particularly among the glossies. The US was a weak spot with profits falling 23% to £17m. FHM is still a star performer, while a new French title, Pleine Vie, aimed at women over 50 has had astounding success. The shares slipped 13p to 817p.
