webTitle: Bonn government casts long shadow

fields.headline: Bonn government casts long shadow
fields.standfirst:
Many of Germany's current scandals can be linked to the country's change of capital city, reports John Hooper in Berlin

The German corruption scandal
fields.trailText: Many of Germany's current scandals can be linked to the country's change of capital city, reports John Hooper in Berlin.
fields.body:
In the past 12 months, the following things have happened, all in one country:

 The main opposition conservative party has become embroiled in an immense scandal involving a distinguished elder statesman and, potentially, tens of millions of pounds.

 The Mr Clean of the country's athletics team has been banned from international competition after testing positive for nandrolone.

 The man named to take over its national football side has fled after he too tested positive in a rather different drugs test - one he had voluntarily accepted to disprove allegations that he was a cocaine addict.

 Tests carried out in the loos of the national parliament building turned up traces of cocaine in almost all of them.

 And now a senior member of the cabinet is resisting calls for his resignation despite being found guilty by the courts of aiding and abetting a fraud.

Italy ? Argentina ? No, Germany.

It is probably no exaggeration to say that, since November 1999 when the row broke over the funding of the Christian Democrat Union (CDU) under the former chancellor Helmut Kohl, Germany has become Europe's most scandal-ridden nation. But why?

Clearly, German society is undergoing a change, one which Germans themselves struggle to describe with two phrases, both referring to the capital: "the Berlin generation" and "the Berlin republic".

The first is used to describe those who are now in their 20s. It conveys the sense of a more easygoing society, free from the rigorous self-discipline that characterised the years of Germany's "economic miracle". The second refers to the bigger, more powerful yet less predictable country created by reunification 10 years ago.

Today's Germany is, in several respects then, a society in transition. And societies in transition have a habit of generating juicy controversies - take Britain in the 1960s. But there are at least two more closely definable reasons why Germany should now be throwing up so many scandals.

The first is that a very specific, collaborative approach to both politics and economics - what came to be known as "Rhineland capitalism" - is beginning to crack under pressure from the free-market forces bearing in on Germany from outside. The second, which is related to the first, is that the German news media have become more competitive and aggressive.

In both, the move of Germany's capital from Bonn to Berlin has played an important role. It is not just that it is a more colourful, indeed eccentric place. While Germany was run from Bonn, it was being run from the very heart of that Rhineland which gave its name to Germany's corporate, increasingly cronyist, capitalism.

Arguably, though, it was not being governed from Bonn at all, but from the Bonn suburb of Bad Godesberg, which was where the parliament, the government, the media bureaux and the foreign embassies were all concentrated. With its tranquil, cosy, intimate atmosphere, Bad Godesberg nurtured a close and deeply unhealthy relationship between German politicians and journalists that is starting to ebb away now that the capital is in Berlin.

Of all Germany's recent scandals, the reported discovery earlier this month by the television channel SAT 1 of traces of cocaine in the Reichstag was both the least conclusive and the most significant.

Whether, as the parliamentary authorities claimed, the results were unreliable is almost irrelevant. What matters is that a TV programme should have dared to embark on such an impudent exercise in the first place.

webTitle: Australia gets in first as Morse breathes his last

fields.headline: Australia gets in first as Morse breathes his last
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Were he not dead, Morse would have spluttered into his pint and demanded an explanation from the hapless Sergeant Lewis. For, to the anger of his creator and the irritation of British viewers, millions of Australians witnessed the sullen inspector's last breaths three days before he was due to expire on ITV.
fields.body:
Were he not dead, Morse would have spluttered into his pint and demanded an explanation from the hapless Sergeant Lewis. For, to the anger of his creator and the irritation of British viewers, millions of Australians witnessed the sullen inspector's last breaths three days before he was due to expire on ITV.

In a misjudgment that demands an inquiry led by the great detective himself, Carlton sold the final instalment of the hit series to Australia's Channel Seven in the knowledge that it would be shown there first.

ITV insisted that, because of the 14,000-mile gap, no viewer in Britain would see the programme before it is aired here tomorrow night. But Colin Dexter, author of the Morse novels, said he was astonished and disappointed. "I don't know if any amount of distance can justify letting another country show it first," he told the Guardian's media website, which revealed the story yesterday.

The Remorseful Day, made and distributed by Carlton and starring John Thaw, was billed as a "movie premiere" when it was broadcast by Channel Seven on Sunday. Millions saw the episode, in which Morse is removed from a murder investigation after his boss judges him "not temperamentally suited" to the case. Morse is later taken to hospital, where his health deteriorates.

Thaw's brother may have been one of those watching - he lives in Australia and saw the actor's other Carlton series, Monsignor Renard, before it was screened in Britain.

The story of Morse's tragic ending was widely trailed when the book was published last year, but Mr Dexter said there was no excuse for showing the television version in Australia first. "I am extremely surprised. I know nothing about it being shown in Australia. I can offer no comment other than to say everyone here felt Wednesday was the first showing.

"Carlton is obviously relaxed about it, but I don't think anybody else would have been happy about this. Most people would have felt that the first public showing of the last Morse should have taken place, as directed and commissioned by the ITV network, on ITV."

A spokeswoman for the ITV network, which granted permission to Carlton for the episode to be screened first in Australia, said viewers would not be disadvantaged because the demise of Morse was widely publicised. "A screening of The Remorseful Day in Australia so close to transmission in the UK will not detract from viewers' enjoyment of the dramatic conclusion of the Morse series on ITV on Wednesday night," she said.

Carlton cited Monsignor Renard as a precedent, but said it would have not allowed the programme to have been shown in a neighbouring European country first. "The fact that this happened 14,000 miles away means that viewers will not be missing out," a spokesman said.

British television series are regularly syndicated to Australia, where Morse is popular. The Royle Family, Cold Feet and The Bill have been recent hits.

webTitle: Confronting the perils of global warming in a vanishing landscape

fields.headline: Confronting the perils of global warming in a vanishing landscape
fields.standfirst:
 Climate change talks begin at the Hague
 Fears that US will block any progress : Last chance to save the world from global warming?
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The town of Rosetta is spread along the last stretch of the Nile's journey from the heart of Africa to the Mediterranean. Its muddy waters have supported along the way millions living on its densely populated banks and have fed the intricate web of irrigation channels which has made the desert bloom for thousands of years.
fields.byline: Madeleine Bunting in Rosetta on the Nile
fields.body:
The town of Rosetta is spread along the last stretch of the Nile's journey from the heart of Africa to the Mediterranean. Its muddy waters have supported along the way millions living on its densely populated banks and have fed the intricate web of irrigation channels which has made the desert bloom for thousands of years.

Rosetta's perch between sea and river on land only a few inches above either provides it with an intimate understanding of both the preciousness of water and the precarious purchase dry land has against the threat of flood.

Now Rosetta, famous for the stone which bears its name in the British Museum, is fast acquiring another kind of fame, as one of the most vulnerable areas in the world to global warming. Here, sea level rise compounded by subsidence in the Nile delta could reach a metre by 2100, which would submerge Rosetta and a swath of the densely populated region.

This is no abstract problem for the future; land around Rosetta has been disappearing at the rate of 148 metres a year. A sea wall, two storeys high, has slowed the rate of attrition. Ali, a boatman who has worked on the Nile all his life, remembers as a boy walking on dry land three kilometres beyond where the promontory now ends.

But sea walls cannot stop the rising salination in the palm groves and fields adjoining the shore. Where the sea walls stop, muddy land is rapidly changing to shore, as winter floods kill off the vegetation. The sea nibbles at a fragile soil crust only a few inches high. Here, we found an engineer sitting under a dilapidated parasol supervising the construction of concrete groynes every few feet - another measure to slow shore erosion.

Down the road in the village teashop, Saad, a farmer, his two-year-old son at his knee, described how he tries to protect their fields with dykes and ditches. He talked of the laborious efforts to wash the soil of salt - flooding the land three or four times with Nile water, but even then only salt resistant crops would grow. It is the slow, insidious saltwater intrusion which threatens to be one of the most difficult consequence of sea level rise, destroying the delta's fertility.

Egypt, where human beings built one of the first and most ambitious civilisations four and half thousand years ago, will be among those countries hit hardest by global warming, the result of the excesses of modern civilisation. While ancient Egyptian civilisation was built on the careful management of the environment, modern civilisation has been built on its destruction.

Teams of officials from 160 countries yesterday arrived in the Hague, the Netherlands, to hammer out an agreement which is the culmination of eight years of international effort to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions which are destroying our climate. On Sunday, John Prescott and the Dutch and French prime ministers lead ministerial delegations to finalise a deal.

At stake is the historic agreement achieved in Kyoto three years ago, when leaders pledged their countries to a 5% cut in greenhouse gas emissions from 1990 levels. Scientists argued at the time that the reduction needed to be of the order of 60-80% to make a real impact. But even Kyoto's target has not been met - emissions have continued to go up at the rate of 1.3% a year. There are so many points of dispute that even Kyoto's limited achievement is in danger of collapse.

Riccardo Navarro, chairman of Friends of the Earth International, warns that the Hague convention could be the last chance to rescue international action on climate change: "Since 1997 we have seen nothing but bureaucratic wrangling, delays and desperate attempts to find loopholes. The US and other governments are rooting around for any excuse which would avoid them taking action."

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, who will attend next week, acknowledges the risk that developed countries will try to wriggle their way out of Kyoto obligations. "We must ensure that we do not significantly weaken the protocol by creating loopholes, which might allow some industrialised countries to avoid real domestic action," he said.

Environmentalists direct much of their frustration at the US. With 5 % of the world's population, it accounts for well over 20% of carbon emissions. Its booming economy has increased emissions since 1990 by 10.7%. The US has admitted it will not meet its Kyoto target and if George W Bush wins the election that will add another threat to the Hague's success - he rejects the existence of global warming.

Just as the UK has had the worst flooding for centuries, so billions around the world will experience climate change through water: too much or too little. Pharaonic officials measured the Nile's annual floods, knowing that feast and famine depended on them. Similarly, billions of lives will be jeopardised by increasingly erratic rainfall from China to Africa. Studies for the International Panel of Climate Change (IPCC) estimate that 170m more people, many of them in Africa, will face extreme water shortages.

The Nile itself is highly sensitive to changes in rainfall, and some predict a 98% drop in volume. Egypt could be hit by a double whammy: rising sea levels and a shrinking Nile.

Yet the plight of farmers such as Saad will not feature at the Hague. One of the central topics will be what ratio of trees or density of foliage, what type of tree, can properly be called a forest. It is a key issue in the US attempt to offset its growing emissions by planting forests.

The countries which stand to suffer most if the Hague fails are those with the smallest voice. Islands in danger of be ing submerged, from the Pacific to the Caribbean, may make eloquent appeals; Egypt, Bangladesh and Vietnam may remind the world that the lives of billions will be defined by these negotiations. But in the end, the fate of such countries lies in the hands of the polluters. The UK produces as much carbon as the whole of Africa.

It is now nearly a decade since the IPCC accepted that human activities were changing the world's climate. At that time it was assumed the world had 50-100 years to prepare. But already there are telltale signs; the time frames are changing rapidly. We are perhaps a generation away from some of the worst predictions.

Tomorrow: Four generations of one family tell the story of why the west is heading for climate hell. Plus: What the scientists say.

webTitle: Europe is best for Britain, says Blair

fields.headline: Europe is best for Britain, says Blair
fields.standfirst:
PM hails constructive policies that have increased Britain's power and influence

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night made an historic claim that Labour has transformed Britain's relationship with Europe for the better - and thereby increased its power, influence and authority in the world.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night made an historic claim that Labour has transformed Britain's relationship with Europe for the better - and thereby increased its power, influence and authority in the world.

"If we want to stand up for Britain then we have to be in Europe, active, constructive, involved all the time. We have to negotiate toughly and get our way, not stand aside and let other European countries make the decisions that matter to us," said Mr Blair.

In a combative speech extolling "enlightened patriotism" he singled out pressure for EU-wide tax harmonisation as an example of where "other countries are wrong". But he insisted that Britain's role as "the bridge between the US and Europe" is itself a rejection of isolationism and Euroscepticism.

The main thrust of the prime minister's annual foreign policy speech to a City audience at the Mansion House was the inter-dependence of the modern world which compels every state, even the US - "the only superpower" - to cooperate on everything from global warming and world trade to Aids and the nuclear threat from rogue states.

He also cited the decision to intervene in Iraq, Kosovo and Sierra Leone and praised the professionalism of Britain's armed forces.

"All this means that the isolationist tendency is at odds with the new reality, even where there is change we want it orderly... there is too much to lose in money, jobs and, of course, with nuclear weapons, in the cataclysm that would be war," Mr Blair said.

In a practical demonstration of the national interest Mr Blair had earlier met leaders of Uefa, football's ruling body, to back its campaign against European Commission proposals on transfer rules which would hurt small football clubs.

Mr Blair avoided overt party politics with an audience that is traditionally pro-Tory. But his stress on closer EU cooperation was a challenge to the Tory leader, William Hague, who last night responded by accusing Mr Blair's team of "using every trick in the spin doctor's book to try and pretend that they are not willing participants in the creation of a European superstate".

The Mansion House speech came hours after the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, had also made an impassioned speech in defence of the benefits Britain will gain from closer European cooperation.

In language even more emphatic than Mr Blair's, he said: "It is patriotism, it is national self-interest, to argue for Britain's full engagement as a leading partner in Europe. It is a betrayal of our nation and our future constantly to obstruct every fresh opportunity for cooperation in Europe."

That will enrage Euro-sceptic newspapers. But Mr Cook signalled he is ready for the long-delayed fight - even if Downing Street holds back - when he attacked the way in which the national press covers the EU. "The media has a mission to entertain, and some of them rise magnificently to that goal. But they are failing in their other mission - to inform," he argued.

"From now on, the government will be rebutting all such stories vigorously and promptly. You will be hearing the catchphrase 'facts, not myths' until that is the way the EU is reported,"he said.

He went on to predict that the Nice summit on December 8-9 would be good news because it would produce two things Britain supports: reform of the EU's creaking structures and its enlargement to take in ex-communist states to the east.

Downing Street last night acknowledged the sensitivity of the Nice agenda after a 45 minute video-conference between Mr Blair and President Jacques Chirac of France highlighted persistent differences over the planned reduction of the national vetos.

Both leaders expressed "broad agreement" on reducing the size of the commission, giving more weight to the votes of larger states and cooperating more closely on defence.

But they diverged on how best to use majority voting instead of unanimous agreement, with Britain insisting on retaining its veto on tax, social security, border control and defence while France refuses to concede powers that protect its film industry.

Viewed from Brussels, the Nice summit looks like being a cliffhanger with haggling into the small hours on how to curb the national veto and - even trickier - give big states, notably Germany, extra votes at the expense of smaller ones. Both are designed to make decision-making easier once the EU grows from 15 to 20 or even 26 members.

Both Mr Blair and Mr Cook sidestepped the single currency issue by stating that the government's wait-and-see policy has not changed. Both concentrated on the benefits to Britain of "working with our neighbours" to combat crime, promote trade and a better environment.

webTitle: Welcome to the new world

fields.headline: Welcome to the new world
fields.standfirst:
Floods in Yorkshire. Millions facing drought in China. Permafrost melting in Russia. Malaria spreading across Africa. And that's just the start. Guardian writers on how global warming is wreaking havoc around the world.
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Floods in Yorkshire. Millions facing drought in China. Permafrost melting in Russia. Malaria spreading across Africa. And that's just the start. Guardian writers on how global warming is wreaking havoc around the world.
fields.body:
Britain

Britain will be a warmer place in future, with drier summers and more frequent droughts, but with wetter autumns and winters. In other words: more rain and more river flooding.

And there is a double jeopardy. The coastal areas are pinched - in danger of fresh water flooding from within, in danger of high tides from without.

Higher sea levels as a result of global warming, combined with the fact that southern England is sinking by about 30 centimetres a century, means that tides will become more threatening. One pessimistic estimate puts the average sea level rise around the coast of East Anglia at 80cm in 50 years' time.

One of the greatest threats to Britain is a storm surge - a gigantic wave of low pressure sweeping across the Atlantic from Canada and funnelling down the North Sea which raises the ocean by 30cm and sends it crashing into the English east coast. The west coast is vulnerable to similar surges in the Irish Sea.

The surge tide of February 1953 killed more than 300 people in eastern England.

It was to prevent such disasters happening again that defences such as the Thames barrier were built.

Detailed regional studies of climate change impacts across the UK show a patchwork of consequences, some dramatic, some sad, some welcome.

In the south-east, average annual temperatures are expected to increase by 1.2 to 3.4C; winter rainfall to go up by 6%-22%, summer rainfall to drop by 8%-22%.

Tracts of country like the Surrey Hills, Kent's "garden of England" and the Hampshire downs could experience invasion by alien species. Faster coastal erosion will hasten the end for coastal landmarks like Hurst Castle Spit, Selsey Bill and East Head. New crops like grapes, soya, maize, sunflowers and navy beans could spread. Milder weather is good news for species such as the Adonis Blue butterfly, sand lizard and smooth snake; bad for the likes of the mole cricket, marsh gentian and shallow-rooted beech.

In the north-west, 95,000 people, and much of the region's industry and tourism, lie in the coastal plain. Hundreds of miles of sea defences protect them, and local authorities reckon existing and planned new works should keep towns like Morecambe and Blackpool safe for 50 years.

There is concern over biodiversity and wildlife habitats. Mudflats and saltmarshes used by species like the knot, curlew, oystercatcher, pink-footed goose, godwit and sanderling may disappear; in upland areas like the Cumbrian mountains, the Pennines and the Peak District, Arctic species like the arctic char, a fish, and plants such as Alpine Lady's Mantle will be put under pressure. James Meek

Russia

The permafrost - permanently frozen subsoil - which covers 65% of Russia is becoming less permanent. A gradual melting process has already begun in developed areas of Siberia and scientists have warned that if temperatures continue to rise, the southern permafrost frontier could retreat by around 150 miles over the next 25 years.

In places like the diamond-producing town Mirny, in Yakutia, a quarter of the population have been evacuated because their homes, built on permafrost foundations, have begun to slide into the melting soil.

Services along the newer Trans-Siberian railway track have been suspended for days, as parts of the track twist and sink. Roads and bridges have buckled, while oil and gas pipelines have been damaged by the gradual shifting movement. Villagers in the northern extremities of Russia, who have traditionally stored their food in pits cut into the permafrost, have returned to find their stocks destroyed.

Were the upper section of permafrost to melt, scientists believe 12 times the level of CO2 normally in the atmosphere would be released, and 2,500 times the normal level of methane, worsening the greenhouse effect. Amelia Gentleman

China

China sighed with relief this summer because the Yellow River, for the first time since 1997, did not run dry before reaching the sea. But scientists are under no illusions that the threat from climate change is growing.

Nearly 400m people in north China live under conditions of "absolute water scarcity". Hundreds of cities face regular restrictions, with flows as little as one hour a day. The water table on the north China plain is falling by 1.5 metres a year.

Glaciers and lakes have shrunk with alarming speed on the Qinghai-Tibet plateau over the past 15 years. The average annual temperature on the Tuotuo River, one of the Yangtze's three sources, has risen from -4.6C to -3.9C since the 1960s - enough to disturb the critical balance between evaporation and precipitation.

Marshlands are drying up while grasslands disappear. China loses nearly 2,500 sq km of cultivated land annually.

Scientists see the Qinghai-Tibet plateau as an early warning system for the world, and admit that the blame must be shared. Energy consumption has grown by 50% in the past decade and will at least double again by the year 2050. John Gittings

US

The movie horror-fantasy of the sea engulfing east coast cities could become reality this century if nothing is done to halt global warming, scientists believe.

Take, as they project, temperatures increasing by between 1.5C and 6C (2.7F and 11F), causing the sea to expand and rise by as much as 60cm (2ft); add stronger storms and greater precipitation causing more extreme downpours and cities such as New York and Boston might be in jeopardy.

Phenomena already attributed to global warming include: 196,000 hectares (485,000 acres) in Florida burned and 300 homes and other structures destroyed by fires two years ago, and an ice storm that killed 44 in New England the same year.

The other impact is the spread of infectious diseases. West Nile disease, borne by mosquitos, has been identified in the greater New York region, killing about 10 people in the past two summers. Higher temperatures allow insects and rodents that would otherwise have died in the winter to survive and breed.

Cases of malaria have been recorded for the first time in Queens, New York. Michael Ellison

Southern Africa

For some, the massive floods which forced tens of thousands of Mozambicans to seek refuge in trees this year provided the final confirmation that global warming is braced to ravage southern Africa. They fear that climate change will lead to prolonged drought and widespread food shortages. What rain does fall will evaporate faster. There are signs of dessication in Botswana, South Africa and Zimbabwe, while water consumption in the cities continues to rise sharply.

In the 1990s, southern Africa was blighted by two of the five driest years of the 20th century. The result was crop failures and water shortages, starving wildlife and desperate humans. Drought hit Zambia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique and South Africa.

Global warming is also being blamed for the spread of mosquitoes carrying malaria, dengue and yellow fever to parts previously untouched by such diseases. Malaria, which already kills 2m people a year in Africa, is reaching higher altitudes, where people have little resistance to the disease. Chris McGreal

Japan

The people of Japan live with volcanoes, earthquakes, typhoons and tidal waves. But global warming could make previous disasters pale into insignificance, forcing 15m people out of their homes and punching a £2.4 trillion hole in the world's second biggest economy.

Japan is at particular risk, says the national institute for environmental studies (NIES), because most of its population and resources are concentrated in the narrow and exposed strip of coastline between Tokyo and Osaka. The greatest threat is posed to the capital, where millions live below sea level or on reclaimed land that will be engulfed if the worst fears of scientists are realised.

Shuzo Nishioka, head of NIES, predicts that a one-metre rise in sea level would force millions from the coastal plains into the mountains, which make up 70% of the country's land mass.

Health problems would increase along with the rising temperatures, which would suck Japan into the malaria zone and push up cases of heat stroke and food poisoning. Jonathan Watts

But scientists are under no illusions that the threat from climate change is growing. Nearly 400m people in north China live under conditions of "absolute water scarcity". Hundreds of cities face regular restrictions, with flows as little as one hour a day. The water table on the north China plain is falling by 1.5 metres a year. Glaciers and lakes have shrunk with alarming speed on the Qinghai-Tibet plateau over the past 15 years. The average annual temperature on the Tuotuo River, one of the Yangtze's three sources, has risen from -4.6C to -3.9C since the 1960s - enough to disturb the critical balance between evaporation and precipitation. Marshlands are drying up while grasslands disappear. China loses nearly 2,500 sq km of cultivated land annually. Scientists see the Qinghai-Tibet plateau as an early warning system for the world, and admit that the blame must be shared. Energy consumption has grown by 50% in the past decade and will at least double again by the year 2050. John Gittings US The movie horror-fantasy of the sea engulfing east coast cities could become reality this century if nothing is done to halt global warming, scientists believe. Take, as they project, temperatures increasing by between 1.5C and 6C (2.7F and 11F), causing the sea to expand and rise by as much as 60cm (2ft); add stronger storms and greater precipitation causing more extreme downpours and cities such as New York and Boston might be in jeopardy. Phenomena already attributed to global warming include: 196,000 hectares (485,000 acres) in Florida burned and 300 homes and other structures destroyed by fires two years ago, and an ice storm that killed 44 in New England the same year. The other impact is the spread of infectious diseases. West Nile disease, borne by mosquitos, has been identified in the greater New York region, killing about 10 people in the past two summers. Higher temperatures allow insects and rodents that would otherwise have died in the winter to survive and breed. Cases of malaria have been recorded for the first time in Queens, New York. Michael Ellison Southern Africa For some, the massive floods which forced tens of thousands of Mozambicans to seek refuge in trees this year provided the final confirmation that global warming is braced to ravage southern Africa. They fear that climate change will lead to prolonged drought and widespread food shortages. What rain does fall will evaporate faster. There are signs of dessication in Botswana, South Africa and Zimbabwe, while water consumption in the cities continues to rise sharply. In the 1990s, southern Africa was blighted by two of the five driest years of the 20th century. The result was crop failures and water shortages, starving wildlife and desperate humans. Drought hit Zambia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique and South Africa. Global warming is also being blamed for the spread of mosquitoes carrying malaria, dengue and yellow fever to parts previously untouched by such diseases. Malaria, which already kills 2m people a year in Africa, is reaching higher altitudes, where people have little resistance to the disease. Chris McGreal Japan The people of Japan live with volcanoes, earthquakes, typhoons and tidal waves. But global warming could make previous disasters pale into insignificance, forcing 15m people out of their homes and punching a £2.4 trillion hole in the world's second biggest economy. Japan is at particular risk, says the national institute for environmental studies (NIES), because most of its population and resources are concentrated in the narrow and exposed strip of coastline between Tokyo and Osaka. The greatest threat is posed to the capital, where millions live below sea level or on reclaimed land that will be engulfed if the worst fears of scientists are realised. Shuzo Nishioka, head of NIES, predicts that a one-metre rise in sea level would force millions from the coastal plains into the mountains, which make up 70% of the country's land mass. Health problems would increase along with the rising temperatures, which would suck Japan into the malaria zone and push up cases of heat stroke and food poisoning. Jonathan Watts

webTitle: Hewlett Packard humbled

fields.headline: Hewlett Packard humbled
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Carly Fiorina, Hewlett Packard's high-profile chief executive officer, was in the media spotlight at the Comdex computer trade show yesterday only hours after her company announced disappointing financial results.
fields.byline: Jack Schofield  in Las Vegas  and Jane Martinson
fields.body:
Carly Fiorina, Hewlett Packard's high-profile chief executive officer, was in the media spotlight at the Comdex computer trade show yesterday only hours after her company announced disappointing financial results.

"We got the bottom line wrong," she admitted while giving a keynote speech, then quipped: "Is a CEO allowed to ask for a recount?"

The company's fourth-quarter revenues climbed 16.7% to $13.3bn but profits came in nearly 20% below expectations at $922m.

HP also unnerved investors by unexpectedly calling off its planned $18bn acquisition of PricewaterhouseCoopers' consulting arm. The news sent HP's share price tumbling more than 15% to an 18-month low.

Before her Comdex speech, Ms Fiorina, who is also HP's chairman and president, said she was "very disappointed" to have missed financial targets "due to the confluence of a number of issues that we now understand and are urgently addressing. I accept full responsibility for the shortfall".

The decision to call off the PwC deal came after investors objected to the company's first major acquisition since Ms Fiorina took over in July 1999.

In a statement she said: "We are disappointed that we have not been able to reach a mutually acceptable agreement to acquire PwC's consulting business."

She blamed "the current market environment" for her inability to pull off a deal she announced just two months ago. "I am unwilling to subject the HP organisation to the continuing distraction of pursuing this acquisition any further," she said.

The company said yesterday that it still wanted to expand its consulting business "aggressively".

Last month Ms Fiorina told a conference in San Francisco: "The best way to accelerate our growth is through the acquisition of a premier consultancy".

In her speech yesterday to several thousand Comdex visitors, Ms Fiorina compared the growth of the internet to the Renaissance and said it was ushering in a new world of e-services: "a new model of computing based on where you are and what you want".

One example she cited was an HP printer cartridge that could order a replacement when it was running out of ink. The technology did not have to be smart, just "smart enough".

Many or perhaps most e-services would be supplied to people on the move. Ms Fiorina said HP had been studying trends in Tokyo, Singapore and Helsinki.

"Here in North America, we think we're a mobile culture, but if you go to Tokyo or Helsinki it's clear we're not," she said.

She said HP was entering into partnership with Nokia, Finland's mobile phone group, to enable web pages and other internet information to be printed mobile links.

Ms Fiorina said it was not enough to invent new technologies; companies had to find new markets. HP's "e-inclusion programme" would help open up the "untapped market of 4bn people" in the world who do not have access to information technology. "It is an extraordinary opportunity."

webTitle: Oftel boosts unmetered access

fields.headline: Oftel boosts unmetered access
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The widespread availability of unmetered internet access moved closer yesterday after British Telecom was ordered to change the way it charges rival operators for using its network.
fields.body:
The widespread availability of unmetered internet access moved closer yesterday after British Telecom was ordered to change the way it charges rival operators for using its network.

From February BT will be forced to stop billing internet service providers on a pence-per-minute rate if they want to offer their customers an unmetered service. BT introduced a flat-rate wholesale product from the home to the local exchange earlier this year but the cost of then carrying the call to the rival's network was still metered.

Rival operators have argued that the metered element undermined efforts to launch profitable unmetered services in Britain - leading to several false starts and a number of heavy users being thrown off unmetered packages.

Analysts estimate that the prices consumers pay will fall from £15 to £10 a month as a result of the introduction of a completely flat-rate wholesale product.

The ruling was welcomed by internet service providers. "It's very good news," said a spokesman for AOL, which has over 1m customers in Britain. "It's the last piece of the jigsaw that's needed to deliver unmetered internet to the UK. Oftel is to be applauded for this."

Oftel warned however that BT will need to invest in its network to cope with the extra traffic encouraged by unmetered access.

The volume of internet traffic on BT's network is doubling every 10 months and parts are in danger of reaching capacity as early as next year without additional monies.

Initially, the amount of traffic BT is obliged to carry under the new pricing agreement will be limited to ensure the network is not choked. The restriction is expected to be lifted by January 2002.

David Edmonds, Oftel director general said: "These proposals will give a boost to the availability of unmetered internet access for consumers. They should allow millions of people to have unlimited access to the internet without running up high call charges.

webTitle: Gates mixes soft talk and hard hitting

fields.headline: Gates mixes soft talk and hard hitting
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: He may have taken a drubbing from the US justice department, but the champ came out jabbing. Unlike Lennox Lewis, who strutted his stuff the night before, Bill Gates lasted 90 minutes without getting booed.
fields.body:
He may have taken a drubbing from the US justice department, but the champ came out jabbing. Unlike Lennox Lewis, who strutted his stuff the night before, Bill Gates lasted 90 minutes without getting booed.

More than 10,000 people turned up to see Microsoft's chief software architect give his traditional opening keynote speech at the Comdex computer trade show on Sunday. Previously the event was held in a hotel conference centre, leading to long queues and a scramble for tickets. This time it was in the huge MGM Garden Arena, where acts such as Bruce Springsteen and Carlos Santana are more customary fare.

Like them, Mr Gates gave his fans what they came for: glimpses of products that will not appear for a couple of years.

The most interesting was "the tablet": a slim, flat-screen PC that not only recognises handwriting but also lets users insert words and move phrases around in the same way that text is handled by a word processor. This includes the facility to change upright handwriting into slanted italic and the use of "shape recognition technology" to clean up drawings.

The tablet was running the next version of Microsoft's Windows 2000 operating system, codenamed Whistler after the Canadian ski resort.

Mr Gates' string of helpers included Dave Lauren, son of Ralph Lauren, plugging Polo.com, the fashionwear company's new website. Mr Lauren introduced the idea of "merchantainment", which he ominously defined as "a combination of merchandising and entertainment".

As well as flogging future products, Mr Gates' speech had a message. "The browser approach that has dominated the past five years was great, but it's really starting to show its age," he said. It was time to move on to a system based on powerful software rather than dumb software and powerful hardware.

This was a jibe at Sun Microsystems, a Silicon Valley company that sells large servers and recommends basing all software on web browsers which can run independently of Microsoft operating systems.

Mr Gates pulled no punches, saying this was a "big iron view" of computing, based on a "stupid client model". The future required a more balanced approach typified, unsurprisingly, by Microsoft's ".Net" strategy.

However, Mr Gates was careful not to appear too devoted to the PC. He showed Microsoft's smart phone, codenamed Stinger, which has "the full power of the Pocket PC built in", and referred to Microsoft's huge investments in WebTV and television set-top boxes, and in the Xbox games console, due next year.

He did not complain about Microsoft's share price, which has taken a beating in the past year, wiping about $40bn off his paper fortune.

Referring mainly to the shake-out in internet stocks generally, Mr Gates said it was probably a good step to have a little bit of sanity in the market.

webTitle: £25m cybercop squad to tackle internet crime

fields.headline: £25m cybercop squad to tackle internet crime
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The growing tide of internet crime, including hacking, porn rackets, extortion and fraud, is to be tackled by a squad of "cybercops" set up in a £25m initiative announced by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday.
fields.body:
The growing tide of internet crime, including hacking, porn rackets, extortion and fraud, is to be tackled by a squad of "cybercops" set up in a £25m initiative announced by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday.

The unit will be headed by 80 officers recruited from the police, customs service, national crime squad and national criminal intelligence service.

Home Office money is also being provided to help fund a 24-hour international hotline for detectives from different countries to "trade information on potential attacks on the national infrastructure".

The initiative follows intelligence that shows terrorists are increasingly using the internet for recruitment and planning.

Internet crime has soared in the last three years as criminals have begun to realise the opportunities it offers.

The dissemination of computer viruses, such as the I Love You bug, which wreaked havoc last summer, is also on the rise. Medium sized businesses are particularly vulnerable to these kinds of attacks because they cannot afford protective filtering systems. Recent research showed that 60% of Britain's online businesses have suffered hacking.

Worrying new trends include evidence of an international internet trade in body parts, including kidneys.

Announcing the creation of the unit yesterday, Mr Straw said the government was "committed to action against hi-tech crime ... making the UK the best and safest place in the world to conduct and engage in e-commerce."

"Modern technologies such as the internet offer huge legitimate benefits, but also powerful opportunities for criminals, from those involved in financial fraud to the activities of paedophiles," he said.

John Abbott, director general of NCIS, said: "Cybercrime ignores borders, be they regional, national or international. Our approach therefore has to be holistic."

Mr Straw also announced £37m for a national information management system for police forces in England and Wales.The new system will allow police intelligence reports to be compared and analysed centrally.

webTitle: Bulger pair 'could die if identities revealed'

fields.headline: Bulger pair 'could die if identities revealed'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: The killers of two-year-old James Bulger are at real risk of reprisals which could threaten their lives if their whereabouts and new identities are revealed, the high court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
The killers of two-year-old James Bulger are at real risk of reprisals which could threaten their lives if their whereabouts and new identities are revealed, the high court was told yesterday.

Lawyers for Jon Venables and Robert Thompson asked Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the family division, for unprecedented lifetime injunctions preventing the media from disclosing information which would identify them.

Mr Fitzgerald said James's father had vowed to hunt his son's killers down. "Taken in context, it is abundantly clear what he intends to do when he hunts them down." There was also a declared intention by the media to "out" the pair.

Ralph Bulger said yesterday: "James had the right to live, the right to grow old, to love and be loved and to have children of his own. But they took his rights away from him and so they should have no rights at all, never mind the right to privacy or the right to hide away."

Thompson and Venables, now 18, could be released early next year after a ruling by the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, that their tariff - the minimum term for punishment and deterrence - expired last month. They will be given new identities when they leave the local authority secure units where they have been detained at her majesty's pleasure after battering James to death on a railway line in Liverpool in February 1993.

Edward Fitzgerald QC, for Venables, told Dame Elizabeth that under the Human Rights Act, which came into force last month, the injunction was justified to protect their right to life and to freedom from inhuman and degrading treatment, which could be threatened by revenge attacks.

Mr Fitzgerald said the injunction also banned anyone publishing anything about the boys' whereabouts or their assumed identities when they are released. "Disclosure of that information would expose him [Venables] and his co-detainee to serious physical risk and serious psychological fear and the likelihood of harassment. It is necessary to protect his right to life and freedom from persecution ."

His argument was backed by the attorney general, in his role as guardian of the public interest. The home secretary and the official solicitor also support the application for a media ban, which is opposed by three newspaper groups.

There is no precedent for granting an injunction to protect the identity of an adult killer on release. Mary Bell, who served 12 years in custody for killing two small children in 1968 when she was 11, won an injunction after her release to protect her daughter, who was made a ward of court.

Mr Fitzgerald stressed that the case was highly unusual and would not necessarily set a precedent. "There are a number of unique features about this case - their extreme youth at the time and the special nature of the detention and the very extreme nature of the risk."

He did not refer to adult killers such as Myra Hindley, but it would be equally open to them to argue that their lives would be endangered by a media free-for-all on their release. Dame Elizabeth asked whether the argument would apply to adult paedophiles at risk of vigilante attacks. Mr Fitzgerald replied: "I do not wish to compromise the position of those who represent paedophiles at serious risk of life or limb."

He also argued that a ban was justified under the law on confidentiality and to protect the pair's right of privacy under the European convention on human rights. The court has to balance the right to privacy against the media's right of free speech under the convention.

Mr Fitzgerald said Desmond Browne QC, for Associated Newspapers, the Mirror Group and News Group, would argue that there was no need for an injunction because the press could be reported to the Press Complaints Council if it overstepped the mark. To argue that the press could be relied on to act responsibly and that any remedy could be sought after the event was "not good enough".

The hearing was adjourned until this afternoon.

webTitle: Schools fight to stop deportation of Chinese children

fields.headline: Schools fight to stop deportation of Chinese children
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Three children who are due to be deported by the Home Office tomorrow have been told by their headteachers to turn up for school as normal.
fields.body:
Three children who are due to be deported by the Home Office tomorrow have been told by their headteachers to turn up for school as normal.

The failure of legal efforts to stop the deportation of Miao Hong Su, 16, and her brothers Jing, 14 and Zhao, 11, has left teachers clinging to the hope that by keeping them in school, they will be able protect the children from seizure. The schools hope that the authorities will realise that it would be too traumatic to remove the children in front of fellow pupils.

The children, two at Astley high school and one at Lyndhurst primary school in Dukinfield, Greater Manchester, fled to England with their father in 1989, after the Tiananmen Square massacre. Lian Hu Su works as a chef and applied for refugee status on the grounds that he could be murdered for his role in sheltering students of the Chinese pro-democracy protest.

But the Home Office ruled against his application and started deportation proceedings, undeterred by protests from the children's schools and letters of appeal from their fellow pupils.

John Mayes, headteacher of Astley high, said: "I have just spoken to the children and they are very anxious. We have posted another petition to Barbara Roche [Home Office minister], and the family solicitor, George Brown, has put in an appeal via the Human Rights Act. But it's a wing and a prayer job. I'm far from hopeful about the legal challenge."

Since they joined his school five years ago speaking little English, Miao Hong and Jing have risen from the bottom 2% of their peer group to somewhere near the top. Jing's teachers believe that he is on course for eight good grades at GCSE. At Lyndhurst primary school, his brother Zhao is said to be well above average.

"What these children have been through over the past six years is emotional abuse," said his headteacher, Dai Williams.

Mr Mayes added: "These are quiet and at times very introspective children, who don't like to be at the centre of attention. They have been subjected to emotional trauma month in month out."

Miao Hong is due to sit her mock GCSE exams in two weeks. Her headteacher said: "She is revising without knowing whether she will even be here to take the tests."

The children, two at Astley high school and one at Lyndhurst primary school in Dukinfield, Greater Manchester, fled to England with their father in 1989, after the Tiananmen Square massacre. Lian Hu Su works as a chef and applied for refugee status on the grounds that he could be murdered for his role in sheltering students of the Chinese pro-democracy protest. But the Home Office ruled against his application and started deportation proceedings, undeterred by protests from the children's schools and letters of appeal from their fellow pupils. John Mayes, headteacher of Astley high, said: "I have just spoken to the children and they are very anxious. We have posted another petition to Barbara Roche [Home Office minister], and the family solicitor, George Brown, has put in an appeal via the Human Rights Act. But it's a wing and a prayer job. I'm far from hopeful about the legal challenge." Since they joined his school five years ago speaking little English, Miao Hong and Jing have risen from the bottom 2% of their peer group to somewhere near the top. Jing's teachers believe that he is on course for eight good grades at GCSE. At Lyndhurst primary school, his brother Zhao is said to be well above average. "What these children have been through over the past six years is emotional abuse," said his headteacher, Dai Williams. Mr Mayes added: "These are quiet and at times very introspective children, who don't like to be at the centre of attention. They have been subjected to emotional trauma month in month out." Miao Hong is due to sit her mock GCSE exams in two weeks. Her headteacher said: "She is revising without knowing whether she will even be here to take the tests."

webTitle: RSPCA defends ban on pro-hunt lobby bar at court

fields.headline: RSPCA defends ban on pro-hunt lobby bar at court
fields.standfirst:
Contest over membership moves to high court

Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Hunt supporters, led by the Olympic equestrian medallist Richard Meade, will this week challenge plans to refuse them membership of the RSPCA, the world's most venerable animal welfare charity.
fields.body:
Hunt supporters, led by the Olympic equestrian medallist Richard Meade, will this week challenge plans to refuse them membership of the RSPCA, the world's most venerable animal welfare charity.

The high court is to rule on who can join the society in the latest battle over the RSPCA's 24-year policy of opposing hunting with dogs.

The society recently claimed it was a victim of entryism by Mr Meade's Countryside Animal Welfare Group. Since the group urged its supporters to join the RSPCA, 600 applications for membership have been suspended.

At the hearing, which begins today, Mr Meade will contest the society's efforts to adopt sweeping powers to decide membership.

Among nine categories specified by the RSPCA as a bar to joining the society, an individual membership can be turned down if the application is from the same family or address, or even same area, as that of a CAWG supporter.

Senior figures in the society have privately accused CAWG of attempting a coup, but Mr Meade, who won show jumping gold medals at the 1968 Mexico and 1972 Munich Olympics, denies the allegation and maintains that CAWG was formed by those in rural areas who believe the RSPCA had "lost its way".

The former chairman of the International Equestrian Federation, who faces expulsion from the RSPCA if the society wins the case, accused the society of acting like a cult, requiring members and would-be members to sign up for every existing policy. He denied entryism and said CAWG had no membership list; it instead relied on its supporters to reveal whether or not they were in the RSPCA.

"The society appears to be intolerant, almost afraid of having a debate. I would have thought that it is basically wrong to exclude people who are genuinely interested in animal welfare. If people behave sensibly, are responsible and caring, then I think it is an extraordinary thing to exclude them from membership," said Mr Meade.

Farmers, anglers and others are under-represented in the RSPCA, argues CAWG, which wants to alter the society's opposition to the sale of livestock at markets and its concerns over the "infliction of pain and suffering on fish" as well as its campaign for a ban on hunting with dogs.

The RSPCA is governed by a 1932 act of parliament and has 750,000 registered supporters, but its policies are determined by 55,000 members who pay £17.50 a year (£25 for couples) for the right to vote at the annual meeting. The charity has been the focus of an organised campaign in the past. Fifteen years ago anti-vivisectionists tried to persuade it to take a tougher line against animal tests in laboratories.

The decision to put 600 membership applications on hold, CAWG claims, has already thrown up a series of anomalies, including the acceptance of a woman with an urban address in Swindon when her sister with a more rural address in Cirencester was refused.

The RSPCA says it will admit individuals who support hunting but not those from organised groups.

"We are seeking to deal in a general way with membership drives that might be damaging to the society - that is campaigns by groups to encourage their members to join the society in order to further their own aims rather than the society's aims," said an RSPCA spokeswoman.

David Jagger, a Shrewsbury vet who also hunts, had his application blocked despite being occasionally employed by the RSPCA, most recently to treat an injured cat. "On the one hand I am suitable to work for the RSPCA and on the other hand I am deemed not suitable for membership of the RSPCA," said Mr Jagger. "I support a lot of the society's aims and feel they have been unfair to me."

webTitle: Railtrack raises dividend

fields.headline: Railtrack raises dividend
fields.standfirst:
Anger as company rewards shareholders amid passenger chaos

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack, the company responsible for Britain's tracks and stations, yesterday provoked widespread fury by increasing its dividend at a time when its emergency repair work following the Hatfield train crash has created disruption for rail travellers.
fields.body:
Railtrack, the company responsible for Britain's tracks and stations, yesterday provoked widespread fury by increasing its dividend at a time when its emergency repair work following the Hatfield train crash has created disruption for rail travellers.

The company's chief executive, Gerald Corbett, said the 5% dividend rise was a signal to shareholders that better times were ahead.

The move came at the same time as Railtrack announced that it was trying to negotiate the end of late running penalties which were costing it £60m a year.

Mr Corbett said that first half pre-tax profits had fallen 31% to £175m, and that the second half results would be hit by a £250m exceptional charge as a result of measures taken since last month's Hatfield train crash, in which four people died.

He said the one-off charge would be made up of £100m for the inspection and relaying of track since the crash, and £150m to compensate the 27 train operating companies for disrupted services. The £150m figure is likely to be challenged by the operators who are seeking about £330m . They claim that the Railtrack figure does not take account of the 20% rise in passenger traffic over the last six years.

George Muir, director general of the Association of Train Operating Companies, said any money received would be used to compensate passengers for delays and to make up for lost revenue.

Railtrack said the dividend increase was an important signal to shareholders of better times to come. Finance director Steve Marshall said shareholders would carry the burden of the £250m charge, and the company needed to be in a financial position to raise money for future investment.

Mick Rix, general secretary of the train drivers' union Aslef, said: "We find it extraordinary that the Railtrack board, while presiding over a shambles unprecedented in the railway industry, should feel that this is the moment to increase rewards to their shareholders rather than putting extra money into maintenance and other investment."

The train operators have yet to decide how travellers will be compensated. Season ticket holders may be offered free days of travel.

Mr Corbett said that the task of inspecting 3,000 miles of track and relaying about 250 miles of rail would be largely completed by Christmas, though disruption was likely to continue well into the new year on five main inter-city lines.

During the first half, passenger train delays caused by Railtrack increased by 10%, against the rail regulator's target of an 8% reduction. The company said the scale of its investment and safety programme had "affected its ability to deliver" on the performance target, resulting in penalty payments to the operators.

It is trying to persuade the regulator to abandon the target so the £60m it pays each year in penalties could be invested in the business.

"We need surplus financial capacity so that we can get out there and borrow more," Mr Marshall said. "Onerous efficiency targets mean we will not have as much confidence to commit."

James Sherwood, president of transport and leisure group Sea Containers, which operates the GNER franchise, described Railtrack as "the track authority whose delivery of track, signalling and stations has been less than perfect". It was a GNER train which came off the lines at Hatfield.

Railtrack shares closed 10p down at 970p.

webTitle: The twisted logic of Corbett-land

fields.headline: The twisted logic of Corbett-land
fields.standfirst:
Railtrack's insult to the City
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: 'Due to this being a Sunday service on a clapped out line, the 14.08 from London Waterloo to Portsmouth will remain at platform 3, Woking, for a further 12 minutes, so that we can meet the new timetable which has been introduced to take into account likely engineering works on this route, which are not happening today due to staff shortages."
fields.body:
'Due to this being a Sunday service on a clapped out line, the 14.08 from London Waterloo to Portsmouth will remain at platform 3, Woking, for a further 12 minutes, so that we can meet the new timetable which has been introduced to take into account likely engineering works on this route, which are not happening today due to staff shortages."

"Connex would like to apologise to passengers expecting the buffet car on this service to be open. This is due to incorrect information being posted on the departure board at Waterloo and is not the responsibility of Connex."

"Pre-tax profits at Railtrack have fallen by 30% - and you know why - but we've decided to increase the dividend by 5% in support of the fact that we have declared a progressive dividend policy and, hell, this is a growth business, don't you know? Broken rails were down by a staggering 32% in the six months to end-September, while the incidence of signals passed at danger was chopped 30%."

These quotes are not verbatim, but they give a flavour of the British railway industry over recent years. It is a surreal world where all the usual connotations of "customer", "shareholder", "risk", "capital provider" and the like are mangled beyond recognition.

If the story was not so grim, the children's author Roger Hargreaves might consider it as a (late) addition to the Little Miss book series. Mr Corbett decided to put on his best suit. Today he was going to visit Lord Macdonald, who'd had a very bad trip and complained to Mr Prescott . . .

On the face of things, Railtrack seemed to have decided to use yesterday's interim figures announcement as an opportunity to treat everyone as children: being ready to take the public relations hit associated with increasing the payout to shareholders during a time when the network has been close to shut-down, simply in order to give a signal to the City that Railtrack is a serious investment proposition is offensive - to the City.

Institutional investors can see the billions of public money due to be poured into the industry. They can make their own minds up about whether this particular company is a "growth stock". (And, yes, shares in Railtrack are up 70% over eight months.)

But then drop back into Mr Corbett land, where the trains are delayed to meet timetables and the toilets closed due to overuse, and things become a little clearer. Railtrack is like the hopeless debtor who wants to make his interest payments on time so that he can borrow more money. This company is coming to the capital markets sometime after January, and its references are looking a bit suspect - hence the dividend increase. It wants to be treated as a "normal" utility, and a progressive dividend policy is one of the boxes that needs a tick.

Of course, those in the private sector brave enough to back the future of rail in Britain with real investment next year, will get something tangible for their money - share certificates, convertible bonds, or another form of ownership. On the other hand, the dividend due to the British taxpayer for the many billions paid over and promised in future can only be measured in macro-economic and environmental intangibles.

Why this is happening is not immediately clear. It must be assumed that Railtrack would not mind the government underwriting a mammoth rights issue which, say, resulted in a 30% holding. Other shareholders might be heartened by such a show of support.

But then, on transport especially, this government is not so sure where either its loyalties or its ideologies lie. In raw capitalist economies such as Hong Kong, the government feels no compunction in stepping in to the stock market to support prices. In Britain, to the Labour government, such a move would feel just a little too much like partial nationalisation. On the other hand, partial-ownership might bring responsibility just a little too close to bear.

Aerial farce

It seemed to be like a licence to print money by selling air - and for a while it was. Auctioning spectrum to mobile phone companies began so spectacularly but has become stuck deep in the mire.

Italy reached a conclusion after three days of bidding, the Dutch and the Austrians suspect bidders of colluding to keep the prices down. And now the Swiss auction descends into farce.

Britain going first when the mobile phone companies were still feeling flush with cash and staging an auction at the top of the market to raise £24.5bn now looks extremely prescient, or extremely lucky.

webTitle: Girl 'stretched' in £12,000 operation

fields.headline: Girl 'stretched' in £12,000 operation
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The surgeon who helped to "stretch" a teenager who was too short to achieve her ambition of becoming an air hostess yesterday defended the £12,000 NHS surgery.
fields.body:
The surgeon who helped to "stretch" a teenager who was too short to achieve her ambition of becoming an air hostess yesterday defended the £12,000 NHS surgery.

Emma Richards, 16, of Wadebridge, Cornwall, is back in hospital for the fourth time after an operation in January which has lengthened her legs by 5in so far. Before surgery she measured just 4ft 9in.

But yesterday the consultant orthopaedic surgeon, Darren Fern, of the Royal Cornwall hospital, Treliske, Truro, said the operation had not been done for cosmetic or career reasons but so that Emma could live a normal life.

"Emma was not just a little bit short, she was very short," he said. "When she first came to see me I thought she was a nine-year-old. She is entering adulthood but everybody thinks she is a child.

"She wasn't sure if she would be able to drive a car because she couldn't see over the dashboard. She couldn't turn on a tap, she couldn't reach things in the kitchen."

Around 150 children have undergone the surgery, although Emma is the tallest person he has operated on. "Each case is taken on its individual merits," he said. "Somebody else who is 4ft 9in may be fine, but Emma was not fine about being that height."

The operation would have cost around £4,000, with each day in hospital costing around £180, without complications.

Both Emma's femurs were broken in the six-hour operation and pins used to attach the bones to a metal frame. This was screwed increasingly tightly to stretch her legs, which grew about 1mm a day.

But Emma's left leg broke within two hours of her discharge. She is now in hospital with her third fracture.

Her mother, Irene, said: "We would have tried to do the operation privately if the NHS had not been able to do it."

webTitle: £500m drugs fund to tackle killer diseases

fields.headline: £500m drugs fund to tackle killer diseases
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will today announce a £500m increase in NHS spending over the coming year to tackle cancer and coronary heart disease, the biggest killers.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will today announce a £500m increase in NHS spending over the coming year to tackle cancer and coronary heart disease, the biggest killers.

Allocations for health authorities and NHS trusts in England for 2001-02 will unlock funds to buy new drugs that are expected be approved shortly by the national institute for clinical excellence.

Mr Milburn is expected to say that expansion of cancer and heart treatment will take almost a quarter of the growth in NHS spending next year.

The extra money will be accompanied by the acceleration of targets to reduce waiting times between GP referral and treatment to a maximum of a month. NHS managers will be told to reach this standard next year for all cases of children's cancer, testicular cancer and leukemia.

Today's announcement is not intended to pre-empt decisions on the effectiveness of 13 new cancer drugs. Chemotherapy drugs being investigated by Nice include Irinotecan for colorectal cancer, Paclitaxel (lung), Gemcitabine (pancreatic) and Popotecan (ovarian).

The government is allocating £255m extra for cancer treatment, of which £170m will be reserved for drugs.

There will be £150m more for tackling coronary heart disease, including £50m for statins, betablockers and other drugs for patients recovering from heart attacks. By 2002, 80-90% of discharged heart patients should be taking these drugs.

Other allocations will include £32.5m to reduce smoking. The £500m package does not include capital investment in equipment and buildings, announced previously.

"This is a big increase in resources and we must now see it accompanied by a big improvement for patients," a Department of Health source said.

The allocations will for the first time give health authorities an indication of their budgets over three years instead of just one. They will include £120m targeted at areas with above average premature deaths.

The government's claim to be making progress in reducing waiting times was disputed last night by Health Care Navigator, an independent healthcare company.

It said the average wait for NHS inpatient treatment after referral by a GP increased from 201.2 days in June to 203.8 days in September.

Roger Hymas, its chairman, said: "It is surprising to see that waiting times have increased since June, as the summer is a period in which one would have expected to see some catching up."

Government figures last week showed the number of people waiting for NHS treatment fell by 5,800 to 1,031,800 over the same period. But analysis showed the average wait was lengthening in all regions except London and in all specialities bar general surgery and gynaecology.

fields.headline: Take back the track
fields.standfirst:
Railtrack's profits should be used to bring it back under public control. It's the only way to restore confidence
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The Hatfield disaster is proving to be a double tragedy. Tragic, first and most importantly of all, for those who died and their loved ones. And tragic, too, for the whole future of the railway industry.
fields.body:
The Hatfield disaster is proving to be a double tragedy. Tragic, first and most importantly of all, for those who died and their loved ones. And tragic, too, for the whole future of the railway industry.

Measured by deaths and injuries, the train crashes at Southall in 1997 and Paddington in 1999 were worse. But Hatfield - and the industry's response to it - seem to have been the straw that is at least straining the back of public confidence in our railways.

Aslef, as the trade union representing those who drive the trains, has a vital interest in seeing our industry thrive. That is why we have tried to avoid playing the "blame game" as far as possible. Confidence will be restored only by an industry seen to be working together.

Furthermore, we know all too well that there have always been those ready to blame our members for accidents in the past - an outlook which is not only unfair to train drivers, who are generally the first victims of rail accidents, but which can also distract attention from the underlying problems which the railways need to address.

The one word which I believe sums up those problems today is fragmentation - operational fragmentation and strategic fragmentation.

At the operational level, we are familiar with the split between train-operating companies and Railtrack, a division which often creates day-to-day differences of interest in running the railway.

Still more serious from the safety point of view, however, is the system of contracting, sub-contracting and sub-sub-contracting vital maintenance and repair work on the railways. However well- intentioned that may be, there is a built-in conflict of interest regarding cost and confusion of command regarding responsibility.

At the strategic level, there is now a cacophony of competing voices, most of which were heard in the aftermath of Hatfield - ministers, the rail regulator, the strategic rail authority. And that's before you even get down to anyone involved in running the railway.

It is little wonder that public confidence is ebbing while it is clear that so much is wrong but unclear who is taking responsibility for putting it right.

The situation has been worsened by Railtrack's alarmist behaviour and statements since Hatfield. Closing down lines at a moment's notice (when the previous day they had been regarded as safe) and warning that the railway will not be back to normal for two years creates an impression of panic designed to drive passengers and freight customers back on to the roads.

Likewise, blaming freight trains for the state of the track is not only unwise (how many other businesses would complain about too many customers?) and inaccurate (the Hatfield line, for example, sees very little freight usage) but seems almost designed to undermine the future of the rail-freight industry.

Aslef is arguing for a four-point approach to tackle the immediate crisis:

First, railway safety should be removed from Railtrack and handed over to an independent body without any connections to commercial interests. The present half-way house will not reassure the public, as we warned at the time.

Second, the owner of the railway infrastructure should take direct responsibility for all maintenance work, directly employing and training to the highest standards those working on the track. This will involve a major restructuring in Railtrack's relationship with Balfour Beatty.

Third, urgent help is required by the rail-freight industry. All the potential environmental and economic benefits of a shift in freight from road to rail will be lost if Railtrack is allowed to continue to play havoc with the industry.

Fourth, it is time that Railtrack itself was restored to the public sector. I do not offer this as a point of political dogma but as a practical - and popular - way of overcoming the industry's problems.

It would end the conflict between shareholder interest and public interest. It would be a step towards rebuilding the stronger safety culture which was one of British Rail's better attributes. It would give the taxpayer a measure of control in return for the billions of pounds being pumped into the privatised industry through subsidies.

It would give the railways an accountable management, able to assist in the development of the government's integrated transport strategy. And it would make it clear that the buck stops with elected ministers, who would have the power and authority to direct this vital strategic industry.

The money is already there - billions in public subsidies are already reaching Railtrack by one means or another. Yesterday's increased payouts to shareholders make it clear what the Railtrack board want to do with the money. I believe it could be used to re-establish public control over the company, without putting any strain on other parts of the government budget.

It is time to end the conflict and chaos at the heart of our railways. It is time to take back the track.

Mick Rix is general secretary of Aslef

webTitle: Mayor offers government way out of tube sell-off

fields.headline: Mayor offers government way out of tube sell-off
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The London mayor Ken Livingstone yesterday offered the government "a face saving formula" to withdraw from its plans for part privatisation of London Underground when he asked ministers to let Bob Kiley, the new tube boss, decide if the scheme made sense.
fields.body:
The London mayor Ken Livingstone yesterday offered the government "a face saving formula" to withdraw from its plans for part privatisation of London Underground when he asked ministers to let Bob Kiley, the new tube boss, decide if the scheme made sense.

Mr Livingstone promised he would drop his opposition if Mr Kiley backed the plans.

Speaking in the Commons Mr Livingstone added that Mr Kiley, the foremost expert in mass transit, would be unable to make a proper judgement unless ministers gave him details of contractors' rival bids, as well as an update of comparisons with a public sector service produced last March.

The environment minister Chris Mullin refused to drop plans for part privatisation, but promised that tube management would let Mr Kiley see the public sector figures.

Mr Livingstone released a poll showing 42% of Londoners thought safety would be jeopardised by privatisation.
