fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: ;Distressingly, we must begin with an apology. According to a Sunday Times front-page report ("Dando murder squad interviews PM's spin doctor") inadvertently I caused Alastair Campbell to be pulled by the Bill.
fields.body:
Distressingly, we must begin with an apology. According to a Sunday Times front-page report ("Dando murder squad interviews PM's spin doctor") inadvertently I caused Alastair Campbell to be pulled by the Bill.

No one will wish to dredge up the grievous confusion whereby it came to be written (note the sudden Biblical tone; where did that come from?) that Ali had claimed over lunch to have once been Miss Dando's lover. No such claim was made, either seriously or in jest, as he assured us, and in fiasco terms, this is well up there with Cherie's car pass and the separation of Gordon and Sarah. However (and this doesn't do much for public confidence) the only people unaware of my absolute unreliability appear to be the police - and a detective who saw the item interviewed Alastair before eliminating him from inquiries. I hope no one is amused at the thought of my old friend's face while being questioned because of a cock-up here. I know I don't. In fact I'm very, very sorry about it. Now then, let that be an end to the whole sorry business.

What a marvellous Saturday for Bernard Manning. By the time Channel 4 broadcast its favourable Heroes of Comedy documentary about him, Bernard had already enjoyed a triumph on the football field. Radcliffe Borough, the non-league club run by his son Young Bernard of which he is life president, beat Unibond First Division rivals Burscough 2-1 to qualify for the first round - "first round proper" to use the correct cliche - of the FA Cup. Next Sunday, Bernard will lead them out at Bury's Gig Lane ground, which is being borrowed for the home tie with York City. You'd have thought York had suffered enough, wouldn't you? It'll be boils next. Then locusts.

Last Wednesday, reports the Washington Post, poll worker Gene Tracy, 79, walked into an election HQ in Florida to explain how an entire bag of ballot papers had been left in his car. "I about had a cotton-pickin' stroke," he told a local reporter. "I hollered for my wife and I said, 'The dadburn ballots are still in the car'." Dadburn ballots indeed. Who now will dare accuse the USA of putting its democracy in the hands of rogues, incompetents, fools, and the cast of the Beverly Hillbillies?

Did anyone else hear the New Labour MP for Ealing Stephen Pound on Bryan Hayes's show on Radio 5 Live on Friday night? Blimey, chief, don't say nuffink, nor nuffink, nor not; but straight up, he sounded like the man who answers the phone dahn Boris the Jackal Johnson's manor. That or the character Cockney Wanker out of Viz. Speaking of the dome, for example, Mr Pound referred to a visit there with his wife thus: "I took the Guv'nor to see it, and she was well choked." God spare us from Mockney MPs who think they're comedians. Steve, son, two words in yer shell-like: shut it.

Last week's item about a Reader's Digest executive being approached by a tart provokes Alastair Stirling to write from Glasgow to recall "a gag so old it needs carbon dating" about a Church of Scotland minister who was tired after a long train journey "and made his way up from Central Station and over Blythswood Square. From the shadows a voice was heard: 'Hello there darlin', d'ye fancy super sex?' To which the minister replied: 'Just the soup thanks. I'm absolutely starving'."

We began with inquiring police, and so must we end. In the Austrian town of Graz, detectives seek a fake nurse inevitably known as the "Angel of Mercy" for her habit of sneaking into hospital wards late at night and having sex with male patients who are seriously ill, preferably in a coma. Eleven incidents in five hospitals have been noted this year. "She believes she's doing the patients a favour," says Bernard Kaiser of the Graz police. "But it's disrespectful."

webTitle: Russian media war hots up as mogul faces new charges

fields.headline: Russian media war hots up as mogul faces new charges
fields.standfirst:
Interpol asked to track down tycoon who is believed to be in London
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The prolonged battle for control of Russia's largest privately held media group intensified yesterday when a new warrant was issued for the arrest of the Media-Most group head, Vladimir Gusinsky.
fields.body:
The prolonged battle for control of Russia's largest privately held media group intensified yesterday when a new warrant was issued for the arrest of the Media-Most group head, Vladimir Gusinsky.

Mr Gusinsky - whose brief imprisonment earlier this year fuelled international concern about the future of press freedoms in Russia - ignored a prosecutor's summons to a Moscow court yesterday and was charged with embezzlement in his absence.

Russia's deputy prosecutor general said that Interpol would be asked to track down the tycoon, who is thought to be in London.

The timing of the warrant bewildered analysts, coming just hours after Media-Most announced a long-awaited decision to hand over a chunk of its shares to the largely state-controlled natural gas monopoly, Gazprom, to which Media-Most owes £147m.

Earlier this year, President Vladimir Putin's media minister had ensured that similar criminal charges against Mr Gusinsky were dropped in return for his agreement to hand Gazprom control of his media empire - encompassing the influential NTV television station, Echo Moscow radio and the Sevodnya daily newspaper, all critical of the Kremlin. Yesterday's arrest warrant came despite the fact that the share dispute appeared to have been resolved in the Kremlin's favour.

Mr Gusinsky made no comment on the case, but Dmitry Ostalsky, a Media-Most spokesman, said he was perplexed by the events: "It's rather strange that prosecutors have charged Mr Gusinksy now, after Media-Most reached an agreement with Gazprom."

Precise details of the agreement were not available, and are expected to emerge only after the deal has been approved in court either today or tomorrow. Mr Ostalsky revealed only that Media-Most would transfer some of its shares to repay its debts to Gazprom.

Although Mr Ostalsky would not say what percentage this represented of the total company, he added that Gazprom would not have a controlling stake in Media-Most. He said that the agreement would not change the editorial policy of the media group, nor would it lead to any dismissals.

Campaigners for press freedom were not reassured, however. "It won't happen overnight, but I have no doubt that over the next few months there will be a softening of Media-Most's editorial line. It is extremely worrying," said Ruslan Gorevoi of the Glasnost Defence Foundation.

Mr Gusinsky's lawyer, Genri Reznik, said his client had no intention of returning to Russia and facing a second arrest. "He does not want to become the victim of arbitrary persecution and cause further suffering to those close to him," Mr Reznik said outside the Moscow court.

The exact charges against Mr Gusinsky were also unclear because prosecutors refused to divulge them in his absence; it is thought he stands accused of misrepresenting Media-Most assets when he accepted bank loans of more than £210m, which were guaranteed by Gazprom. Prosecutors said that the group was bankrupt at the time. Media-Most officials deny the claim.

The tangled Media-Most saga has dragged on since the spring and has been interpreted as an unsettling example of Mr Putin's determination to grasp control of unruly media outlets.

A few weeks after masked paramilitaries raided his Moscow offices, Mr Gusinsky was held for four days in June on charges of defrauding the state in a privatisation deal. The charges were later dropped after an agreement - signed by the media minister, Mikhail Lesin - stipulated that a criminal investigation into Mr Gusinsky would be abandoned and a travel ban lifted in exchange for the proposed Gazprom takeover of Media-Most.

A new outcry was triggered in September when Mr Gusinsky revealed details of the deal, which he claimed he was forced to sign, prompting the former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev to accuse the government of "crude blackmail".

Gazprom maintains that it sought the share handover to allow it to resell its assets in the group to foreign investors, and then recoup the money owed after Media-Most defaulted on its loans.

 Mr Putin indicated yesterday that he was prepared to cut back nuclear warheads to a greater extent than previously indicated, as Russia appeared to shift away from an outright rejection of America's anti-missile plans.

The commander of Russia's strategic missile forces, Colonel-General Vladimir Yakovlev, said it would be extremely difficult to persuade America to abandon its plans for a national missile defence system.

Mr Putin took up the general's lead, saying Russia was prepared to enter into new negotiations, and might be ready to go beyond the previously offered cuts of 1,500 nuclear warheads on each side.

Mr Putin is set to meet President Bill Clinton for the last time during the US leader's presidency later this week at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation group meeting in Brunei.

webTitle: Call for tougher arms export rules

fields.headline: Call for tougher arms export rules
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Procedures designed to control arms exports to prevent them getting into the "wrong hands" are riddled with loopholes, Amnesty International and Oxfam say in a report to be released later this month.
fields.body:
Procedures designed to control arms exports to prevent them getting into the "wrong hands" are riddled with loopholes, Amnesty International and Oxfam say in a report to be released later this month.

Official figures show that 81 export licences for military equipment have been issued for the Channel Islands, yet there is no recorded information about the physical movement of goods to the islands.

Parliamentary questions established that some of the exports were insignificant - one reference, to "machine guns", was said to mean only a single gun tripod for a museum.

However, the lack of information shows that "conditions exist for an offshore, export black hole" whereby a seemingly non-sensitive dependent territory could be used to channel arms to undesirable end-users, says the report, entitled Destination Unknown. It is known that a number of arms dealers are based in the Channel Islands.

End-use certificates do not legally bind the recipients, the report points out. Last year, for instance, the head of the Indonesian armed forces admitted that a British-supplied Hawk plane flew over East Timor's capital, Dili, despite assurances given by Indonesia to the UK government that the jets would not be used there.

The report urges the government to require embassies to verify end-use documents relating to UK weapons exports. There should be a legal obligation stating that equipment specified in end-use certificates was not used in violation of international humanitarian or human rights law.

Arms suppliers, it says, must be responsible for the delivery of arms to the stated end-user. A list of "undesirable end-users" should be published, annual reports on arms exports should be specific, and parliament should scrutinise arms export licence applications.

webTitle: Sketch

fields.headline: Enter Mayor Ken, signalling trouble ahead
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Sketch  by Simon Hoggart
fields.body:
The Mayor of London made a rare visit to the Commons yesterday, in order to denounce the new system for funding the tube.

This is the public-private partnership, a bizarre new arrangement modelled on the way the Tories privatised the railways, only more complicated. It's been operating as a "shadow" system since April, since when the tube has got much worse.

The PPP splits the responsibility for running trains away from tracks and signals, the same plan which gave us Hatfield and other disasters. The tough new American tube boss, Bob Kiley, will only run half the system.

Imagine that New Labour had been fighting El Alamein. "Now, look, Monty," John Prescott would have said, "we want you to run the tanks, but we're going to be in charge of the chaps inside them. Oh, and we've brought in a contractor to look after ammo, which he'll get from a sub-contractor. In Germany. I'm sure it'll all work out!"

This was a vital issue for Mr Prescott's department, so as usual he wasn't there for the debate. Tories pretended to be enraged. Mr Eric Forth demanded of the Speaker how the deputy prime minister could be persuaded to come to the House.

"The important thing," replied Mr Martin runically, "is that I am here and the honourable gentleman is here." The odd thing about the new speaker is that even when you can make out what he is saying, you have no idea what he means.

Dale Campbell-Savours said that all these late arrivals were the fault of rail privatisation. "But he's got two Jags! Two Jags!" bellowed the Tories.

Bernard Jenkin wondered where Mr Prescott was, and surmised he was skulking in his den. "If I raise my eyes towards the camera, I am probably looking at the secretary of state in his office," he said, lifting his head but resisting the temptation to wave and shout "hello, John!" This is very modernistic Commons behaviour, acknowledging you're being watched, like Craig on Big Brother.

"He has lost his grip, lost his nerve, and soon he will lose his office, his salary, his grace and favour houses, and his chauffeur-driven cars as well!" Mr Jenkin concluded with lip-smacking relish.

Keith Hill, the minister for London, is a sensible fellow and so cannot possibly support the PPP. But he has to pretend he does. So he resorted to sounding like the late Frankie Howerd. As Mr Jenkin tried to make him give way, Mr Hill camped at him. "I want to make progress, but if you behave yourself, I might look favourably on you later," he said, sadly failing to add: "Oooh, missus!" The unspoken message was, "this isn't the real me talking, it's a fictional comedy me!".

Finally it was the mayor's turn. He knows very well that one reason Mr Prescott is obsessed with ramming through the PPP is that he hates Ken. So Ken went for his strategy of last resort: statesmanship. Every reputable report on the PPP condemned it. However, if Mr Kiley decided it would work, he, Ken, would take his word for it. Would the government do the same if Mr Kiley thought the whole thing was a disaster? Fat chance, as Mr Livingstone well knows.

As for the present bosses, or "dullards... Bob Kiley will cut through the senior management of the tube like a scythe through butter!" he said, but you knew it was Mr Prescott's neck he really had in mind.

"I honestly have to say that I fear this system will bring about a major loss of life. This is something we cannot blame on the previous administration. It will be our fault. I beg the government to step back!"

Of course Mr Prescott still wasn't there to listen. He very rarely is.

webTitle: Passnotes

fields.headline: No: 1760
fields.standfirst:
Robert Bourne

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Robert Bourne
fields.body:
Age:
50.

Appearance:
Expensively coiffed Italian opposition politician.

Job: "Regenerator," so he says.

Explain?
"Saviour" might be more appropriate.

Now I really am lost.
So, some might say, are the great minds behind the Millennium Dome - and that is where property developer Bourne comes in. After Nomura pulled out in September, his consortium Legacy became the sole bidder still prepared to take the dome off the government's hands. That makes him the only man who can save some very battered reputations in the run-up to the election.

Now that's what I call regeneration. But why on earth would he want to buy the dome?
He hopes to build an enormous development under canvas called Knowledge City.

You mean a series of interactive exhibits showing the best of British innovation, both educational and entertaining? Perhaps one of them could be called the Learning Zone...
Don't be stupid, who would pay good money to see that?

OK, what then?
Think "hi-tech, eco-friendly business park". Think "innovative work and leisure space".

In other words?
An enormous open-plan office housing an indoor forest of trees and 10,000 internet workers, all networking furiously over lattes and sushi. But no diamonds, so far as we know.

One amazing idea!
Hang on, nothing is definite yet. In fact, Bourne has told Lord Falconer and chums that if they don't close the deal by Friday, he's off, taking his £150m with him.

What happens then?
The "nuclear option".

Oh yes, I saw the movie. Piers Brosnan on a speedboat, isn't it?
Even more nuclear than that. They'd have to send the bulldozers in. Which would see the dome deflating slowly just as the election campaign started gathering hot air. Not a prospect the Labour party relishes.

Don't say:
"What kind of idiot would try to attract 10,000 people to a tent in Greenwich every day?"

Do say:
"Unto us a saviour is Bourne."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed Charles cited in prayer book revolt, page 10, early editions, November 11, we said that the new prayer book and liturgy, Common Worship, would "provide the standard texts for all Anglican worship from the end of this year". In fact, it will do so for the Church of England, but not for the millions of Anglicans in other provinces of the Anglican Communion round the world, all of which have their own prayer books and other liturgical material.
fields.body:
In a report headed Charles cited in prayer book revolt, page 10, early editions, November 11, we said that the new prayer book and liturgy, Common Worship, would "provide the standard texts for all Anglican worship from the end of this year". In fact, it will do so for the Church of England, but not for the millions of Anglicans in other provinces of the Anglican Communion round the world, all of which have their own prayer books and other liturgical material.

The solicitor for Trinity Mirror who was quoted in our piece about the killers of James Bulger, pages 14 and 15 (Law), G2, yesterday, is Marcus Partington, not Martin Partington. Apologies.

The photograph on the front of G2, November 8, with the headings, "The secret of Porton Down," and, "Why did the government gas thousands of British servicemen in this building...?" in fact, showed the wrong building. The building in the picture is not part of the CBD (chemical and biological defence) sector of Porton Down. It is the powerhouse of CAMR (the centre for applied microbiology and research), a Department of Health institution at Porton Down. A subheading on page 2 said, "Over the past 80 years, 25,000 people have been exposed to chemical weapons at Porton Down." The figure is an estimate of the total number of volunteers who have taken part in all studies there, many of which did not involve exposure to chemical weapons.

A report of the Rugby League World Cup game between New Zealand and France, page 7, Sport, yesterday, included the following, "...Quentin Pongia, the Sydney Roosters prop dismissed on the RL's official World Cup website as a 'crazy selection'..." In fact the quote came from the following site: http://worldcup.rleague.com/nations/nz and not the official site. Sorry for that.

A correction, this column, yesterday, relating to the dates of the Great Plague and Great Fire of London, was unnecessary, or to put it another way, wrong. The sentence which said "the Great Fire brought the Plague," eventually went on to say, "to its finality". Apologies to the incorrectly corrected.

webTitle: Comment: Patten report

fields.headline: Patten has been gutted
fields.standfirst:
An independent member of the Patten commission on the RUC speaks out

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Belfast agreement recognised that peace in Northern Ireland required a "new beginning" for policing. The Patten commission created a plan of action for doing just that. Although the British prime minister warmly welcomed the report, stating that it "charts the way forward in the interests of all the people of Northern Ireland", the bill before parliament (with its third reading in the Lords tomorrow) dismantles the foundations on which the Patten commission's plan was built.
fields.body:
The Belfast agreement recognised that peace in Northern Ireland required a "new beginning" for policing. The Patten commission created a plan of action for doing just that. Although the British prime minister warmly welcomed the report, stating that it "charts the way forward in the interests of all the people of Northern Ireland", the bill before parliament (with its third reading in the Lords tomorrow) dismantles the foundations on which the Patten commission's plan was built.

Patten report: The terms of reference of the Patten commission called on it to "inquire into policing in Northern Ireland and, on the basis of its findings, to bring forward proposals for future policing arrangements, including means of encouraging widespread community support for those arrangements". These terms make clear that policing is, and should be, more than the police. They recognise that much is, and can, be done to promote security outside of the activities of the police.

The commission took this seriously. It developed a plan for renewing policing. It expressed this in its core premise: "Policing should be a collective responsibility: a partnership for community safety." Policing, the report stated, "is a matter for the whole community, not something that the community leaves to the police to do". This principle unified its report.

The bill: The bill, as its name makes clear, rejects this conception. It is a police bill not a policing bill. Its focus is consistently on the police rather than on policing. It reflects the limited conception of policing the Patten report sought to transcend.

Does this matter? Yes. It abandons the Patten report's "core project". The bill, as Paddy Hillyard and Mike Tomlinson have recently observed, doesn't simply "water down" the Patten report, it "completely rejects" it. It abandons the notion of policing as a "collective community responsibility" and fails to heed the Patten report's plea for "an end to 'us' and 'them' concepts of policing".

 Patten report: The commission proposed the establishment of a policing board. In proposing this it wrote: "The title 'policing board' is deliberate. We see the role of the new body going beyond supervision of the police service itself, extending to the wider issues of policing and the contributions that people and organisations other than the police can make towards public safety". To realise this wider conception, Patten proposed that the board have a policing budget not a police budget.

The bill: The bill creates a policing board in name only. Its focus is the police, not policing as the Patten commission conceived of it. What it actually establishes is a police board. This board will have a police budget not a policing budget.

Does this matter? Yes. The vision of a policing board administering a policing budget and overseeing policing lies at the very centre of the arrangements proposed in the Patten report. The network of partnerships the commission regarded as essential to a new beginning for policing require it.

 Patten report: The commission proposed that the policing board have extensive powers of, and resources for, oversight to enable it to hold the police accountable. It rejected the established doctrine of "operational independence" in favour of the concept of "operational responsibility". It proposed "the policing board should have the power to require the chief constable to report on any issue pertaining to the performance of his functions or those of the police service. The obligation to report should extend to operational decisions". The Patten report strictly limited the "grounds on which the chief constable might question this requirement" to issues involving "national security, sensitive personnel matters and cases before the courts". The report further proposed "the policing board should have the power to follow up on any report from the chief constable by initiating an inquiry into any aspect of the police service or police conduct".

The bill: The bill completely eviscerates these proposals. To the three very limited grounds on which the chief constable might question an instruction to provide a report, the bill adds a fourth. It would allow the chief constable to question almost any attempt by the board to require a report or get behind a report they have received. The bill states that "if it appears" to the chief constable that such a report "would, or would be likely to, prejudice the prevention or detection of crime or apprehension or prosecution of offenders" s/he may refer it to the secretary of state who may overrule the board. The bill also allows the secretary of state to quash an independent inquiry initiated by the board on the same grounds. Brendan O'Leary has described these provisions as a "travesty". He is absolutely correct.

Does this matter? Yes. The Patten commission recommended "a comprehensive programme of action to focus policing in Northern Ireland on a human rights-based approach". This re quires transparency. The terms of reference of the commission required it to "bring forward proposals" that would ensure that the police service enjoys "widespread support from, and is seen to be part of, the community as a whole". This too requires transparency. This bill does the very opposite. It provisions make it possible to hide and obscure.

This analysis could be continued. The core elements of the Patten commission's report have been undermined everywhere. The district policing partnership boards that are so vital to the Patten commission's vision have been diluted. So have its recommendations in the key areas outlined in its terms of reference - composition, recruitment, culture, ethos and symbols. The Patten report has not been cherry picked - it has been gutted.

The bill does not fulfil the hopes and vision of the Belfast agreement. Nor does it satisfy the very clear mandate set out in the commission's terms of reference. It is not a new beginning. It will not serve the people of Northern Ireland. Nor will it serve the many, many dedicated persons within the RUC who have been looking for a new vision for policing that will move and inspire them to police in partnership with the communities they serve.

Brendan O'Leary, Perfidious Britannia, Guardian, June 15 2000.

Paddy Hillyard and Mike Tomlinson, Patterns of Policing and Policing Patten, Journal of Law and Society

Clifford Shearing is director of the centre of criminology at the University of Toronto

webTitle: Comment: Hackney is much too PC

fields.headline: Hackney is much too PC
fields.trailText: My local council, Hackney, is bust. Why? Huge articles in the Guardian and Observer concentrated on the incompetence of councillors and officials. The Guardian traced the Hackney horror back to 1982 when "the hard left took over".
fields.body:
My local council, Hackney, is bust. Why? Huge articles in the Guardian and Observer concentrated on the incompetence of councillors and officials. The Guardian traced the Hackney horror back to 1982 when "the hard left took over".

Well, the hard left, if it ever existed, vanished without trace from Hackney council years ago. So did the entire left. The council is now run by a Labour rump in coalition with a Tory rump helped out by Liberal Democrats who are always eager to take part in anything PC. PC used to stand for "politically correct" but now it stands for the two remedies to which all three major parties aspire: privatisation and cuts.

How has a once vibrant local Labour party been so humiliated? The answer goes much deeper than incompetence. It goes back to Thatcher's assault on local democracy. Her government abolished the large councils which raised some of their rates from the rich to help the poor (GLC, Ilea and the metropolitan boroughs), and stifled the rest by capping their ability to raise rates. This put a stop to the process of municipal reform that sustained so many Labour councillors when they were elected (including rightwing Labour politicians like Herbert Morrison, the first Labour mayor of Hackney).

In reply to Thatcher, there was none of the defiance shown by another Labour mayor, George Lansbury, at Poplar in 1921. He went to prison rather than implement government policies against the poor. "The workers must be given tangible proof that Labour administration means something different from capitalist administration," he said.

No such proof was available to local electors during Thatcher's attack on them. So the problem became not the power of local councils but their impotence. If you can't do anything about poverty in your area, why bother being a councillor at all? In areas like Hackney, pretty well everyone with any reformist inclination has dropped out of the council, leaving the spineless residue with nothing but PC - privatisation and cuts.

The government meanwhile treats elected local councils as springboards for their vacuous public relations offensives. I cite a press release issued by Hackney Council on March 18 1998 entitled "Top government official helps launch Hackney's anti-poverty strategy". The "top government official" was Guy Gardiner from the cabinet office's social exclusion unit who visited Hackney the following day for the launch of the council's "ground-breaking anti-poverty strategy". The ground was broken with Hackney's two MPs over appropriately proletarian fish and chips in a local pensioners' club. The strategy, said the press release, "is closely linked to Prime Minister Tony Blair's work on social exclusion". A foreword to the strategy was written by Professor Peter Townsend, the veteran anti-poverty campaigner. The strategy, wrote Townsend, needed "decently paid jobs and more of them in local public services".

What happened to that strategy? It vanished as fast as the fish and chips. A cabinet office spokeswoman told me nothing more was said on the matter. Guy Gardiner, who turns out to be an assistant chief constable in Kent, was an "external adviser" to the cabinet office. And now, as Hackney disappears under mountains of rubbish bags, the strategy of providing more jobs in the public services has been replaced by, well, you've guessed it, privatisation and cuts (and the sacking of hundreds of public service workers). Blair's great campaign against social exclusion turns out to be devoted in Hackney to social exclusion on an unimaginable scale.

However clever we journalists think we are, we can only publish new stories when we find them out, and we can only find them out when somebody tells us. The journalist's hero or heroine runs great risks to provide proof of secrecy and skulduggery in high places. Such a hero is Mordechai Vanunu, who went to the Sunday Times in 1986 with proof of one of the most important stories since the war: the fact that Israel was making nuclear weapons.

The Sunday Times made full use of this fantastic scoop, but did not properly protect its source. Mordechai was seduced by an agent from Israeli intelligence, kidnapped, drugged and carried off to Israel where he was jailed for 18 years. The Israeli government has announced that Mordechai, whose endurance of appalling prison conditions has been miraculous, must serve every minute of his full term, and will not be released until 2004. I'll be hobbling down to the Conway Hall in central London on Saturday evening to take part in a benefit for the campaign to release him, and I hope any journalist or anyone else who cares for press freedom and human rights will join me.

No such proof was available to local electors during Thatcher's attack on them. So the problem became not the power of local councils but their impotence. If you can't do anything about poverty in your area, why bother being a councillor at all? In areas like Hackney, pretty well everyone with any reformist inclination has dropped out of the council, leaving the spineless residue with nothing but PC - privatisation and cuts. The government meanwhile treats elected local councils as springboards for their vacuous public relations offensives. I cite a press release issued by Hackney Council on March 18 1998 entitled "Top government official helps launch Hackney's anti-poverty strategy". The "top government official" was Guy Gardiner from the cabinet office's social exclusion unit who visited Hackney the following day for the launch of the council's "ground-breaking anti-poverty strategy". The ground was broken with Hackney's two MPs over appropriately proletarian fish and chips in a local pensioners' club. The strategy, said the press release, "is closely linked to Prime Minister Tony Blair's work on social exclusion". A foreword to the strategy was written by Professor Peter Townsend, the veteran anti-poverty campaigner. The strategy, wrote Townsend, needed "decently paid jobs and more of them in local public services". What happened to that strategy? It vanished as fast as the fish and chips. A cabinet office spokeswoman told me nothing more was said on the matter. Guy Gardiner, who turns out to be an assistant chief constable in Kent, was an "external adviser" to the cabinet office. And now, as Hackney disappears under mountains of rubbish bags, the strategy of providing more jobs in the public services has been replaced by, well, you've guessed it, privatisation and cuts (and the sacking of hundreds of public service workers). Blair's great campaign against social exclusion turns out to be devoted in Hackney to social exclusion on an unimaginable scale. However clever we journalists think we are, we can only publish new stories when we find them out, and we can only find them out when somebody tells us. The journalist's hero or heroine runs great risks to provide proof of secrecy and skulduggery in high places. Such a hero is Mordechai Vanunu, who went to the Sunday Times in 1986 with proof of one of the most important stories since the war: the fact that Israel was making nuclear weapons. The Sunday Times made full use of this fantastic scoop, but did not properly protect its source. Mordechai was seduced by an agent from Israeli intelligence, kidnapped, drugged and carried off to Israel where he was jailed for 18 years. The Israeli government has announced that Mordechai, whose endurance of appalling prison conditions has been miraculous, must serve every minute of his full term, and will not be released until 2004. I'll be hobbling down to the Conway Hall in central London on Saturday evening to take part in a benefit for the campaign to release him, and I hope any journalist or anyone else who cares for press freedom and human rights will join me. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Rose's £14m deal to lift Arcadia

fields.headline: Rose's £14m deal to lift Arcadia
fields.trailText: Arcadia's new chief executive, Stuart Rose, will be awarded share options worth more than £14m if he can transform the fortunes of the struggling clothes retailer over the next four years.
fields.body:
Arcadia's new chief executive, Stuart Rose, will be awarded share options worth more than £14m if he can transform the fortunes of the struggling clothes retailer over the next four years.

Mr Rose, who quit as chief executive of frozen food chain Iceland at the weekend, will qualify for the maximum award if Arcadia's shares reach 270p. He got off to a good start yesterday, as the price jumped 8p to 59p.

The 6.5m options, exercisable at 51p, will be on top of an annual salary of £550,000, making Mr Rose one of the highest paid executives in the retailing industry.

Arcadia's chairman, Adam Broadbent, defended the package, saying it was "very highly geared to the company's performance".

Mr Rose hinted that under his leadership, more of the company's retailing brands could be axed. "Any group with the number of facias this business has got need careful thinking about. I can look at things with a fresh pair of eyes and ask questions that the current management can't."

Mr Rose will be followed to Arcadia by a fellow Iceland director, Charles Wilson, next year. The pair replace the clothes retailer's chief executive John Hoerner and brands boss Richard Maney, who both left with immediate effect.

Arcadia's brands include Dorothy Perkins, Principles, Miss Selfridge and Warehouse. Several, such as Principles for Men, have already been dropped. Mr Rose said: "It's a good business with a turnover of £2bn but it's not making any money. It's got fundamentally good brands but the market's been in turmoil."

Referring to his departure from Iceland, Mr Rose rejected suggestions that he had been reluctant to work from the food firm's Cheshire head office: "I spent at least two days a week up there, and up to two days going round all the shops."

webTitle: See the Lib Dem approach: compliant, abject, half-baked

fields.headline: See the Lib Dem approach: compliant, abject, half-baked
fields.standfirst:
They have let the government butcher the freedom of information bill
Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: They have let the government butcher the freedom of information bill
fields.body:
No measure on the progressive agenda has a longer pedigree than freedom of information. Labour has been committed to it for at least 20 years, the Liberal Democrats for longer. The Blair government, though once its trumpeter, has taken three-and-a-half years to bring it to the brink of law, a point which will be reached today when final passage through the House of Lords begins.

The progressive alliance that got it this far, however, is turning into a conspiracy to gut true reform. From the government this has been signalled for a long time. What is new and shocking is the willingness of the Liberal Democrat peers to assist in the butchery.

The bill began as very bad and, in its tortuous parliamentary history, has been somewhat improved. A series of small concessions were slowly squeezed out of Jack Straw and Lord Falconer, who acts for the prime minister, to get rid of some egregious weaknesses. The Lib Dems assisted creatively in this process. The bill is, after all, among the measures closest to their hearts.

But the worst flaws have still not been satisfactorily addressed. The greatest of all, which was to construct a bill round whole classes of exemptions from the disclosure principle it purported to enshrine, cannot at this stage be challenged. We have to live in the real world. To that end also, liberal critics of the bill were prepared to surrender quite a lot of ground, for example the demand that, to be exempt, information should come into the category of doing "substantial harm" if disclosed. A lesser test now applies. The dilutions from a real right to know have been significant.

Some big issues remain alive, though, and it is here that the Lib Dems have decided to do the government a favour. One issue is: who decides? In the space that the bill still leaves for disclosure, even in some of the exempt categories, a public-interest test is to be applied by an information commissioner - but subject to ministerial override.

If a cabinet minister deems that disclosure would "be likely to prejudice the effective conduct of public affairs" - a very wide zone of possibility - the commissioner's opinion will be swept aside. On that basis, anything that might alarm the public in any way, let alone make it suspect it is not being told the truth, would fall under the veto.

Ministers have fought for 18 months to retain this protective catch-all. Understandably. They've done the same with the demand that factual data, about policy while it's being made, should be automatically available.

Policy advice from Whitehall, and policy discussions in cabinet (give or take the occasional verbatim leak), have always been accepted as appropriate for secrecy, but the facts behind policy - from BSE to police recruitment to university funding and a thousand other areas where secrecy has not proved a reliable context for good decisions - are another matter. Doubtless fearing what can be done with facts, the Blair-Falconer-Straw alliance has defended its barricades, in the face of every reasoned argument from its own MPs and, in earlier mode, from the Liberal Democrats.

But the alliance has been canny. It knew that it would face problems in the Lords, because the session in which this bill can finally be passed is close to its end. It prepared four more small concessions, two of which are of some importance, especially one which adjusts the way the public interest is assessed, so as to load the dice slightly less against the applicant for information.

Falconer explicitly stated that this did not shift the burden of proof from the citizen to the department whose information is sought. It does little more than send a signal to the department to be even-handed in weighing up whether to revealwhat it knows. It may be useful - but the Lib Dems' lead speaker, Lord Goodhart, himself said he doubted "whether, in practice, this will make an enormous difference".

The difference is big enough, however, to have persuaded the Lib Dems to reverse their position on a bill which they had always and rightly called defective. Last week Mr Straw signalled a deal, and the Lib Dems crowed about it. In exchange for small concessions which there is good reason to believe ministers were already prepared to make, they said they were now ready to help the bill pass expeditiously through these final log-jammed days of the Lords' present session, and not obstruct any other part of the programme either.

Unless they're prepared to reconsider today, they have thus removed all pressure on the government to yield on major points still in play. This is a tactical error that casts bleak doubt on their managerial judgment. More calamitously, it's a political blunder suggesting they have crossed a crucial line from the territory of constructive scepticism into that of compliant, abject governmentalism.

Approaching the end of the session, the government has to get this bill through. If it fails, its humiliation before its own constituency will be corrosively damaging. It might not like to surrender on the veto, or on factual data, or on one or two other large categories, such as accident investigations, where it has held out for total control and secrecy. But if the Lib Dems hadn't blinked first, it rather than they would now be facing the need to make some big concessions.

This is because of the Conservative peers, who have shown surprising resilience in support of a proper bill. There may be an aura of cheap politics about that. The Tories, after all, resisted an information law for years, though they did introduce a code. All that can be said is that so far they have proposed their own amendments, and encouraged Lib Dem amendments - even though, in the wonderful way of British coalition politics, neither party will talk to the other.

Moreover, since these were last debated, William Hague has made a speech strongly supporting the kind of bill the Lib Dems once upon a time insisted on: no ministerial veto, no class exemptions, disclosure of factual data, the explicit presumption in favour of greater public access as the central purpose of the exercise.

Some Lib Dems claim that the Tory peers cannot be relied on. The more glaring truth is that they themselves have removed the need to put the Tories to the test, just as they've knocked the bottom out of any meaningful resistance among Labour peers and MPs. They have been suckered into entering the manoeuvres of government which, in this field, have nothing to do with the interest of the public.

There's little danger of the bill being lost. The choice is between a weak bill, and one that can still be much strengthened by politicians prepared to exploit ministers' desperation. Instead those politicians have become, in the worst sense, ministerial: half-baked in their pragmatism, and amnesiac in their regard for principle. Unless they're summoned to their senses, they will assist Mr Blair with a measure he has spent some years crafting towards inanition.

webTitle: Brazil beckons for tycoons

fields.headline: Brazil beckons for tycoons
fields.standfirst: Britain is near bottom of start-up league
fields.trailText: Budding entrepreneurs would be better off leaving Britain and seeking their fortunes in the sunnier climes of Brazil, according to a survey of top executives.
fields.body:
Budding entrepreneurs would be better off leaving Britain and seeking their fortunes in the sunnier climes of Brazil, according to a survey of top executives.

The second annual Global Entrepreneurship Monitor, which measures the number of adults involved in new firms, places Britain 12th in a league table of 21 countries.

The monitor, published by London Business School and Babson College in the United States, ranks Britain behind Australia, India and Brazil.

If true, it would appear that Gordon Brown's vision of transforming the UK into a haven for entrepreneurs is a long way from being fulfilled.

The survey found that only one in 33 adults is trying to start a business, compared to one in 8 in Brazil, one in 10 in the United States and one in 12 in Australia.

Languishing at the bottom of the league table are Japan and Ireland, where fewer than one in a 100 people is trying to start a business.

The survey, which is based on a sample of 43,000 individuals and nearly 800 experts around the globe, claims that there is a strong link between entrepreneurial activity and economic growth, although the authors admit that there are a number of anomalies.

For example, both Ireland and Singapore, which consistently post strong growth rates, have low levels of entrepreneurship.

Professor Paul Reynolds of London Business School and Babson College, said this was because both countries relied heavily for growth on external trade rather than indigenous entrepreneurial activity.

However, he admitted that France, which shows the same pattern of high growth and a low rate of entrepreneurship, was harder to explain.

Prof Reynolds said levels of entrepreneurship were influenced by a wide range of factors, including the age structure of the population, the availability of finances for start-ups, the perception of opportunity and the number of people going into higher education.

He said the main ingredient was cultural. Until young people received encouragement from their parents to start a business - as they did in America - levels of entrepreneurship in the laggards would remain weak.

webTitle: Opec turns deaf ear to fuel pleas

fields.headline: Opec turns deaf ear to fuel pleas
fields.trailText: The 11-nation Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries yesterday dashed hopes of lower energy prices during the critical northern hemisphere winter when it rejected calls for another increase in output.
fields.body:
The 11-nation Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries yesterday dashed hopes of lower energy prices during the critical northern hemisphere winter when it rejected calls for another increase in output.

Opec minsters, meeting in Vienna, decided not to raise their production quotas arguing that crude prices will soon fall back to their target range of $22-28 a barrel.

"The feeling we have now is that the market is getting perhaps a little a saturated and as stocks build up it is likely to hit us in the face later in the New Year if we don't watch it," said the cartel's secretary-general, Rilwanu Lukman.

The news pushed Brent crude oil up by 41 cents to $32.43 a barrel. In the US, light crude was up 46 cents to $34.48 a barrel.

Opec has already increased its quotas four times this year, adding a total of 3.7m extra barrels a day to the market in an attempt to drag down oil prices. But both Brent crude and US light crude have remained stubbornly above $30 a barrel since spring, threatening American consumers with large heating bills this winter.

Opec's president, Ali Rodriguez of Venezuela, signalled yesterday that the cartel has abandoned its automatic mechanism for regulating prices if they go above its target range. He indicated that further production increases this year were highly unlikely, even if prices stayed at current levels. The cartel fears that deeper cuts could result in a glut of cheap oil on world markets next year.

Oil prices have already eased from the ten year peaks above $35 reached in September, providing some respite for British firms, government figures showed yesterday. The cost of manufacturers' fuel and raw materials fell by 0.9% in October, driven by a 5.4% fall in price of crude, according to data from the office for national statistics. The monthly drop was the sharpest since April, and larger than the market had been expecting.

Inflation at the factory gate was subdued despite increases in petrol and petroleum products, rising just 0.1% over the month, according to the ONS.

"Pipeline inflation pressures in the goods sector remain pretty benign, with little evidence of any real acceleration outside of those areas directly related to oil," said Jonathan Loynes, UK economist with Capital Economics.

webTitle: Toyota UK goes into red and fuels new euro row

fields.headline: Toyota UK goes into red and fuels new euro row
fields.trailText: A new row between pro-euro campaigners and opponents of UK entry to the single currency broke out yesterday after Toyota, the Japanese car-maker, warned that the strong pound and weak euro had turned its UK operations into a loss-making business.
fields.body:
A new row between pro-euro campaigners and opponents of UK entry to the single currency broke out yesterday after Toyota, the Japanese car-maker, warned that the strong pound and weak euro had turned its UK operations into a loss-making business.

The world's third-largest auto manufacturer, due to announce its global interim results tomorrow, said currency instability in Europe had helped turn a pre-tax profit of £19.1m in 1998 into a loss of £52m last year.

Officials said the situation had deteriorated since last year, with the stronger pound ensuring that the group's two UK plants - Burnaston, Derbyshire, which employs 2,800, and Deeside, north Wales, employing 300 - would continue to make losses "unless economic circumstances change soon."

Toyota, which is expected to disclose slightly stronger global profits in the first half, has invested £1.5bn in the UK where Burnaston, which makes the Avensis and Corolla, is now Europe's second most productive plant even though its annual output of 179,000 is some 20% below fixed capacity of 220,000 units.

It is the latest Far East investor, after Nissan and Honda as well as Sony, Hitachi and Panasonic, to point to deteriorating terms of trade caused by the strong pound and to adopt a pan-European manufactur ing and marketing strategy to combat this.

Its new plant in Valenciennes, northern France, begins production of the Yaris in January, with output due to rise to 150,000 a year, while its Polish factory starts producing transmission systems a year later and its Turkish operations produce 60,000 Corollas a year.

Toyota insisted it saw no threat to its continued UK presence, but Sir Ken Jackson, leader of the AEEU engineering union which organises around 65% of the Burnaston workforce, said the weak euro was crippling production at the Derbyshire plant despite its productivity record - matched by investment.

"There's constant speculation about the workforce's future because the pound gets stronger and stronger," Sir Ken, a leading pro-euro campaigner, said.

"If anyone thinks being outside the euro is not a problem they should go to Burnaston: it will change their minds."

webTitle: Biotech firm's US launch hit by slump

fields.headline: Biotech firm's US launch hit by slump
fields.standfirst: Oxford Glycosciences' new clinical trials put on hold
fields.trailText: Oxford Glycosciences, the protein-based drugs specialist, yesterday launched a £150m fundraising on the hi-tech US stockmarket Nasdaq, with plans to double its workforce and take up to 30 new drugs into clinical trials.
fields.body:
Oxford Glycosciences, the protein-based drugs specialist, yesterday launched a £150m fundraising on the hi-tech US stockmarket Nasdaq, with plans to double its workforce and take up to 30 new drugs into clinical trials.

However, the equity issue was immediately plunged into doubt as the biotech company's shares slumped 302.5p to £20.22 amid a general sell-off of technology stocks in the US. The company said unless it could get a minimum price of £20.92 for its new shares, it would abandon the fundraising.

The money is initially intended to pay for a network of sales representatives to sell Oxford Glycosciences' drug Vevesca, which treats a rare disorder of the liver called Gaucher's Disease.

It will also fund a rapid expansion of the firm's 167-strong workforce and the development of a stronger pipeline of drugs.

Chief executive Michael Kranda said: "We have a technology platform which can find hundreds, even thousands of new drug targets. Our lead in the area is something which we have an opportunity to leverage."

Oxford Glycosciences has a library containing thousands of human proteins, many of which are significant in causing disease. Up to now, its main focus has been on collaborative agreements, in which it provides information about these proteins to help other pharmaceuticals companies develop medicines.

Mr Kranda said a "natural evolution" of the firm's activities was to begin large-scale drug development itself. A tie-up in September with a US biotech firm, Medarex, gives it access to expertise in making antibodies: "We want to substantially increase our clinical development commitment - we're looking at up to 30 new antibodies."

The first of the new drugs will target tumours, with a particular focus on breast cancer.

Oxford Glycosciences is hoping to begin clinical trials of these new drugs next year. At present, the company has just Vevesca in trials, although tests are under way for its use in several different diseases.

Oxford Glycosciences recently moved into a new head office called Milton Park, and Mr Kranda is keen to expand rapidly, to counter fierce competition in protein-based medicine from US biotech firms.

A listing of shares in Nasdaq is intended to raise the company's profile and give it the option of using paper to make acquisitions in America.

The size of planned fundraising surprised some analysts, particularly given the volatile climate for biotechnology shares. Bill Blair of Nomura said: "The timing is interesting, to say the least, given the current market conditions. It's a very chunky issue and it'll be interesting to see how they get on."

Syngenta, the agrochemicals spin-off from AstraZeneca and Novartis, flopped on its stockmarket debut yesterday as its shares fell from an issue price of £33.65 to just £31.

The company is the world's biggest crop protection business, the third largest supplier of seeds and a leading developer of genetically modified foods.

It ended the day worth little more than half the $10bn (£7bn) price tag its two parents had initially anticipated, as investors ran scared of environmental controversy.

webTitle: Wates confirms it is takeover target

fields.headline: Wates confirms it is takeover target
fields.trailText: Property group Wates City of London confirmed yesterday it was in takeover talks but refused to comment on speculation that the main suitor was Pillar Property.
fields.body:
Property group Wates City of London confirmed yesterday it was in takeover talks but refused to comment on speculation that the main suitor was Pillar Property.

Industry sources said outline discussions had taken place between the two companies and valued the initial approach at £300m.

The news saw shares in Wates rise almost 8% to a year's high of 120.5p at the close, while Pillar edged up 0.5p to 339.5p.

In a statement to the stock market, Wates said it was in discussions that "may or may not lead to an offer for Wates".

It pledged to "explore all methods" of realising value, including the return of £70m to shareholders following the sale of investment properties to Prudential for £252m.

Any offer for the company would be subject to the approval of the Duke of Westminster's Grosvenor Estate, the biggest shareholder in Wates with a 17% stake.

Analysts labelled Wates "an interesting proposition" and said a deal would be another example of the consolidation that has helped to shake up a jaded property sector.

"It depends on what they can buy it for as it's not going to go cheap," one said. "No deal has been done but it's highly likely that something will happen. Anyone following the sector would have seen it was an obvious target."

webTitle: TTP finds new outlet for phone chip designs

fields.headline: TTP finds new outlet for phone chip designs
fields.trailText: TTP Communications, the Cambridge-based intellectual property developer, yesterday announced a licensing deal with ST Microelectronics.
fields.body:
TTP Communications, the Cambridge-based intellectual property developer, yesterday announced a licensing deal with ST Microelectronics.

The agreement with the European semiconductor manufacturer gives TTPCom more platforms from which to sell its software and designs to handset manufacturers.

TTPCom floated last month, raising £40m to fund overseas expansion and to recruit staff. It designs mobile phone chips and software which it licenses out to manufacturers.

The products are aimed at the digital cellular market and are expected to be used in the next generation of mobile phones. The company said the growth of palmtop and handheld devices with telephony built in was key to TTPCom's future.

Half year revenues were up 44% to £11.4m from £7.9m in 1999, with a growing proportion - nearly 80% - coming from licence fees and royalties. Pretax profits rose to £3.1m from £1.6m but included an exceptional £1.4m in licence termination fees after the bankruptcy of satellite mobile firm ICO. The share price edged up 1p to 275p.

webTitle: BT sell-off delays auction

fields.headline: BT sell-off delays auction
fields.trailText: British Telecom was yesterday at the centre of new controversy in the auction of next generation mobile phone licences on mainland Europe.
fields.body:
British Telecom was yesterday at the centre of new controversy in the auction of next generation mobile phone licences on mainland Europe.

The company found itself embroiled in an investigation by the Swiss government after its decision to sell its stake in local network Sunrise for £460m.

The 34% stake was sold to fellow shareholder TeleDanmark, which at the same time took control of another bidder for the Swiss third generation mobile licence, diAx.

TeleDanmark intends to merge the two companies leaving only four businesses bidding for four licences, derailing the process and denying the Swiss government a potential windfall.

Officials immediately announced a postponement of the auction which had been due to start yesterday.

Bakom, the Swiss telecoms regulator, has been ordered to investigate any potential collusion among the bidders. A decision on what to do with the licences has been put back to next month.

A BT spokesman said the company would be happy to comply with any investigation by the Swiss government. "We have been talking to our other shareholders about this for the past month," he said. "What we did was take the opportunity to realise a handsome profit by selling the stake at this time."

BT has realised a £390m profit from Sunrise, which was set up in 1997 and operates in the fixed line and internet access residential market.

BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield last week outlined a broad restructuring of the company with the key aim of paying down some of its £30bn debts.

He said the company would sell around £5bn worth of assets and noted that, as in Switzerland, BT would be unlikely to bid for third generation mobile phone licences where it did not already have a network.

The disarray in Switzerland is the latest in a series of problems to hit mobile licence auctions in Europe.

The British and German auctions were huge money-spinners for their respective governments, and others had been hoping to repeat their good fortune.

But a change in market sentiment and the financial pres sures on the telecom companies hoping to bid have taken the shine from many of the subsequent auctions.

In Italy, the auction ended after just three days, raising only €13.8bn compared to €50.8bn in Germany, and leading to a string of legal actions. The Dutch government raised only €2.3bn. It is also considering an investigation into possible collusion among bidders.

The Swiss authorities are considering a number of options including proceeding with four bidders, calling a new auction or simply allocating the licences to the remaining four companies.

webTitle: Future Network shares fall 47%

fields.headline: Future Network shares fall 47%
fields.trailText: Shares in Future Network collapsed 47% to 260p yesterday after the magazine publishing group warned that profits for the year end would fall short of expectations.
fields.body:
Shares in Future Network collapsed 47% to 260p yesterday after the magazine publishing group warned that profits for the year end would fall short of expectations.

Future cited a series of problems that are likely to result in a full-year reduction of £6m in underlying profits.

"This is quite an enormous blow," said chief executive Greg Ingham. "This has been an exceptionally tough reaction but then the markets are not in a particularly forgiving mood at the moment. It's going to be a long climb back."

Future's shares were worth 937p during the market peak in March.

The main problem for Future is an overstatement of earnings at its French business, disclosed at the start of last month. The restatement wiped £1.1m off first-half earnings and led to a downward move in the forecast for the second half of the year.

Future has also been hit by continuing difficulties in the computer games market. Around 30% of Future's group revenues are from games magazines and delays in the introduction of next-generation consoles, particularly Sony's PlayStation2, are affecting advertising budgets.

Perhaps more worrying however was the weakening of the advertising market for Business 2.0, the company's new-economy magazine. The company's investment plans for next year have been put under review.

Mr Ingham was at pains to stress that Future remains a high-growth business. Revenues for the year are expected to come in 30% higher at £260m and underlying profits 25% up at £40m.

Paul Richards, media analyst at West LB Panmure, described the problems experienced by Future as "growing pains".

"There's still a heck of a lot of growth in this company. There's nothing, structural or fundamental, wrong. It's more that when there is a big increase in scale it is a very difficult process to manage."

webTitle: To let: large slice of North Korea

fields.headline: To let: large slice of North Korea
fields.standfirst: The 'hermit' state is opening up with plans for a huge business complex aided by the south
fields.trailText: Business tenants wanted: prime 16,000-acre, green-field site conveniently located between two of Asia's biggest capital cities. Communist owners willing to throw in low-paid, highly educated workforce, tax breaks and security by a 1m-man army, but tenants must provide their own roads, rail links and power stations. Local attractions include the world's most heavily fortified border and hours of free propaganda broadcasts.
fields.body:
Business tenants wanted: prime 16,000-acre, green-field site conveniently located between two of Asia's biggest capital cities. Communist owners willing to throw in low-paid, highly educated workforce, tax breaks and security by a 1m-man army, but tenants must provide their own roads, rail links and power stations. Local attractions include the world's most heavily fortified border and hours of free propaganda broadcasts.

Such could be the pitch for the Kaesong industrial complex, the envisaged development of a sizeable chunk of North Korean territory with billions of dollars of foreign investment, which was a main reason for a ground-breaking economic agreement between Seoul and Pyongyang - South and North Korea - on Saturday. The two cold war enemies signed a deal to protect investment, end double taxation, open a direct route for financial transactions and establish a panel to settle trade disputes.

For the moment, the Kaesong complex is little more than a twinkle in the eye of North Korea's "dear leader" Kim Jong-il, who has promised the land to his main business partner in the south, Chung Mon-hun, the head of Hyundai Asan. But the plan for the site - an almost undeveloped plain 18km from the demilitarised zone that separates the two Koreas - is fast becoming a litmus test for the entire process of reconciliation.

After decades of isolation that have left its economy in tatters and millions of its people malnourished, North Korea has started opening up to the outside world. Since the summer, a series of meetings between Mr Kim and the leaders of South Korea and Russia and US secretary of state Madeleine Albright have prompted comparisons with the developments that preceded the fall of the Berlin Wall.

But unlike Germany, economics rather than politics is the driving force. South Korean president Kim Dae-jung wants re-unification over a generation because he says the peninsula cannot afford to move quickly in closing the chasm that has opened up in the lifestyles of the two nations. Goldman Sachs estimates Seoul will have to spend $1 trillion (£690bn) to remove this disparity and rebuild its neighbour's shattered infrastructure.

Even the far more robust German economy was dragged into reverse by the $90bn a year cost of evening out a smaller disparity between west and east. For South Korea, which is still recovering from the Asian financial crisis of 1997-98, such a burden could be devastating. Seoul's wobbly financial health has been underlined by the bankruptcy of Daewoo Motors, once part of the country's second-biggest conglomerate, which led to violent weekend demonstrations by about 20,000 workers. Dozens of other firms, including several in the Hyundai group, remain on the brink of collapse.

To achieve a soft landing, the South Korean president is desperate to avoid a sudden collapse of the regime in the north. His "sunshine policy" aims to lure the hermit state slowly out of its shell with the promise of aid and investment.

The north's dear leader has milked this for all he is worth, demanding hundreds of thousands of tonnes of rice from the south, billions of dollars worth of second-world-war reparations from Japan and reportedly $3bn from the United States in return for a pledge to abandon the country's missile programme.

While visits to the north by politicians, diplomats and generals have grabbed the headlines, arguably the most important emissary has been Chung Ju-yung, the octogenarian founder of the Hyundai conglomerate who broke the ice between north and south two years ago by crossing the border with a gift of 500 cattle.

As part of the process of confidence-building - which so far has been synonymous with loss making - Hyundai Asan has pumped $1bn into the North Korean resort of Mt Kumgang. The resort has attracted 310,000 tourists in two years - well short of the breakeven point of 500,000 that it hopes to reach by 2002.

Undeterred, Hyundai Asan is now drawing up even more ambitious plans for Kaesong. According to blueprints, the site will be developed over eight years from an empty plot into a bustling commercial centre of 1,200 firms and 160,000 workers, producing $20bn worth of goods each year. Underlining the policy of economic integration and political separation, the complex will be fenced off and guarded by North Korean troops.

South Korean companies in labour intensive industries such as textiles, footwear and electronic assembly have already applied for space in the complex, where they will benefit from wage costs that are anything from a fifth to a twentieth of those south of the border.

Despite this advantage, no foreign companies are expected to join the first stage of the development, which is scheduled for completion by this time next year. "Its too early for western firms to make a commitment. There are still too many unknowns," said a European diplomat.

Given the uncertainties that still surround the venture, it would be a miracle if the project goes ahead. But several miracles have already occurred in this amazing year for Korea.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Bidders spurn airwave auction
The auction for licences to beam high-speed wireless internet services appeared headed for a flop yesterday as a second bidder withdrew and the others snubbed more than half the regions on offer.
fields.body:
Bidders spurn airwave auction
The auction for licences to beam high-speed wireless internet services appeared headed for a flop yesterday as a second bidder withdrew and the others snubbed more than half the regions on offer.

FirstMark Communications, a private US company, pulled out during round five on day two, following Unica Communications, which quit on Friday before the bidding started.

The auction had raised less than £36.5m by the end of round six, compared to analysts' initial estimates of £1bn or more for the final tally.

Eight companies remain in the running for 42 licences. However, eight of the 14 regions have failed to attract bids, with the action centring on London and other big cities. Energis leads the bidding with £4.5m for one of three London licences.

World Online under scrutiny
The Rotterdam headquarters of internet service provider World Online has been raided following allegations of insider trading during the company's disastrous initial public offering in March. The company said it was cooperating with Dutch justice department investigators.

Schroders' new arm for the rich Schroders, the financial services group, has introduced a Europe-wide private banking business targeting clients with more than £250,000 in spare cash. It claims to stand out from those promoted by other financial institutions for the "mass affluent", with £50,000 to invest.

Holding firms in Lazards merge
Eurafrance and Azeo, which hold 4% and 13% respectively in Paris-based Lazards, plan to merge by the end of the first quarter of 2001. The two companies are under pressure from investors to improve returns.

Michel David-Weill, chairman of Lazards and of Eurafrance, was quoted in the French media as saying the bank was not for sale. Yet it has been linked with Deutsche Bank and Italian group Mediobank.

VW withdraws from show
Volkswagen has pulled out of next year's London motor show, saying it prefers to concentrate on the Birmingham biennial motor show in 2002.

A recent survey of car manufacturers found they preferred to exhibit in the larger and more prestigious Birmingham show.

The mobile phone news

iTouch grows abroad
Messaging service iTouch is to expand its international operation despite yesterday's announcement of a pre-tax loss of £9.9m for the first nine months of the year. The company, which provides users with voicemail, text message, and Wap service updates on a range of news topics, said it was looking at countries close to existing operations. The firm does business in Ireland, South Africa, Britain, Australia, New Zealand and Israel.

webTitle: TMT detonates implosion

fields.headline: TMT detonates implosion
fields.trailText: Few brokers in London would claim to have a firm grasp of the intricacies of the North American PC market, but they all know what the phrase "earnings have fallen short of expectations" means and they do not like the sound of it.
fields.body:
Few brokers in London would claim to have a firm grasp of the intricacies of the North American PC market, but they all know what the phrase "earnings have fallen short of expectations" means and they do not like the sound of it.

So when PC maker Hewlett Packard posted fourth-quarter figures which fell way short of Wall Street expectations yesterday they all knew the market was heading only one way - lower.

In fact, the market had been weak from the outset yesterday, pressured by continued electoral uncertainty in the US and the performance of the Nasdaq composite on Friday. Then, the world's tech benchmark had fallen 5% to its lowest close of the year, unsettled by a revenue warning from another PC maker, Dell.

But things got much worse after the news from Hewlett Packard sent the Nasdaq skid ding below 3,000 for the first time in about a year. By the close of play the FTSE 100 was 125.4 points adrift at 6,247.8 while the FTSE Mid 250 was 107.1 weaker at 6,629.1 and the FTSE Techmark 100 was 145.2 lower at 3,077.24.

Put simply, investors are starting to accept that maybe, just maybe, they have got the whole TMT (tech, media and telecom) thing wrong. Having pushed prices up to levels that could only be justified by massive long-term growth they are starting to have second thoughts, and not without reason.

Basically the argument runs like this: if tech leaders such as Hewlett Packard and Dell cannot meet their growth expectations then what hope is there for the rest? And if the rest cannot meet expectations then their share prices will have to fall to reflect the more modest assumptions. This is usually called rerating and was vividly illustrated by the performance of Bookham Technology yesterday .

While investors accept that the optical components group has some innovative technology they no longer think it is enough to support a stock price of £20 or more. They reckon a price of nearer £10 might be more appropriate and sent Bookham shares down 165p to £13.95 yesterday to prove it. At this level the company is almost certain to leave the FTSE 100 at next month's review.

Elsewhere in the TMT world, Baltimore Technology , another company likely to be relegated at the review, fell 39.5p to 420.5p, while Sema dipped 68p to 702p and Marconi surrendered 67p to 743p. Lower down the corporate scale the picture was much the same. Freeserve , was off 18.75p to 132p, below its 150p flotation price, while software group Orchestream lost 102.5p to 360p and PC seller Computacenter eased 42.5p to 340p.

Away from the TMTs, banking stocks were weak on the back of a broker downgrade. HSBC fell 28p to 999p after analysts at its investment banking offshoot, HSBC Securities, cut their recommenda tion on the stock to "hold" from "add". They dished out the same punishment to Bank of Scotland , off 32p to 672p, and Northern Rock , down 15.25p to 420p.

In the gloom there were some bright spots, notably in the retail sector. Arcadia , the owner of Top Shop and Dorothy Perkins, rose 8p to 59p, as investors registered their approval at the appointment of former Iceland boss Stuart Rose as chief executive. Meanwhile, Debenhams , the department store group, gained 11.75p to 266.75p on the back of a Merrill Lynch upgrade.

With most investors suffering from events in the TMT shake-out there was little appetite to chase speculative stories. One recent takeover favourite, City Centre Restaurants , fell 4.5p to 51.5p after PizzaExpress , off 3.5p to 642.5p, said it had withdrawn its 65p-a-share offer. Bulls of City Centre still insist that PizzaExpress will return with a hostile offer.

A few punters long on Kewill Systems shares were trying to put around a tale that interim profits, out today, will come in about 10% better than expected. However, the stock ended 32.5p lower at 478p.

webTitle: Relief for Durlacher

fields.headline: Relief for Durlacher
fields.trailText: Durlacher shareholders were breathing a sigh of relief yesterday after the niche investment bank raised £30m in convertible debt via a deal with three institutions, one of which was CSFB.
fields.body:
Durlacher shareholders were breathing a sigh of relief yesterday after the niche investment bank raised £30m in convertible debt via a deal with three institutions, one of which was CSFB.

The cash will allow Durlacher to continue its strategy of identifying and investing in growth markets, the expansion of its broking activities and the commencement of a private equity operation.

The shares dipped 4p, or 7.48%, to 49.5p, on the news. The stock was hit by the sharp fall in the Nasdaq composite, but dealers were unnerved also by details of the bond issue.

The three investors will be able to convert the debt into Durlacher stock after the first 120 days at a price near to the average closing price of the shares in the 45 trading days prior to notification.

All of which means existing Durlacher holders could be facing dilution of their stakes without the prospect of any upside.

webTitle: At this price?

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: Renold
fields.trailText: Renold
fields.body:
Few industries have experienced a more turbulent two years than engineering, which has suffered at the hands of currency fluctuations, global financial crises and a hostile marketplace.

Initial problems can be traced back to the late 1990s when the strong pound made exporting difficult, while encouraging an influx of cheap imports that squeezed the markets at home.

And when economic problems in the Far East were added into the mix, coupled with a sentiment swing towards service sector companies, the result was an explosive cocktail of cutbacks and redundancies.

For those companies which managed to survive - and a great many were forced out of business - it has been a time for drastic action.

Renold, the precision engineering firm, can justifiably lay claim to being a victim of the period, but yesterday gave reasons for optimism with the publication of improved half-year results.

The company, which makes chains and machine tools, as well as being involved with the production of escalators on the Jubilee Line extension, reported pre-tax profits for the six months to September 30, before redundancies, were up 24% at £5.1m on a £106.6m turnover - 8% up on a like-for-like basis. Sales of the company's Holroyd's machine tool brand are ahead of last year while one of its sites, vacant for a decade, has finally been sold for a realisation of £7.7m.

The figures were in marked contrast to 12 months ago when the company reported profits had sunk to £3.8m and complained there were "few tangible signs" of a recovery in Britain.

Yesterday's results, however, failed to ignite the City with the company's shares creeping up just 1p to 84.5p as the London markets closed last night. This is marginally better than February's 80p year low, but way off the high of 125p.

This is a recovering stock but is likely to need more time. While orders are increasing it still needs to win more major contracts. Hold.
