webTitle: Sign language

fields.headline: Sign language
fields.standfirst: Matt Mullican's painted banners and stick men suck you into hidden universes and secret worlds.  Adrian Searle  is confused, amused - and occasionally tearful
fields.trailText: Matt Mullican's painted banners and stick men suck you into hidden universes and secret worlds. Adrian Searle is confused, amused - and occasionally tearful
fields.body:
What a peculiar artist Matt Mullican is. For a number of years following his wave of success in the 1980s I would see fragments of Mullican's work and sort of gloss over it. I filed it in the wrong place in my mind, among the wrong artists, mistaking him for a kind of neo-Pop signmaker, an artist whom one could lodge somewhere between American painter Peter Halley and British artist Julian Opie. I liked a set of geometric, semi-abstract motifs cut in stone that Mullican placed around the edge of a pond in Middleheim Sculpture Park in Antwerp, and whenever I thought about Mullican's work I would find myself beside that little lake in my imagination, as though barely discerning something that lay beneath the surface.

My fuzzy misappraisal of Mullican, even my inability to focus on what he did, is itself an illustration of the preoccupations of his art. His work is about how we log the world, how we perceive signs and symbols and pictures, and how we flesh them out into full-blown mental images. His work is also about the imaginary mental maps we make, the lists, the baggage, the black holes in our consciousness, and the cosmologies we keep in our heads. Further - there's always a further in Mullican's art - his is an art that triggers thoughts that leap from one thing to another. His work is encyclopedic, leaky, paradoxical and complicated. Mullican has made drawings, photographs, sculptures, objects, performances, texts, appropriations, rubbings, installations, banners. He has made drawn, painted, printed, carved and cast signs; computer-generated models; virtual-reality pieces. It is exhausting to list. I don't claim to understand the half of it, but seeing his work en masse is as absorbing as it is often incomprehensible.

Mullican's solo show at the Museum of Modern Art in Oxford is just one half of a travelling exhibition of his work. Another swathe of it is also currently at the Tapies Foundation in Barcelona. Imagining the unseen half of the show is part of the game. The exhibition, after all, is subtitled More Details From an Imaginary Universe. I get caught up in details - his stained glass pieces, beautiful abstract windows leaning against a wall; the fact that all Mullican's work is colour-coded, but that I can't remember which colours denote inner experience, the hard-assed world of facts and the things we've heard about but haven't quite grasped for ourselves.

I laugh at his lexicon of hand-drawn symbols - a nose, an eye, the devil and the fires of hell and a toothpaste tube. Among his collection of photographs, pinned-up scrapbook- style on the wall, Mullican often uses a photographic portrait of a dead man, and invariably places it next to a picture of a painted wooden mannequin of a young boy. These images make us think about how the smiling wooden face is more life-like than the deathly portrait of someone who once truly was alive. "I slept like a log," the saying goes. Mullican's Sleeping Child is a timber off-cut, one end resting on a pillow on the floor. A child might turn anything into a doll, and we are invited to view the piece of wood in just such a light. The lump of sawn wood, the soft white pillow.

Inevitably, I also think (as has Mullican) of certain kinds of reductive sculpture from the 1960s and 1970s, and how Mullican has turned the simplest thing into a symbol, and how complex such symbols can be. He has remade this work several times over the years, and it is more than a one-line gag. Like the double portrait, it tells us something about affective, and how impossible it is to live like Mr Gradgrind, in a world of mere utility and facts. I guess Sleeping Child is a kind of Ur-sculpture, a comment on creativity. But, however much it is a symbol, it is a thing. It has presence. Its components are familiar, yet it disturbs. It hangs around in my head and won't go away.

I look at Mullican's bold pictographic signs and read the artist's name, and the words God, Before Birth, Death, Heaven and Hell, and realise that these concepts have become off-limits for most artists, even though they have been the major preoccupations of art for thousands of years. Mullican watches the world - and life - go by. He knows detachment is impossible, and that in the midst of things any world-view is liable to be scrambled, incomplete.

The stick man, that universal pictogram, is a major presence in Mullican's work. His stick man's name is Glen. Glen falls asleep on the floor, he squats against the wall and thinks about the time he hurt himself skiing. He holds his hands to his ears because, a caption tells us, the sound from next door is driving him crazy. We flesh Glen out for ourselves, and imagine his maunderings and his worries. We fill the empty white space around him in our minds, imagining his complications. We do the same thing when we read a novel or watch a movie. Filling in the details, and knowing that the world we invent is a dubious, faulty place, is just one of the lessons of Mullican's work.

Glen's world is just a fragment among fragments in this cluttered, strange exhibition. There are bulletin boards, reams of pictograms, big painted signs and videos of the artist, hypnotised, performing and acting out various activities. Mullican hypnotised - acting as a five-year-old, and as a 55-year-old, is painful to watch. He is both there and not there, self-aware but somehow not there. He speaks of the experience as one of acute clarity, but fuzzy at the edges. He says it is like having jet lag, though I reckon many of us go around in such a state most of the time.

At Oxford, there are things that make you laugh and confuse you. There were also one or two moments when Mullican almost had me in tears. On one of his casually arranged bulletin boards is a text from a performance, to be read aloud by the artist. It recounts incidents from the fictional life of a woman, from her birth to her death. It includes rites of passage, such as, "Learning to use her hands... experiencing puberty... her husband dies", alongside stray but poignant details: "Learning about gravity in school... tasting that there's too much salt in the salad... thinking of her husband's childhood... the backyard flooded during a heavy rain."

Time goes by and the incidents pile up. She looks at herself in the mirror; the days seem to be going by faster. Her hair goes white. She thinks about dying; she dies. Reading, we flip between her inner thoughts and feelings and objective fact, places, experiences and things. It is a life of accumulated details; then it ends. The text is poignant and terribly restrained. You feel a whole life hidden behind a dam of facts, a personality in suspension. Focus on the little things in Mullican's work, and it is great. Try to eat it all at once, and it is indigestible - just, you might say, like life.

 At the Museum of Modern Art, Oxford (01865 722733), until January 7.

webTitle: 'It's a cruel thing to do, to put me to sleep'

fields.headline: 'It's a cruel thing to do, to put me to sleep'
fields.standfirst: How a death-row inmate with a mental age of six will die on Thursday - unless the state of Texas shows mercy
fields.trailText: How a death-row inmate with a mental age of six will die on Thursday - unless the state of Texas shows mercy
fields.byline: Raymond Bonner and Sara Rimer in Livingston, Texas
fields.body:
Even on death row, Johnny Paul Penry is an outcast, shunned by other inmates because of his learning disabilities. Penry, whose IQ has been tested at 56, spends his days colouring with crayons and looking at comics he cannot read, his lawyers say.Now, after 20 years on death row, he is due to be executed this Thursday by lethal injection.

Penry, 44, seems uncertain about just what that means. "The only thing what I know is that they will have a needle in my arm, just like an IV, that's going to put me to sleep," he said in a recent hour-long interview from behind a window on death row in Livingston, Texas. "I think it's a cruel thing to do, to put me to sleep."

He is to die for the 1979 rape and murder of Pamela Mosley Carpenter, 22, the daughter of a prominent local family, who was decorating her new home when he forced his way in. Penry was on parole after serving two years for an earlier rape.

Tormented childhood

Penry, who rode to the crime scene on his bicycle, was the son of an absent father who taunted him as retarded and a mother who tormented him because she considered him illegitimate, relatives said. According to family members and neighbours, when he was a child, his mother burned him in a scalding bath, locked him in his room without food or water and forced him to eat his own faeces and drink his own urine.

The case has attracted widespread attention. In 1989 it was the subject of a landmark ruling by the US supreme court which said it was not cruel and unusual punishment to execute those with learning disabilities. But a sharply divided court said that a jury had to consider evidence of such disabilities when deciding whether to impose the death sentence, and it ordered a new trial for Penry.

At his second trial, Penry was again sentenced to death.

Now, although his lawyers have appealed to the supreme court, arguing that the judge's instructions to the jury at the second trial were defective, the real battle is for the hearts of the 18 people on the Texas board of pardons and paroles, which has granted clemency in a capital case only once in the last five years. A wide range of individuals and organisations have asked the board to spare Penry's life.

Describing it as an "urgent humanitarian appeal", the European Union wrote that executions of people with learning disabilities "degrade the dignity and worth of the human person". The American Bar Association, which has no policy on the death penalty in general, wrote that such executions were "unacceptable in a civilised world".

In their arguments to the board, the state and Penry's lawyers reflect opposing attitudes to the death penalty. Almost half of the state's brief is devoted to graphic details of the crime, and it concludes by saying Penry should be executed "for the sake of Pamela Carpenter".

In contrast, Penry's lawyers barely mention the crime or the victim, and they ask for mercy for the defendant. The victim's family "has suffered an unspeakable loss and the hearts of everyone on the defence team go out to them", his lawyer, Robert Smith - whose New York law firm is representing Penry without a fee - wrote in his brief to the pardons board.

"The question before you now, however, is the appropriate punishment for Penry," Mr Smith said. "There is no societal retribution in killing a person with the mind of a six-year-old."

Of the 38 states which have capital punishment, 13 bar the execution of people with learning disabilities, as does federal law. The classification covers people with an IQ of below 70 who are unable to adapt to daily life. Those who oppose the execution of people with such disabilities say they lack the moral culpability to justify their receiving the ultimate punishment.

Last year, the Texas legislature rejected a bill that would have barred such executions. One of the prosecutors in the Penry case, William Lee Hon, an assistant district attorney, testified against the bill.

In an interview, Mr Hon said that he did not accept that Penry had learning disabilities, and he did not understand how the supreme court, in its 1989 opinion, agreed with such a finding. Mr Hon said that Penry was a "sociopath", and that he had been sent to schools for people with learning disabilities merely because he was "an uncontrollable child".

Penry was one of four siblings. His mother was 18 when he was born, and she was placed in a mental institution in Oklahoma for nearly a year after his birth, according to state records.

Penry's childhood has been described by his two sisters, an aunt, and a neighbour in court documents as one of unrelenting abuse at the hands of his mother.

"We were all abused, but he was abused the worst," said one of the sisters, Sally Belinda Potts Gonzales, who is two years younger than Penry. "She would beat him with anything in sight. She would threaten to gouge his eyeballs out with her long fingernails. She would threaten to cut off his private parts with a butcher knife."

She said that her mother had taken her brother out of school in the first grade because he had embarrassed her by getting in trouble climbing a flagpole.

Because Penry would wander around the neighbourhood, his mother locked him in his room for long periods without food or water. "When the poor kid got thirsty," his sister said, "she'd make him drink his urine out of the toilet."

Ms Gonzales added that as a child she had also seen her mother force Penry to eat his own faeces.

Mr Hon said he did not believe the accounts of the boy's abuse because he thought family members were not telling the truth, quoting their testimony that Penry had been scalded in a bath by his mother. The prosecutor said that Mrs Penry, who is now dead, had testified she left her son in the sink near a hot water heater, and that he had grabbed a hose line and sprayed himself.

Mr Hon said he believed the mother, adding: "Self-mutilation, even at that early age, would not surprise me."

When Penry was nine, his IQ was 56, according to a state psychologist's report. "John seems so seriously impaired that he is incapable of intellectually functioning at anything like an age-appropriate level," the report said.

At 12, Penry was institutionalised at the Mexia State School for the Mentally Retarded. When staff gave him a haircut, according to a school report, they noticed many small scars on his head. When he was asked about them, the report stated that staff were told: "They were from cuts made by a large belt buckle which his mother used when whipping him."

At 15, he was given a reading test, which required him to match drawings with the corresponding words. He identified a door as a dress, a chicken as a drum, and a hat as a flag, according to the test.

When he was 22, Penry was convicted of rape. A state psychiatrist found that he was still a bed-wetter, that his judgment was "severely impaired" and that he had little regard for others or even himself.

Penry said he had meant no harm to the woman he had raped, the psychiatrist wrote in his report, but that "he had never had a woman before and he wanted to see what it would be like".

Shunned in prison

He is not unaware that people say he has learning disabilities. "They say I have a mentality of a kid, but I don't know what that means," he said in the prison interview. "I wanted to learn so bad. I wanted to be just like you and everybody else. I can't. I'm very slow."

Penry said he knew that some inmates avoided him. "I have noticed some of the guys don't like talking to me because I can't carry on no conversation like most people," he said. "I'm not on their level. I ask them: 'What, do I bore you?'"

He said he spent 21 hours a day locked in his cell and one hour out of it. When asked how many hours there were in a day, he said, "I don't know, I think six." Asked how high he could count, he counted on his fingers to 10, then closed his eyes, clenched his fists and concentrated before replying: "To 40, I think."

As his execution date approaches, he said: "I'm scared. Sometimes, I take my head and pound it against the wall so bad that it hurts."

He went on: "I walk back and forth in my house and wonder why does it have to be me."

In another part of the interview, Penry talked about his belief in Santa Claus. "They keep talking about Santa Claus being down in the North Pole." he said. "Some people say it's not true. I got to where I do believe there's a Santa Claus."

webTitle: Philippine president put on trial

fields.headline: Philippine president put on trial
fields.trailText: A defiant President Joseph Estrada was impeached yesterday in the Philippines congress, but insisted that he would "face the trial" rather than resign.
fields.body:
A defiant President Joseph Estrada was impeached yesterday in the Philippines congress, but insisted that he would "face the trial" rather than resign.

There were cheers from the gallery as the house of representatives passed the indictment against Mr Estrada, on charges of corruption, in eight minutes flat.

He is accused of receiving 10m pesos (£140,000) every month for nearly two years as a payoff from an illegal gambling operation run by his former crony, provincial governor Luis Singson.

In another charge, Mr Estrada is said to have "unexplained wealth", arising from financial interests held by him and "his wife and mistresses and their children".

There was no debate or formal vote in the house where the assent of only one-third of its members is needed to bring the impeachment motion to the senate.

Government supporters complained loudly that the usual rules had not been observed, but opposition congressmen waved triumphantly and chanted "Erap [Mr Estrada's nickname] resign".

Mr Estrada dismissed in advance a nationwide strike set by the opposition for today, saying that "no amount of rally will force me to step down".

The president appealed to the working classes to support him, arguing that there was no need for demonstrations which would reduce confidence in the Filipino peso and threaten their jobs.

"The rally and strike will affect our countrymen, especially our poor workers who earn very little and who will go hungry if they do not get their daily wage even for one day," he said in a radio broadcast.

But Mr Estrada himself is widely regarded as the principal cause of the peso's slide while his populist appeal has weakened.

"The economic crisis is central because Erap is seen as a negative factor," says the economist Professor Walden Bello. "The fall of the currency has become a daily referendum on him."

Working class Filipinos no longer provide active support for Mr Estrada whom they voted to power in 1998. "But they are not going to denounce him either. They are very cynical about this whole process," says Mr Bello.

In other articles of impeachment, Mr Estrada is accused of participating directly in real estate business through a family-controlled corporation, and in using his position to secure favours for his "relatives, pals and friends".

He is also said to have spoken in favour of two sons who faced legal action after one was involved in a dispute at a hospital and the other failed to pay some hotel bills.

Members of Mr Estrada's coalition, who still command a theoretical majority in congress, are seeking to oust key figures in the impeachment process.

In a move initiated by an Estrada ally, the senate president, Franklin Drilon, a former presidential supporter who quit the coalition earlier this month and demanded Mr Estrada's resignation, was replaced by an independent , Aquilino Pimentel.

Commentators believe that Mr Estrada will show he is serious about not going down without a protracted political fight.

In a rival pro-Estrada rally staged on Saturday, hundreds of thousands of Filipinos had joined a "prayer meeting" in Manila. Many of them belonged to the charismatic Catholic movement El Shaddai which is run by the president's personal spiritual adviser.

At a much smaller rally on Sunday, Mr Estrada appeared on the same platform as Imelda Marcos in her home town, Batac.

She is the widow of the former president, Ferdinand Marcos, who was forced to flee in 1986 by a popular movement against his corrupt regime.

After Mrs Marcos told the rally she was "praying for the president and the Filipino people", Mr Estrada repaid the compliment by calling her "the most beautiful first lady in Philippine history".

The president's dwindling support sagged further after his admission last week that 400m pesos (£5.6m) was channelled into a youth fund controlled by his aides.

"He basically testified against himself," said opposition representative Isabela Alvarez. "He dug his own grave."

webTitle: 300 boys invade school in rape bid

fields.headline: 300 boys invade school in rape bid
fields.trailText: Three hundred Kenyan schoolboys tried to fight their way into a neighbouring co-educational school on Saturday night, allegedly in an attempt to rape the school's 200 female boarders.
fields.body:
Three hundred Kenyan schoolboys tried to fight their way into a neighbouring co-educational school on Saturday night, allegedly in an attempt to rape the school's 200 female boarders.

After a pitched battle with the girls and their male classmates lasting most of the night, the boys were dispersed when police arrived and fired shots over their heads. Thirty-four boys were yesterday arrested in connection with the attack, which apparently failed in its objective.

"This raid was well organised," said a teacher at the besieged Ndururmo Mixed High School in Kenya's Central Province, who wished to remain anonymous. "The invaders came dressed in our uniforms which they had stolen on Thursday night. We suspect they planned to rape the girls."

Several dozen students were injured in the attack, which began when the boys gathered around the girls' dormitory at 10pm, reportedly high on drink and drugs.

Alerted by the girls' screams as the intruders tried to force their way in, male pupils came running from their own dormitory to fight them off with broken-up chairs and other makeshift weapons.

Police called all 600 pupils of Nyahururu Boys High School, at the foot of Mt Kenya, to an inspection yesterday morning. Any boy with fresh cuts or bruises was arrested. However, many of the schoolboys were thought to be hiding in nearby maize fields to escape arrest.

The incident is only the latest example of the violence currently plaguing Kenya's schools. More than 100 pupil riots have been reported this year. In one recent incident, schoolboys torched their matron's house after she refused them access to their female classmates' dormitory. In another, high school pupils attempted to burn their prefects alive, complaining that they were too strict.

webTitle: Iran hardliners blamed for student bloodshed

fields.headline: Iran hardliners blamed for student bloodshed
fields.trailText: Iran's parliament issued a report yesterday saying that a conspiracy concocted by hardline clerics and executed by the country's security forces was responsible for a bloody crackdown last summer against pro-democracy students.
fields.body:
Iran's parliament issued a report yesterday saying that a conspiracy concocted by hardline clerics and executed by the country's security forces was responsible for a bloody crackdown last summer against pro-democracy students.

Reformist deputies who wrote the report said Iran's elite Revolutionary Guards and the Islamic militia, under the influence of hardline clerics and the protection of the judiciary, beat university students in the city of Khorramabad on August 24 to 27.

The young activists had gathered in the city for a national congress organised by the largest student group, the Office to Consolidate Unity. Four days of protest erupted after the Islamic militia blocked two religious scholars from leaving Khorramabad airport.

One policeman was killed and dozens of people were injured in the violence.

The long-awaited parliamentary report identified one of the gravest obstacles Iran faces in its struggle towards political development, namely that institutions within the state, not freelance vigilantes, are responsible for many of the periodic explosions against activists working for reform and democracy.

Factions within the Islamic militia, the Revolutionary Guards and the intelligence service have been accused in recent years of ordering the murderof dissident intellectuals, the beatingof students, and threats against those who oppose the conservative establishment. But there has been little documentation to substantiate these claims, making it difficult to prosecute the culprits.

"Some people have tried to say that ethical and geographical issues are responsible for the outburst of violence," the report says. "But the real reason was political violence-mongering and the unlawful use of levers of pressure by one faction in order to attain its own goals and to stop the other faction from continuing its programmes".

Student leaders declined to comment on the report, fearing repercussions for speaking to the western press.

The moderate president, Mohammad Khatami, was elected by a landslide in 1997 on a promise to bring law and order to Iran. But three years later, he still lacks control over the armed forces, which in Iran include the police.

In July 1999, hundreds of people were severely injured and an unknown number died in Tehran during five days of pro-democracy student demonstrations. Blame for the violence was placed upon the Islamic militia and the police.

The report also blames the state-owned television network, which is controlled by hardliners. The Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting caused the unrest to escalate, the report says, by airing sermons from hardline clerics, who stirred up hatred against the students.

webTitle: Israelis seal off towns after four deaths

fields.headline: Israelis seal off towns after four deaths
fields.trailText: Israel suffered its heaviest casualties in a single day since the current conflict began when Palestinian gunmen killed three Jewish settlers in the West Bank yesterday and a man in the Gaza Strip.
fields.body:
Israel suffered its heaviest casualties in a single day since the current conflict began when Palestinian gunmen killed three Jewish settlers in the West Bank yesterday and a man in the Gaza Strip.

In response, Israel moved to cordon off all Palestinian-ruled towns in the West Bank, said Major-General Yitzhak Eitan, Israel's West Bank commander. The move is a return to the widespread sanctions Israel lifted in mid-October.

A teacher in her car and two men on an army bus were killed in the drive-by shootings on a bypass road for Jewish settlers north-east of the West Bank city of Ramallah. Eight people were wounded. Later, an Israeli truck driver was shot dead in the Gaza Strip.

Two Palestinian teenagers were shot dead by Israeli soldiers near Khan Yunis, also in the Gaza Strip.

The convoy killings brought home the risks of the Israeli army's new policy of targeted attacks on armed Palestinian militants, which was put into effect four days ago. In recent weeks, leaders of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement have warned repeatedly of a shift in tactics away from popular protests to strategic attacks.

Stone-throwing protests by Palestinian youths are giving way to carefully calculated attacks on Israeli troops and the 200,000 Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza.

The Israeli military imposed curbs on movement in and out of self-ruled towns earlier in the seven-week Palestinian revolt, but Gen Eitan said the new closure policy would affect "most Palestinian towns and areas". In effect, only cars transporting food or medicine would be able to enter or leave sealed zones, he said.

Israeli military analysts are now predicting a long and nasty low-intensity conflict. Israel's army chief, Shaul Mofaz, says the fighting could drag on for a year.

Israel has the strongest army in the Middle East and the 40,000 lightly armed Palestinian police are no match for its tanks and helicopter gunships, but as this conflict descends into guerrilla war, its casualties are rising. Although Palestinians make up the vast majority of the more than 200 fatalities, yesterday's attack raises Israeli losses to six in just the last four days.

Yesterday's shootings followed almost nightly bursts of gunfire on the Jewish settlements of Gilo, built on occupied land south of Jerusalem, and on Psagot, a few hundred metres from Ramallah.

Israeli radio said the bus, which was travelling on a road built to serve the West Bank settlements of Ofra and Shilo, was riddled with 50-odd bullets from a passing Palestinian car.

The gunmen drove off towards Ramallah, which is under the control of Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority. Within hours of the attack, Palestinian radio reported shelling by tanks and helicopters of Silwad village, outside Ramallah.

The inevitable retaliation - and the use of heavy weaponry - illustrates the contradictions surrounding Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak.

On Sunday night, the Israeli prime minister told President Bill Clinton that he remained committed to dialogue. A spokesman said Mr Barak took "a grave view of the continuing violations of [Israel's] understanding with the Palestinians by the Palestinian Authority".

Later, an Israeli truck driver was shot dead in the Gaza Strip. Two Palestinian teenagers were shot dead by Israeli soldiers near Khan Yunis, also in the Gaza Strip. The convoy killings brought home the risks of the Israeli army's new policy of targeted attacks on armed Palestinian militants, which was put into effect four days ago. In recent weeks, leaders of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement have warned repeatedly of a shift in tactics away from popular protests to strategic attacks. Stone-throwing protests by Palestinian youths are giving way to carefully calculated attacks on Israeli troops and the 200,000 Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza. The Israeli military imposed curbs on movement in and out of self-ruled towns earlier in the seven-week Palestinian revolt, but Gen Eitan said the new closure policy would affect "most Palestinian towns and areas". In effect, only cars transporting food or medicine would be able to enter or leave sealed zones, he said. Israeli military analysts are now predicting a long and nasty low-intensity conflict. Israel's army chief, Shaul Mofaz, says the fighting could drag on for a year. Israel has the strongest army in the Middle East and the 40,000 lightly armed Palestinian police are no match for its tanks and helicopter gunships, but as this conflict descends into guerrilla war, its casualties are rising. Although Palestinians make up the vast majority of the more than 200 fatalities, yesterday's attack raises Israeli losses to six in just the last four days. Yesterday's shootings followed almost nightly bursts of gunfire on the Jewish settlements of Gilo, built on occupied land south of Jerusalem, and on Psagot, a few hundred metres from Ramallah. Israeli radio said the bus, which was travelling on a road built to serve the West Bank settlements of Ofra and Shilo, was riddled with 50-odd bullets from a passing Palestinian car. The gunmen drove off towards Ramallah, which is under the control of Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority. Within hours of the attack, Palestinian radio reported shelling by tanks and helicopters of Silwad village, outside Ramallah. The inevitable retaliation - and the use of heavy weaponry - illustrates the contradictions surrounding Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak. On Sunday night, the Israeli prime minister told President Bill Clinton that he remained committed to dialogue. A spokesman said Mr Barak took "a grave view of the continuing violations of [Israel's] understanding with the Palestinians by the Palestinian Authority".

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Somali MP shot dead
fields.body:
Somali MP shot dead

Gunmen killed a member of Somalia's new parliament outside his house in Mogadishu on Sunday, witnesses said yesterday.

The killing of Hassan Ahmed Elmi took place in a district controlled by Muse Sudi Yalahow, a faction leader opposed to the new government. But a commander of Mr Yalahow's private militia said his gunmen were not responsible.
AP, Mogadishu

Earthquake shakes Turkey

An earthquake hit northwestern Turkey yesterday, a day after the first anniversary of a quake that killed more than 800 people in the region, an official said.

Residents of the town of Duzce fled their homes after the 4.3-magnitude quake struck the area. No injuries were reported.
Reuters, Ankara

Ebola toll rises to 110 in Uganda

A woman who fled a hospital in northern Uganda when she feared she had contracted the Ebola virus has died together with three relatives, raising the death toll in the outbreak to 110, a health official said yesterday.
AP, Kampala

webTitle: Neo-Nazi tormentors get light sentences

fields.headline: Neo-Nazi tormentors get light sentences
fields.trailText: There was uproar in Germany yesterday after a court in the eastern city of Cottbus passed lenient sentences on 11 young neo-Nazis who last year hunted an asylum seeker to his death.
fields.body:
There was uproar in Germany yesterday after a court in the eastern city of Cottbus passed lenient sentences on 11 young neo-Nazis who last year hunted an asylum seeker to his death.

Only three, who were convicted of manslaughter, were given jail terms - of just two to three years. Two were let off with warnings. The remaining six were given suspended sentences of between one and two years.

The outcome of the trial came as a big setback to the drive by the German government to clamp down on the far right and promote greater tolerance of foreigners.

Its campaign, which has won the backing of all Germany's mainstream parties, inspired a demonstration last week that brought more than 200,000 people on to the streets of Berlin in support of a multi-ethnic society.

The general secretary of the liberal Free Democrats, Guido Westerwelle, said: "I find it hard to take this sentence, even to the point of retaining my composure." Mr Westerwelle, who worked as a lawyer in the juvenile courts before entering politics, said the suspended sentences and warnings were "incomprehensible".

Farid Guendoul from Algeria died in the town of Guben near the Polish border in January 1999. He had hurled himself through the glass door of a house to get away from his pursuers and severed an artery at the knee. He bled to death in 15 minutes.

During the trial, the court heard how the defendants had set out to catch a Cuban they suspected of carrying out a machete attack on one of their associates.

The judge in his summing up acknowledged that their manhunt was well-prepared: three cars were used, and the defendants coordinated their movements by mobile telephone.

After they failed to find their intended victim, they embarked on an indiscriminate anti-foreigner rampage. Screaming "We'll get you all!" and "Hate! Hate! Hate!", the defendants threw paving stones at an Asian corner shop and a Vietnamese restaurant before targeting Mr Guendoul and two other asylum seekers.

The trial and the circumstances surrounding it reeked of tolerance for the activities of the neo-Nazi right.

In court, the defendants felt free to pull faces, insult witnesses and deride evidence. Their lawyers held up the proceedings with a flood of objections that dragged out the hearing for 17 months.

The speaker of the lower house of parliament, Wolfgang Thierse, called the delays "scandalous".

Only one defendant pleaded guilty. He was subsequently beaten up in a disco.

His co-defendants got a foretaste of the outcome when one of them was convicted of beating up an immigrant while still on trial. He was ordered to pay DM500 (£150) to charity.

Other defendants were alleged to have tried to destroy a memorial to Mr Guendoul while the trial was in progress. It has been defaced five times since it was put up.

One of the two men hunted with Mr Guendoul later lost his right to stay in Germany on the grounds that he was no longer mentally fit to manage his life by himself. However, he and his lawyer maintained that this was because of the trauma he had undergone as a result of the manhunt.

After Mr Thierse publicly criticised the regional authorities who had taken the decision, the man was granted permission to stay.

The victim's brothers announced that they intended to lodge an appeal against the sentences. But their lawyer said they did not have the funds needed to pursue the case further.

The lawyer added: "They are shocked. They had believed that would get a just outcome from Germany, as a state governed by the rule of law".

webTitle: US presidential battle moves to the courtrooms

fields.headline: US presidential battle moves to the courtrooms
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore was yesterday still clinging to an outside chance of winning the White House when a federal judge in Miami threw out a Republican bid to halt a manual vote recount in the pivotal state of Florida.
fields.byline: Julian Borger in Miami and Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
Al Gore was yesterday still clinging to an outside chance of winning the White House when a federal judge in Miami threw out a Republican bid to halt a manual vote recount in the pivotal state of Florida.

But the week ahead looks fraught with legal battles, after Florida's Republican secretary of state, Katherine Harris, insisted that the hand recounts be finished by 5pm today, a task that will probably be impossible in three of the four counties where the Democrats have called for a new tally.

The Gore camp went to a judge in the Florida state capital, Tallahassee, to overturn Ms Harris's decision. Meanwhile, the Republicans were considering whether to take their fight to block a manual count to an appeals court, and perhaps the supreme court.

In the south Florida district court yesterday, Judge Donald Middlebrooks listened to con flicting arguments about the relative powers of the federal and state governments, before rejecting a Republican attempt to stop the hand count in Florida on constitutional grounds. "While I share a desire for finality, I do not believe it is served by involving a federal court," he said.

Yesterday afternoon the Texas governor, George W Bush, was ahead in the Florida count by 388 votes, after two automated tallies. The Democratic party has argued that the vote-counting machines systematically undercounted Mr Gore's support. They have called for manual recounts in Palm Beach, Broward, Volusia and Miami-Dade.

Following the Miami ruling, all attention switched to Ms Harris, a friend of Mr Bush's brother, Jeb, the governor of Florida. Defying strong pressure from the Gore camp for the deadline to be extended to allow the completion of the hand recounts, Ms Harris said she intended to stick to 5pm as the final time by which certified results must be received by her office.

Only Volusia county is likely to have completed its hand count by that time.

The final results from Florida would be fully certified on Saturday, Mrs Harris said, once overseas postal votes had been counted.

webTitle: It's divine justice, Gore is told

fields.headline: It's divine justice, Gore is told
fields.standfirst:
Drugs policy denied vote to 2m blacks
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore may have lost America's presidential election not because of a badly designed ballot, dubious counting practices in Florida or the defection of independents to Ralph Nader, but because of the criminal justice policy he and Bill Clinton have pursued for the past eight years.
fields.body:
Al Gore may have lost America's presidential election not because of a badly designed ballot, dubious counting practices in Florida or the defection of independents to Ralph Nader, but because of the criminal justice policy he and Bill Clinton have pursued for the past eight years.

That policy appears to have robbed the Democrats of victory by disenfranchising nearly one in three black men in Florida, most of whose votes he would have received.

Figures published yesterday show that 92% of black voters in the south backed Mr Gore, compared with 7% per cent for George W Bush, in last Tuesday's election. Elsewhere in the US, Mr Gore led Mr Bush by 85% to 12% among black men and 94% to 6% among black women.

A total of 4.2m Americans were not allowed to vote last Tuesday because they were in prison or had felony convictions. Of those, more than one third, or around 1.8m, were black, according to the Sentencing Project, a Washington-based group that researches and campaigns on the issue. Nationally, this amounts to 13% of all black men.

The Sentencing Project, a Washington-based organisation that campaigns for alternatives to jail, and Human Rights Watch examined the extent of disenfranchisement in 1998 and discovered that in two states, Florida and Alabama, 31% of all black men were permanently disenfranchised because of convictions, many for non-violent offences. In five other states, including the marginal states of Iowa and New Mexico, one in four black men were permanently disenfranchised, and in Texas one in five black men could not vote. Only Maine, Vermont and Massachusetts allow those jailed for felonies to vote.

"In a stroke of divine justice, it turns out he [Gore] might have easily won Florida had it not been for the felony disenfranchisement laws that disproportionately strip the vote from African-American men," said Sanho Tree, director of the drug policy project of the Institute for Policy Studies in Washington. "Let's hope he ponders this long and hard while he waits for the recount."

The Clinton-Gore adminis tration has been heavily criticised by penal reformers for its "war on drugs" which has led to more than 400,000 people being jailed, a disproportionate number being black and Latino.

Only the states of Maine, Vermont and Massachusetts allow those convicted of felonies to vote.

Cedric Muhammad, editor of the blackelectorate.com website, writes in his latest bulletin: "If he [Gore] and his supporters are honest, they may have to blame the Clinton-Gore administration and a criminal justice system that locked up blacks wholesale over the last eight years for non-violent offences.

"Because 13% of all black men [nationally] cannot vote because of incarceration and past felony convictions, and because this presidential election is so close, it may well be true that blacks who have served their time in prison and gone on to lead productive and reformed lives could have provided the margin of victory for Al Gore and Democrats if they were allowed to vote."

Attempts to extend voting rights to ex-offenders have been stalled for more than a year by the House of Representatives' judiciary committee, and some see the disenfranchisement as a subtle form of denying the vote to a substantial part of the black community.

Whether or not the Democrats examine this issue as a result 5of the closeness of the election, they will certainly accept that they have to pay their dues to Jesse Jackson and other leading African-Americans for mobilising the black vote so successfully. The Rev Jackson and the local unions played a key part in Mr Gore's victory in the vital state of Pennsylvania, and it was notable during the final days of the campaign that the Gore team relied increasingly on the organisational skills of the black churches.

President Clinton chose mainly black audiences and venues for his pro-Gore electioneering.

It was noticeable after the first televised presidential debate that one of the first peo ple Mr Gore embraced was the Rev Jackson. His son, Jesse Jackson Jnr, a Democratic party congressman from Chicago, also played a major part in trying to persuade the left not to stray to Mr Nader. The National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People, meanwhile, spent £4.9m on advertising, mailings, telephone calls and leafletting in an attempt to get the black vote out.

webTitle: Deadline for hand counts raises new fears

fields.headline: Deadline for hand counts raises new fears
fields.standfirst:
Democrats fear suspected errors will go unchecked
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Only one Florida county is likely to meet today's 5pm deadline to complete a hand count of the presidential vote, raising the prospect that hundreds of thousands of mainly Democratic votes will not be counted, and paving the way for a political crisis.
fields.body:
Only one Florida county is likely to meet today's 5pm deadline to complete a hand count of the presidential vote, raising the prospect that hundreds of thousands of mainly Democratic votes will not be counted, and paving the way for a political crisis.

As of yesterday, Governor George W Bush was still leading the presidential race in Florida by more than 380 votes after two automated counts, but Democrats have argued that that margin might be overturned if the count was checked by hand.

They have also called for recounts in four populous and largely Democratic counties, where Gore supporters said there were irregularities or the possibility of an error in the machine count.

Of those four counties, only Volusia (the area surrounding Daytona beach on the east Florida coast) is likely to have completed its manual count by the deadline laid down by the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, for the counties to certify their vote.

After completing a sample recount over the weekend, Palm Beach county authorities decided to go ahead with a full hand recount yesterday, but with about 430,000 votes to count, there seemed almost no chance the task could be completed on time.

It took 11 hours for the sample count of fewer than 5,000 votes on Saturday.

"This will take six days in 14-hour shifts from 7am to 9pm," said the Palm Beach elections supervisor Therese LePore. She said there would be two seven-hour shifts for workers and that the count would be conducted at the county's emergency operations centre.

Meanwhile, officials in Broward county only began a manual recount of a sample group of precincts yesterday. And the huge Miami-Dade area is only due to decide today on whether to have recount at all.

In each county, Democrats have argued that there is reason to believe that there were irregularities in the vote-counting process which may have led to an under-counting of votes for vice-president Gore.

In Volusia, where more than 184,000 votes were cast, computers which read ballot papers by optical scan broke down in one precinct, and produced an impossible result in another precinct.

Meanwhile, in Palm Beach county the ballot was in the form of a punchcard, with which voters indicated their preferences by punching out a small perforated rectangle alongside their candidate's name.

Democrats argued that some of those small rectangles, called "chad", clung to the voting card and were pushed back into their hole when the cards were fed into the vote counting machines, nullifying the vote.

Furthermore, more than 19,000 votes in the county were invalidated after last Tuesday's vote because they were double-punched and hundreds of people complained that a confusing ballot paper led them to vote accidentally for the Reform Party's Pat Buchanan instead of Democrat Al Gore.

Even if today's Florida deadline holds, it would not represent the end of the count, which would only come on Friday evening with a final tally of absentee ballots sent in by Americans living abroad.

Republicans have argued that they traditionally win a majority of the absentee ballot as many overseas voters are in the armed forces. However, Democrats argue that they have solid support among the lower ranks in forces, and they say they expect thousands of votes from Jewish Floridians living in Israel, who traditionally support the Democratic party.

Officials from Volusia county yesterday went to court in Tallahassee to lift Ms Harris's deadline.

Although they expected to certify their count in time, they said they wanted to avoid any risk that the county's vote would not be counted.

In announcing her decision, Ms Harris said that any county which had not completed its count and certified its vote in time would not be counted in the final Florida tally.

However, the state's agriculture commissioner and electoral board member, Bob Crawford, said that if the state authorities did not receive county results by Tuesday they would certify the election with the latest machine recount from every county.

Meanwhile, vote-checking and recounting was also under way in Oregon, New Mexico and Iowa were the vote was also too close too call.

At one point, Mr Bush was leading by only 17 votes in New Mexico, in the closest presidential election in recent US history.

webTitle: A taste for quiet and a talent for discord

fields.headline: A taste for quiet and a talent for discord
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: When Katherine Harris was elected Florida secretary of state she said modestly she was not seeking prominence greater than that which came with the job.
fields.body:
When Katherine Harris was elected Florida secretary of state she said modestly she was not seeking prominence greater than that which came with the job.

Two years later, the responsibilities discharged by 43-year-old Ms Harris include elections in the state, and it is for this that she will be remembered across the world after imposing a deadline of 5pm today on certification of the results.

Ms Harris, a Republican who has served in the state senate, is a friend of Jeb Bush, the state's governor, and sat on the election committee of George W.

"She is a long-standing supporter of governor Bush and I think her statement has to be seen in that context," Warren Christopher, the Gore campaign's chief emissary to Florida, said yesterday. In private, other Democrats described her as a crony of the Bush brothers.

The secretary of state is a member of one of Florida's grandest political families and is the richest member of the cabinet, her personal wealth put at $6.6m, unremarkable, however, in a system that makes one in every four members of the Florida senate and house of representatives a millionaire. The average household income in the state is below $30,000.

Her grandfather, a fruit-growing magnate, served in the state legislature and her father was active in Democratic politics. "Everyone I knew growing up was a Democrat," she says.

webTitle: As tension rises in Florida, five more states brace for recounts

fields.headline: As tension rises in Florida, five more states brace for recounts
fields.standfirst:
Another 34 college votes at stake
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A week after the closest US presidential election in decades, the results still remained in doubt in five other states, as well as Florida yesterday.
fields.body:
A week after the closest US presidential election in decades, the results still remained in doubt in five other states, as well as Florida yesterday.

The five states, with a combined 34 electoral college votes at stake, were bracing for the possibility of recounts and legal challenges which could leave the results uncertain until into next month, if not beyond.

Realistically, the situations in Iowa, New Hampshire, New Mexico, Oregon and Wisconsin seem likely to be left alone by the two political parties unless the disputes in Florida spill out into a nationwide re-examination of every close result later this week.

The latest position in the five was that that Al Gore led by 4,949 in Iowa, by 5,756 in Oregon and by 6,099 in Wisconsin. George W Bush led by 7,782 in New Hampshire and by 17 in New Mexico.

Mr Gore remained ahead as counting continued in Oregon's all-postal ballot election, with the state's seven electoral college votes still at stake, but an automatic recount looked a possibility. About 40,000 Oregon votes remained uncounted early yesterday.

Like Florida, Oregon has a state law which triggers an au tomatic recount if the margin of victory if less than 0.2%, equivalent to about 2,800 votes.

The results in Iowa (seven electoral college votes) and Wisconsin (11 votes) still favoured Mr Gore as well, but the margins of victory were so close that Republicans may call for recounts, depending partly on events in Florida.

Iowa does not have an auto matic recount provision, but candidates may request recounts within three days of the final tabulation of results, which is expected to be issued today. Iowa's 99 counties would have 18 days to complete a recount.

A similar timetable applies in Wisconsin, where the final tabulation is also expected today. Either candidate has until Friday to request a recount in any or all of the state's 72 counties.

Yesterday was the deadline for a recount call against Mr Bush's narrow victory in New Hampshire (four votes), where officials said the result had tightened to 7,068 votes.

The back-and-forth situation in New Mexico (five electoral college votes) seems likely to trigger further challenges, with Mr Gore's original 6,825 vote lead switching to a wafer-thin 17-vote majority for Mr Bush. Counting of New Mexico postal votes is expected to be completed this week.

Mr Gore's election-night advantage dwindled away after some 60,000 postal, damaged and early ballots had all been counted, and after 252 missing votes were discovered in a locked box in one election supervision office.

webTitle: A Country Diary

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Somerset
fields.trailText: Somerset
fields.body:
By the time I got to the farm-sale, it was hard to get a footing at the waterlogged entrance to the field marked "Car Park". Inside, items of farm machinery were scattered across a big space.

There were tractors, trailers, muck-spreaders, ploughs, harrows, a yard-scraper and a concrete mixer. The auctioneer had by now moved into the barn to dispose of the stock. This was a County farm of 140 acres with about 90 milking cows, and was for sale because the long-term tenants were to take semi-retirement.

The sale had attracted a big proportion of the farming community from miles around. It was a popular social event, an opportunity for friends to gather, reminisce, and show their regard for a family that had worked hard and done well. There was satisfaction that the County was not to sell the farmhouse for profit or the land for development. This will still be a working farm. A good crowd was gathered for the cattle auction; the first to be sold, the best milkers, were fetching 500 or 600 guineas.

The cows had not been milked that morning so as to be shown with udders full; some of them were already waiting to be let in to the milking parlour. They enjoy the milking; it is a relief, the parlour is warm, dry and familiar, and a ration of palatable cake is released when the cowman pulls on a rope. One of these cows had learned to twist her neck round, pull the rope herself, and so get an extra delivery of cake. This herd, described in the catalogue as having "good feet and tidy udders", was to be dispersed in bits and pieces later in the day. Now they must adapt to new environments, groupings and pecking orders. It may take time to learn how to get extra cake.

webTitle: Soldiers accused of Ulster atrocity

fields.headline: Soldiers accused of Ulster atrocity
fields.standfirst:
Bloody Sunday troops 'castrated man then dumped his body'

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Paratroopers who fired on civil rights demonstrators in Derry went on to electrocute and castrate a man, the Bloody Sunday inquiry was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Paratroopers who fired on civil rights demonstrators in Derry went on to electrocute and castrate a man, the Bloody Sunday inquiry was told yesterday.

The allegation was made as the inquiry into the events of January 30 1972 reopened, while later a lawyer representing families of many of the 13 killed described the killings as the result of failures, misjudgments and "wholly unacceptable" policies at the highest political and military levels.

The alleged atrocity, a month after Bloody Sunday, was described by Christopher Clarke QC, counsel to the Saville inquiry, reading a statement from a paratrooper, identified only as soldier 027. The inquiry had heard allegations by 027 that fellow paratroopers used illegal dum-dum bullets and deliberately shot unarmed civilians on Bloody Sunday.

Material passed to the inquiry by the Irish government in September included a description by 027 of an operation in Divis Flats, west Belfast, in which soldiers G and F "ran a man bent double between them into the plating of a pig [army slang for an armoured personnel carrier]".

According to the account, Mr Clarke said, the man was "knocked out but then revived, and thrown into the back of the pig where he was electrocuted in some way, castrated, sliced in the face with a knife, and kicked and beaten. The statement then asserts that his body was taken to the Shankill and dumped to await his fate."

Another soldier, H, had since denied knowledge of any such event, or of robbing the civilian inside the vehicle.

Soldier 027 agreed to give evidence to the Saville inquiry in exchange for a personal security package from the Northern Ireland Office worth £44,000. His claim that his written evidence to the original Widgery inquiry in 1972 was fabricated by government lawyers, helped persuade the prime minister to set up the Saville inquiry in 1998.

Mr Clarke also played a recording of conversations from the Victoria barracks on Bloody Sunday - apparently bugged by the IRA - and said to be soldiers speaking of "things going badly wrong".

According to the tape, General Robert Ford, then deputy commander in Northern Ireland, was jubilant at the outcome of Bloody Sunday. Three weeks earlier, he allegedly recommended shooting selected ringleaders of the youths who regularly rioted in Derry.

A version of the tape, played to a news conference in Dublin in 1974, was alleged by one witness, James Ferry, to have been seized by Garda special branch in a raid in Ireland in 1976.

Madden and Finucane, solicitors representing most of the Bloody Sunday victims, wrote to the Garda commissioner, Pat Byrne, in 1999 asking whether he held the tape. The inquiry had also asked the Irish government for the tape, but had received no substantive reply, Mr Clarke said.

Arthur Harvey QC, for many of the victims, later compared Bloody Sunday with the Sharpville and Tiananmen Square massacres. He said the 1972 Widgery inquiry was tainted, and designed to save the faces of the then government and the army.

A memorandum by the secretary to the Widgery tribunal, William Smith, recording that Lord Widgery would "pile up the case against the deceased" in the face of doubts over forensic tests used to conclude that some had been handling weapons that day.

The document also noted that Brigadier Patrick MacLellan, in charge overall that day, "loyally covered up for his subordinates" over whether the operation was bungled.

Mr Harvey said: "The truth is that soldiers of the 1st Battalion, the Parachute Regiment, opened fire on an unarmed people, most of whom were in flight. It killed 13 and wounded 14, not simply as a result of some 27 acts of individual indiscipline, but rather as a result of failures, misjudgments and wholly unacceptable policies made at the highest level both politically and militarily. The truth is that, when the disastrous consequences became known to the defence ministry and the government of the day, they quite literally launched a cover-up."

webTitle: Ministers 'gutted' Patten report on Ulster policing

fields.headline: Ministers 'gutted' Patten report on Ulster policing
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A senior member of the Patten commission today launches a powerful attack on the government for "gutting" the independent report on the future of policing in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
A senior member of the Patten commission today launches a powerful attack on the government for "gutting" the independent report on the future of policing in Northern Ireland.

In the most outspoken intervention by a member of the commission, Professor Clifford Shearing subjects the government's Police (Northern Ireland) Bill to a line-by-line analysis to prove that it bears little relation to Chris Patten's original recommendations.

"The Patten report has not been cherry picked, it has been gutted," he writes in today's Guardian.

Prof Shearing, director of the Centre of Criminology at the University of Toronto, says the bill, which faces its third reading in the Lords tomorrow, "dismantles the foundations" of the report in key areas:

 It waters down the report's recommendation for a power ful board by limiting its budget and its power to investigate police wrongdoing. "The bill completely eviscerates these proposals," he writes.

 It dilutes the powers of district policing partnerships (DPPs) which are designed to involve local councils in the new force. Nationalists are angry that Mr Patten's proposal for the DPPs to raise their own funds has been abandoned.

 It abandons the Patten report's "core project" to improve security in Northern Ireland in the broadest sense - beyond simply reforming the police. The bill focuses solely on the police, rather than the wider issues of policing, he says. "It reflects the limited conception of policing Patten sought to transcend."

The bill fails to "fulfill the hopes and vision" of the Good Friday agreement, which called for a "new beginning" for policing, he says. "The core elements of the Patten commission's report have been undermined everywhere."

His intervention was hailed last night by nationalists. Gerry Kelly, Sinn Fein's policing spokesman, said: "It underlines exactly what Sinn Fein have been saying for a number of months. It shows the lie Peter Mandelson [the Northern Ireland secretary] has been purveying - that the Patten report has been implemented fully and faithfully."

The government last night rejected Prof Shearing's criticisms. A source said: "We are keeping to the essence of Patten. But equally that means recognising that Patten said that the new force should evolve out of the old."

Some of the strongest criticisms of the government have focused on its plans to keep alive memories of the RUC by incorporating the old name in the "title deeds" of the bill setting up the new force. Ministers say this is in line with the Patten report, which said the RUC should not be disbanded.

webTitle: Getting personal with... Bear

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Bear
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Bear
fields.body:
Full Name:
Bear

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?

No, "bear years" are different from "people years"(I go by a "Luna calendar"), so let's say I'm a grown-up bear who's still in touch with his "inner cub".

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Are you a home body? Do you like walks by an Otter Pond? Do you like quiet conversations with the moon? Do you love to dance and sing? Adult male home-owner would like to meet you.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

I'm a good bear.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

I like to lend my hand or paw. We all pitched in and raised money to help the muskrats who live down by the river build new homes after their flood.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

I've met a lot of nice people. Folks like Donny and Marie Osmond, I've even met President Clinton. Now how many bears in a Big Blue House get to meet the guy in the big white house?

What would you advertise without a fee?

Shriner's Hospitals and in London I visited the Coram Family Centre for creative services to children and parents.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?

Funny you should ask. Just the other night I dreamt I was eating a giant marshmallow. Then, I woke up and my pillow was gone.

What takes you to a "happy place"?

The stairs in the house lead up to the attic, where I have nightly conversations with Luna the Moon, but usually it's my nose.

Bear In The Big Blue House is on Playhouse Disney Channel every day.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Plunkett and Macleane | Monty Python's Life Of Brian | This Year's Love | Caligula
fields.body:
Plunkett and Macleane

(Jake Scott, 1999)

9.45pm, Sky Premier

Jake Scott directs this tale of 18th-century highwaymen as though it were one of his dad, Ridley's sci-fi forays: Blade Riders, perhaps, full of exotic visuals and pumping dance music. But unlike his father's films, there's not much else to enjoy beyond the sheer elan: the chaotic plot has Robert Carlyle's lowly Plunkett teaming up with Jonny Lee Miller's gentlemanly Macleane to steal from the rich - and keep it. Liv Tyler is underemployed as Macleane's wench and Ken Stott is a pantomime baddy.

Monty Python's Life Of Brian

(Terry Jones, 1979)

10pm, FilmFour

Howls of protest greeted the Python team's supposedly sacrilegious romp through the New Testament. Among many funny skits, the Sermon on the Mount stands out: far down the hill, one listener to another: "What's he say? Blessed are the cheese-makers?" The whole Python crew is here: Jones, Cleese, Palin, Idle, Gilliam, and Chapman as the hapless Brian.

This Year's Love

(David Kane, 1998)

11.30pm, Sky Premier

Kane's comedy covers a year in the lives of a semi bohemian Camden Town. It opens with the wedding of Danny (Douglas Henshall) and Hannah (Catherine McCormack), but the marriage fails even before they get to the honeymoon. She takes up with the Ian Hart; Danny with pub rocker Kathy Burke. Womaniser Dougray Scott and wealthy Sophie Ehle also cross their paths.

Caligula

(Tinto Brass, 1979)

11.40pm, FilmFour

Depending on your peccadillos, you'll be pleased or saddened to learn that this version of Tinto Brass's infamous view of ancient Rome in flagrante has been snipped to remove much of producer and Penthouse boss Bob Guccione's tacky pornographic additions. What's left is still no classic. Malcolm McDowell as the mad emperor Caligula, Peter O'Toole as Tiberius, Helen Mirren the rampant Caesonia and John Gielgud a noble old senator: all, along with writer Gore washed their hands of it.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Unearthing Mysteries | File On 4
fields.body:
Last April German officials presented the Russian president Vladimir Putin with an elaborately inlaid chest and a tiny fragment of amber. They were apparently all that's left of the Amber Room , an 11-foot square, bejewelled chamber which the Prussian king gave Peter the Great in 1716. It remained at Tsarskoye Selo, the imperial residence near St Petersburg, until Nazi troops packed it up as loot in 1941. No one has seen it since. But, as Aubrey Manning reports in Unearthing Mysteries (11.0am, Radio 4), they are still looking.

The eccentric workings of the European single market are examined by Mark Whitaker for File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). One of the community's key policies is designed to spread the richest regions' wealth to struggling peripheral areas. Yet a British government scheme to attract private investment to the north-east has been ruled illegal. It would, the commission claimed, give some of the enterprises there an unfair advantage.

They were apparently all that's left of the Amber Room , an 11-foot square, bejewelled chamber which the Prussian king gave Peter the Great in 1716. It remained at Tsarskoye Selo, the imperial residence near St Petersburg, until Nazi troops packed it up as loot in 1941. No one has seen it since. But, as Aubrey Manning reports in Unearthing Mysteries (11.0am, Radio 4), they are still looking. The eccentric workings of the European single market are examined by Mark Whitaker for File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). One of the community's key policies is designed to spread the richest regions' wealth to struggling peripheral areas. webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: A touch of class
fields.trailText: Human Remains - An English Squeak | Coronation Street | The Royle Family
fields.body:
Like an elephant out for an evening amble, you could unsuspectingly fall into the elephant trap of Human Remains - An English Squeak (BBC2), the first of a six-part series.

Peter and Flick (Rob Brydon and Julia Davis) live in a half-timbered manor house with flowers just foaming round its foundations. Much like the Tavistocks, who were recently kind enough to show us round their lovely home. On the face of it, it's a documentary about a nicer class of person altogether (as my mother called the shifty crew in the billiard room, who paid an extra penny for their beer and kept their illegal betting slips inside their trilby hats.)

Peter said of Flick "She's matured into something very regal, with more than a passing resemblance to Camilla Parker-Bowles. Lucky, old Peter." Flick showed her excellent teeth in a wide smile and said "I think a husband is in many way like having a pet. Peter is always under my feet and one sometimes wishes one could put them outside."

(Curiously, this was also the downmarket Vera Duckworth's opinion of husbands in Coronation Street, "You're lucky if you can 'ouse-train 'em, let alone change 'em.")

You slowly noticed that the ill-named Felicity sometimes used a crutch, an eyepatch and even a wheelchair and you adjusted your face accordingly. She said, "I have vaginismus which has caused me a number of problems, sporadic blindness, limb seizures and a swelling of the brain in damp conditions." It also prevented her having sex with Peter.

"Even a small penis", said Peter pitifully, "feels like an aubergine."

Which brought us briskly to Geoffrey, Flick's late fiancé, whose penis actually was like an aubergine. As he was always filmed from knee height, he looked like Rupert Brooke winning the high jump without a pole. (He also looked like Rob Brydon in a wig.) Peter, who was now clutching a cushion for comfort, said Geoffrey was really very good at everything he did. "He was medically a giant. A huge, bright, spectacular man", said Flick, fondling her photos. "Small head for the size of body, though", said Peter. "Darling, your hand is in a fist", said Flick.

Geoffrey, though so good at everything, drowned in a punting accident and is now buried at the bottom of their garden. Vertically. In his riding outfit. Possibly on his horse. Flick intends to be buried beside him "Curved around him rather like a banana, which was one of our very favourite positions." Peter is to be buried beside his guinea pig. Meanwhile, each finds consolation with the staff.

Does anyone share my strong suspicion that Geoffrey was done in?

In the delightful series Marion And Geoff (which continues on BBC2 tonight) Rob Brydon plays a minicab driver of preternatural sweetness, whose wife, Marion, has run away with a thrusting hotshot, called, what else, Geoffrey. An English Squeak was essentially the same story. I liked it fine the first time around.

In Coronation Street (Granada) Rita and Anthony, who says he is a theatre critic, were enjoying a civilised glass of claret, to which admittedly theatre critics are partial, when his brother-in-law, George, burst in crying "My sister is lying ill while you gad about with this trollop!" (Believed to be a reference to Rita, a woman whose impregnable respectability is reinforced with sequined sweaters.) Trollop, forsooth. The very word brings tears to your eyes. Trollops used to go on the stage and die in disgrace and Biarritz. I thought Painted Trollops were extinct, driven out by the Common Slapper, as the red squirrel was by the grey. We must do our utmost to conserve them. Trollops are a glory and a splendour and a wonder and we should not be responsible for their disappearance. Sir David Attenborough says so. Tony Blair's stepmother-in-law, Elsie Tanner, was one of the great trollops of her time. I hope we can count on his active support.

Nan in The Royle Family (BBC 1): "Barbara, did you see that programme last night with that woman that I like? She's posh and she talks like this, (adopts an excruciatingly cut-glass voice) 'Hello, Terry Wogan. How are you?' She's always got a cigarette in one hand and a glass of booze in the other. What's she called?"

Is it (a) Princess Margaret (b) Mrs Wogan (c) Joanna Lumley (d) Dame Judy Dench. Do you want to phone a friend?

webTitle: MPs warn post offices rescue plan is threatened

fields.headline: MPs warn post offices rescue plan is threatened
fields.trailText: Ministers may be unable to prevent a rising rate of post office closures unless they review plans to give them a new role, MPs warn today.
fields.body:
Ministers may be unable to prevent a rising rate of post office closures unless they review plans to give them a new role, MPs warn today.

In a report on the future of the post office network the trade and industry select committee cast doubt over the cornerstone of the government's plans to give the post offices new income, because of hostility from high street banks and unrealistic costings.

The government has tried to defuse a politically explosive collapse in the network of 18,000 post offices by negotiating new markets for them, including proposals that they become a universal bank for the socially excluded.

The government has proposed that banks be obliged to make their basic accounts accessible through post offices and pay for the privilege. The system would also ensure that social security benefit payments could still be paid in cash through post offices.

But confidential information given to the select committee by the post office has led the MPs to warn that the banks "will be unwilling to pay for the service unless the post office comes up with a cheaper and fairer system".

The committee concluded: "There remains a substantial gap between the post office's aspirations to provide financial services and its ability to do so at present."

The MPs point out that retail banks do not want a large number of their customers to switch to a new post office bank, nor will they want the rate of take-up of basic accounts to swamp their systems with non-profitable business.

Each "socially excluded" account would need an average daily balance of £1,300 to cover the annual costs of the system. As a result, the £150m widely quoted cost of the universal bank is seen as on "the low side" by the select committee. A decision on the contract between the high street banks and the Post Office is expected by the end of the year.

The committee also warn that plans for automatic cash machines in post offices is in serious danger. Earlier this year the prime minister predicted more than 3,000 post offices will install cash machines within two years, so drawing in extra business.

But so far, the committee says, only 341 post offices had been selected for installation, of which just 50 were in rural areas.

The crisis in the post office network deepened this year with a net loss of 333 post offices in the first six months of the financial year.

Other government- related departments, including the department of health, the UK passport agency and the BBC are also chastised for taking their business away from the Post Office, or threatening to do so.

webTitle: Lords reject gay bill for third time

fields.headline: Lords reject gay bill for third time
fields.trailText: Lesbian and gay rights groups last night urged the government to invoke the Parliament Act after the House of Lords for the third time rejected plans to lower the gay age of consent to 16.
fields.body:
Lesbian and gay rights groups last night urged the government to invoke the Parliament Act after the House of Lords for the third time rejected plans to lower the gay age of consent to 16.

Voting in the Lords was 205 to 144, with the opposition to the change led by the Conservative family values campaigner Baroness Young.

Government sources made clear that ministers would use the Parliament Act to get the Sexual Offences (Amendment) Bill on to the statute book. The rarely used Act allows the government to override the Lords.

Last week the Labour leader of the Lords, Baroness Jay, insisted: "This will become law one way or another by the end of this session."

Angela Mason, executive director of the gay rights organisation Stonewall, said: "An equal age of consent is just and fair. The Commons and the majority of professional medical, legal and childcare opinion support it. Baroness Young must now accept the will of the elected house."

Peter Tatchell of OutRage! said the vote "reinforces the need for a democratically elected second chamber which respects the human rights of everyone".

A Home Office spokesman said: "The government has always made clear that it would invoke the Parliament Act at the appropriate stage, if necessary. The Bill has been previously overwhelmingly endorsed by the Commons."

A government spokesman said: "The government remains committed to equality for all citizens, and that means equal age of consent at 16."
