webTitle: Obituary: David Flusser

fields.headline: David Flusser
fields.trailText: Edmund Wilson described David Flusser, who has died on his 83rd birthday, as a somewhat eccentric genius who translated the Dead Sea scrolls from Hebrew into Greek in order to demonstrate their similarities to the New Testament. In this description lies much of his brilliance and charm. Encyclopaedic in his range of interests and intell-ectual pursuits, Flusser was renowned as a scholar of biblical and rabbinic Judaism, and of Christianity.
fields.body:
Edmund Wilson described David Flusser, who has died on his 83rd birthday, as a somewhat eccentric genius who translated the Dead Sea scrolls from Hebrew into Greek in order to demonstrate their similarities to the New Testament. In this description lies much of his brilliance and charm. Encyclopaedic in his range of interests and intell-ectual pursuits, Flusser was renowned as a scholar of biblical and rabbinic Judaism, and of Christianity.

Formally a historian, he lectured in the department of comparative religion at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem for more than 50 years. A scholar of both the classics and talmudic literature, he was aided by a knowledge of 26 languages, in nine of which he lectured to audiences around the world.

Flusser lived in near obscurity, not to say penury, until his late 30s. Born in Austria, he developed his love of philology, history and animals in Prague. His family, thoroughly emancipated Austrian Jews, were tough on their physically awkward child, and sent him to the local Christian school.

According to one of his two sons, Johanan, it was a reaction to his assimilated parents that triggered Flusser's interest in Judaism. He escaped the full horrors of the Holocaust years, but was put through a humiliating encounter with the SS on his way to receiving an exit visa from Europe, and forced to declare that he was "a Jewish pig".

In Palestine in the late 1930s, he became an observant Jew and a master of biblical and talmudic texts. His interest in Christianity was stimulated by Gershom Scholem, who enabled him, in 1955, to land a secure academic position, a boon for himself and for his recently wedded wife Hannah, herself a Holocaust survivor and widow.

Flusser's fame had a double edge. His vastly popular book on Jesus, published first in 1968 in German, and subsequently in seven other languages (including English), demonstrated how the historical Jesus was totally at home in the Jewish and rabbinical environment of his time. It was only later that Christianity emerged through the hands of others less sympathetic to, and certainly not as knowledgeable of, their saviour's Jewish roots. Only his thorough knowledge of Greek and Jewish sources allowed Flusser to compare the Jewish original and the early Christians' distorted interpretations.

Flusser came to admire - and even to love - Jesus, seeing in him a legitimate heir to the Hebrew prophets, a man possessed of the holy spirit. When he spoke of this kinship with the Dominican priest and philosopher, Father Marcel Dubois, he referred to him as, "My teacher and your God".

A ccording to Dubois, one of the highest level intellectuals Rome ever sent to the holy land, Flusser's Jesus changed New Testament scholarship radically. Flusser was a free spirit, observed Dubois, and because he was serious about spiritual matters, he was able to believe in Jesus' spirituality and yet stay an observant Jew. "He saw the real significance of religion - of God's way to speak to humankind; at the same time, he saw the humour in it." Unlike his fellow professor and friend-in-combat, Yehoshua Leibowitz, who stressed the differences between Judaism and Christianity, Flusser saw "the deep connections".

Of the many prizes that he was awarded, the prestigious Israel Prize for his redaction of the 10th-century book, The Josippon, was probably his most coveted. It marked his central concern with late antiquity and its historical repercussions in Jewish history.

The New Testament And Christian-Jewish Dialogue, an English language festschrift in Flusser's honour, published by the Ecumenical Theological Research Fraternity in Israel (no 24/25), contains a bibliography of Flusser's books and more than 700 articles. It also contains a warm appreciation of the man himself by both Jewish and Christian scholars.

Flusser is survived by his wife, two sons and seven grandchildren

 David Flusser, biblical scholar, born September 15 1917; died September 15 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Alan Tyson

fields.headline: Alan Tyson
fields.standfirst: Brilliant musicologist who used his forensic skills to uncover the secrets of Beethoven and Mozart's manuscripts
fields.trailText: Brilliant musicologist who used his forensic skills to uncover the secrets of Beethoven and Mozart's manuscripts.
fields.body:
Alan Tyson, who has died aged 74, added significantly to our knowledge of how Mozart and Beethoven wrote their music. One of the leading musicologists of his generation, he brought all the rigour and insight of a medical and psychoanalytical training to the discipline.

Tyson's main achievement was to establish more accurate chronologies of the works of Mozart and Beeth- oven through a study of their published editions and manuscripts, the latter ranging from sketches and fragments to complete compos- itions. His tools were the tried-and-true measuring instruments of an older time - callipers, microscopes, magnifying glasses, light-boxes and rulers.

Travelling, often on his Lambretta motor scooter, to every conceivable manuscript archive on two continents, he examined documents, analy- sed and recorded their watermarks, identified different kinds of paper stocks, and was constantly on the look-out for any clues these materials might throw up - noting, for example, how the offset of an ink-blot from the front of one sheet passed through on to the back of the next.

On one occasion, he discovered matching stitch-holes in a notebook, which showed that a loose page of Beeth-oven sketches had actually been removed from a particular bound volume years ago; now it could be restored to its rightful sequence. By such methods, he was able to reconstruct the original order of many of Beethoven's sketchbooks, and to propose redatings for dozens of Mozart's compositions.

In all, Tyson wrote or edited 13 books and published more than 90 papers, plus numerous reviews, editions and facsimile reproductions of musical scores. His main findings on Beethoven are summarised in the prize-winning collaboration, The Beethoven Sketchbooks: History, Reconstruction, Inventory (with Douglas Johnson and Robert S Winter, 1985), an indispensable reference work to which he contributed the studies of Beethoven's sketchbooks from 1801-16. In collaboration with Joseph Kerman, he also wrote the widely acclaimed Beethoven entry for the New Grove Dictionary Of Music And Musicians (1980, published as a separate book in 1983).

Tyson devoted most of his later researches to Mozart, his best-known book being Mozart: Studies Of The Autograph Scores (1986), which collects 18 papers detailing his deductions from his analyses of the watermarks and other physical properties of Mozart's manuscripts. In it, he also established the order in which Mozart wrote the separate numbers of Così fan tutte and La Clemenza di Tito, and discovered some of the composer's afterthoughts for Le Nozze di Figaro.

Tyson's facsimile edition of Mozart's Thematic Catalogue (with Albi Rosenthal) was published in 1990, and he concluded his scholarly career with a definitive catalogue of the Mozart watermarks. In addition, he made news by identifying previously unknown music by Mozart, notably the lost ending of the Rondo in A, K386, for piano and orchestra, which he found in the British library in 1980.

Tyson was born in Glasgow, the eldest of the three sons of Henry Tyson, surmaster (deputy head) of St Paul's school, London, and his wife, Dorothy. He was educated at Rugby school from 1940-45 and, after two years in the Royal Navy, took up a scholarship at Magdalen College, Oxford, gaining a double first in classics.

With a view to making a career as a clinical and research psychoanalyst, Tyson trained at the Institute of Psycho-Analysis, in north London, from 1953-57, and, after qualifying, practised as a lay psychoanalyst for a while. From 1960-67, he studied medicine at University College hospital medical school (MB and BS, 1965) and New End hospital, and was registered with the general medical council in 1967.

His talents in psychoanalysis were recognised early, when he was asked to join the editorial staff, headed by James Strachey, which prepared the standard edition of The Complete Psychological Works Of Sigmund Freud, published in 24 volumes (1953-74), to which he also contributed his own translations of Freud's Leonardo Da Vinci And A Memory Of His Childhood (1957), The Psychopathology Of Every-day Life (1960), and three of Freud's clinical papers.

During his years of training, Tyson published many studies and reviews on musical topics of a textual and bibliographical nature, edited a definitive edition of Beethoven's Violin Concerto, and compiled two standard catalogues, A Thematic Catalogue Of The Works Of Muzio Clementi (1967) and The Authentic English Editions Of Beethoven (1963). By the late 1960s and early 1970s, he undertook increasingly ambitious musicological projects; and from the time his major writings on Beeth- oven's sketches began to appear, around 1970, and from his appointment as senior research fellow at All Souls College, Oxford, 1971-94, he was fully dedicated to musical research.

Tyson held posts as visiting professor at various American universities and received several of the highest honours in his profession, as well as the CBE in 1989. A book of essays by his friends and colleagues was dedicated to him as a birthday tribute in 1991 and published in 1998.

Brimming with good humour, erudition and vitality, he was a vibrant presence at All Souls, where he had been a fellow since 1952, and his visits abroad were often the occasion of memorable gatherings of friends. He was known to break into a tune by Noel Coward, Frank Loesser, or Gilbert and Sullivan, with lyrics that he improvised on the spur of the moment.

Tyson was a voluminous letter-writer, to whom many scholars turned for assistance; and he generously shared his resources and knowledge. His fine collection of first and rare editions of the great composers has been divided between the British library and the Bodleian.

He is survived by his brothers, John and Donald.

 Alan Walker Tyson, musicologist, born October 27 1926; died November 10 2000

Tyson devoted most of his later researches to Mozart, his best-known book being Mozart: Studies Of The Autograph Scores (1986), which collects 18 papers detailing his deductions from his analyses of the watermarks and other physical properties of Mozart's manuscripts. In it, he also established the order in which Mozart wrote the separate numbers of Così fan tutte and La Clemenza di Tito, and discovered some of the composer's afterthoughts for Le Nozze di Figaro. Tyson's facsimile edition of Mozart's Thematic Catalogue (with Albi Rosenthal) was published in 1990, and he concluded his scholarly career with a definitive catalogue of the Mozart watermarks. In addition, he made news by identifying previously unknown music by Mozart, notably the lost ending of the Rondo in A, K386, for piano and orchestra, which he found in the British library in 1980. Tyson was born in Glasgow, the eldest of the three sons of Henry Tyson, surmaster (deputy head) of St Paul's school, London, and his wife, Dorothy. He was educated at Rugby school from 1940-45 and, after two years in the Royal Navy, took up a scholarship at Magdalen College, Oxford, gaining a double first in classics. With a view to making a career as a clinical and research psychoanalyst, Tyson trained at the Institute of Psycho-Analysis, in north London, from 1953-57, and, after qualifying, practised as a lay psychoanalyst for a while. From 1960-67, he studied medicine at University College hospital medical school (MB and BS, 1965) and New End hospital, and was registered with the general medical council in 1967. His talents in psychoanalysis were recognised early, when he was asked to join the editorial staff, headed by James Strachey, which prepared the standard edition of The Complete Psychological Works Of Sigmund Freud, published in 24 volumes (1953-74), to which he also contributed his own translations of Freud's Leonardo Da Vinci And A Memory Of His Childhood (1957), The Psychopathology Of Every-day Life (1960), and three of Freud's clinical papers. During his years of training, Tyson published many studies and reviews on musical topics of a textual and bibliographical nature, edited a definitive edition of Beethoven's Violin Concerto, and compiled two standard catalogues, A Thematic Catalogue Of The Works Of Muzio Clementi (1967) and The Authentic English Editions Of Beethoven (1963). By the late 1960s and early 1970s, he undertook increasingly ambitious musicological projects; and from the time his major writings on Beeth- oven's sketches began to appear, around 1970, and from his appointment as senior research fellow at All Souls College, Oxford, 1971-94, he was fully dedicated to musical research. He was known to break into a tune by Noel Coward, Frank Loesser, or Gilbert and Sullivan, with lyrics that he improvised on the spur of the moment. Tyson was a voluminous letter-writer, to whom many scholars turned for assistance; and he generously shared his resources and knowledge. He is survived by his brothers, John and Donald.  Alan Walker Tyson, musicologist, born October 27 1926; died November 10 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Bobby King

fields.headline: Bobby King
fields.standfirst: Reformed bank robber who found freedom in literature
fields.trailText: Reformed bank robber who found freedom in literature
fields.body:
Bobby King, who has died aged 59, was a bank robber who swapped his sawn-off shotgun for academia while behind bars to become a cheerful example of the redemptive powers of the Open University and the doors it can open. The chance to learn changed his life.

Born in north London to a Scottish father who had fought with the International Brigade in the Spanish civil war, and a long-suffering mother who wanted her bright boy to excel at school, King was in trouble while barely in his teens. He graduated through the penal system to emerge, in his 20s, as one of a small team of very active bank robbers, mainly from the Hornsey area.

They were aided by the then deeply corrupt detective branch at New Scotland Yard, and King had many tales of handing over grubby envelopes stuffed with cash to bent officers in exchange for his freedom. He lived high on the hog, believing that he had finally made it when he was bombing down the motorway in a Jaguar with the Doors playing on his car tape-deck.

But a reckoning was not long in coming. In 1973, Bertie Smalls, one of King's fellow robbers, became the first of the big supergrasses and helped jail 21 robbers, including King, who received an 18-year sentence. He and a fellow-accused sang, "We'll meet again..." to Smalls from the dock as he gave evidence against them, a scene reprised by Peter Prince in his script for the film, The Hit.

They did meet again, in fact, years after King had completed 10 years in jail. But he saw it as a test of his rehabilitation that he was able to pass Smalls, when he saw him in Crouch End, without whacking him.

Once inside, King discovered the joys of English literature and took an OU degree. Aided by a sympathetic prison governor, he was allowed to slip out and make use of the local library for his studies on Quakerism. He emerged from prison determined not to return, and found work in Lambeth with a pioneering experiment confronting young criminals with their victims. He would also explain to them what a boring waste of time prison was.

When this project folded, he found work as a chef in the City, having learned to cook in jail. He continued his voracious reading and was a star in pub quizes, one of a group of former criminals who had spent their time inside studying.

I came across him once in the pub reading Virginia Woolf's To The Lighthouse. When I mentioned this with a snigger to another ex-bank robber friend of King's, he replied, without missing a beat, "not one of her best".

King never returned to crime, although he was always happy to talk about his experiences. He told one story of how a diminutive fellow bank-robber had dressed up as a woman in order to get close to security men making a cash delivery. The robber-in-drag was pushing a pram, with a gun hidden inside it, towards the target when a group of building workers whistled at "her". Being short of temper as well as of stature, the robber turned, pulled out the sawn-off shot-gun and threatened them - striking an unintentional blow for feminism, but blowing out the robbery.

King appeared in the 1994 BBC documentary series, The Underworld, and later gave advice to Robert Carlyle, Ray Winstone and Damon Albarn for their parts in Face, the heist film written by Ronan Bennett and directed by Antonia Bird. King, who played a security guard in the film, said that Winstone made a considerably more ferocious blagger than he ever was.

He also went undercover for the television programme, World In Action, in a story exposing the security business's lack of background checks. During his researches, he was tickled to be offered a job at Conservative Central Office, having explained away his missing 10 years by saying he had been "at sea".

He leaves two sons of whom he was immmensely proud because neither had followed his criminal path. He was also touched to discover a few years ago that he was the father of a successful and happy daughter, now in her 30s, who had traced him through an adoption agency; they discovered that they had the same taste in books and football teams - Arsenal, the bank robbers' favourite club.

 Robert Alles King, former criminal and consultant, born August 8 1941; died October 18 2000

webTitle: Schools, custody and access rights

fields.headline: Battle cries
fields.standfirst: Schools are increasingly being caught in the crossfire between estranged parents slugging it out over custody and access rights - and it's hard to duck, says  Sally Weale
fields.trailText: Schools are increasingly being caught in the crossfire between estranged parents slugging it out over custody and access rights - and it's hard to duck, says Sally Weale
fields.body:
This is a story about a family breakdown. A separation, a divorce and a child's education. The child is Nicole Lavelle. When she was 12 years old, her parents split up. Two years later they divorced and Nicole went to live with her father in Dunblane, near Stirling, while her mother and sister moved to the Midlands.

Callum Lavelle, a senior computer executive, enrolled his daughter at Harrogate Ladies' College, a boarding school which she liked at first. But she soon began to miss home and family life.

She wanted to move to a school closer to her mother, but according to Nicole, her father did not approve. As she sees it, he was happy to pay the £12,000 fees for Harrogate, but when she decided to go to King's School, Worcester, to be near her mother, he withdrew his support.

Last week Nicole, now 16, made legal history when she took her father to court to force him to pay her annual £6,600 school fees. He claims he simply cannot afford to pay regular fees for private education at the moment; she argues the only explanation for his action is the continuing feud between her parents.

The Lavelles' case is a vivid illustration of how schools are increasingly being used as a battleground for estranged parents. Last week King's School was understandably reluctant to comment on the case. "It's a private matter between Nicole and her father," a spokesperson said.

Private it should be, but increasingly, with the breakdown of marriages and the ever-diversifying range of family situations in Britain today, our schools - under-funded and over-stretched - are finding themselves caught up in the battles between warring parents. And there's nothing private about it then.

Such cases do not often reach the courts. Many separated or divorced couples remain on reasonable terms in the interests of their children and their children's education. They reach amicable agreements; schools are informed and staff can then try to take into account the new family situation of the child concerned.

But in another case earlier this year an unnamed Englishwoman was ordered by two judges to send her children to a French-speaking school against her wishes. Her estranged husband, a Frenchman, wanted them to retain their language and cultural background. In that case, one of the children's head teachers was dragged into the fray, making a plea to the court asking that the girl should be allowed remain in her English-speaking school.

Cynthia Thumwood, headteacher of Hanover Primary School in Islington, London, often finds herself involved with the fall-out from family breakdowns. "The most difficult thing is when it's acrimonious and the legal beagles are involved. We often find as a school that parents want to use you as piggy-in-the-middle to gather evidence against the other parent.

"Often it's not centred around the welfare of the child but around the acrimony between parents - when they want to make things difficult for the other parent. As a school you can't get involved. You have to keep reminding people that's their private affair and they must deal with it."

In the 11 years that Lesley Hughes has been head of Longcroft School, a comprehensive with 1,500 pupils in Beverley, East Riding, Yorkshire, the school has rarely become directly involved in an acrimonious family breakdown - although on one occasion an aggrieved, angry parent turned up at school demanding access to their child which had been denied by the courts.

"One of the issues we've become more aware of is the need to be very clear about what the situation is in law," said Hughes. Because there was a custody order in place, and the school was clear about where it stood legally, it was able to act decisively and say "no".

Longcroft, like other schools, is increasingly having to cater for estranged parents, both of whom are interested in and concerned about their child's development, but who may wish to see the school separately.

"In the past (separated) parents have made joint appointments to talk about their child's progress, but we have had more parents wanting separate appointments," she said.

Schools face an infinite number of practical problems involved in dealing with changes in families. Increasingly, there is no single main adult contact between home and school; that contact may not be the child's parent; and children may divide their time between two households.

And schools still largely revolve around an outdated model of the family - two parents who can come to parents' evening (often held early in the evening, when most working parents are still in the office) and a non-working mother at home who can be contacted at all times.

Joe Hallgarten, in his book Parents Exist, OK!?, published by the Institute for Public Policy Research earlier this year, calls for a radical and ambitious overhaul of the relationship between home and school, to try to respond to the dramatic change in family structures.

He wants estranged parents to be given more support from schools to allow them to play an active part in the children's education and warns that there is a danger of separated fathers being excluded from decisions about their children's education.

Schools, he says, have been teaching increasing numbers of children whose home lives range from temporary disruption to near-permanent crisis. He proposes that schools, particularly in disadvantaged areas, should employ home-school "link workers" to act as brokers between schools and families.

"The proposals are based on the premise that the onus for change to improve parent-school relationships must fall on the school, not the parent. The aim should be to create family-like schools in all their shapes and diversity, not school-like families."

Hallgarten's recommendations are worthy of government consideration. At the moment, however, the first consideration for a school is to ensure that it has accurate and up-to-date information about both parents and other carers involved in looking after the child, and that staff understand what can often be complex family relationships.

Michael Marland, a former head of one of London's largest comprehensives, said: "One of the most difficult things when interviewing an incoming family to a school is to ask the right questions about the marital situation. You don't want to appear offensive, but you need to know whether the other parent is in contact or whether they've been totally alienated.

One aspect of UK schooling which is the least of our successes is working with parents. We have a very long, poor tradition of this weakness. Then there's the problem of time." Inevitably, with the government's emphasis on performance tables and good results, teachers under pressure have little time to develop the best possible contacts with parents - those at war or otherwise.

So what happens with parents' evenings; invitations to school events; school reports? What about permission for school outings, subject choices or careers guidance?

"If there is a battle between estranged parents, they may use those issues to continue their battle," says Colleen McLaughlin, lecturer at the School of Education, Cambridge University, and vice-chair of the National Association of Pastoral Care in Education.

The government issued guidelines earlier this year reminding schools that all parents - whether living with the child or not - must be treated equally (unless there is a court order limiting a parent's exercise of parental responsibility). The guidance is that all parents, including non-resident parents, should be sent all relevant information about their child and her school - pupil records, class information, governors' reports, attendance records and so on. Which is a great idea but a big extra burden on already stretched school offices.

"It's not as simple as it sounds," says McLaughlin. "There will be ethical difficulties in implementing any sort of guidelines.

"It's an unworked-out area; that's always the way it's been in pastoral care. It's just now there are more complex family relationships to deal with You try to play it by the book, you try to contact both parents, but in the end, you can only do your best."

As for Nicole Lavelle, a ruling is expected in the next few weeks. Her father wants her to return to Scotland, while she wants to continue her education where she is. Let's hope the court arrives at the best decision for Nicole.

webTitle: If you ask me...PE and sport

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My child doesn't get very much physical activity. She is bogged down with homework most nights, and isn't spending much time at school doing PE or sport. What should she be doing at school, how can I get her more active, and am I right to be concerned?
fields.trailText: What sport and PE should my child be doing at school, how can I get her more active, and am I right to be concerned?
fields.body:
Belinda Linden, cardiac nurse adviser, British Heart Foundation

You're right to be concerned. Inactivity increases the risk of coronary heart disease in adults, so encouraging good habits at a young age is important. Only half of 11- to 16-year-olds walk for 10 minutes a day and only 1% cycle to school. This has brought a rapid rise in obesity among our kids, never mind the risk to their hearts.

As a parent, lead by example. Take up family activities such as cycling, walking or playing football together. Ensure your child's school provides an hour's physical activity a day and interesting after-school activities. If the school also needs encouragement, suggest it gets hold of the British Heart Foundation's resource packs to help keep pupils active. Older kids love ice skating, skateboarding and dancing - all great ways to become cardioactive.

Getting healthier through exercise doesn't just have to be done after school. If you drive your kids to school, think about making them walk - at least part of the way! If it's too far, a bike could get them there faster and fitter. It's hard in the age of computer game consoles and home entertainment to get kids exercising. But a little encouragement can pay dividends.

Elisa Davies, director of the National Playing Fields Association

First contact the school directly to find out just how much time is being spent doing PE and sport. Also find out for yourself what after-school activities are provided, and if the children have access to playing fields, etc, at break and lunchtimes. The school's health education policy will also show the importance the school attaches to sporting and physical education.

Look at how much outdoor playing space the school has, its layout and the use made of it. The recognised quality standard for a playing field is that it should be able to withstand at least seven hours' use a week. If not, there may not be enough playing space to sustain the school's population and curriculum requirements. Which begs the question how many school playing fields are being disposed of. Figures show that, since October 1 1998, of the119 applications on school playing field disposals, only four have been refused.

Latest figures show that over the last four years 1,015 playing fields were threatened by building developments. Of these, 466 were for residential developments -155 were built on by schools and educational establishments themselves. Unless this tide is stemmed, it will become increasingly impossible for schools to offer a full and varied physical curriculum.

 For more details on physical activity, call the heart health line on 0870 600 6566 ( www.bhf.org.uk ) or the National Association for Playing Fields can be contacted on 020-7833 5360 ( www.npfa.co.uk).

Elaine Burgess, active schools team, Sport England

Physical education is a statutory subject within the national curriculum for all pupils to encourage children to enjoy being active and remain active for life.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, and Chris Smith, the culture, media and sport secretary, made a joint statement encouraging two hours of physical activity provision (both within and beyond) the curriculum for all pupils, when they announced National Curriculum 2000. Yet Sport England believes two hours should be the minimum time allocated to PE within the curriculum.

Homework plays a vital part in education and it should be completed. But it's also important to recognise that everyone needs to develop other interests and hobbies. There is a link between physical activity and improved learning - youngsters who take part in sport perform better academically, as highlighted in the Ofsted report, Specialist Sports Colleges.

Arrange a meeting to talk to the head about the amount of homework being issued, how long your daughter is taking to complete it and the fact that subjects such as PE and drama are equally valuable to ensure a holistic approach to development. You should also contact the head of PE to discuss the extra curricular sports opportunities available.

Another option is to encourage your daughter to build physical activity into her daily routine by either cycling or walking to school. Perhaps the school can set up a "Walk to school club" involving other pupils? The school should provide somewhere suitable for pupils to park their bikes.

If not, there may not be enough playing space to sustain the school's population and curriculum requirements. Which begs the question how many school playing fields are being disposed of. Figures show that, since October 1 1998, of the119 applications on school playing field disposals, only four have been refused. Latest figures show that over the last four years 1,015 playing fields were threatened by building developments. Of these, 466 were for residential developments -155 were built on by schools and educational establishments themselves. Unless this tide is stemmed, it will become increasingly impossible for schools to offer a full and varied physical curriculum.  For more details on physical activity, call the heart health line on 0870 600 6566 ( www.bhf.org.uk ) or the National Association for Playing Fields can be contacted on 020-7833 5360 ( www.npfa.co.uk). Elaine Burgess, active schools team, Sport England Physical education is a statutory subject within the national curriculum for all pupils to encourage children to enjoy being active and remain active for life. David Blunkett, the education secretary, and Chris Smith, the culture, media and sport secretary, made a joint statement encouraging two hours of physical activity provision (both within and beyond) the curriculum for all pupils, when they announced National Curriculum 2000. Yet Sport England believes two hours should be the minimum time allocated to PE within the curriculum. Homework plays a vital part in education and it should be completed. But it's also important to recognise that everyone needs to develop other interests and hobbies. There is a link between physical activity and improved learning - youngsters who take part in sport perform better academically, as highlighted in the Ofsted report, Specialist Sports Colleges. Arrange a meeting to talk to the head about the amount of homework being issued, how long your daughter is taking to complete it and the fact that subjects such as PE and drama are equally valuable to ensure a holistic approach to development. You should also contact the head of PE to discuss the extra curricular sports opportunities available. Another option is to encourage your daughter to build physical activity into her daily routine by either cycling or walking to school. Perhaps the school can set up a "Walk to school club" involving other pupils? The school should provide somewhere suitable for pupils to park their bikes.

webTitle: Equipped for life

fields.headline: Equipped for life
fields.trailText: Harriet Costello School in Basingstoke
fields.body:
Liesha, a pupil on the life skills course at Harriet Costello School in Basingstoke, sometimes used to be put off her work by the reaction of other pupils. "They'd be taking the mick and laughing," she says. One exercise involved washing cars. "They were all saying 'Is that all you do in life skills?'" she recalls.

Liesha is in year 11. And life skills, she says, has kept her in school. "If I didn't have this course I'd have been expelled by now," she says. "I still get stressed in maths, English, science, but this takes the pressure off."

It's a two-year course for pupils in years 10 and 11 who find that working towards 10 GCSEs is not a realistic target, based on analysis of their CAT and SAT scores and behavioural records. They keep taking the core subjects of maths, English, science, RE, IT and PSHE, plus PE. But they drop their other academic options in favour of a broad-based programme that concentrates on vocational learning and reinforcing key skills such as working with others, communicating, problem solving and learning about the world of work. As well as five hours a week of class room-based activities, they spend two hours at local colleges; the possibilities there include training in hair and beauty, painting and decorating, catering and vehicle maintenance. And one full day each week is spent on work experience linked to their chosen practical subject.

The life skills course was the inspiration of Diane Marchant, head of year 11, and it was implemented with the help of a grant from the Human Scale Education organisation. "I wanted to minimise the times these pupils can fail and maximise the times they can succeed," she explains. It's clear that part of the course's success depends on the strong relationship that exists between Marchant and the 17 life skills pupils, who have an average age of 15.

David admits he has a problem with punctuality. Now he is studying IT and working at the local bowling alley, using an electronic till and computers to reset the lanes. "I'm never late for work experience," he says. "School is very boring, I didn't like the work. This is better."

The tools that Marchant uses to make learning enjoyable are legion: trips outside the classroom, visiting speakers, outdoor pursuits (a recent visit to an army base was "wicked"), sports, drama and improvisation, discussion. These are structured using the Award Scheme Development and Accreditation Network (Asdan). Asdan sets out a series of challenges that pupils can work through to gain credits to reach bronze or silver achievement levels.

It can all seem an uphill struggle. "They are up against a society that measures the best by their GCSE grades," says Marchant. One boy says that he was told that life skills is for the "thick". Harriet Costello School has nearly 1,000 pupils of mixed abilities, and some of them are very bright. The school's Ofsted report has praised its standards across the board, including the life skills class.

This kind of project isn't one to un dertake lightly, however. It carries on outside the classroom. Marchant works tirelessly to smooth the paths of her students. Without this kind of personal connection, the programme would lose its force. "It works because they know what I think of them and how I believe in them and how I want them to succeed," she says.

webTitle: On the board:

fields.headline: My governing body, and other animals
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
One lesson of the first meeting of the school governing body (SGB) which I attend is that governors come in all varieties. Not only are teachers, staff and parents all represented, but there are other, more exotic species: "partnership" governors and "co-opted" ones. The former, I understand, are drawn from institutions in the local community. This is not a church school, but we get the local vicar anyway: no identifying dog-collar, so clearly an evangelical type. My friend on the PTA, Susie, is always muttering darkly about "the God squad" taking over the school. Hmm.

"Co-opted" seems a category devised to enable the head to corral into governorship anyone he likes the look of once the partnership places have been filled. I suspect that it was due originally to post-Thatcherite notions that education is far too important to be left to educationists, but should draw also on the expertise of people with knowledge of the "real world" distilled through the crucible of business experience. In this case, Mr Richardson seems to have collared the architect who did some work designing the school nursery extension - widely regarded as "a very good thing". The architect says very little but he looks as though he knows what he's doing: he wears Sven Goran specs.

Once the meeting had moved into closed session, it was down to brass tacks - no substantive debate, just a rapid forced march across the agenda of "matters arising", "standing orders", "setting-up of committees", and, of course, "any other business". The school administrator Joan, in her capacity as clerk to the governing body, turned out to be a procedural Rottweiler.

I probably shouldn't complain. Each agenda item had a figure in brackets next to it, delineating the number of minutes allocated for discussion. I smirked inwardly: there was no way, I thought, that we would stick to this. I had never been in a meeting that started, let alone finished, on time. Until now.

But before we were sent home, the governors were obliged to reconstitute the statutory committees, as required by the standing orders governing the governing body. The committees, too, come in all varieties: finance, staff salaries, curriculum development, discipline, admissions and appeals. They deal with the more day-to-day business of the school, acting as a filter for the governing body. Not very sexy stuff, admittedly, but important nevertheless.

All these committees require the presence of at least one governor, presumably as a counterweight to staff presence and the head's influence. As we worked down the list, it soon became plain that "England expects" - it was practically, as well as morally, impossible NOT to volunteer for at least one of these committees. I steered clear of the finance and budgetary ones. The school's wage bill last year, I noticed in the annual report, cleared a million quid: I can't be responsible for that kind of money - I'm barely competent to fill in my own cheque-book stubs.

So in a fit of mingled idealism, embarrassment and apprehension, I put my hand up for curriculum development, admissions policy, and one of the disciplinary appeals committees. (I pick pupil, as opposed to staff, disciplinary appeals - a snap decision on my part on the grounds that it would be bad enough dealing with the case of a kid who's been excluded, let alone a teacher who's been suspended.)

The date and time of the next meeting swiftly decreed, the meeting dissolved. I said my goodbyes and made an exit, feeling faintly dazed both by the staccato committee-speak and by the idea of the additional commitments I had taken on.

I had not thought to become so involved so soon, but on the other hand I am genuinely interested in admissions policy: like many parents, I feel baffled by the rigid rules that control a local authority school's intake - but that these apparently coexist with a head's discretion to gerrymander at will. And curriculum - well, what could be more important than to discover how and what one's child is actually being taught?

I am back at school: I might as well get an education, after all.

webTitle: One in five primary scholl children can't swim

fields.headline: Sink or swim?
fields.standfirst: Some one in five children leave primary school unable to swim, Ofsted says.  Claire Phipps was one of them
fields.trailText: Some one in five children leave primary school unable to swim, Ofsted says. Claire Phipps was one of them
fields.body:
I remember being very impressed, upon starting secondary school, to discover that it had its own swimming pool. I knew of no other local schools that enjoyed a dip on their doorstep. When it was demolished - subsidence, I think - not long after I left the school, it felt like a real loss.

There was one problem with my admiration for the pool: I couldn't swim. At the age of 11, in fact, I'd have had trouble getting across its 5m width, even with the assistance of floats, armbands, and fins and flippers of my own. The thought of doing the same without these back-ups was a less likely prospect than passing my A-levels in that first term.

As it turned out, neither of these fantasies was to come true during my time at the school. Exams followed their normal course as, I suppose, did my swimming lessons, given the fact that not one of us who was not already "water confident" ever made it down to the deep end. A report last week by Ofsted into swimming provision at key stage 2 - the only level of the national curriculum at which swimming is compulsory - confirmed that my experience was far from unusual: almost one in five children now leaves primary school unable to swim the 25m specified in the curriculum. As swimming declines to optional status at secondary level, those who haven't managed the length of a pool by the time they leave year 6 are unlikely ever to catch up with their peers.

"There is this one window of opportunity at key stage 2 and it has to be grabbed," says David Sparkes, chief executive of the Amateur Swimming Association (ASA). "After that, many people feel embarrassed that they can't swim, and that puts a barrier up. Very few secondary schools actually offer swimming, so it's unlikely that the inability to swim will be picked up after the age of 11."

Even if the opportunity for further instruction is there, learning to swim in the teenage years is a fraught business. During my brief spell of primary school lessons, I enjoyed it - although the same could probably not be said for the teacher charged with cramming my waist-length hair into a recalcitrant swimming cap. The Ofsted report, in fact, praised pupils' responses to the lessons at KS2, stating, "the overwhelming majority of pupils looked forward to their lessons".

But all this changed, for me, at secondary school. A combination of adolescent self-consciousness (mine) and adolescent bitchiness (everyone else) meant that I was never likely to emerge victorious at the end of a 25m front crawl. "Forgotten" costumes, rather too frequent periods and, when actually forced into the pool, a display of utter terror were called into play by me, and other non-swimmers, to make sure we would never join the ranks of those who sped from one end of the pool to another. Floats, at this crucial stage of teen image-forming, were unthinkable. Failure was the more comfortable option.

For those charged with getting the nation's children treading water, this won't do. Figures from the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA) reveal that the third most common cause of accidental death for those aged under 14 is drowning - due, it claims, to children's misjudgments of their ability and a failure to appreciate the dangers of water. The last annual survey recorded a 50% increase in deaths by drowning in this age group. More than half of those who drowned could swim.

"The national curriculum includes water safety, but a lot of youngsters are just not getting this knowledge," says Sparkes. Val Sumner, technical support officer at the Royal Life Saving Society (RLSS), part of the Swim for Life campaign that fought to get swimming into schools, agrees. "The time devoted to swimming and water safety in the average primary school is negligible. You can't expect to turn all non-swimmers into confident swimmers in the time they have."

The problems, as with so many issues in education, rarely come down to natural ability. Ofsted inspectors noted that, while 91% of pupils in rural schools reached the 25m target by the age of 11, just 67% of those in the most deprived areas managed the same. An average of 5.29 hours per year was spent on swimming lessons in the most advantaged schools, compared to 3.49 hours in their least well-off counterparts. The report notes, tellingly, that those schools with the best record of provision for non-swimmers were those which "encouraged [parents] to join a swimming club or go swimming together at the local pool". In other words, it's often what happens outside school swimming lessons that determines whether the key stage 2 target is met.

This is hardly a surprise. With all the other pressures on the curriculum, schools are hard-pressed to find time to teach everything. Competence in swimming - in which success is monitored by Ofsted, but does not count towards league table position - is a less urgent concern. Sumner confirms that it is often not in the school's interest to push children to become better swimmers. "Once you've achieved that attainment target of 25m, there's no point in continuing the lessons," she explains. "Walking to the pool and back, getting changed - that's one and a half hours of valuable lesson time for a 20-minute swim."

Worse, many schools have no members of staff qualified to teach swimming, forcing them to pay instructors' fees. The ASA would like to see government funds ringfenced for lessons and more help for training teachers. A scheme in conjunction with BT is already up and running but, says Sparkes, more support is needed.

Schools cannot levy charges for transport or lessons that take place within school hours, but they can ask for voluntary contributions; one-quarter of schools fund KS2 swimming in this way. Add the yearly costs of pool use and instructor fees (anything from £1,000 to £9,000, according to Ofsted), and the fact that most children learn to swim outside school time, and the arguments for forcing schools to take responsibility for swimming look weak. Over half, in fact, have slashed the time they devote to it over the past three years.

But the experts see problems in abandoning the statutory commitment to teach water competence. "Swimming is not getting the attention it needs in schools, and the result is that we are seeing a nation of appalling adult swimmers," says Sumner. "If adults themselves are less competent, then they're less able to teach. It's a downward spiral."

What is the best way to teach a child to swim?

Advice from experts and the experience of parents provide a model swimming guide for children. The problem is, it bears little relation to that practised in schools.

Swimming is a compulsory element of key stage 2, although schools have the option to introduce it in the earlier key stage 1. Most lessons, according to Ofsted findings, actually take place in year 5, when children are nine or 10. But experts suggest that the ideal time to learn is somewhat earlier.

"The longer you leave it, the more difficult it gets," says David Sparkes of the Amateur Swimming Association. "The best age to learn is about six, when there are no built-in inhibitions. It's a good time to teach them: their co-ordination, strength and motor skills are about right."

It's a view backed up by Val Sumner of the Royal Life Saving Society. "The critical time is usually about the age of seven," she says. "Of course, some will swim younger and some will swim older. But, for most, seven is the age when their bodies and their mental processes are sufficiently developed. Little children will become more water confident with lessons, but in terms of making satisfactory progress, the child needs to be around the seven years mark."

The problem for schools is that their pupils' seventh birthdays clash with compulsory testing for KS1: many simply cannot afford the time away from the classroom. Some might even be hoping that, by year 5, parents will already have taken the initiative.

Joanna Smith, with three children aged eight, six and two, did exactly that. Her eldest daughter, Rosie, had a term of swimming lessons at school; Elinor, six, has had none so far. Both have begun private swimming lessons with an instructor who teaches only two children at a time. "They didn't do classes properly at school," she says. "The truth is that, as with many things, swimming is better done on a smaller class basis, and that's too much to ask of a school."

Sumner agrees that the current set-up in schools of lessons spread over a term is inefficient. "It needs more organisation - a term's worth concentrated over 10 days would be far more effective. It corresponds to the manner in which children learn."

Smith's daughters have certainly found the intensity of one-to-two lessons more productive. The drawback, she admits, is the cost.

"It is expensive - I pay £100 for a six-week course - and how on earth could a DfEE budget stretch to that?"

webTitle: What use are parents when it comes to homework?

fields.headline: Home alone
fields.standfirst: More and more six-year-olds get homework ... but what use can parents be when, as a new survey reveals, it leaves them bewildered and anxious?  Maureen Freely  finds out
fields.trailText: More and more six-year-olds get homework ... but what use can parents be when, as a new survey reveals, it leaves them bewildered and anxious? Maureen Freely finds out
fields.body:
It began with a chirpy letter. Dear Parents, it said. Due to the new government guidelines, children in years 4 and 5 will now be expected to build on the skills they've acquired in class by doing half an hour of homework, four or five times a week. All children will be taking homework diaries home with them. Please sign these to let us know that your child has done the work. There will be a place for you to write down how you think your children are coming along. We will use the same book to pass on information that we think you might find useful.

A day or two later my nine-year-old daughter announced at breakfast that she'd forgotten to put her spelling words into sentences. She began to cry and told me that now she was going to be punished by being kept in at break. As we still had plenty of time, I sat Helen down and got her started. This was when I found out there was a form she had to follow. But she could not quite remember it.

We muddled through and later that week she told me she had done badly on her homework because she'd done it in pencil, not pen. But that was just a little error, I insisted. What had the teacher said to make her think she'd done badly? "I only got three stars. Some people got four. I'll never get four." It was the first time she'd ever talked about her schoolwork being marked.

On Wednesday night, we were meant to practice her tables. And we did, for hours, because every time I tried to stop, Helen started worrying about the ones she still didn't know. Then on Friday she woke up crying at 3am and told me she was worried she was not going to have enough time to finish her homework by Monday. Her assignment was to take a story she loved and give it a new ending. She wanted to rewrite Helen of Troy, but she was afraid that if she got it wrong, she wouldn't even get ONE star. It took me most of Sunday to calm her down enough to get her to give it a try.

So yes, I did speak to her teacher, who was appalled and concerned. She made it clear to Helen that she was not in any danger of getting punished. The homework kept coming, but with the two of us working together to reassure Helen, she found her confidence. She can still tell me exactly how many people in her class got more stars than she did, and how many got fewer. But she also insists that she likes getting stars, because "that way I know if my homework is good or not and before when I only did things in class I never knew."

Both her father and I have come to like the homework routine, too. We have a much clearer idea of what she's learning, and the bigger, more creative projects she has at weekends are fun to help her with. My six-year-old, who has watched all this from a jealous distance, seems to associate homework with getting a lot of attention. Two weeks ago, when her teacher told her that her homework was to read for 20 minutes, she told me it was the happiest day of her life.

However, it's clear when I ask around that our case is not typical. A friend with a very active son the same age has such a hard time making him sit down that they are spending up to three hours a night on homework that should take 30 minutes. Another friend who works three nights a week is distraught because her dyslexic babysitter can't help her children. Another is thinking of taking her child out of after-school ballet, because she's too tired to do homework when she gets home. None of the above are against homework, but they don't understand why it has suddenly become such a big deal. They also wonder if it is advisable for children so young.

They are in good company. The "Homework Question" is as old as it is difficult to answer. Educators have been arguing about it in this country since homework became commonplace in the mid-19th century. The average workload has gone up and down in keeping with political ideologies. Whenever there has been widespread public concern about "falling standards", schools have responded to the crisis by assigning more homework. Eventually a moment arrives when they give one assignment too many, then there is uproar about the cruelty of it all. Schools respond by assigning less and less until one day someone asks why it is that standards are dropping and draws the inevitable, if oversimplified, conclusion: more homework needed.

That's where we are at the moment. Since home-school agreements were introduced last year, most parents have had to sign a statement saying they will help their children with their homework. The guidelines published by the DfEE last year recommend that children in years 1, 2, and 3 do one hour of homework a week, and that children in years 5 and 6 do half an hour five times a week. Primary schools are under no obligation to assign homework but are expected to make their policy explicit.

According to the 1997 Ofsted study on which the government's guidelines are based, schools with successful homework strategies are ones in which homework is appropriate to the age of the child and increases gradually over time. Feedback is clear and prompt; rewards and sanctions are clear and consistent. There is extra guidance and support for those who need it. Parents and teachers "work in partnership".

There is simply an assumption that homework is a good thing. However, outside of government departments, the consensus is less secure. New research published today by Parentline Plus suggests that homework anxiety amongst both children and their parents is a much larger problem than the DfEE realises. Four hundred parents who called the helpline were surveyed about their children's school-related problems. Bullying emerged as their greatest concern; but homework was not far behind.

In a related pilot study specifically about homework problems, Parentline Plus found that parents were not just lacking in confidence but also unclear as to exactly what their children were expected to do, and what role they were meant to play as parents.

They needed better information from schools, not just about the actual assignments, but about how much help they were meant to provide. Many also wanted the schools to provide workshops, so that they could have a general idea of what their children were learning. Maths was the subject they wanted most help with, but there was also a high level of uneasiness expressed by parents who had schooled in a very different way, in this country and abroad.

Many educators are uneasy, too. A 1999 study led by Steve Timms of Durham University found there was no evidence that homework in primary schools boosted academic performance, and some evidence that it might even cause harm. In the same year, David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Headteachers, warned that too much homework could mean no time for sports and hobbies.

There is also widespread concern in the profession that clumsily constructed homework policies could lead to a widening of the gap between children with educated parents and children whose parents who have no English or who left school early. In a MORI poll conducted last winter, a third of parents admitted to being worried about making mistakes while helping their children.

Even those who think homework can be a good thing point out that, actually, it's hard to prove. Those schools deemed most successful tend to be the ones with successful homework policies, but this is only one of many factors. Even if it had been established that more homework led directly to higher Sats scores (and it hasn't), it is not clear that high achievement at seven or 11 leads directly to high achievement in secondary school - or in life.

So the question is, why is Blunkett going to all this trouble, when it's not clear what the benefits are? According to Dr Richard Cowan, of the Institute of Education at the University of London, the government has two larger projects in mind. The first is to train parents so that they can play a key part in the education process. However, there is a long way to go, he thinks; right now, schools are telling parents what to do rather than engaging with them as equal partners.

Dr Cowan has higher hopes for the government's second, even loftier, project: this, he thinks, is to produce a new generation of workers who take the initiative. Homework is seen as a practice that breeds such qualities - and, certainly, that is how I would describe the transformation I've seen in my daughter over the past two months. But it's a programme that needs fine-tuning so that the needs of each child are taken into account.

In the best-case scenario, homework could become the vehicle by which parents and teachers learned to work with each other more closely. But according to Dorit Braun, chief executive of Parentline Plus, there has to be a big change in the way schools engage with pupils and their families. "They need to be more explicit. They need to communicate more effectively." Last but not least, she says, they need to forget about targets and Ofsted from time to time, and remind themselves "who schools are for".

webTitle: Can small universities survive alone?

fields.headline: Disappearing worlds
fields.standfirst: Like many other universities in Wales, Lampeter is small, effective and increasingly well known abroad - but can it survive on its own?  Donald MacLeod  reports
fields.trailText: Like many other universities in Wales, Lampeter is small, effective and increasingly well known abroad - but can it survive on its own? Donald MacLeod reports
fields.body:
Prisoners and prostitutes are now students of Wales' most ancient seat of learning - a thought to have the bishop who founded it spinning in his grave. But Bishop David Burgess would be even more surprised to find a mosque housed in the college he founded in 1822 to train men for the church.

Lampeter's grey stone quadrangle - an Oxbridge college dropped onto the Welsh hills - is still standing, its chapel still in daily use, but the smallest public university in Europe is having to run hard to stand still. The mosque signals the presence of many Muslim students, who are attracted by the renowned department of theology, religious studies and Islamic studies. It is also a sign that Bishop David has been followed as a benefactor of the university by Sheikh Khalifa of Abu Dhabi and the rulers of Bahrain and Qatar. Their £1.8m endowment helps fund Islamic studies in the heart of rural Wales.

The prisoners and prostitutes, on the other hand, are among the increasing band of Lampeter's distance-learning students - some of the 2,500 people now working towards a degree in voluntary sector studies. The university's Welsh department has uncovered a worldwide appetite for learning the language via the internet - more than 600 signed up, half from Wales and the rest scattered from Korea to Sweden to Puerto Rico. (One Slovakian student was so taken with Catatonia's Cerys Matthews that apparently she just had to learn the language.)

Unique it may be, but the University of Wales, Lampeter, to give it its full title, is a microcosm of the threats facing Welsh higher education - and the ingenuity with which parts of the sector are responding.

Size is one problem. With little more than 1,000 undergraduates on campus, Lampeter has the numbers of a school but has to provide the education of a university - with the library, the computing and the specialist lecturers that entails.

It is not a problem for the students - all the ones I met were extraordinarily positive about the experience and didn't pine for the bright city lights.

Caroline Gradwell, a third year student from Blackpool studying English, said she wanted to stay after graduating. "There are lots of people living in the hills in caravans because they can't bear to leave Lampeter. I love it - I wouldn't have gone anywhere else. It's friendly, no one feels isolated or on their own. The lecturers know your name and you feel people take an interest in you rather than just your tuition fees."

Adam D'Arcy found it a big change from his home city of Edinburgh but is enjoying his anthropology and archaeology course - and being on the student union executive.

In a small town without a cinema or night club, the student union takes on a lot of significance - there's entertainment as long as you make it yourself. There is a thriving gay and lesbian society.

FJ Ali is among the 30% of mature students - she went to art college in London 12 years ago and worked in the fashion trade before coming to Lampeter to study anthropology and Islamic studies. (This was despite the Big Issue branding it the dullest university in the country at the time she took the plunge.)

"The age range is very varied," she says. "It's an education in itself just being here - it's very cosmopolitan for the middle of Wales! It has a family feel - there's no division between lecturers and students. It's a great lifestyle if you've got an enthusiasm to learn. It prepares you socially better than any other university. It's not just teenagers - it prepares you to deal with a varied social world."

Enthusiastic though the students are, there are fewer of them. Three years ago intake was about 450 a year. Last year it was 350, and this October dropped to 300. One whole hall of residence is empty.

Lampeter has been hit by three trends sparked by the introduction of tuition fees - a triple whammy, according to Professor David "DP" Davies, the pro-vice chancellor. Mature students - one of the university's strong points - have become more reluctant to take full-time degrees for fear of debt. More students are living at home, or at least in their home areas where they can find term-time jobs more easily; Lampeter's local population is sparse. And the trend towards more vocational subjects, as students want to be sure of paying off their debts, does not suit the university's strengths in classics, archaeology and religious studies.

This year things got worse. Figures for admissions to Welsh universities are expected to show an overall drop of 10%, attributed to the last-minute rise in recruitment by the old, well-placed universities in England when they were given more leeway by the Higher Education Funding Council for England. The knock-on effect was to take students from many of the new universities - and from Wales.

"A place like ours is finding it increasingly difficult to provide the level of service that students and staff working in a university expect to have in terms of administration, computing network, library etc. Technology doesn't stand still, and you need more skilled people to keep it going," explains Davies.

Lampeter has compensated by moving swiftly into part-time undergraduate and masters degrees, often through distance learning. Theology is now taught in church groups around Wales and England, and there is a Masters in Celtic Christianity with summer schools in Ireland. "We are a long way from London, but very close to Ireland and some of us are beginning to look west. The European Union is keen on partnerships in other nation states."

The religious studies department (ironically one of the biggest in the country, where Judaism, Islam, Buddhism, Hinduism, Sikhism and the Chinese traditions of Taoism and Confucianism are all taught by believers) is also beginning to attract more international students. Lampeter is discussing a merger with Newport 90 miles away - but seems in no rush.

Size is definitely a problem for Wales, where small institutions are a feature of higher education - 13 serving a student population that in England would be catered for by five or six institutions of 12,000 to 15,000.

Last year the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales detonated a bombshell by proposing precisely that. The case for mergers was argued in the light of the need for new technologies and flexibility. "What is striking about developments in the provision of learning opportunities is the extent to which the significance of the campus is diminishing. Courses are taken out to the work place, continuous attendance on campus is not a requirement for learning, staff (particularly where a division of labour occurs) need not all be located in the same place."

Previous mergers "prompted" by the funding council - the Welsh Agricultural College with Aberystwyth and Coleg Normal with Bangor - had both been timely and prevented more severe difficulties developing, said the document, which bemoaned the reluctance of Welsh institutions to consider mergers. Proposals for Lampeter to join with Trinity College Carmarthen and be tween Swansea and the Swansea Institute of Higher Education had come to nothing: "The Council believes the evidence provided above points inexorably to the increasing problems likely to be faced by relatively small institutions, and concludes that Wales should aim for fewer, larger, institutions."

The merger plan has been put on ice as the Welsh Assembly's new Labour/Liberal Democrat leadership orders a complete review of post-16 education. Steve Martin, the funding council's new chief executive remarks: "Although there is a degree of collaboration, we still have a disproportionate number of relatively small institutions in a world that demands increasing economies of scale."

But he is quick to disavow any intention to issue merger directives. "They are independent institutions -we can't make them do things," he said more than once during our interview. But there will have to be more collaboration both between higher education institutions and with further education colleges -something potentially easier in Wales as the funding bodies for the two sectors are under one executive.

Welsh universities must not only compete with English ones for students and staff - the competition is global. Sir Adrian Webb, vice-chancellor of Glamorgan University, says they cannot afford to lag behind in developing new teaching and learning methods: "It is all expensive in hardware, software, staff time to develop curricula and prepare materials." He is critical of the merger document but believes a smaller number of big organisations - not necessarily merged - and a number of small collegial ones, might be best.

The assembly, unlike the Scottish parliament, has no direct powers over universities or student funding, though it may come to test the limits of the current arrangements and has made an extra £15m available for student hardship. What not all its politicians appreciate is the dependence of Welsh universities on England - 55% of their students are from outside Wales, predominantly from England (even if some have Welsh family connections). And ironically it is the most Welsh institutions - Aberystwyth, Bangor, Lampeter - that are the most dependent.

And it is easy for students - and staff - to travel in the other direction. From South Wales it is quicker to get to London than the north of the principality, where Liverpool and Manchester are in easy reach. Professor Phil Gummett, the new director of higher education for the Welsh funding council, points out that most academics could take a job at an English university without moving house.

How would the assembly - and Welsh academia - react to the idea that their future is so bound up with England that the eventual outcome will be a northern consortium linked to Manchester and/or Liverpool and perhaps two or three institutions in south Wales tied to Bath or Bristol? That is the prediction of one highly placed insider in the Welsh establishment, who says: "I don't think the Welsh higher education system is big enough to cope." Prudently, he remains anonymous.

U of Glamorgan 10,477

U of Wales, Aberystwyth 6,903

U of Wales, Bangor 7,020

Cardiff 15,658

U of Wales, Lampeter 1,401

U of Wales, Swansea 9,242

U of Wales, Coll of Medicine 2,326

U of Wales Institute, Cardiff 5,904

U of Wales Coll, Newport 3,004

North East Wales Institute 2,637

Swansea Inst of HE 3,129

Trinity College Carmathen 1,197

Welsh Coll of Music/Drama 513

Total 69,411

Proposals for Lampeter to join with Trinity College Carmarthen and be tween Swansea and the Swansea Institute of Higher Education had come to nothing: "The Council believes the evidence provided above points inexorably to the increasing problems likely to be faced by relatively small institutions, and concludes that Wales should aim for fewer, larger, institutions." Welsh universities must not only compete with English ones for students and staff - the competition is global. From South Wales it is quicker to get to London than the north of the principality, where Liverpool and Manchester are in easy reach. Professor Phil Gummett, the new director of higher education for the Welsh funding council, points out that most academics could take a job at an English university without moving house. How would the assembly - and Welsh academia - react to the idea that their future is so bound up with England that the eventual outcome will be a northern consortium linked to Manchester and/or Liverpool and perhaps two or three institutions in south Wales tied to Bath or Bristol? That is the prediction of one highly placed insider in the Welsh establishment, who says: "I don't think the Welsh higher education system is big enough to cope." Prudently, he remains anonymous. webTitle: Deafness and studying

fields.headline: Are you reading me?
fields.standfirst: Being deaf makes it all the harder to study.  Stephen Hoare looks at the problems and the successes
fields.trailText: Being deaf makes it all the harder to study. Stephen Hoare looks at the problems and the successes
fields.body:
Catherine Cassidy has every reason to be proud. This summer she graduated with a 2:1 honours degree in zoology and biological sciences from Queens University, Belfast, where she won a "blue" for water-polo and swimming. She is going on to read an MSc and has ambitions to be a scientific journalist. She is also profoundly deaf.

Catherine is oral-deaf, which means she can lip-read. Deaf students who cannot lip-read need interpreters to translate speech into sign language, while partially deaf students can benefit from FM radio hearing aids and induction loops.

I interviewed Catherine via e-mail. Given the patchy nature of special needs provision in school, she told me getting to university was an achievement in itself. Disabled students need an enormous amount of determination to succeed, and role models are thin on the ground. She says: "You have to work considerably harder than your peers and have to be prepared to commit yourself. Luckily, I have had a phenomenal level of support from my family." Catherine is one of 22 deaf students at Queens.

The Disability Discrimination Act and the Dearing Report have tasked universities with increasing their intake of special needs students to reflect the numbers of disabled in the community, and all now set targets for admissions. But there are difficulties. First, there are no reliable figures on the numbers of disabled in the community, hence universities are unsure of the percentages they should be aiming to recruit.

Second, definitions of disability are hard to pin down. Some students on the margins of disability such as dyslexia might require very little extra provision, while others might have a severe physical handicap requiring specially adapted computers, or online learning support.

Of all the disabilities, deafness is probably the one that is hardest to cope with at university. Dr Roddie Cowie, a senior lecturer in psychology at Queens, explains: "Universities run on talk. Knowledge is communicated in lectures, seminars, talking to fellow students - reading is only secondary. For deaf students, casual spontaneous discussions are out."

Fortunately for Catherine, Queens is a beacon of excellence for the teaching of deaf students on account of a special project, Succeed, set up in 1995 with an award of £95,000 from BT. The Joint Universities Deaf Education centre (Jude) organised a special phonic earpiece that enabled Catherine to listen to lectures.

Now self-financing, Jude has been extended to the other further and higher education institutions of Northern Ireland. Jude is setting an example in what can be achieved. Sharon Easton, deaf student support officer, says: "Our outreach officer visits schools to make deaf people aware that higher education is a possibility. Another part of our role is to talk with employers. We're offering them deaf awareness training - how to adapt to the needs of deaf employees, and applying for grants. There is no reason why a deaf person shouldn't cope with any job within reason."

Jude's funding may be secure but there are no universally agreed standards of provision and no handy funding formulae. The Higher Education Funding Council for England, Hefce, is currently working with the Department for Education and Employment and local authorities to draw up funding proposals. A spokesman for Hefce says: "Robust data on numbers and types of disability is unbelievably difficult to come by. The cost of provision for an individual student could be anything from £50 to £3,000. We are committed to removing cost barriers."

Further help is in the pipeline. On November 6, school standards minister Jacqui Smith announced a £220m spend over the next three years to improve access for the disabled in schools and, for the first time, funding of £172m for improving provision at further and higher education colleges.

Hefce is also spending £6m on improvements for disabled students. The programme aims to strengthen provision at institutions that have little experience in supporting students with special needs, to spread best practice, and to encourage collaboration between institutions.

Standards of provision vary widely but many special needs initiatives have been funded by industry sponsorship. Besides Jude, BT's higher education awards have helped to fund initiatives such as facilitating access to learning resources for disabled students at the University of the West of England and a multimedia environment foundation course at the University of Leeds. Part of UWE's pack age is a pilot scheme with the Royal National Institute for the Deaf to provide a network of video-phones giving deaf students access to sign language interpreters. At Leeds, the emphasis is on the special needs of dyslexics and the blind, with enlarged PC screens, colour modification software and speech synthesised text.

Support and encouragement was an essential part of Jude's offering. Catherine says: "Having a tailor-made service gave me independence that was a key element to my enjoying university life." But Catherine presented a major challenge for the staff at Jude: her skill in lip-reading made communicating with her seem so effortless that many people did not believe she had a problem. At times this experience has been painful. Catherine says: "People have labelled me 'not really deaf'. It is like telling me I don't count. And this can be very disheartening, very demoralising."

At the end of the day, Catherine believes that excellent and well-focused special needs support should be available to all disabled students whatever the cost. She says: "You are accepted by a university on the basis of your ability to learn and carry out mental tasks. You have a right to be there - people should not judge the mental capability of a person by any physical disability."
