webTitle: Many courses will not survive new postgrad quality controls

fields.headline: Out of the maze
fields.standfirst: Many courses will not survive new postgrad quality controls, says  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Many courses will not survive new postgrad quality controls, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
A third of all masters degrees could face the axe as a result of plans by university inspectors to expose courses that fail to meet postgraduate academic standards.

Quality watchdog heads last week endorsed proposals to reclassify the the "alphabet soup" of university degree titles - baffling for students and companies alike - into just five distinct strands of qualifications.

From now on universities will need to demonstrate that PhD courses, masters degrees, honours degrees, foundation degrees and one-year diplomas all meet nationally set academic standards.

"The public needs to know what it's getting when it signs up for degrees," said John Randall, chief executive of the Quality Assurance Agency. "That is as true for the people paying fees to enrol on courses as the employers giving them jobs afterwards."

The biggest impact of the reforms will be felt on the postgraduate sector. This has ballooned over the past decade as universities have pounced on new opportunities to generate income from fees charged on masters degrees. But the frantic expansion has created a plethora of confusing and inconsistent degree titles. Degrees with the same title may mean completely different courses for students - from research degrees and conversion courses to extended undergraduate programmes and honorary degrees.

But now inspection teams visiting universities will judge whether masters courses meet a set of detailed academic criteria. They will have to show for example that study work is "at the forefront of its academic discipline". Failure to do so would be reported publicly and could lead to loss of any government grants.

No one knows how many courses would fail the inspections. But the Economic and Social Research Council turned down a third of the 1,000 masters degrees applying for council recognition during an assessment five years ago. The most common failing uncovered in the social sciences - too much undergraduate content on courses - is likely to be repeated for masters degrees across the academic sector.

Some academic leaders estimate that as many as 50% of degrees could get the thumbs down from inspectors in some subjects. Professional qualifications, such as the Masters of Business Administration, are set to come under particular scrutiny. Jonathan Slack, chief executive of the Association of Business Schools, said he welcomed the reforms. But he pointed out that there was no way to estimate how many MBAs might lose their title.

Some long established titles, however, are set to escape the scrutiny of inspectors. The UK's ancient degree system owes much to historical quirks - the Archbishop of Canterbury, and the Presbyterian Theological Faculty in Ireland, for example, enjoy the same degree-awarding powers as universities - and many are proud of its traditions. Scottish universities will benefit from strong political support in their battle to retain MA titles for undergraduate courses, as most Scottish MPs are the owners of the degree.

Meanwhile Oxbridge MAs, which involve no extra study and are automatically awarded to graduates provided they have not been convicted, bankrupted or divorced, have conveniently avoided the new inspection regime - as there are no courses as such to inspect.

But the UK reforms are likely to gather momentum as a result of wider political moves to forge a unified degree system across Europe - based on the Anglo-Saxon nomenclature of bachelor and masters degrees. Leading academics are to discuss the implications of a Europe-wide system, enshrined in the Bologna declaration signed by ministers in 29 countries, during a conference in London today.

webTitle: An internet deal and the NUS

fields.headline: Net losers
fields.standfirst: Accusations against the NUS over an internet deal are smashing dreams of a unified movement that can mobilise against fees. Ros Taylor reports
fields.trailText: Accusations against the NUS over an internet deal are smashing dreams of a unified movement that can mobilise against fees. Ros Taylor reports
fields.body:
Tomorrow students will gather in London for the National Union of Students' latest attempt to bottle that old-fashioned spirit, student protest, and send it out to galvanise the pre-election campaign against tuition fees.

This, the "biggest ever" demonstration against tuition fees, is the best chance president Owain James - with London mayor Ken Livingstone in tow - will ever have to inspire the confidence of his members. But the union's grand online strategy, which was meant to bring students out on the streets of Kennington, has fallen flat.

It started so promisingly. At the beginning of September, the NUS announced an "online revolution" for their members which would, Owain James promised, reach out to every student in the country. Lured by bargains and online discounts, they would see an NUS that was a long way from the braying, disunited politicking of campus elections; a union that saved them money and campaigned on their behalf.

Most student union websites had already thrown up a site of their own. Some were sophisticated efforts; others were just a page with a few contacts. Many used the JANET network, and depended on their university for webspace and email facilities. The NUS spotted an opportunity. And in June, a 30-year deal was signed with ITM Activate which would offer all unions free hosting, email, software and an e-commerce service.

"Major partners" in the revolution - Abbey National, Studentmobiles, Microsoft and, of course, Activate.co.uk, a jobs site owned by ITM - were signed up. Individual unions were urged to join in with the promise of £500 worth of computer equipment and a guaranteed income.

If 30 years strikes you as a long time in the internet's future, you're not alone. "The length of the deal was a strong reason not to join," says Alistair Thompson, the president of Portsmouth SU, which has signed a deal with Virginstudent.com instead. "We were told that big universities might not get [the computer equipment at all]," explains Thompson, "and I was concerned about our own student database."

Do Portsmouth students even know about tomorrow's demonstration? Certainly not from their own website, which no longer even links to NUS Online.

By August, ITM Activate had announced that it intended to float on the stock market. With a 2.5% stake in the company and the chance of an other 2.5% if the site performed well, the NUS stood to make up to £50m - unheard-of riches for the union. Three months ago ITM was valued at up to £10bn by City analysts.

"We're not trying to get money out of it," insists James. "If we ever did make any money from it, the SUS would vote on it. The only payment ITM has made to us is to cover staff costs - £100,000 maximum."

Windfall or not, many student unions take exception to the contract. "It's an atrocious deal," commented one officer at a major southern uni versity. "We have no intention of signing up for that."

"This hosting deal is perhaps one of the most poorly researched and instigated internet deals that I have heard of in a long time," wrote the webmaster of the Guild of Essex Students' site on the student union bulletin board. Others agreed. So far, just 60 of the 704 affiliated unions have signed up.

The NUS can't ignore commercial realities, he argues, describing the 11 product placements dominating the front of NUS Online as "nothing more than discount zones". National advertisements, he says, "give us the freedom to do everything else."

Meanwhile, the contract is being redrafted - "nothing fundamental," says ITM CEO Ian Rose, "just clarifying certain points". The 30-year lock-in period stays, but Rose is coy about which clauses are being rewritten. Is it the agreement that ITM will have "complete editorial freedom" over their portion of the union site? The clause that requires unions to "encourage" students to register their names and email and postal addresses on the site so that ITM can add them to its direct marketing database? The promise that the union will ensure positive publicity for ITM and its major partners? The four-year commitment to ITM that each union must make?

Activate.co.uk rival Gradunet, which says it has reported the deal to the Office of Fair Trading, believes the deal is intrinsically flawed.

"This may come under the new European Competition Act," complains Adam Bass, the CEO. "It's a very poor agreement. Clearly the NUS are just lining their pockets at the expense of students. I think a thorough investigation of the NUS's trading process is in order."

He explains that many organisations, including Gradunet, pay the NUS to market in a concession on campus. The two most profitable union options in the ITM deal, however, ban "offline" as well as online marketing from ITM's commercial rivals - in other words advertising in union-controlled newspapers, poster sites, magazines or sponsorship deals on lager. Advertising a bank other than Abbey National, say, would be forbidden.

According to Owain James, the objections to the deal are groundless. "It's commercial companies and the rumour mill ... I'm not saying we haven't made mistakes, and I'm not saying there aren't a couple of things that can't be improved in the contract. But there's no pressure on a union to sign up for a deal if they don't want to."

Still in its infancy is the slick anythingstudent.com, an Andersen Consulting venture which intends to exploit the expected boom in e-learning. Having swallowed up studentmagazine.com, it claims to have collected a quarter of a million email addresses from student visitors already.

As befits a company with close government links, anythingstudent.com is unlikely to stir up the issue of tuition fees. "We've signed some mind-blowing deals," boasts CEO Nicolas Shulman - the man who, during his stint as president of the Student Law Society, signed up Guinness, Eurostar and Smirnoff vodka as event sponsors.

Paula Shutkever, the departing editor of studentuk.com, one of the most venerable of the student websites, points out that the student market is worth £5bn a year - "even though they appear to have no money" - to those who can nurture it properly.

"They seem to get quite turned off by commercial approaches to them," she explains, "which is why I think a Times venture folded a couple of years ago. The Virgin site is very functional, but without any depth of content. I think where we differ is that we pick our content very carefully."

James, the first politically nonaligned president of the NUS, will decide next month whether he wants to seek re-election. His reputation depends on the success of the south London rally and hopes that the unions can eventually be won over to the ITM deal.

In the meantime, the 3.5m NUS members can expect a slightly better deal on their mobile phones and bus tickets - if not their tuition fees.

webTitle: Is the government finally taking basic skills seriously?

fields.headline: Back to basics
fields.standfirst: Is the government finally taking basic skills seriously with its new unit?  Francis Beckett  investigates
fields.trailText: Is the government finally taking basic skills seriously with its new unit? Francis Beckett investigates
fields.body:
Last week Sue Pember moved into her new offices in the Department for Education and Employment and started recruiting the 20 or so staff who will help her to devise a strategy for helping the estimated 7m adults who lack basic skills such as literacy and numeracy. It could be that the formation of her Adult Basic Skills Strategy Unit marks the point at which Britain at last provides the necessary resources and new thinking. Yet doubts persist. Could we, even now, fail to make the necessary leap of the imagination?

For 25 years, people like Alan Tuckett of the adult learners' organisation, Niace, and Alan Wells of the Basic Skills Agency have campaigned to get something serious done about adult basic skills. They have kept it on the public agenda, but, as Tuckett puts it, "never quite high enough."

Basic skills are central to social policy, he says. Poor numeracy, for example, has a very high correlation with crime, because an innumerate person cannot plan, is prey to loan sharks, and can easily turn to crime. More than two thirds of prisoners have poor numeracy. We have more adults with basic skills needs than any country in Europe except for Ireland and Poland. One adult in five is unable to cope with everyday tasks such as consulting a telephone directory.

In the 1980s, the Manpower Services Commission started running 36-week courses, but then these were cut to 13 weeks, which is not enough for those with the most serious problems. Will things be better this time? There are plenty of good auguries. The Moser report concentrated minds wonderfully, and basic skills are one area in which the government seems willing to find enough money.

Pember herself is generally well thought of. The 45-year-old principal of Canterbury College has an OBE for service to further education, and understands that basic skills are essentially a job for government. You can't shuffle it off onto local authorities, or suppose that the private sector will ride to the rescue, as the government is inclined to do with schools. You need to make the Whitehall connections that link what the education department does with what, say, the Home Office does with prisons. Employers see it as the job of the state to provide their staff with basic skills.

Pember was a successful college principal, and has worked for local government as well as in colleges, so she understands how the machine works. It was while working for Enfield Council in the 1980s that she first became interested in basic skills, because it was her job to find out what industry and employers wanted from further education. She saw that people without good key skills were destined for the scrapheap.

She is, of course, uncomfortably close to New Labour. That might be seen as an advantage in a job where nothing can be achieved without the commitment of ministers. But this closeness, combined with the fact that she is not a traditional basic skills expert, has fuelled fears that even now the government is not ready to think the radical thoughts that the experts say need to be thought.

"They say the strategy will be radical," says Alan Wells. "I hope it will. My fear is that it will be too traditional." He worries that policy-makers' vision is still bound by college-based courses. "How do you motivate the 7m people with poor basic skills? Some of them will come into colleges. But there is no evidence that the majority will do that. People think there's an audience out there, and all you have to do is give them a bit of childcare and they will come in. They won't."

In Ireland, he says, they advertised a self-help pack on television; and in Britain, a survey has shown that more than half of those with poor basic skills want to learn in their own home. A few years ago the Basic Skills Agency gave a literacy pack out via the BBC. And why not make packs available through supermarkets?

There's some evidence that policy-makers' thinking is still college-bound. Pember herself talks a lot about teaching. She wants to see basics skills teaching being accredited by a university, to ensure that "if learners move from one provider to another, they will feel at home - the learning materials will be the same." She wants to see a common training for basics skills teachers. She talks of ensuring that efforts to tackle basic skills are co-ordinated across the country and across government - her basic skills unit at Canterbury had to bid for money from up to 15 sources. It's all excellent, but hardly radical.

Unlike Wells, she has not been steeped in basic skills thinking for years. That could be an advantage, according to Steve Broomfield, the chief executive of Warrington Council and a former further education college principal who, as a government adviser, has been a kind of godfather to Pember's strategy unit. He says: "She is not a basic skills expert, but that is a good thing. She's new, she'll bring fresh ideas to it."

Pember herself points out that she first trained as a primary school teacher, so she ought to know something about teaching basic skills. She fully expected to spend her career in primary schools. Like most of her generation she knew practically nothing about colleges. But, fatefully, she applied for a job at Redbridge Technical College for interview experience. The moment she stepped inside, she knew that colleges were the place she wanted to work in. "You saw you could make a difference to these people's lives," she says. Many of her students had basic skills needs.

If enthusiasm were enough, she would be home and dry already. "I'm very optimistic - I think an excellent strategy will come out of this, better than anywhere else in the world. This is a really important piece of work and I'm privileged to get to do it," she says.

Who will improve the UK's adult literacy and numeracy?

Born December 29, 1946; east London

1960s -1973 Taught in London secondary and special schools

1973 Birmingham's first full-time adult literacy specialist

1976 Deputy director Adult Literacy Resource Agency (ALRA), the first national adult literacy body

1978 Director of ALRA

1980 Director, Adult Literacy and Basic Skills Unit

1995 Director, Basic Skills Agency, with extended remit for schools

Susan Pember

Born December 23, 1954, Pontypridd

1978 Lecturer, textiles, fashion and clothing, Redbridge Technical College

1982 Deputy head, clothes, textiles and window-dressing, Southgate college

1987 Senior education officer for further and adult education, career and youth services, Enfield borough

1991 Principal, Canterbury College. Sat on Further Education Funding Council committees.

webTitle: UK leads Europe in providing a  meaning of qualifications

fields.headline: Masters stroke
fields.standfirst: From today the UK leads Europe in providing a precise guide to the meaning of qualifications, says John Randall
fields.trailText: From today the UK leads Europe in providing a precise guide to the meaning of qualifications, says John Randall
fields.body:
The British empire left much of the developing world a legacy of universities teaching through the medium of English. Not surprisingly, many of their students look to Europe for their postgraduate qualifications, particularly for the masters degrees in science and engineering that give access to globally recognised professional qualifications. But increasingly it is continental, and especially German, universities which are attracting students who might previously have come to the United Kingdom. Why is this happening?

Eighteen months ago, the higher education ministers from 29 European countries met in Bologna and signed a declaration setting out objectives for the development of European higher education. In the United Kingdom the declaration was noticed little, and understood less. Among its concrete proposals, the one which attracted most attention was the intention to replace seven- or eight-year continental courses with two cycles of qualification based on bachelors and masters degrees.

To view this, complacently, as the rest of Europe lining up with the UK would be a grave mistake. A prime objective of the Bologna declaration is to promote the international competitiveness of the European higher education system. To do this it was necessary to adopt the structure of degrees that is commonly recognised throughout the world. That objective is being pursued with alacrity: in Germany there are already 400 pilots of the bachelors/masters structure.

Adoption of a familiar structure of qualifications is not enough to become competitive. Increasingly, English is to higher education what Microsoft is to computing. Like it or not, it is becoming the universal language. And that is why, as the Germans pilot their new, post-Bologna qualifications, they will teach many of them in English.

The UK's natural advantages in the overseas student market are being whittled away. The advantages of historical links are not what they were. The generation now in power in many developing countries is the generation that was the first to suffer from the sharp increase in overseas student fees that Britain imposed 30 years ago. The UK cannot compete on price, as fees charged to overseas students remain amongst the highest in Europe. And now the advantage of the English language is diminished, as universities across Europe provide teaching in English.

But the reputation and standing of UK higher education should not rest on accidents of history, price, or convenience of a common language. UK higher education will stand or fall on academic standards.

In 1997 the Dearing Report called for "greater explicitness and clarity about standards and the levels of achievement required for different awards". Dearing was addressing the concerns of employers who wanted to know what they could expect from candidates for jobs. To illustrate his point, he cited the confusion that arose from five different usages of the qualification "masters". Today, it is not just UK employers who want to know what degrees stand for, it is would-be students from around the world.

Calibrating standards across subjects and between countries may seem daunting. But regardless of discipline or location, all higher education has one thing in common. It is concerned with exploration and discovery at the boundaries of our knowledge and understanding. Through grappling with complex subject matter, and difficult concepts, students learn to order and explain information, to define and to solve problems. Teaching that is informed by the fresh insights that come from research and development helps provide students with an appreciation of the uncertainty, ambiguity and limits of knowledge. Learning to make sound judgements in complex, unpredictable contexts is a key intellectual skill.

Knowledge itself knows no national boundaries, so its own boundary provides a common, global point of reference for the calibration of degree standards. Proximity to that boundary is the reference point proposed by the Quality Assurance Agency for determining the stan dards of UK degrees. The Qualifications Framework for Higher Education, launched today, sets out expectations for degrees at all levels.

An honours degree is expected to address the mastery of knowledge, understanding and ideas at the forefront of an academic discipline; and the problem-solving and communication skills that should be developed by study at that level.

The expectations of masters degrees will challenge universities to show that they are awarding the title for advanced study requiring a critical awareness of current academic problems, and the ability to advance new hypotheses. Use of the title for conversion courses teaching undergraduate material should stop.

In making clear the achievements represented by the main degree titles, and the attributes and abilities that holders of those degrees possess, the UK is leading the world in developing a new explicitness about academic standards. That will ensure that in the new European common market of qualifications, established by the Bologna Declaration, it is UK standards that set the pace. And it is those standards, not the accidents of history or language, that will maintain the UK's pre-eminent role in the global market for overseas students.

 John Randall is chief executive, Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education. A QAA conference, Bachelors, Masters and Bologna, starts 10am today at the New Connaught Rooms, London

webTitle: New qualifications come of age

fields.headline: New qualifications come of age
fields.standfirst: Tony Higgins argues that institutions now fully recognise the new Curriculum 2000 and what it means for application criteria
fields.trailText: Tony Higgins argues that institutions now fully recognise the new Curriculum 2000 and what it means for application criteria
fields.body:
Universities and colleges of higher education have fully embraced the concept of Curriculum 2000 and the broadening of the preparatory curriculum to access higher education which it brings.

When the previous AS (advanced supplementary) qualifications were introduced, higher education institutions were reluctant to include them in their entry criteria until they could see what students offering those qualifications were like. Unable to break into the vicious circle, schools were reticent about offering those qualifications until they knew whether universities and colleges would accept them for entry to higher education.

This sort of reticence was being shown in the early days of the introduction of Curriculum 2000 and yet it's clear that institutions will now accept those who offer qualifications within this new imaginative framework.

We at UCAS have had to abandon the publication of entry requirements in hard-copy format under columns because universities and colleges are beginning to act flexibly in the way in which the qualifications of A-level, AS-level, applied A-level and key skills can be mixed and matched.

It will be not until October/November next year that offers will be made by universities and colleges. And that explains why some have hesitated to express clearly, even at this stage, what their entrance requirements will be. But let me outline what some institutions have stated.

One school of medicine has set out the following entry criteria:

 21 units must be completed (a combination of advanced GCE, advanced subsidiary GCE (AS), vocational A-levels and key skills qualifications may be included).

 12 units must comprise two full advanced GCE subjects out of the science group (chemistry, biology, physics, maths or statistics), one of which must be biology or chemistry. Biology or chemistry - if not offered at advanced GCE level - must be offered at AS-level.

 For the remaining nine units, we strongly encourage applicants to offer at least six units of subjects outside the science group - of which three units could be key skills at Level 3.

 General Studies is not acceptable at advanced GCE or AS-level.

 A minimum of 370 points must be achieved, including AB grades in the science advanced GCE subjects. Chemistry or biology, if not offered at advanced GCE level, must be passed with a minimum of grade B at AS-level.

This is an example of a so-called "old" university phrasing its offers in terms of units and points, indicating that key skills qualifications, which are not integrated into the sciences, would be acceptable and also suggesting that units not integrated into the sciences should be offered. This is clearly not a university asking for bjust for performance at three A-levels.

Another university, part of the so-called elite Russell Group, says it expects applicants to achieve 18 units for entry and that the following combinations will be normally acceptable:

 12 units from two A-levels plus six units from a third A-level GNVQ plus six units from an A-level or a six-unit advanced GNVQ

 12 units from two six-unit advanced GNVQs. Plus six units from an A-level or from two AS-levels.

 A 12-unit advanced GNVQ plus six units from an A-level or two AS-levels.

A further Russell Group university will be looking for achievement in 18 units as follows:

 The 18 units can be met in various ways. A few degree programmes will give preference to students offering three A2s. Many will equally accept, say, two A2s with either two AS-levels or single (six-unit) advanced GNVQ, or one A2 with a double (12 unit) advanced GNVQ. Some may accept one A2 with four AS-levels. Other combinations may also be possible.

UCAS has now set up a special section on its website listing all institutions that have published entry requirements for 2002 entry so far. By clicking on the institution's name, you can find out exactly how it will be reacting to the new qualifications.

The list has nearly 100 institutions and this number will grow. It is in the "for schools and colleges" section of the advice centre on the UCAS.

Institutions are now publishing transparent criteria against which they intend to select students. These will mostly be indicated in so-called entry profiles available through the UCAS website. While many do not insist on a key skills qualification for entry, their entry profiles ask for certain skills that can be evidenced by the new key skills qualification.

I think that within a year or so, institutions will recognise the fact and, as an admission criterion, will be asking for achievement in the new key skills qualification.

 Tony Higgins is chief executive of the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service.

webTitle: DIY police checks

fields.headline: DIY police checks
fields.standfirst: Should teachers of the under-16s supply their own background vetting, asks  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Should teachers of the under-16s supply their own background vetting, asks Peter Kingston
fields.body:
The country's biggest lecturing agency is asking tutors to get their own criminal records from the police to prove they are fit to work with under-16s and have no disqualifying convictions.

It is cheaper and quicker for individuals to arrange these mandatory checks themselves than for Education Lecturing Services to do it via local education authorities, according to an internal ELS memo obtained by Guardian Further.

But the records that individuals are entitled to get from the police can omit vital information that would be given to colleges or local authorities if they made the checks themselves, according to the Home Office.

David Chaytor MP, chair of the Commons all-party further education group, called for agencies deploying staff to work with children to take responsibility for all police checks to avoid the risk of paedophiles or other unsuitable individuals slipping through the net.

The internal memo obtained by Guardian Further - an email from an ELS regional director, Amanda McBride, to her staff - concerns a contract to supply Uxbridge college with tutors for a "school links" programme, a national scheme that is growing in popularity. The tutors would be working with 14- to 16-year-olds who were doing vocational courses - motor vehicle maintenance, hair and beauty, catering - at the college.

"Lecturers who work with under-16s must be police checked," her email stresses. She suggests that ELS "rallers" - staff who offer assignments to lecturers - ask them if they have already been police checked.

If they haven't, they can be told that it is "very simple" to organise it themselves via their local police HQ.

"In most cases this is provided free to the individual and only takes a week to 10 days," the email says. "Agencies such as ourselves can obtain them on the tutors' behalf but it takes longer, and most areas levy a fee of around £35."

McBride told Guardian Further that the lecturers were self-employed. "It's up to them to organise their fitness to work in a place."

They had a right to the information from the police and it was free to them. ELS would usually have to ask a local authority to get the information on its behalf, at a cost, she said.

A Home Office spokesman said that members of the public who fill in a "subject access" form at a police station simply get a list of their previous live and spent convictions.

But certain organisations providing access to children under 16 or people with serious learning difficulties are entitled to be told more. This might include local criminal intelligence on an individual or details of any court case where they were acquitted of a sexual offence, for instance, on a technicality, he said.

ELS's executive director, Richard Eve, said there was no suggestion that the agency was "trying to get around the law" but added that it was colleges' responsibility to get police checks on lecturers in sustained, unsupervised contact with under-16s.

webTitle: How many 16-year-olds have money to save?

fields.headline: Taxing question
fields.standfirst: How many 16-year-olds have money to save? asks  John Crace following the government's ISA announcement
fields.trailText: How many 16-year-olds have money to save? asks John Crace following the government's ISA announcement
fields.body:
After months of direct action, blockading building societies and post office counters, further education students finally forced the government to back down last week in the row over personal savings. As the chastened Chancellor, Gordon Brown, announced that the age limit for tax-free individual savings accounts (ISAs) was to be reduced from 18 to 16, students welcomed the news that they would no longer be crippled by the upper bracket 40% tax rate or forced to only attend day-release courses from their Cayman Island havens for fear of contravening tax-exemption laws.

Well, that's the story we would like to have run. In fact, the news that Gordon's twin pillars of thrift and prudence are to be extended to the tune of a tax-free £3,000 per annum to 16-year olds, either at work or at school, has been greeted with almost total indifference, except for concerns for the Chancellor's mental health.

Very few studies have been conducted into the savings habits of young people. As banks and building societies generally like to know as much as possible about the public's financial routines, one can only assume this is not an oversight but an indication that there is nothing much to report.

Most 16-year-olds in full-time work are likely to be earning around £8,000 per year; after deductions for tax, national insurance, rent and living expenses there's not going to be much to save. For students, the picture is bleaker still. Further education students may get a massive £150 individual learning allowance, and some might be lucky enough, depending on their parents' income, to qualify for between £5 and £30 per week under the newly piloted Educational Maintenance Allowance. How much of that are they expected to save? Not much, if the Further Education Development Agency's own research into student hardship is anything to go by. This suggests that 65% of 19-year-olds on full-time courses work at least 10 hours just to keep their head above water.

The National Union of Students is clearly sceptical but is anxious to impart a diplomatic spin. "We obviously support any measures that encourage savings," says Mark Atkinson, NUS chief executive representative for further education. But who is it aimed at? "Perhaps it's a government admission of the widening gulf between student incomes and expenditure," he continues. "Maybe by encouraging 16- and 17-year-olds to save, they hope they will have fewer financial difficulties in post-18 education."

This has a logic, albeit a somewhat tortured one. But it might still not be quite what Gordon Brown had in mind. For that, one has to ask the financial experts. "It's basically a means to allow the better-off to save more money," says one, who prefers to remain anonymous. "Well-off parents can now put away extra cash in a child's name at 16 rather than 18. In theory, this money is being saved on behalf of the child, but this is not set in stone as the child could always be asked to give it back." So it's just another scam, then? "You said it, not me," he mutters, before downing another glass of champagne.

webTitle: So you want to learn...stage management

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: ...stage management
fields.trailText: ...stage management
fields.body:
I say! Yes?

Could you sign this? How peachy! I'd be charmed.

You were awfully good. Think so?

Yes, really, terrific. Too kind.

It's just . . . Yes?

I don't quite recognise you, um, without the greasepaint. Never wear greasepaint, luvvie.

You don't? No, leastways not to work.

Oh, why not? No need, luvvie, doing what I do.

What's that? Only holding the show together, luvvie.

Wow. You're the director? Oh, no. Much more important than that.

You mean you wrote the play? Give off, luvvie. That heap of shite.

It was wonderful! You should get out more, luvvie.

So, what do you do? I'm the stage manager.

I see. What exactly does that mean? Oh God, the ignorant public. Who do you think organises all this spectacle you've been enjoying? The actors?

No, um . . . Actors, luvvie, can walk, and some can talk a bit, but that's about it.

Oh, that's a bit rich - Anyway, as I was saying, a stage manager's responsibilities include organising rehearsals and productions, co-ordinating props, ensuring that stage costumes are at hand when needed, making sure that actors know what they are doing and when, and much more besides.

Do tell. They also supervise scene production, scene changes, lighting, musical accompaniment, prompting etc, with particular attention paid to the safety of the crew, actors and audience. Usually they have an assistant stage manager and scene movers, although this is often not the case in smaller companies.

Jack of all trades, eh? The job definitely requires a certain amount of "multi-skilling" and it is not unheard of for the role to require standing in for ill performers during rehearsals and even for assistant stage managers to do "walk on" or small speaking parts.

So you do get a chance of stardom? I have lugged on the odd spear in my time, luvvie, yes.

Any qualifications needed? Many applicants have a drama school qualification in stage management or a degree in theatre studies or drama. But many stage managers begin as assistants for which there are no minimum requirements. Experience of any kind within the stage management field at amateur level (in college or local amateur dramatics) will also help and look good on your CV, as will any related casual work experience such as being a ticket seller.

What qualities are preferred? Good organisational and interpersonal skills are essential. A stage manager must be practical with good literary and technical knowledge of the theatre. A sound grounding in both the artistic and technical side of the theatre is desirable.

 Association of British Theatre Technicians (ABTT), 47 Bermondsey Street, London, SE1 3XT

Telephone: 0207 403 3778

Website www.abtt.org.uk

 Conference of Drama Schools

Website www.drama.ac.uk

 Stage Management Association (SMA), 47 Bermondsey Street, London, SE1 3XT

Telephone 020 7403 6655

Website www.stagemangementassociation.co.uk

webTitle: The case for a national minimum training entitlement

fields.headline: Fragile employment
fields.standfirst: David Chaytor  puts the case for a national minimum training entitlement
fields.trailText: David Chaytor puts the case for a national minimum training entitlement
fields.body:
The unemployment rate in my constituency of Bury North is 2.8%. I like to quote that because it is significantly lower than the rate of 3.5% used by the 1945 Labour government to define full employment.

But I know that in Bury, as elsewhere in the UK, the full employment we are now enjoying is fragile. The reserve army of labour created by the noble Baroness Thatcher has either been temporarily absorbed by the hamburger economy or pensioned off with Incapacity Benefit.

Almost all of my constituents are in work. But far too many are surviving just above the breadline, doing jobs that are way below their potential with little chance of increasing their level of skill or their earnings.

How do we overcome a century and a half of failure to take seriously the importance of vocational education and training? How do we unify the academic/vocational divide? And how do we imprint on the brain of every parent and every employer in Britain the message that skill, knowledge, creativity and innovation are the tools of survival, not to mention success, in the weightless economy?

Far too many British employers have viewed training as a cost and not an investment. Far too many British politicians have ignored work-based training (because that's what other people's children did) and have decided to let employers get on with it.

And they haven't. That's partly why 20% of adult workers struggle with basic literacy and numeracy. It's largely why the number of British workers with level 3 qualifications is less than half the number in Germany. And it's probably why BMW bought, and then sold, Rover and not the other way round.

In Europe they do it differently. The Swedes introduced a law on educational leave in 1974, the year of the ILO Convention on the subject, to which the UK is a signatory. The Italians established their 150 hours scheme and the French followed in 1984. Article 15 of the European Social Chapter, to which the UK government is now a signatory, calls on governments and both sides of industry to set up schemes of leave for retraining purposes. And in the last few years British trade unions and the TUC have been pushing hard to get skills and training at the top of the collective bargaining agenda.

The British problem isn't primarily a lack of aggregate investment in training. Employers spend over £10bn annually on training. The budget of the new National Learning and Skills Council will be almost £6bn. The problem is that almost a quarter of the workforce doesn't get any.

I want to change that. My Lifelong Learning (Paid Study Time) bill puts before parliament the concept of a national minimum entitlement to training - an annual time allowance for training purposes for everyone in work. Most employees have this already. If you're an MP, a media consultant or a managing director, there's no shortage of opportunities for personal and professional development.

My bill would extend a bit of that opportunity to the caretaker, the cleaner and the care assistant. Paid study time really is the most effective way of extending vocational education to the many and not just the few.

The bill doesn't specify the minimum number of hours. It simply establishes the principle. It won't make much progress in this parliament. But it will get people talking about the ideas and thinking about the mechanisms. And it will come back, again and again, until it is accepted alongside acceptance of the national minimum wage.

The right to earn and the right to learn. Nothing revolutionary. Just a bit more security and opportunity for low-paid workers in the weightless economy.

 David Chaytor is the Labour Member of Parliament for Bury North and the Co-Chair of the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Further Education.

webTitle: Are student governors ready for reform?

fields.headline: A rare breed
fields.standfirst: Are student governors ready for reform? asks  Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: Are student governors ready for reform? asks Simon Midgley
fields.body:
It's not always easy to recruit student governors in the further education sector. Because students spend much less time in colleges than universities and are often part-time, colleges sometimes have to go to great lengths to attract and retain student governors.

Nevertheless, a new wave of funding, inspection and curriculum reforms is being ushered in for FE colleges, and with this in mind, the National Union of Students last week staged a conference preparing student governors for the reforms.

The convention was addressed by Stephen Grix, Ofsted's chief inspector for 16-19 education, who introduced student governors to the new inspection arrangements.

A new instrument of governance introduced last year made it compulsory for colleges to have at least one student governor on their governing bodies. Some colleges, in fact, had such representatives for several years before this new requirement was introduced.

Ivor Jones, an Association of Colleges personnel and employee relations consultant, says: "Hurdles include ensuring effective representation is available where colleges have multiple sites, [are] geographically far apart and cater for different types of curriculum provision and methods of delivery. But given that so many students in colleges are part-time and, even if full-time, at the college for only a year, there is often understandable resistance by students to become engaged in this aspect of college life."

Because of this, colleges often do find it difficult to retain continuity of student governor representation.

In order to maintain some governor continuity, Lewisham College has just decided to create a new role of governor emeritus. Asquith Gibbes, who has served on the governing body since before incorporation, will take up this new role in August next year after his current term of office ends. Although Gibbes is not a student representative, his new role will maintain governor continuity and help to preserve the collective college memory.

Jane Stroud, clerk to the college's governing body, added that Lewisham's governing board has also just voted that in future a student observer should attend governors' meetings in addition to the existing single student representative on the governing body.

"We have had some very effective student governors in the last few years. We do not have trouble in getting them," she said. "Sometimes they have trouble fitting in governance as well as their studies. The ones that we have had have been very committed and I think we have been very fortunate."

John Hogg, principal of Middlesbrough College, which has had student representatives on its governing body for several years now, said that last year his college had its most successful student representative ever. Imran Khan, 19, who was studying for a national diploma in public services, not only attended all the governors' meetings but also played an active role.

"He did not just sit there and take notes and report back," Hogg said. "He actually participated, asked relevant questions, sometimes awkward questions as good governors do."

Khan, who underwent National Union of Students' training in how to be a student governor, presented a written report on student matters to the governing body and spoke to it. He also kept governors abreast of what was happening within the student body.

"It's easy for management to say that the student body is happy; much more difficult for them to say it if a student governor is sitting there," Hogg added.

A good student governor, the principal said, can get across to the governors what the students really feel and what being at college is like for them. The main personal qualities student governors need, he said, are not to be afraid, to be clear about their own agenda and to be willing to act as the voice of the student body.

webTitle: Furthermore: The megaphone window

fields.headline: The megaphone window
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones muses on when you should speak up and when it's best to remain silent
fields.trailText: Janet Jones muses on when you should speak up and when it's best to remain silent
fields.body:
We have all sorts of ethicals to conjure with in further education. The most recent is the megaphone window.

There is an office in our college which, when the window is open at a certain angle, serves as a highly efficient loudspeaker system. But the spokesperson is oblivious to the fact that every word spoken is carried straight to the pigeons that inhabit our car park. The pigeons hang around unmoved. There have not been any people hanging around, moved or otherwise, which suggests that the broadcasts are not attracting attention.

However, would you like every word you spoke trumpeted to the outside world - every word that you thought was between you and your telephone, or you and A N Other, or you and yourself, if you are in the habit of soliloquy?

My guess is, you wouldn't.

The next question is whether or not you would wish to be told. Do you want to shut the window and scrabble through your memory of each word that might have reached an unknown ear? Or do you want to chatter on in ignorance? The last time I told somebody about something similar, they left the building forever. But the situation touched on the interests of the students which, happily for me, matched self-interest.

My classes were in a classroom with a partitioned section, which housed a "separate" office. The inhabitant of the office was spending the day on the telephone locked in a lengthy, articulate and acrimonious marital drama. My students relished their alternative English lessons to the extent of not hearing my more traditional ones and not bothering with their tea breaks. So I said something. Verbal combat stopped. The combatant departed.

Then there is the person who has sat in something; the person who has been underneath something; the person who has brushed against something; the person who has not done something up; the person who has left something hanging out. Speaking personally, I was glad to be told, by someone who has been a friend ever since, that my display of inner-wear as outer-wear was providing amusement up and down the corridors.

Then we leave those practical ethicals for the less literal ethicals: the person who is metaphorically sitting in something - or metaphorically sitting on something; metaphorically brushing against something; metaphorically not doing something up; metaphorically letting something hang out. But do we all want to be told?

Then we get to the big and nasty ethicals: professional cheating, for example. Or personal troubles which overflow into the building - the child's school is on the phone because nobody has collected the child and none of us can find the parent, but all of us have our ideas. Or the person with unidentified substances. Or the person carrying out some illicit business on the premises. Or the minefields of refugee status, immigration, and unofficial employment. Or the New Deal. Or a fellow tutor who did his best to help students with little English through the labyrinth of hiring a car only to recognise it during a police chase on the BBC news after an act of international terrorism.

fields.bodyText: We have all sorts of ethicals to conjure with in further education. The most recent is the megaphone window. There is an office in our college which, when the window is open at a certain angle, serves as a highly efficient loudspeaker system. But the spokesperson is oblivious to the fact that every word spoken is carried straight to the pigeons that inhabit our car park. The pigeons hang around unmoved. There have not been any people hanging around, moved or otherwise, which suggests that the broadcasts are not attracting attention. However, would you like every word you spoke trumpeted to the outside world - every word that you thought was between you and your telephone, or you and A N Other, or you and yourself, if you are in the habit of soliloquy? My guess is, you wouldn't. The next question is whether or not you would wish to be told. Do you want to shut the window and scrabble through your memory of each word that might have reached an unknown ear? Or do you want to chatter on in ignorance? The last time I told somebody about something similar, they left the building forever. But the situation touched on the interests of the students which, happily for me, matched self-interest. My classes were in a classroom with a partitioned section, which housed a "separate" office. The inhabitant of the office was spending the day on the telephone locked in a lengthy, articulate and acrimonious marital drama. My students relished their alternative English lessons to the extent of not hearing my more traditional ones and not bothering with their tea breaks. So I said something. Verbal combat stopped. The combatant departed. Then there is the person who has sat in something; the person who has been underneath something; the person who has brushed against something; the person who has not done something up; the person who has left something hanging out. Speaking personally, I was glad to be told, by someone who has been a friend ever since, that my display of inner-wear as outer-wear was providing amusement up and down the corridors. Then we leave those practical ethicals for the less literal ethicals: the person who is metaphorically sitting in something - or metaphorically sitting on something; metaphorically brushing against something; metaphorically not doing something up; metaphorically letting something hang out. But do we all want to be told? Then we get to the big and nasty ethicals: professional cheating, for example. Or personal troubles which overflow into the building - the child's school is on the phone because nobody has collected the child and none of us can find the parent, but all of us have our ideas. Or the person with unidentified substances. Or the person carrying out some illicit business on the premises. Or the minefields of refugee status, immigration, and unofficial employment. Or the New Deal. It's best to keep clear of ethicals if you can.

webTitle: Internet know-how: Links abroad

fields.headline: Internet know-how: Links abroad
fields.trailText: How to link with a foreign school
fields.body:
Practical guides to setting up links with schools abroad are hard to find. The best place to look is the National Advisory Centre for Early Language Learning's page. Another is AEDE, the European Association of Teachers).

Having decided on a school, the next step is to establish a working relationship and a time scale - especially important when you can't ring them up or set up a meeting face to face. The page at http://www.ultralab.ac.uk/ (which can be a little slow to load) has some good advice on this. Language teachers should also find www.linguanet.org of help.

Andy Williams of Knotty Ash school, Liverpool, which was awarded funding for videoconferencing equipment in the BT Schools Awards BT Schools Awards said their partnership with schools in Germany, Greece and Sweden started slowly, with teachers making the first contact. "We also have a partner school in New York, and they have been sending our year 3s at Hallowe'en email cards. We sent them Guy Fawkes cards back." Thirty-three children at Knotty Ash are deaf, and the Swedish school is for the partially-hearing, so the pupils often communicate via British and Swedish sign language.

The Central Bureau (part of the British Council) is also hoping that teachers will forge email partnerships as part of the new citizenship curriculum. On their Partners in Learning project launched last week and at the Windows on the World site, you can search for partner schools all over the world.

Meanwhile, 300 schools have signed up to MyEurope, one of many EU projects to en courage Europhilia among the young. The worthy Commonwealth Voices encourages debates and audio and video contributions from its members.

Something similar seems to have been attempted at Teachers' International Professional Development, but exactly what is not clear. Could it mean a stint abroad, or does it put teachers in touch with other schools? In any event the registration link is broken.

The Australians have done a much better job at www.montage.edu.au which is the best place to find an Australian partner school. Resources on schools in less developed countries, including a photo gallery, links, graphics and articles, can be found on the Guardian network at www.educationunlimited.co.uk/specialreports/readtheworld

webTitle: Resources: What does it mean to be British?

fields.headline: Beyond bulldogs
fields.trailText: This week First Edition has been asking young people what it means to be British
fields.body:
There are 59.5 million people in the UK. We live in an area of 242,000 square kilometres, contained within a coastline 12,429 kilometres long. More than a half of the days we wake up to are cloudy. Eight million households own a cat.

These are British facts and figures - measured, and defined. But the answers are far less certain when people are quizzed about what it means to be British. This week First Edition has been asking young people just this question.

Why ask them now?

Controversial research has been produced by an organisation called The Runnymede Trust as a result of its investigation into race equality in Britain. What attracted the most attention was the trust's suggestion that the word "British" fails to define the people of this country in a way that fully includes the 3.3m ethnic minority Britons who make up more than 6% of the population.

What's in a name?

What comes to mind when you hear the word "British"? The Trust decided the term offers a narrow vision of our population - conjuring up thoughts of white people going to church on Sunday and drinking beer. The report suggested the word was "racially exclusive" because it does not yet reflect the reality of multi-cultural Britain - which includes a wide range of ethnic groups following different religions.

Does this mean that "British" is a racist term?

Not at all. "Racial" just refers to ethnic origin, like someone being Chinese. This is very different from "racist" and so deliberately insulting.

Is it only some black people who feel left out when the word "British" is used?

No. Many people in Wales and Scotland dislike the term because of the way it is often used to mean "English". They feel Welsh and Scottish before they feel British - particularly because they now enjoy their own forms of self-government. They generally take their symbols, national poets and saints' days more seriously than the English, using them to underline their sense of national identity. When was the last time you saw someone English celebrating St George's Day or Wordsworth's birthday?

In Northern Ireland, too, the word is far from "innocent" in a community split between people who want to see the creation of an independent, unified Ireland and people who feel deep loyalties towards Britain and the Union Jack.

Also, many of the places and traditions that have become attached to the word British are linked to southern England in a way that excludes other areas - particularly in the north.

Are there other ways in which "Britishness" can be defined?

"Britishness" is more than cod and chips. It can bring to mind certain attitudes that seem to define the national character. These sometimes include ideas of courage and fairness. In the First Edition interviews, people also explain how the word links with institutions they feel proud of, such as the National Health Service or their schools.

Are these services, or the more general notions of Britishness, things that everyone can share in?

Ideally, yes. Such things could possibly form the basis of a much more inclusive idea of Britishness. But there's a problem. Despite the success of lots of people from ethnic minorities in Britain - black British people contribute £5bn spending to the economy - large numbers still experience unfairness and discrimination in their dealings with the police, schools and health services. Many also face lives blighted by poverty and limited opportunities. The Runnymede Trust report identified this and made over 100 recommendations for change.

Did it suggest the word "British" should be altered?

No, but it said that Britain is changing faster than the meanings associated with the word "British" and that the way people define themselves needs to catch up with the fact that we are a racially mixed nation. Britain has lost most of its empire and "Britishness" should no longer suggest superiority. Cultures, like the meanings of words, change, and it is important that they should - otherwise they could become negative and unhealthy.

Further information:

See the following websites:

 www.runnymedetrust.org.uk

 www.cre.gov.uk

 www.blink.org.uk

 Race is discussed in the Special Reports section at: www.guardian unlimited.co.uk/racism

webTitle: Shadows of doubt

fields.headline: Shadows of doubt
fields.standfirst: Three years after her disappearance, the police still have no idea what happened to Gracia Morton - and her family is still fighting to uncover the truth.  Nick Hopkins  reports
fields.trailText: Three years after her disappearance, the police still have no idea what happened to Gracia Morton - and her family is still fighting to uncover the truth.  Nick Hopkins  reports
fields.body:
Celeste Morton has been told her mother Gracia is dead. She doesn't know how it happened, or why, and so far, she hasn't wanted - or perhaps dared - to ask. For the moment, the difficult questions which she must have are locked inside the private world of this bright, otherwise inquisitive, seven-year-old girl. In some ways, it is a relief for those who care for her.

Because nobody, including her father Jonathan, her aunt Constanza Lezama, and one of Scotland Yard's most scrupulous detectives, Hamish Campbell - can tell her the answers she will one day want to know.

Three years ago last Sunday, Gracia Morton, then 40, disappeared without trace. She dropped Celeste at nursery school in Holland Park, west London, and was due to meet her brother-in-law, Peter Thomas, at the Barbican, where he was performing with the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra. She never arrived.

The police deal with reports of missing people all the time, but this case was particularly unusual. Gracia, an Argentinian musician who moved to the UK in 1985, was not a difficult or troubled woman. She was in fine spirits. No money had been taken from her bank account, and her flat in Kensington was exactly as she left it. Her passport was among her belongings at home. Her luggage and clothes were untouched.

Could Gracia abandon her daughter suddenly and without warning? Preposterous, her family said. Detectives dismissed the idea too. She adored Celeste.

Gracia left one confusing clue. After kissing her daughter goodbye, she popped in to see her estranged husband, Jonathan, who owns a house in nearby St Ann's Road, Holland Park. They had been separated for 10 months. The 62-year-old architect told detectives she had asked him to fetch their daughter later that day and keep her overnight. She also asked him to look after her Rover car and gave him the keys to the vehicle and her flat. She did not tell him where she was going or what she intended to do. After this, the trail goes cold.

There have been no sightings of Gracia since then. There has been no contact of any kind. Her savings remain untouched. To begin with, her older sister Constanza, 45, an interpreter who lives in Oxfordshire, hoped Gracia would call or write to explain, but the more she thought about it, the gloomier she became. Gracia was punctilious, straightforward and reliable.

Constanza now assumes her younger sister was attacked and killed, but because her body has not been found, she says she has been grieving a "non-death". The intense pain she and her family felt when Gracia first vanished has been replaced by a desperate aching to understand what happened.

"It is hard to move on," says Constanza. "Above all, I am sad because I miss my sister so much. I can't even talk about that without crying, especially at a time like this.

"And I am livid. Livid that something like this could happen with apparent impunity. That somebody has killed my sister and left us nothing. That someone has done something terrible and got away with it."

Constanza spent the third anniversary of Gracia's disappearance with her other sister, Maria, the youngest of the three. The sis- ters were very close and chatted most days.

The last time Constanza spoke to Gracia - 24 hours before she disappeared - they gossiped about their family and teased each other about Christmas. "I remember the conversation so well. She loved Christmas and I hated it. She was trying to soften me up, telling me all the things we could do that would make it more bearable. We had a gossip about the family, as we always did. She was very relaxed. Her life was full of projects and she was enjoying her job.

"She had had a difficult time with the separation, but that was behind her and she was looking forward. She was a positive woman. There was absolutely nothing to make me think something was wrong. It is strange how conversations like this have become landmarks in my life," she adds. "Keeping the memories alive are terribly important to us all."

Constanza's prime concern is Celeste, who is living with her father. "She will tell you, 'Mummy is dead', but she does not talk about what has happened in any proper sense. She does not know and she does not ask. There are certain things she will talk about, safe areas. She will recognise a pair of earrings and say, 'They were mummy's.' But when I ask her if she misses her mother, she clams up."

Constanza believes Celeste is blocking off hurtful thoughts, and she is fearful of the psychological damage that may have been done over the last three years. "I think we need to take professional advice on how to explain a disappearance like this to a little girl. I hope that I am wrong, but I worry there are things being stored up inside that need to be let out."

Although they have given up hope that Gracia is alive, the sisters will continue to look for her. Constanza's husband, Peter, has been working with a forensic archaeologist to identify possible areas where Gracia's body may have been buried. They are still quietly confident that the police inquiry will eventually uncover a vital clue.

"I don't believe in the idea of a perfect murder," says Constanza."I am heartened that the police have not given up hope. I can see they are still interested, and they still have ideas."

The family was understandably frustrated when Mr Campbell, the officer in charge of the inquiry, was sidetracked by another bewildering and time-consuming case. Rightly or wrongly, the murder of Jill Dando, in April 1999, overshadowed every other crime, and left Mr Campbell managing one of the biggest investigations undertaken in the UK. A man has been charged with Ms Dando's murder, leaving Mr Campbell more time to look afresh at the outstanding cases on his books.

He is a patient officer, used to fussing over details. Logic tells him that Gracia's family is right to fear the worst. "Would she have left the country and left her child? I don't think so," said Mr Campbell. "If she was alive, what circumstances would she be in? I can't imagine them.

"We searched her flat from top to bottom. I am sure she did not return there after taking Celeste to school. The breakfast things were still out on the table; her cat was there. We found nothing to suggest that she was making plans to go anywhere. From an investigator's point of view, I have to say that I do not believe she is alive. We believe she is dead, and we believe she was murdered."

Mr Campbell is still looking for her body, and he is again appealing for witnesses who might have seen her on the day she disappeared. "People need to think back and ask themselves if they saw anything suspicious. We need to find them. Someone, somewhere, knows what happened. The family has not given up. Neither will I."

 Anyone with information should contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

webTitle: Life after birth

fields.headline: Life after birth
fields.standfirst: Was Meg Mathews so wrong to live it up so soon after having a baby? Not every new mum has to be a saint, argues  Kate Clanchy
fields.trailText: Was Meg Mathews so wrong to live it up so soon after having a baby? Not every new mum has to be a saint, argues  Kate Clanchy
fields.body:
Does becoming a mother make you nice? According to Noel Gallagher, impending parenthood brought him closer to his wife Meg Mathews as their marriage foundered. In an interview yesterday, he explained: "Then Meg got pregnant and it was OK, because they're nice and mellow when they get pregnant. And after that it all went a bit pear-shaped, the constant larging it."

It is true that Mathews' apparent post-natal haste to return to the party scene does not fit with our tender image of the rosily radiant new mother. Kate Winslet, by contrast, fits perfectly. "I'm a lot less hectic than I was," she said last week in her first interview since her daughter's birth in October. "I've stopped smoking and I've become a much calmer, softer person. I'm becoming much more squishy and emotional."

I've always appreciated Kate Winslet as a figure - boldly three-dimensional and messy in a world of personally trained, tightly smiling x-rays. But I'm not so sure about this latest, madonna-like incarnation - I don't think motherhood makes very many women "less hectic".

In fact, I think motherhood makes you tougher. Take a look round your local supermarket. The mothers are the ones with the strained, hard-bitten faces, surreptitiously kicking their children as they stage a sit-down protest in the checkout queue, or studiedly ignoring them as they produce a note of pleading as sustained as a car alarm. "Not very nice," we tut under our breath. But the woman hitting the hardest is probably the most "squishy and emotional" of them all. Motherhood is state of coping with an infinite series of demands, most of which are invisible to everyone except the mother. Mothers who are left alone to cope with these demands, who are depressed, or poor, may well show their squishy vulnerability in ugly ways. And these ugly responses will in turn stop them from getting the approbation and support they need, because they've shown themselves to be a "bad mother" - as opposed to the "good mothers", whose feelings are vaunted in the papers.

But all mothers need to be a little hard - to reserve time for themselves, to set standards of behaviour, to make sure they don't end up joining the child-beaters in Tesco. Even Kate Winslet may well, in a week's time, need to put the baby down for half an hour while she gets some sleep, while Meg Mathews' refusal to act the stay-at-home should be no cause for automatic condemnation.

From time to time, all new mothers feel vulnerable. But this quality does not need celebrating - that simply encourages martyrdom. What mothers need instead are hard-nosed grannies assuring us, as a taxi driver told me once, that "crying makes them grow".

Interviewers of celebrity mothers should ask the question all mothers ask each other: does the baby sleep through the night? And above all, the media must stop implying that motherhood is a hobby and as improving to the spirit as a new face cream to the complexion. Motherhood is a job, and a very hard one. And it only makes you nice if everyone respects that.

But I'm not so sure about this latest, madonna-like incarnation - I don't think motherhood makes very many women "less hectic". In fact, I think motherhood makes you tougher. Take a look round your local supermarket. The mothers are the ones with the strained, hard-bitten faces, surreptitiously kicking their children as they stage a sit-down protest in the checkout queue, or studiedly ignoring them as they produce a note of pleading as sustained as a car alarm. "Not very nice," we tut under our breath. But the woman hitting the hardest is probably the most "squishy and emotional" of them all. Motherhood is state of coping with an infinite series of demands, most of which are invisible to everyone except the mother. Mothers who are left alone to cope with these demands, who are depressed, or poor, may well show their squishy vulnerability in ugly ways. And these ugly responses will in turn stop them from getting the approbation and support they need, because they've shown themselves to be a "bad mother" - as opposed to the "good mothers", whose feelings are vaunted in the papers. But all mothers need to be a little hard - to reserve time for themselves, to set standards of behaviour, to make sure they don't end up joining the child-beaters in Tesco. Even Kate Winslet may well, in a week's time, need to put the baby down for half an hour while she gets some sleep, while Meg Mathews' refusal to act the stay-at-home should be no cause for automatic condemnation. From time to time, all new mothers feel vulnerable. But this quality does not need celebrating - that simply encourages martyrdom. What mothers need instead are hard-nosed grannies assuring us, as a taxi driver told me once, that "crying makes them grow". Interviewers of celebrity mothers should ask the question all mothers ask each other: does the baby sleep through the night? And above all, the media must stop implying that motherhood is a hobby and as improving to the spirit as a new face cream to the complexion. Motherhood is a job, and a very hard one. And it only makes you nice if everyone respects that.

webTitle: Roman knife casts light on gladiators

fields.headline: Roman knife casts light on gladiators
fields.trailText: Conservators at the British Museum have cleaned a tiny bronze and iron knife, excavated in the east Midlands, to reveal the most detailed image of a Roman gladiator ever found in Britain.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Conservators at the British Museum have cleaned a tiny bronze and iron knife, excavated in the east Midlands, to reveal the most detailed image of a Roman gladiator ever found in Britain.

The detail is so minute that Ralph Jackson, a British Museum expert on gladiators, believes it reveals a previously unknown detail of their armour. It appears to show a ruffle at the neck, which he believes may be a scarf worn to stop the heavy helmet chafing the fighter's naked neck and shoulders. Although many gladiators' helmets have been found, including one in Britain identical to that worn by the figure, any fabric would have rotted away centuries ago.

The knife was excavated a week after the British Museum opened an exhibition on the Roman passion for gladiatorial combat. After rapid conservation work, it has been lent for the exhibition.

It is displayed beside a knife found near Cologne in Germany, with a bone handle, which shows the same type of gladiator but is far more crudely carved. The east Midlands figure is a Secutor, who carried a half length shield, and had the leading leg exposed below it bound with padding.

Archaeologists are still working on the site, which is being kept secret to protect it from looters. The knife was found in a layer with evidence of Roman habitation, not in a grave, the source of most gladiatorial items.

"This would have been a costly and prized possession," Dr Jackson said. "If we assume that it was an accidental loss, somebody will have been pretty fed up about it."

Cleaning has revealed two studs, possibly of silver, inlaid into the iron blade, which folded into a superbly cast and cut slot in the gladiator. The equally detailed back of the figure has still to be conserved.

"There is nothing to suggest that this knife was associated with an actual gladiator, but the owner may well have seen gladiatorial combat in London, Gaul, where superb bronzework was made, or even Rome, and bought it as a souvenir," Dr Jackson said.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
£1.35m for sleepwalker
A young sleepwalker left as a wheelchair user after falling from his fourth floor bedroom window seven years ago was yesterday awarded £1.35m damages at the high court. Reading borough council accepted that limit stops should have been installed to prevent Stuart Miller, now 16, opening the window beyond the point necessary for ventilation.
fields.body:
£1.35m for sleepwalker
A young sleepwalker left as a wheelchair user after falling from his fourth floor bedroom window seven years ago was yesterday awarded £1.35m damages at the high court. Reading borough council accepted that limit stops should have been installed to prevent Stuart Miller, now 16, opening the window beyond the point necessary for ventilation.

Two share GCSE award
Richard Tydeman, from King Edward VI grammar school, in Chelmsford, Essex, and Benjamin Collie, from Tanbridge House school, in Horsham, West Sussex, were jointly named GCSE Student of the Year for gaining 10 A* grades.

£5,000 price for Rowling
A first edition of JK Rowling's Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone is expected to sell for up to £5,000 at an auction in Swindon, Wiltshire, tomorrow. It is one of only 500 copies published three years ago.

Court case player sacked
Cambridge United sacked midfielder Neil Mackenzie yesterday for persistent misconduct after he appeared in court charged with a racially aggravated public order offence.

Larvae released
Three hundred rare hazel beetle larvae were released yesterday at a nature reserve in Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire. At one time the species was widespread.

Heart tremor link to crash
The pilot of an air ambulance which crashed into the River Mersey near Liverpool airport killing all five on board may have suffered a heart tremor, an inquest heard yesterday. Keith Whyham, 58, had passed a medical but had an enlarged heart and narrowed arteries. The inquest continues today.

Head who hit boy avoids jail
The deputy head of a public school who struck a 10-year-old pupil across the face with a slipper came "within a whisker" of going to jail, magistrates in Stroud, Gloucestershire, said yesterday. Ian Gurteen, 50, who was convicted of assault, was given 240 hours' community service.

Radioactive link ruled out
A report yesterday ruled out a link between radioactive fall-out from a fire at the Sellafield nuclear installation in 1957 and Down's syndrome births among women who were pupils at a school in and around Dundalk, Co Louth. Geoffrey Dean, who conducted the five year study, said: ."The cluster was due to some unknown factor."

Bar killing
Police were yesterday hunting masked gunmen who killed a 40-year-old man and injured a mother and daughter in a Limerick bar.
