webTitle: Foetus store triggers new row at Alder Hey hospital

fields.headline: Foetus store triggers new row at Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: Four hundred foetuses which were miscarried, stillborn or aborted have been discovered stored without their parents' consent at Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Four hundred foetuses which were miscarried, stillborn or aborted have been discovered stored without their parents' consent at Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool, it emerged yesterday.

All but 80 of the foetuses originated from two maternity hospitals in the city, which merged five years ago to form the Liverpool women's hospital. The others are from other hospitals around the north west.

The foetuses, which range in development from early pregnancy to almost full term, were sent to Alder Hey for post mortem examinations between 1988 and 1995, because it provided a pathology service.

Alder Hey hospital is already the subject of an independent inquiry into the issue of the organ retention of 893 babies and children. It was ordered by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, last year. Ministers received a copy last week of the inquiry report from Michael Redfern QC.

Dick van Velzen, the pathologist at the centre of the organ retention scandal, is believed to have been responsible for storing the foetuses. The families were not told that they had been retained.

Ian Cohen, a solicitor representing many of the families affected by organ retention, said they had been making discreet inquiries about the foetuses over the past four weeks.

"It now transpires that there is in fact a collection and, more worryingly, it seems to be directly connected to the period when Professor van Velzen was in charge of postmortems at Alder Hey," he said.

His colleague, Raymond Goodman, said: "We have for some time been requesting full information as to exactly what has gone on in relation to these foetuses, upon what authority they have been retained and what research has been carried out."

But the NHS executive in the north west accused Pity II, the parents' support group, of another attempt to put the boot into Alder Hey.

"There is nothing new or newsworthy about this story," said its spokesman, Hugh Lamont. "It has been looked at by the inquiry - it is not a secret."

He said the revelation formed part of the terms of reference of Alder Hey's special incident project board, set up this year, which includes members of Pity II. It was discussed at a meeting in July.

Kate Jackson, the project director of Alder Hey's serious incident team, said the hospital was aware that a number of foetuses had been retained. "We do not contact families proactively," she said. "Many families will not want to be reminded. We do rely on parents to contact the hospital."

She said any families who had been affected would be offered the same support and counselling as other families whose children's organs were retained following their death at Alder Hey.

webTitle: Scots solution to riddle of the pyramids

fields.headline: Scots solution to riddle of the pyramids
fields.trailText: It was Scots who brought the world the telephone, television, whisky and golf. Now it seems they may also have been responsible for the pyramids.
fields.body:
It was Scots who brought the world the telephone, television, whisky and golf. Now it seems they may also have been responsible for the pyramids.

Robert Lomas, of the University of Bradford, says builders in Orkney developed the complex techniques and methods of measurement needed to construct the sophisticated buildings more than 1,000 years before Egyptians started using them.

Dr Lomas believes the Egyptians heard of the Orcadians' ideas after they spread across Europe, and copied them. He said remains of buildings on Orkney dating from 3800BC show an extremely sophisticated construction technique.

"We were amazed. They seem to have been led by a group of astronomer priests who passed their knowledge to pilgrims all over Britain," he said.

"Unfortunately, they had not developed any type of writing we are able to read, so their discoveries have been forgotten. We can see what they did, but have to experiment to find out how they did it."

At the chambered tomb of Maes Howe, on Orkney, the builders devised a standard unit of length by taking detailed readings from the movement of the sun and stars.

Dr Lomas thinks the measurement - the megalithic yard - proves the islanders knew that the earth was round and that it moved around the sun centuries before it was generally accepted by the rest of the world. The measurement was used to build state-of-the-art monuments, he said.

In his new book, Uriel's Machine: the Ancient Origins of Science, Dr Lomas and his co-author Christopher Knight argue that the megalithic yard, which measures 82.966cm, could easily have been taken by seafarers to Brittany and beyond.

The megalithic yard was first discovered in 1967 by Alexander Thom, of Oxford University, after he had analysed more than 400 sites around the British Isles and northern France.

But, Dr Lomas says, Professor Thom was never able to explain the "physical reality" behind the measure.

webTitle: UK pledges 18,000 troops to EU force

fields.headline: UK pledges 18,000 troops to EU force
fields.trailText: The government has agreed to commit up to 18,000 troops to a joint European military force, Whitehall officials disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
The government has agreed to commit up to 18,000 troops to a joint European military force, Whitehall officials disclosed yesterday.

Pledges from all 15 EU member countries for the proposed new European rapid reaction force are due to be made in Brussels next week at an unprecedented meeting of foreign and defence ministers.

Closer defence and security cooperation is one area of EU policy where Tony Blair's government - along with France - is taking a clear lead.

Ministry of Defence and Foreign Office officials expressed confidence yesterday in the EU's ability to mount further joint operations in response to a crisis. EU states are committed by 2003 to be able to deploy 60,000 troops within 60 days and to sustain the force in the field for a year.

Responding to Tory claims, the officials insisted there was no question of setting up a "European army". The joint force would not even be a standing army, they said.

Decisions would be taken by consensus, British troops would be under national control, the common language would be English, and EU states would be under no obligation to take part in operations, they insisted.

Operations would be carried out by a "coalition of the willing", a senior official said.

Lord Robertson, Nato's secretary general, recently expressed concern that Tony Blair was allowing France too much say in the plans in a way that could arouse US suspicion. However, Whitehall officials insisted yesterday that EU operations would take off only with Nato - which in effect means US - support.

Six European Nato allies which are not EU members would have the right to participate in the force if Nato assets are involved, under plans being drawn up in Brussels.

The six include Turkey, which is pressing for a voice equal to that of EU members. EU countries which are not members of Nato - notably Sweden - are said to be enthusiastic supporters of the plan.

Politicians should start preparing for the day when British forces fight under an EU flag, according to a thinktank report published today.

The Institute for Public Policy Research said strengthening of the EU's defence capacity would be undermined unless politicians across Europe prepared public opinion for "difficult choices ahead".

webTitle: Wife 'framed as cocaine dealer'

fields.headline: Wife 'framed as cocaine dealer'
fields.trailText: A corrupt detective and a police informer helped frame a model as a cocaine dealer to ensure she lost custody of her child during divorce proceedings, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A corrupt detective and a police informer helped frame a model as a cocaine dealer to ensure she lost custody of her child during divorce proceedings, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Kim James, a part-time model and fitness instructor, might have been jailed for drugs dealing if the conspiracy had not been detected through a police surveillance device at the offices of a private investigation agency, said Bruce Houlder QC, prosecuting.

Mrs James was involved in divorce proceedings against her husband, Simon. The drugs find was designed to get her arrested and then discredited in child custody proceedings over their two-year-old son, Mr Houlder said.

Simon James recruited the help of Jonathan Rees, head of the private detective agency Law and Commercial. The drugs were placed in Mrs James's Fiat Punto car by another man, James Cook, the prosecution said.

Austin Warnes, a detective constable, allegedly was also brought into the plot and used his registered police informant, Dave Courtney, to persuade a senior officer that the information about the drugs was genuine. Warnes, 38, of Bexleyheath, south London, has pleaded guilty to conspiracy to pervert the course of justice between May and September last year, the jury was told.

But, Courtney, 41, of Plumstead, south London, James, 34, of Battersea, south London, Rees, 46, of Thornton Heath, south London, and Cook, 45, of Tadworth, Surrey, all deny the charge.

Mr Houlder said the crime had been staged "to see that [Mrs James] was arrested, prosecuted and sent to jail for a long time for that crime which she did not commit". The aim was custody of the child for her husband.

Mr Houlder said James and Rees "tried to paint Mrs James as some kind of loose woman", who went around West End clubs "peddling drugs".

Mr Houlder told how the estranged husband had met Kim in 1994, married her in June 1995 and divorced her in April 1999 when their son was aged two.

He branded James and Rees as the "heartless instigators" of the alleged plot, saying James had paid Rees a large sum of money for his "dishonest service".

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Eden Project partner to sue

fields.headline: Eden Project partner to sue
fields.trailText: In a falling out of biblical proportions, the Eden Project, which is building the world's largest greenhouse in an old china clay pit in Cornwall, is being sued by its co-founder for £5.5m damages.
fields.body:
In a falling out of biblical proportions, the Eden Project, which is building the world's largest greenhouse in an old china clay pit in Cornwall, is being sued by its co-founder for £5.5m damages.

Jonathan Ball, the architect who helped mastermind the pioneering scheme, which is backed by the millennium commission, was sacked from the Eden board in June.

Now he is suing the project, seeking compensation for the intellectual property rights he claims to have generated for Eden and for the time and expenses he invested in the scheme.

Attempts to reach a negotiated settlement with the charitable trust behind the venture are understood to have collapsed several weeks ago.

Eden's directors and trustees yesterday refused to comment on the legal proceedings or on Mr Ball's claim. But a spokesman for the £80m project said that the writ, issued last month, would be defended.

Mr Ball, 53, who lives in Cornwall, co-founded the project in 1994 with Tim Smit, the former music producer responsible for restoring Cornwall's Lost Gardens of Heligan.

The project, which secured more than £37m of millennium commission funding in 1997, is not due to open to the public until spring. However, it has already attracted 450,000 visitors who have been able to watch the transformation of the site.

At the heart of the project are two giant biomes or indoor greenhouses, where planting is under way - to include Amazonian, African and Asian plants like cocoa trees, vanilla orchids and bamboo.

The aim is to illustrate mankind's dependence on plants.

The writ, details of which emerged yesterday, shows Mr Ball was locked in a wrangle with Eden over payments before his sacking and had raised concerns with the board, the trustees and the millennium commission about alleged mismanagement.

According to the writ the commission had instructed accountants KPMG to investigate Mr Ball's complaints in June last year, but refused to show him the report.

A spokeswoman for the commission said KPMG had investigated but found "nothing of substance". She added: "We informed Mr Ball about this in March this year. The report is internal and confidential. The commission cannot comment on the action."

The writ says that because of the actions of Eden's directors, Mr Ball is no longer able to have an ongoing interest in Eden; he is therefore seeking compensation for his investment of time and expenses, for the benefits he expected from the project, and for his intellectual property rights.

Mr Ball also seeks an injunction that Eden acknowledges him in all publications as the project's co-founder and originator.

A spokeswoman for the commission said KPMG had investigated but found "nothing of substance". She added: "We informed Mr Ball about this in March this year. The report is internal and confidential. The commission cannot comment on the action." The writ says that because of the actions of Eden's directors, Mr Ball is no longer able to have an ongoing interest in Eden; he is therefore seeking compensation for his investment of time and expenses, for the benefits he expected from the project, and for his intellectual property rights. Mr Ball also seeks an injunction that Eden acknowledges him in all publications as the project's co-founder and originator.

webTitle: Crash pilot 'had heart ailment'

fields.headline: Crash pilot 'had heart ailment'
fields.trailText: The pilot of an air ambulance which crashed into the river Mersey near Liverpool airport killing five people suffered from a heart condition, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The pilot of an air ambulance which crashed into the river Mersey near Liverpool airport killing five people suffered from a heart condition, an inquest heard yesterday.

Keith Whyham, 58, may have suffered a heart tremor or discomfort which led him to lose control of the twin engine aircraft, which was travelling from the Isle of Man to Liverpool airport in June.

He had passed a civil avia tion authority medical five weeks before the crash and doctors said he did not have a heart attack. But he was suffering from an enlarged heart and narrowed arteries at the time of the crash.

Liverpool coroner's court was told that the bodies of Stephen Charlton, 52, a stroke patient who was being transferred to Walton hospital in Liverpool, his wife Lynn, staff nurse Karen Cowan and those of Mr Whyham and medical student Hannah Hollinshead were recovered from the Mersey.

Andre Rebello, the Liverpool coroner, told the jury that the 10 seater Piper Navajo Chieftain aircraft lost contact as it made its final approach to the airport.

Tony Evans, deputy medical officer at the CAA, said that Mr Whyham had a medical check every six months, to comply with industry regulations.

He said Mr Whyham did not report any problems between his electrocardiogram on May 4 this year and the crash the following month. "His heart was still beating on impact with the water and the pathologist found the cause of death was drowning and multiple injuries," he said. "His medical condition may have caused some distress and contributed to the loss of the plane, but complete loss of consciousness before the crash is unlikely."

He said that cardiac disease was coincidental rather than causative of the crash.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Spell of dry weather eases flood worries

fields.headline: Spell of dry weather eases flood worries
fields.standfirst: Special report: weather watch
fields.trailText: The first consistently dry spell for almost three weeks moved the meteorological office yesterday to echo Mrs Thatcher's celebrated Falklands instruction: "Rejoice, rejoice."
fields.body:
The first consistently dry spell for almost three weeks moved the meteorological office yesterday to echo Mrs Thatcher's celebrated Falklands instruction: "Rejoice, rejoice."

Less than a quarter of an inch of rain is forecast over the next 24 hours compared with 10 times that much in a series of eight-hour spells since late October.

"We can't say we're out of trouble yet by any means," said Adam Morris of the environment agency. "But this looks like the first real lull since the exceptional rains began. There are still eight areas in real danger of flooding, however, and another 46 where serious risks remain."

The main crisis point last night was at Wressle on the lower river Ouse in North Yorkshire, where earth dyke defences have been badly damaged by the force of the swollen river. Troops continued to work round the clock to shore up crumbling sections of the river wall with sandbags while pumps were deployed to run off floodwater into nearby meadows.

Severe flood warnings prevented residents in seven other areas from getting their first night at home for more than a week, including Malton in North Yorkshire and areas of the lower Dee in Cheshire. Elsewhere a huge clean-up got under way, dogged by controversy over charges for essential work. In West Yorkshire, the fire service apologised for having to charge a fee for pumping out cellars, based on the time and number of officers involved.

webTitle: Price is high for the ultimate hi-fi

fields.headline: Price is high for the ultimate hi-fi
fields.trailText: It is described as the Rolls Royce of hi-fis and priced at £75,000.
fields.body:
It is described as the Rolls Royce of hi-fis and priced at £75,000.

But if money is no object and the prospect of spending £35,000 on a set of speakers does not make you hit the high note, then you too can attain the holy grail of home entertainment.

Requiem by Yamamura Churchill is described by the company as "entirely free from the limitations normally imposed by commercial necessity". In other words, it will cost you an arm and a leg.

Created by acclaimed Japanese musician Bé Yamamura, the Requiem system boasts an impressive range of features that rely on complex calculations to determine just what is needed to handle the complete frequency range of the widest possible array of music.

The horn loudspeakers stand seven and a half feet tall and four and a half feet wide and according to the company's brochure, "each speaker is covered by hand with layers of tiny granules of Sardinian cork in order to eliminate any potential discolouration of pure sound".

Similarly the speaker drive units - the voice coil, bobbin and cones - are hand crafted from special paper used by traditional Japanese painters. Racing car technology has also been incorporated into the speakers' suspension.

The Wiltshire-based manufacturers believe that even in this digital age, vinyl rules supreme and claim to have constructed the world's first true uni-pivot turntable, relying on a complex system of outriggers to support the disc itself instead of a conventional platter which, they say, impairs sound quality.

To counteract interference and minute distortions from mains electricity, cabling alone costs £500 a metre, and then there is the cost of the pre-amps, power-amps, CD player and an AC mains box.

Kevin Scott, an audio consultant with Midlands-based Definitive Audio, said: "This is very much in the superniche audio market. You are paying for immaculate hand construction, no economies of scale and an incredible selection of unusual and difficult to make components, silvers, odd coppers and other strange things.

"These horn speakers are very big and what you would get is dynamic range, scale and tone colour, whereas even a quite expensive system sold in the high street would still sound like a hi-fi rather than 52 people playing acoustic instruments in an auditorium."

webTitle: Boy cleared of petrol attack on schoolmate

fields.headline: Boy cleared of petrol attack on schoolmate
fields.standfirst: Jury finds 12-year-old not guilty of deliberate harm to child left with permanent scars after being engulfed in flames
fields.trailText: A boy who almost burned another child to death while they were playing with home-made petrol bombs was yesterday cleared of intentionally injuring him.
fields.body:
A boy who almost burned another child to death while they were playing with home-made petrol bombs was yesterday cleared of intentionally injuring him.

Alfred Page, now 12, survived but the fire stripped the skin from 70% of his body and left him permanently scarred.

The defendant, also 12, still faces a sentence after admitting "recklessly" causing grievous bodily harm to Alfred, a charge that carries a penalty of five years' imprisonment for an adult.

Both Alfred and the defendant, who cannot be named for legal reasons, were among a group of children who had skipped school to play with petrol-filled milk bottles in woods near Gillingham, Kent.

The defendant claimed that Alfred caught his trousers on a fence and asked him to burn off the snagged material. Alfred was clutching one of the petrol bombs to his chest and was engulfed in flames when the defendant sparked his lighter. But Alfred told police he had been doused in petrol and set alight by the other boy, who then pushed him into a bush and called him a "bastard". He made no mention of petrol bombs and claimed that the other boy had turned up uninvited and joined their group who were playing "manhunt", a game of tag.

The jury at Southwark crown court, London, unanimously cleared the defendant of inflicting grievous bodily harm with intent and of a second allegation of injuring Alfred "deliberately".

The verdicts were greeted with disbelief by Alfred's mother Maria Page, who stormed out of the court room, sobbing: "He's a liar." Outside court, Mrs Page said: "I'm going to appeal against it. He's a monster and ought to be locked up. He nearly killed my son."

The defendant was remanded in custody to secure accommodation while a psychologist and the probation service prepare reports. A source close to the case said the boy's sentence over the recklessness finding was likely to be "non-custodial".

The trial has highlighted the difficulties of cases involving child witnesses, with inconsistencies in both prosecution and defence evidence. Alfred's alleged attacker spent several hours in the witness box insisting it had all been a "terrible accident". Describing how he had tried to free the other boy from the fence, he told the jury: "I weren't thinking properly what I was doing."

His actions, he agreed, were "risky", and before he knew what had happened Alfred was on fire.

However, Robin Johnson, prosecuting, said that the defendant had then gone to Alfred's home and told his older sister, Marcia, that the boy was on fire, using the words: "Someone just chucked petrol over him."

A crucial prosecution witness, another 12-year-old boy, admitted telling lies in his statement to police because he was scared of being arrested for having had a petrol bomb with him.

The jury heard that the defendant had been a victim of bullying, while Alfred alleged that the same child "beats up cats and dogs".

The defendant's mother left court without comment, but his solicitor, Richard Atkinson, said: "It is clearly very difficult trying young people, particularly as young as this defendant, but the courts, since the case of Venables and Thompson, have had to come to terms with that."

Sergeant Andy Short of Kent police said: "From my viewpoint I can't say that there are any winners or losers.It has really been a life-changing event for both parties. The victim has now got to live with the horrific injuries that he received and the defendant has got to live with the fact that he has done this to a friend of his."

Although his face and hands were unscathed, Alfred's chest, stomach, back and limbs were ravaged by the flames. The burns penetrated the skin across most of his body, eating into the fatty layer underneath - a type of injury with a high mortality rate.

The child underwent 19 skin operations, which included the grafting of sections of whaleskin and cowhide on to his body, as well as the removal of a length of his intestine. By his hospital bed he had a signed picture of Tony Blair and a get-well-soon message from his favourite actor, Mel Gibson.

Alfred's mother said: "The first 10 weeks we were watching him minute by minute. We nearly lost him three times, and three times he came back. He amazed everyone with his recovery. Of course he cried and was angry, but he doesn't complain, even before operations."

For the trial, the judge and barristers had dispensed with their usual wigs and gowns, following criticism by the European court of human rights that the Bulger trial, held in an adult court setting, had been unfair to the defendants. To make the case as "unoppressive" as possible, the judge also told the barristers they need not stand when addressing him and that the defendant did not have to sit in the dock.

webTitle: Letters: Green Britain

fields.headline: A very pale shade of green
fields.trailText: As someone who spent the first 14 years of my life in Germany I am perplexed by how few effective green initiatives Britain has succeeded in setting up (How to go green, November 13).
fields.body:
As someone who spent the first 14 years of my life in Germany I am perplexed by how few effective green initiatives Britain has succeeded in setting up (How to go green, November 13).

There are so many simple steps we could take, for instance with regard to our use of horrid, plastic shopping bags. In Germany almost every supermarket check-out will sell plain, cotton bags for the equivalent of 30p. They are "green", durable and convenient (no useless, cutting-flesh, plastic handles).

Ros Coward touches upon recycling schemes, but it can be taken so much further. Recycling is second nature in Germany; you even separate litter (glass, paper, packaging) in public places such as bus stations and airports. Shops provide facilities for you to leave behind unnecessary packaging - in the UK even bananas warrant plastic wrappers.

We could introduce the returnable deposit system, whereby crates of beer, water, juices and soft drinks can be returned to the store, where they are sterilised for re-use. These kind of initiatives have been in place for years in Germany and make such perfect sense.
Frances Mossop
Burnley, Lancs

On page 7 of G2 you urge us to be green and not use our cars, or to drive at lower speeds with no rapid acceleration. On page 16, Giles Smith extols the virtues of a £30,000 car with a top speed of 112mph, acceleration of 0-62 in 9.2 seconds, doing a mere 21 miles per gallon.
Sydney Davies
London syd@beathotel.freeserve.co.uk

I was reading Ros Coward advising that I should recycle my Guardian, when all the advertising leaflets fell out.
Richard Lindley
Brighton
richardlindley@breathe.com

We have been comforted by assumptions that Britain will be a net beneficiary from climate change with warmer winters and longer growing seasons. The truth is that winters will get warmer but this might be a temporary respite. Scientists warn that the Gulf Stream, which adds 30 degrees C to our climate, could switch off. It is, in fact, a pump which relies on tropical waters migrating north cooling. Dilute them with meltwater and the circulation stops. Melting Greenland ice is already changing the consistency of the north Atlantic.

The longer growing seasons could not only be temporary but more than offset by the loss of 50% of grade one agricultural land in East Anglia and Lincolnshire through flooding and salination due to rising sea levels and the increase in storms (caused by the build-up of heat in the system).

At the Hague meeting on climate change this week, the US will be seen as the victim of its own success. At the time of Kyoto its share of the carbon dioxide abatement burden was 7% as against the 1990 emissions level. Thanks to their economic miracle that is now 30%. The deal to be brokered is that, in return for business as usual, the US will plant new forests and possibly buy up existing ones in developing countries.

The problem here is that trees offer a zero net benefit in terms of carbon dioxide since they ultimately return all their carbon to the atmosphere. Add to this the prediction by the Hadley Centre at the Met Office that rising temperatures by 2050 will cause forests to die on a massive scale, returning catastrophic amounts of carbon to the atmosphere. In return for this sticking plaster solution the US will sign. The only carbon benefit of this policy would be if trees were used to replace carbon-intensive materials involved in construction like aluminium.
Prof Peter F Smith
Sheffield

webTitle: Letters: On dumbing down

fields.headline: Dumber than ever
fields.trailText: Madeleine Bunting's description of the alleged phenomenon of "clevering up" as a feminisation of knowledge (Rewiring our brains, November 13) is an unconsidered reversion to the bad old days of vulgar feminism.
fields.body:
Madeleine Bunting's description of the alleged phenomenon of "clevering up" as a feminisation of knowledge (Rewiring our brains, November 13) is an unconsidered reversion to the bad old days of vulgar feminism. There is no such thing as gendered knowing: one is rational or irrational, informed or ignorant. The examples of the new styles of knowing she quotes would strike most educated people of any period other than our own as hardly knowledge at all, except in the debased sense familiar from TV quiz shows.

What has changed in our culture is neither a "dumbing down" nor a "clevering up" (still less the "wising up" Madeleine Bunting rather belatedly recommends). Rather it is the rise of an enormous intellectual middle class of the half-educated, who mistake for wisdom a broad but shallow general knowledge derived largely from the media.

It's hardly surprising that these same people see the ability to half-attend to many matters simultaneously as proof of intellectual grasp. This is why the vague concept of the interconnectedness of all things has been greeted with such general acclaim: not because it describes any reality, but because it describes the habitual state of mind of individuals chronically unable to make hard distinctions.
Paul Bowes
Llandinam, Powys Bowes9116@aol.com

Andrew Clements on "classical music" (Dumb? November 11) concludes: "Music has to speak on behalf of the society that spawns it" and suggests that music produced in previous ages is therefore irrelevant. This is a relativist view. Of course, styles change, but is a Bach cello suite relevant only to the early 18th century? A piano piece by Prokofiev may be produced in the 20th century, but that doesn't mean that it must be associated always and irrevocably with that time and with a particular society. It is only the listeners' habit of association that forges this link. Modernists dislike the baroque and the classical because it is associated with a privileged society. But if Bach is deemed unfit for democratic ears, what are the chances of Pierre Boulez being accepted by the masses?

The present use of the term "classical" is not a useful description of the diversity of art music. How can Sibelius be lumped with Telemann? It throws out the distinction between classical and romantic.
A Mackie
Dunbar, East Lothian

fields.headline: Deadly lure of cold cure
fields.trailText: Rob Evans (The guinea pigs, November 8) does not explain why hundreds of servicemen took part in the Porton Down experiments.
fields.body:
Rob Evans (The guinea pigs, November 8) does not explain why hundreds of servicemen took part in the Porton Down experiments. In 1957-8 I was doing national service in the RAF at Upavon, a few miles from Porton Down. I remember a request on the camp noticeboard for volunteers for experiments on the "common cold". The inducement was two weeks' free of any duties. Fortunately, I resisted.
RR Jordan
Cheadle Hulme, Cheshire

Two problems: what to do with the Millennium Dome and the lamentable state of British tennis. One solution: turn the dome into an all-year, all-weather tennis coaching centre, open to all. Give inner-city kids the chance to become the Wimbledon champions of tomorrow.

webTitle: Letters: Last skirmishes in the Spanish civil war

fields.headline: Last skirmishes in the Spanish civil war
fields.trailText: Mark Taylor (Letters, November 13) maintains I exaggerate, that at most only a dozen Britons volunteered for Franco. In his preface to the memoirs of Frank Thomas, a Welshman who did, Robert Strading mentions the difficulty in making surviving Welsh volunteers come forward now.
fields.body:
Mark Taylor (Letters, November 13) maintains I exaggerate, that at most only a dozen Britons volunteered for Franco. In his preface to the memoirs of Frank Thomas, a Welshman who did, Robert Strading mentions the difficulty in making surviving Welsh volunteers come forward now.

In his memoirs, Peter Kemp mentions casual encounters with at least four or five Englishmen fighting for or helping Franco (the kind of people he knew socially and fraternised with, not the likes of Frank Thomas). If Mr Taylor is right, Kemp managed to come across 40% of British volunteers while fighting in a few areas of an enormous front. In the first half of his book Kemp is posted with the Requetes, a purely Spanish corps; he couldn't have met many foreigners there.

Chips Channon's diaries show that in 1936 endorsement of fascism was predominant among the London elite, including the king. It seems unlikely that nearly 2,500 young British men of the left (not all of them communists), decided to fight in Spain but only 12 from the right.
Guillermo Gil
London

The International Brigade Association met recently at the Marx Memorial Library, which holds a large archive of British members. A committee was formed to keep alive the spirit and inspiration of all who fought for the republic in Spain. Your excellent homage to our members (G2, November 10) will help to achieve this, but we are anxious that widows and families with whom we have lost touch should be included in any future gatherings. We can be contacted at the address below.
David Marshall
37 Reginald Road, London E7 9HS

Every year, veterans, friends and families gather alongside the International Brigade memorial in Jubilee Gardens, on London's South Bank, in a moving and poignant ceremony. Next time you're on the South Bank, stop to take a look at the monument which is next to the Millennium Wheel. It's a beautiful piece of work and a fitting tribute to their selfless heroism.
Richard Baxell
London
r.baxell@lse.ac.uk

webTitle: Leader: Labour and Europe

fields.headline: Europe... the true story
fields.standfirst:
But Cook's big splash is a bit overwritten
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: But Cook's big splash is a bit overwritten
fields.body:
A brace of speeches yesterday by Tony Blair and Robin Cook in which they sought to remind the British public of the benefits of European Union membership was remarkable in several respects.

One is that such boosterism is deemed to be necessary at all. The truth of the prime minister's assertion that "to cut ourselves off from the major strategic alliance on our doorstep would be a supreme act of folly" should be obvious to all. The foreign secretary's list of reasons for valuing our common European home - three million jobs, open and expanding markets, greater national security, enhanced global influence - should be equally self-evident and convincing.

That such statements do in fact need to be made, 27 years after Britain acceded to the Treaty of Rome, amounts to a grudging recognition of the corrosive, growing influence of euroscepticism, within and beyond the Tory party.

Only a few months ago, a reluctant Mr Blair was being urged to make the case for joining the euro. Now, after the Danish referendum and his own remarks in Seoul, the single currency is well and truly off Labour's pre-election agenda (although not William Hague's). Instead, more basic questions about EU membership have come into play. For that reason, the government's pro-Europe PR offensive is as welcome as it is overdue.

If Labour is being forced to fight old battles, it must shoulder part of the blame. It has allowed Mr Hague to gain the initiative over the euro: significantly, the first of the "five commitments" of his election battleplan is Keep the Pound. This obsessive Tory emphasis encourages a broader europhobia. Labour became embroiled in a furious row over France's refusal to lift the beef ban, for example, but watched helplessly as the EC failed to force Paris to back down.

For the lay voter, fairly or unfairly, this episode seriously undermined Labour's claims to wield greater influence within Europe. Labour supports a common EU foreign and defence policy but fails to explain exactly how such projects serve Britain's interests in its relations with the US or Nato or, say, in Sierra Leone.

Mr Cook blames sections of the British media for peddling "euro-myths". His claim that some press reporting is biased against Brussels and thus disinforms the British public is certainly justified. His contention that "it is patriotism, it is national self-interest, to argue for Britain's full engagement as a leading partner in Europe" and that it is a self-defeating "betrayal" constantly to obstruct and criticise efforts at enhanced cooperation, while a trifle overwrought, is one we support. But it is plain daft to suggest there are not serious problems concerning the EU's aspirations, institutions and lack of democracy that require continuous, rigorous media examination.

In describing next month's Nice summit as unadulterated "good news", Mr Cook lurches towards the very kind of misleading exaggeration he deplores in Britain's press. He also commits the cardinal journalistic error of underestimating his audience. Nice will present difficult choices for Britain, for example on the surrender of the national veto in many areas. People know this. And they know the Tories will exploit it.

It is unclear whether Nice will deliver other measures needed to facilitate enlargement; or whether France and Germany will again embarrass Britain with their federalising ideas and plans for a two-speed community. Speaking up for the EU and for Britain's membership is vitally important. But that should not mean pretending that everything in the Brussels garden is blooming.

webTitle: Letters: Defending the Food Standards Agency

fields.headline: Chewing over the facts on food safety
fields.trailText: Food is an issue that can divide people and provoke polarised views. Everyone is entitled to their opinion, but Joanna Blythman (Weekend, November 4) does readers a disservice by dressing up opinion and presenting it as fact.
fields.body:
Food is an issue that can divide people and provoke polarised views. Everyone is entitled to their opinion, but Joanna Blythman (Weekend, November 4) does readers a disservice by dressing up opinion and presenting it as fact.

The FSA is accused of "last month seriously considering relaxing safeguards on BSE". On September 13 we issued our latest draft review saying "Food Standards Agency consults on retaining current controls in BSE review".

We are accused of being out of touch with consumers and dealing in "trivia" in relation to food poisoning. Most consumers would not consider aiming to reduce food-borne illness by 20% over the next five years as trivial.

When I said that organic food has not been shown to be safer or more nutritious than conventional food I wanted to ensure consumers had the facts when making choices.

Ms Blythman says that there is "enhanced safety" in organic food and claims that 43% of conventional fruit and vegetables tested contained pesticide residues. What she omits to say is that they are within acceptable safety limits and at very low levels. Her final proof of organic safety is the claim that organic cattle have not succumbed to BSE. Not true, at least 215, according to Lord Phillips.

What this points to is the danger of entrenched views on food safety. Precisely the approach that Lord Phillips criticises as being the harbinger of BSE: an inability to consider all the facts because of either producer interest, political motivation or ideological certainty.
Sir John Krebs
Chairman, Food Standards Agency

webTitle: On the web: Unusual languages

fields.headline: On the web: Unusual languages
fields.trailText: Sites for pupils
fields.body:
Learn Dutch

Aimed at: older learners

A quaint, rather contrived attempt to teach Dutch through the medium of a story set in the Crossroads Cafe (a Dutch version of Cheers set circa 1975). The chief virtue of the site is the ability to hear phrases spoken and to practise vocabulary, but the introduction of new words is unclear and explanations of grammar hard to find.

Swedish

Aimed at: older learners

Four introductory lessons in Swedish. The author has also produced a similar site for Hungarian.

Swahili
Aimed at: older learners

Swahili may not be an obvious choice (although it is spoken by 50 million people in Africa), and no attempt is made here to teach the alphabet, but these pages would be of particular use if you want to introduce students to a non-European language and illustrate the difficulties involved - for example, to show the problems a non-English-speaking refugee might experience. Nine lessons and a good selection of links cover the most basic grammar and vocabulary of Swahili.

Learning Latvian

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

A cheery site which teaches some basic Latvian vocabulary and phrases.

Hebrew for me

Aimed at: KS2/3

Numerous games and activities for practising Hebrew, with a particular emphasis on Jewish festivals. The keyboard tutor teaches children how to type in Hebrew.

Children's Chinese

Aimed at: KS1 onwards

Colourful, animated activities for young children which practise listening, reading and writing skills in Chinese. Many of them can be printed off and filled in.

Russian Dictionary

Aimed at: KS1 onwards

A small "speaking" dictionary with large pictures and sound files, this is likely to appeal only to very young children.

Japanese Writing Tutor

Aimed at: everyone

It focuses exclusively on practising Japanese characters (Katakana, Hiragana and Kanji). Watch each being formed and copy the strokes on your own paper. Highly recommended.

About.com: Japanese

Aimed at: KS2 onwards

The About.com guides produce their own resources as well as linking to other sites on the web, and they are just about the best place to start looking for resources. Some use manga (Japanese cartoons ) and quizzes for practise. Replace the Japanese in the site address with Chinese, Hebrew, Russian, or HindiUrdu (eg hebrew.about.com) to find excellent sites for these languages.

webTitle: Bulger pair 'could die if identities revealed'

fields.headline: Bulger pair 'could die if identities revealed'
fields.standfirst: Boys have right to freedom from persecution, say lawyers
fields.trailText: The killers of two-year-old James Bulger are at real risk of reprisals which could threaten their lives if their whereabouts and new identities are revealed, the high court was told yesterday.
fields.byline: By Clare Dyer, legal correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
The killers of two-year-old James Bulger are at real risk of reprisals which could threaten their lives if their whereabouts and new identities are revealed, the high court was told yesterday.

Lawyers for Jon Venables and Robert Thompson asked Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the family division, for unprecedented lifetime injunctions preventing the media from disclosing information which would identify them.

Mr Fitzgerald said James's father had vowed to hunt his son's killers down. "Taken in context, it is abundantly clear what he intends to do when he hunts them down." There was also a declared intention by the media to "out" the pair.

Ralph Bulger said yesterday: "James had the right to live, the right to grow old, to love and be loved and to have children of his own. But they took his rights away from him and so they should have no rights at all, never mind the right to privacy or the right to hide away."

Thompson and Venables, now 18, could be released early next year after a ruling by the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, that their tariff - the minimum term for punishment and deterrence - expired last month. They will be given new identities when they leave the local authority secure units where they have been detained at her majesty's pleasure after battering James to death on a railway line in Liverpool in February 1993.

Edward Fitzgerald QC, for Venables, told Dame Elizabeth that under the Human Rights Act, which came into force last month, the injunction was justified to protect their right to life and to freedom from inhuman and degrading treatment, which could be threatened by revenge attacks.

Mr Fitzgerald said the injunction also banned anyone publishing anything about the boys' whereabouts or their assumed identities when they are released. "Disclosure of that information would expose him [Venables] and his co-detainee to serious physical risk and serious psychological fear and the likelihood of harassment. It is necessary to protect his right to life and freedom from persecution ."

His argument was backed by the attorney general, in his role as guardian of the public interest. The home secretary and the official solicitor also support the application for a media ban, which is opposed by three newspaper groups.

There is no precedent for granting an injunction to protect the identity of an adult killer on release. Mary Bell, who served 12 years in custody for killing two small children in 1968 when she was 11, won an injunction after her release to protect her daughter, who was made a ward of court.

Mr Fitzgerald stressed that the case was highly unusual and would not necessarily set a precedent. "There are a number of unique features about this case - their extreme youth at the time and the special nature of the detention and the very extreme nature of the risk."

He did not refer to adult killers such as Myra Hindley, but it would be equally open to them to argue that their lives would be endangered by a media free-for-all on their release. Dame Elizabeth asked whether the argument would apply to adult paedophiles at risk of vigilante attacks. Mr Fitzgerald replied: "I do not wish to compromise the position of those who represent paedophiles at serious risk of life or limb."

He also argued that a ban was justified under the law on confidentiality and to protect the pair's right of privacy under the European convention on human rights. The court has to balance the right to privacy against the media's right of free speech under the convention.

Mr Fitzgerald said Desmond Browne QC, for Associated Newspapers, the Mirror Group and News Group, would argue that there was no need for an injunction because the press could be reported to the Press Complaints Council if it overstepped the mark. To argue that the press could be relied on to act responsibly and that any remedy could be sought after the event was "not good enough".

The hearing was adjourned until this afternoon.

webTitle: Tax credits for social investment are vital

fields.headline: Tax credits for social investment are vital
fields.standfirst: Tax credits for investment in deprived communities were a major ommission from the pre-budget report, writes Michael Brophy, head of the Charities Aid Foundation
fields.trailText: Tax credits for social investment were a major ommission from the pre-budget report, writes Michael Brophy, head of the Charities Aid Foundation
fields.body:
The last budget saw the introduction of important tax incentives for charities, prompting them to realise the potential for major increases in giving from individuals and companies. Over the next few years charities will publicise these vital new arrangements, aimed at persuading people to give more and make their donations tax-effective.

Apart from failing to address a long running demand for relief from VAT payments on the goods and services that charities buy, the hole in the government's plans is still in the area of tax credits for social investment. There seems no reason why someone who lends to charities should not get the same tax relief as a giver.

However, the government has rightly identified the need to encourage private funding into the country's most deprived areas and disadvantaged communities. In his recent pre-budget statement the chancellor of the exchequer referred to his programme to direct a £1bn package toward the regeneration of Britain's towns and cities. The package responded to an important social investment taskforce report which recommended a number of measures to encourage community finance initiatives. It suggested the creation of community development venture funds, increased support for community finance institutions, greater disclosure by the banks of their support for under-invested communities and a community investment tax credit to encourage private investment in community development.

Although many of these measures were adopted, the idea of the tax credit appears to need more work. The government says it is committed to "consult widely on the proposal for a new community investment tax credit, designed to encourage private investment in both not-for-profit and profit-seeking enterprises in under-invested communities."

The social investment taskforce made a rigorous case for a community investment tax credit, which was its first recommendation to government. There will need to be much consultation about the precise ways in which tax credits can be triggered and a robust evaluation system to demonstrate how well they are working.

But the principle is surely unassailable. As the taskforce says in its report: "By stimulating new private investment into under-invested communities, the taskforce believes the government can reverse the downward spiral so that investment stimulates enterprise growth, which in turn provides employment and builds assets and wealth".

CAF is committed to seeing a major growth in lending for charitable and enterprise purposes and believes that a community investment tax credit would be essential to stimulating growth in the social economy in many of Britain's deprived communities. The government should hold further consultation with all due speed so that such a tax credit can be included in next April's real budget.

webTitle: Peers challenge ministers to insist on gay law

fields.headline: Peers challenge ministers to insist on gay law
fields.trailText: Ministers insisted they would force through measures to lower the age of consent for gay sex to 16 despite it being thrown out by peers for the third time last night.
fields.body:
Ministers insisted they would force through measures to lower the age of consent for gay sex to 16 despite it being thrown out by peers for the third time last night.

The government plans to invoke the rarely used Parliament Act - which allows it to override the Lords if it defeats a bill - if peers do not back down before the end of this month.

While there is still time for the Lords' amendment to be overturned in the Commons and then returned to peers, the government privately anticipates the act being invoked for only the third time in a decade. It would also mean the bill would have to be rubber stamped by the new Speaker Michael Martin, one of just six Labour MPs who opposed the lowering of the age of consent.

The move follows the government's defeat last night by 205 to 144 over plans to reduce the age of consent for homosexuals from 18 to 16. A second defeat by 139 to 124 followed as peers voted to extend the number of categories of people who could be prosecuted for abusing positions of trust.

Lady Young, the Tory peer who has crusaded against the change, successfully put forward an amendment which would keep the age of consent for anal sex for both boys and girls at 18 but allow any other homosexual acts to be committed at 16.

She said it would also prevent buggery of girls at 16 being legalised for the first time. "Our concern is to protect children," she said. "Sixteen-year-olds are children in law. By keeping the age of buggery at 18, we protect young 16-year-olds from the most dangerous of sexual practices."

The Liberal Democrat peer, Lord Russell, said students and young people favoured a change in the law, and older people opposed it. He told peers: "I believe this issue has done more damage to the reputation of this house in those quarters in which I move than anything else since Irish home rule (in 1911)." The debate also revealed divisions among clerics, with the Bishop of Birm ingham supporting the bill, and the Bishop of Chelmsford opposing it.

Lord Alli, the Labour millionaire and gay peer, likened Lady Young to a concerned grandparent who should leave a younger generation to "live our own lives.

"We are not asking for you to approve of homosexuality or homosexual acts. I am not even asking for you to understand why they happen," he said. "What I am asking you to do is to remove the penalty and weight of the law from those young men aged 16 and 17 who consent to have sex with other men. Surely there can be nobody, except those on the very extreme of this debate, who believe that we should criminalise 16 and 17 year olds for having sex by consent."

The cabinet office minister Lord Falconer, for the government, argued that the issue was one of equality, adding "far from providing the protection that the baroness claims that they (the amendments) will, the view of many people involved in that process appears to say they would have the reverse effect".

webTitle: Teams recover bodies from Austrian train

fields.headline: Teams recover bodies from Austrian train
fields.standfirst: More about the tunnel tragedy
fields.trailText: Rescue teams in Austria working to recover some of the estimated 159 victims of the world's worst-ever skiing tragedy pulled the first human remains from the Alpine train's charred wreckage yesterday.
fields.body:
Rescue teams in Austria working to recover some of the estimated 159 victims of the world's worst-ever skiing tragedy pulled the first human remains from the Alpine train's charred wreckage yesterday.

Among the dead was Briton Kevin Challis, 40. Yesterday, in contrast to long black flags hung throughout the town, a union flag was flying from the Challis family home in central Kaprun.

Further "indirect identification" of victims, based on evidence said to be "90% certain", was made yesterday, increasing the total number of dead by four, to 159. The number of Austrian dead rose substantially to 92; Germans accounted for 37 dead, 10 victims were from Japan, eight from the United States, four from Slovenia, two fromthe Netherlands, and one from the Czech Republic. The nationalities of four others remain uncertain but officials warned that the toll could rise yet further.

Investigators said that much of the identification had been made possible as people returned to work after the weekend, and reported missing colleagues. A telephone hotline set up to deal with inquiries about victims had received more than 20,000 calls.

Experts remain baffled about the cause of the inferno on the 26-year-old train system, which created temperatures inside the train carriage - known as "the glacier dragon" - of up to 1,000C.

Investigators from Austria and Germany are working with forensic scientists, fire experts, mountain rescuers and military personnel on the scene as police sealed off several miles of mountain around the disaster area.

The 200-strong emergency teams were working in 90-minute shifts because of the "huge psychological pressure" of the job. Counsellors were also at the scene to talk to the workers after each shift.

The accident happened on Saturday morning, the first official day of the ski season, as the sleek funicular train passed 600 metres into a tunnel pass leading to the Kitzsteinhorn ski slope just outside Kaprun, 50 miles south-west of Salzburg.

Eye-witnesses reported seeing a cable snap and hearing a massive explosion. Others say the fire began well before the train entered the tunnel.

By yesterday morning, 29 bodies had been flown by helicopter to the Forensic Science Institute in Salzburg. A further 17, uncovered five metres from the upper part of the train, were being held at the top of the mountain in the afternoon after a strong, warm wind from the south made conditions unsafe and hampered the operation.

Professor Edith Tutsch-Bauer, a forensic scientist from the Salzburg institute said that friends and relatives of the victims - 60 of whom are being cared for by counsellors at the youth hostel in Kaprun - have been asked to provide personal items belonging to the victims to help DNA testing.

"We're asking relatives to supply us with personal objects such as clothing, razors, toothbrushes, and lipsticks so we can carry this out," Prof Tutsch-Bauer said. It is expected to take three teams of two scientists between three up to a month to finish the autopsies, Prof Tutsch-Bauer added. Identification would not be possible in all cases.

The sheer extent of the tragedy began to sink in in the 2,900-inhabitant town yesterday. Five locals - including ski instructors and an eight-year-old boy whose mother was waiting for him near the summit - are believed to be among the victims.

Other victims named in Austrian newspapers included a nine-year-old boy, his 17-year-old sister and 40-year-old father from Upper Austria, a 43-year-old doctor and his two sons, from Burgenland, and possibly the youngest victim, a boy aged five from Salzburg who died alongside his father and brother.

Organisers of the World Snowboarding Championships, due to be held at Kitzsteinhorn on November 24, called off the event. But, elsewhere, the practical attitude of the Bergvolk (" mountain people") resurfaced yesterday.

Snowboarders due to start a course tomorrow, began arriving in Kaprun while an alternative method of transport, the gondola system built eight years ago and which runs alongside the railway was due to reopen on Friday, along with the ski slopes.

Officials in ski resorts throughout Austria shut down similar train systems for safety checks following claims that the Kitzsteinhorn train was not properly fitted with safety devices such as a sprinkler system, did not have enough emergency exits or fire extinguishers and the allegation that an evacuation drill had never been carried out.

webTitle: Sullivan seduced by cheap Spurs

fields.headline: Sullivan seduced by cheap Spurs
fields.trailText: Birmingham City's co-owner David Sullivan may raise his stake in Tottenham - but only for business reasons.
fields.body:
Birmingham City's co-owner David Sullivan may raise his stake in Tottenham - but only for business reasons.

"Spurs are a company I believe are underpriced and undervalued," said Sullivan, who already owns a 1% stake in the club. "I may raise my stake to 9.9% but I won't be going any higher until I've done my job at Birmingham."

That job is guiding the Midlands club to the Premiership, after which he plans to sell up and become involved elsewhere, either at Cardiff City, his home-town club, or nearer his Essex base.

The Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson has transfer-listed his Italian defender Gianluca Festa at the player's request.

The 31-year-old, signed from Internazionale for £2.7m in 1997, has been out of the side in recent weeks and, with the £8m defender Ugo Ehiogu back in training after a calf injury, asked Robson for a move.

"I have asked to leave because I am not playing but I believe that I deserve to," said Festa. "I can accept being on the bench if the team is doing well, but we are not. It's very hard because I love Middlesbrough."

"As far as I am concerned, if he doesn't want to play for the club then his request is granted," said Robson.

The Scotland defender Brian O'Neil yesterday joined Derby in a swap deal which saw Stefan Schnoor return to Germany with Wolfsburg. O'Neil has signed a 2-year contract and is expected to make his debut against Bradford on Saturday.

Fears that the Croatian Igor Biscan's transfer to Liverpool would collapse have been lifted after the £5m midfielder was granted a work permit. He will now arrive at Anfield on December 1 - two weeks earlier than originally planned.

webTitle: Spots and the American election

fields.headline: Spot of bother
fields.standfirst:
Poor old George. What a time to get a boil, says Sally Weale

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Poor old George. What a time to get a boil, says  Sally Weale
fields.body:
If the American elections were to be won on complexions, Al Gore would be home and dry. Smooth, pink, shiny, flawless - his skin was a story of success as he went to the cinema last weekend.

In contrast, his rival for the presidency, George W Bush, relaxing on Prairie Chapel Ranch, sported a large plaster on his right cheek, running vertically down his face an inch or so from his ear.

Not the sort of blemish to be covered by spot concealer - too bulbous, too lumpy. The plaster didn't sit flat against the skin, it couldn't quite hide what was underneath. Poking out from the side, bulging up into the pad of the plaster was a red, angry boil, refusing to be concealed. No wonder Bush was keeping a low profile. To develop a boil - on your face of all places - while an election hangs in the balance, is unfortunate, to say the least.

So what exactly is Bush suffering from? Quite simply, a boil, or skin abscess, is an infection deep in the skin which usually occurs if bacteria get into a deep break in the skin, which can be caused by an ingrown hair, or a splinter, acne, or a blocked sweat or oil gland.

They are more common in people with diabetes, kidney failure or immune deficiency, and when a large number of boils form close together, the mass is called a carbuncle. Most boils will drain on their own, but larger ones may need to be lanced by a health-care professional. Occasionally, antibiotics may be needed.

They're miserable, and embarrassing. But why? The technical word for a boil is furuncle, which has its origins in the Latin word furunculus, meaning petty thief, suggesting perhaps that the poor, the dirty, the undernourished are more likely to suffer.

They ooze and suppurate in the pages of William Shakespeare and Ben Jonson and the Bible - festering boils were the ninth plague on Egypt, according to Exodus. Job, whom "Satan smote with sore boils from the sole of his feet unto the crown" suffered from them, Oliver Cromwell suffered from them.

Throughout most of his adult life Karl Marx was tormented by boils, which were particularly prevalent when he was writing Das Kapital, which he wrote in a fit of spleen, in the hope of destroying capitalism and undermining existing society.

Such was the work's destructive potential, he suspected there was some mysterious link between it and his boils. As if his inner impulses had somehow taken shape on his skin in the form of festering sores and seeping lumps.

So Bush is in good, if not like-minded company. Keep putting on the plasters, George.

webTitle: Euronext makes its play for LSE

fields.headline: Euronext makes its play for LSE
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Euronext, the pan-European stock exchange, expressed its interest in a merger with the London Stock Exchange yesterday as it emerged that its talks with Liffe, the UK derivatives market, had ended without agreement.
fields.body:
Euronext, the pan-European stock exchange, expressed its interest in a merger with the London Stock Exchange yesterday as it emerged that its talks with Liffe, the UK derivatives market, had ended without agreement.

Speaking in New York, Jean-François Theodore, chairman and chief executive of French-led Euronext, said the troubled London exchange needed to put its affairs in order before talks could begin. "We are available for talks with the LSE. But they need to reassess the situation in order to have a clear vision of what they want to do."

His comments came days after the collapse of a hostile bid for the LSE by OM, the Swedish technology group.

Senior executives of Euronext, a partnership of the French, Belgian and Dutch bourses, had expressed a de sire to join up with the British before the OM bid.

In September, Euronext announced that it was talking with Liffe, the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange, about a merger or cooperation. In Amsterdam yesterday, Dan Casey, a managing director of Liffe, confirmed the talks had ended after failing to reach agreement on a structure to emerge from the deal.

Liffe would have lost "the independence we need to develop our technology" in the event of a full merger.

Euronext executives said they were unwilling simply to buy Liffe's trading systems and were interested in a full merger.

Euronext, which opened only two months ago, was in New York to convince US investors to buy and sell financial products through its exchanges rather than London or Germany.

webTitle: Review: Jill Scott

fields.headline: Jill Scott
fields.standfirst: Liquid Rooms, Edinburgh  *****
fields.trailText: Liquid Rooms, Edinburgh *****
fields.body:
Just as in the good luvin' Scott sings about on her Who Is Jill Scott? album, the foreplay leading up to her appearance on stage is lengthy. Later, she will sing to us of fellas who make you feel as if you've got "Heaven and Miles Davis between your thighs", but you could have gone to heaven and back in the gap between Phil Collins's support (no, not that one, but instead a dreadlocked songster who comes from Leith) and La Scott's opening tune.

But all thoughts of clock-watching dissolved as soon as the new queen of he-done-me-wrong R&B joins us. Maybe she was delayed by putting together her outfit for Scotland: tartan slacks, a chunky cardigan and scarf and earrings like giant funky horse-brasses.

Comparisons have been made between Scott and Macy Gray, but the only thing they share is a mad shock of a hair style. On stage, fiercer than on her slick and lovely album, Scott has the attitude of Nina Simone meets Queen Latifah; Erykah Badu meets Aretha Franklin.

And yet she is her own woman, blessed with a voice that can do scat-singing, operatic strains, good-time funk-ups and soulful ballads, and a songwriting range to match.

In Getting in the Way, she takes off her rings before punching her boyfriend's ex; in He Loves Me (Lyzel in E flat) she shows off her engagement ring to the crowd. In between these two extremes of love and hate, she recites a poem, The Thickness, about the evil that men can do to young women lacking in self-respect. It's a mad, bad, wild feminist rant of a track that silences the room. A lot of men choose now to go to the loo.

The musical arrangement is what lifts the live performance from the polished, laid-back tenor of the album. Blending jazz, soul, and R&B, with a blasting horn section, the set harks back to 1970s highly orchestrated joys such as The Commodores or Earth, Wind and Fire.

During the finest tracks, Scott played an imaginary double bass in the air - sometimes looking like Oliver Hardy picking bits off of his tie - and it was perhaps possible to believe that the naff 1980s and bland 1990s had never happened.

The only blemish on a set that reminded us exactly what feel-good music is all about was an overly-indulgent introduction to the band, with too-lengthy solo spots for all. Nonetheless, if you can get a ticket to see her, even if it involves stealing, do.

Jill Scott plays the Shepherds Bush Empire, London W12 (020-7771 2000), tonight and tomorrow.

webTitle: Review: BBC Phil/ Sinaisky

fields.headline: BBC Phil/ Sinaisky
fields.standfirst: Bridgewater Hall, Manchester ***
fields.trailText: Bridgewater Hall, Manchester ***
fields.body:
The BBC Philharmonic played to a full and enthusiastic house on Saturday, in a programme consisting of Mahler's Second Symphony and a world premiere of a new work by young English composer Kenneth Hesketh.

At God Speeded Summer's End (the title comes from Dylan Thomas's Prologue) is, in the composer's words, a procession of scherzos constructed on the same formal ideas as Dylan's poem, complete with its own acrostic pattern. At a time when many new works declare affinities with a poem or a painting - even a line of philosophy - it was heartening to receive the composer's explanation of exactly how a piece of music relates to its supposed source of inspiration.

All the same, interesting and invaluable though this information is, it rarely impacts on the listener's experience, particularly at first hearing. Nevertheless, each section had its own character, ranging from mystical to hard-driven and climactic. Hints of a dance seemed to bubble beneath the surface, never coming up for air but breathing life into the fast-flowing stream of sound. Punctuated throughout with climaxes, all the music's accumulated energy exploded dramatically in the final moments.

The Mahler got off to a slightly shaky start with a few accidents that may have had an unsettling effect on the orchestra, although Sinaisky's approach was generally a little on the nervy side. Mahler's frequent tempo shifts occasionally caused problems. The graceful second movement flowed beautifully in Mahler's smoothest Austrian dialect, and the scherzo depicting St Anthony's sermon to the fishes was biting, with all his characteristically grotesque personae delivering their sarcastic commentary.

The fourth movement struggled to retain its magic in places, with the brass chorales just slightly too loud and fast for Mahler's carefully notated articulation to speak.

Mezzo soprano Jean Rigby and the principal oboist recaptured some of that magic in some beautifully crafted phrasing. Despite a heart- stopping incorrect entry at one point, the theatrical drama of the finale was suitably thrilling, with all off-stage effects expertly controlled.

The final few minutes were irresistible; the City of Birmingham Chorus, Rigby and soprano Susan Bullock declaimed Mahler's ecstatic text with passionate conviction. But somehow the sense of holiness and joy was never quite there.

webTitle: Review: Boutique Tour

fields.headline: Boutique Tour
fields.standfirst: Rocket, Leeds  ***
fields.trailText: Rocket, Leeds ***
fields.body:
You don't get much for seven quid these days, but this amount buys three hours in the company of the Boutique Bands and Booze tour.

Boutique, is not a wry tribute to George Best's 1970s clothes store but the adopted name of the Skint Records-associated Brighton club that put the tour together. Three bands (and a few DJs) alternate every night, and as for the booze, the whole shebang is sponsored by Carling, with the NME and Rizla. The beer certainly flows, much of it from full cans hurled dangerously from the stage, so we hope the sponsor's involvement extends to public liability insurance and the provision of tin hats for the crowd.

If only our lovely licensing laws were as adventurous as this bill. Sadly, the Draconian restrictions ensure that hotly-tipped South are on absurdly early, before most of the audience have arrived. Despite conducting an inquiry worthy of Inspector Morse, I can't locate anyone who saw them. A shame.

Instead, an adjoining room recreates the Boutique's fabled atmosphere, as DJs Future Shock and Because of You hitmaker Scanty Sandwich rattle everybody's senses with uplifting, twangy house.

If there's a heap of sponsors' booze on the artists' contracts, it's unlikely that much of it will end up in Alpinestars. Two angst-ridden, serious young men who look less likely to down a pint than indulge in a philosophical discussion about it, they nevertheless could be the find of the tour.

Originally formed for a one-off slot at Manchester gay night Homo-Electric, their luscious, thoughtful music manages to combine Chemical Brothers electro with the more naive melodies of synth-pop pioneers Kraftwerk and New Order. Not exactly ones to watch (look closely, and their heads move), but an invigorating listen.

On different nights, headliners include Lo-Fi Allstars and Dirty Beatniks, but here Regular Fries perform the honours. These London Happy Mondays have been much maligned recently, but it's hard to see why. They might be lacking on the tunes front but, live, their war-like grooves are simply fearsome. Sweating profusely in their leather coats, their refreshing (and presumably, Carling assisted) fervour ignites the crowd into the most riotous dancing seen in Yorkshire since the infamous Itching Powder Disaster of 1942. Good value: this is less a tour than a travelling event.

At the Wedgewood, Portsmouth (02392 863911), tonight and the Astoria, London WC2 (020-74349592), tomorrow.

webTitle: Review: A Great Reckonin'

fields.headline: No sex please, we're Scottish
fields.standfirst:
A Great Reckonin'
Perth Theatre **
fields.trailText:
A Great Reckonin'
Perth Theatre **
fields.body:
If history had taken a different course, Ewan McGregor might well have been starring in this production. "The first theatre to move me," he says on a fund-raising leaflet for the place whose boards he trod in pre-Trainspotting days.

The twists and turns of history is the subject of this new play by Ian Brown, set in Perth in 1437, days after the murder of King James I of Scotland.

A troupe of actors from the Royal company have travelled from Edinburgh to Perth to perform for the king. With the loss of their patron, the players have to find a new play, and fast, to pull in crowds despite a period of mourning and the onset of Lent. They decide upon a life of the king, and their rehearsals of key scenes form the biography-in-flashback structure of the play.

This structure might have worked better without the accompanying emphasis on bawdy farce. You can see the gags approaching without having to climb up into a watchtower; any serious intent to look at the nature of power is reduced to little more than a pantomime romp through Scottish history.

The company leader splits his trousers, at crotch level of course, only to have them attended to by one saucy maid, Jinty. Just as she is on her knees, the rest of the gang troop in and, do you know, they don't believe she has sewing on her mind. Boom boom!

Strip away the farce and there are some good things here, however. Brown has a knack for dialogue in lively Scots, and is able to bring history to life in the strongest scenes. In one of the simplest and least rompy, those who died in an inter-clan battle provide moving testimony: "I did my duty and died" each says. Their words build up into a litany of lives lost and, uniquely in the play, raise the question: "For what?"

The cast do their best to be engaging, with Ann Scott Jones as Phemy and Lorraine McGowan as Jinty shining despite the sometimes wooden gags. And the audience lap up jokes about their despised neighbours. "Blood, death, atrocity? Sounds like Dundee," was savoured, as was "Noisy neighbours, the English."

Those who recognised the Shakespearean lines, cheekily included in 1437-time, more than a century before they were written, chortled away smugly.

Other than these smiles, you wonder what an audience might take away from the play on the issues it touches upon: power, politics and how individuals relate to both. Little, one suspects, though the fact that James I died in a drain in Perth was well established by the end. Historically this might be fascinating, but dramatically we are left wanting and oddly unmoved.

Until November 25. Box office: 01738 621031.

webTitle: Fund supermarkets set to bust into the big time

fields.headline: Fund supermarkets set to bust into the big time
fields.trailText: Growth in the investment supermarket sector looks set to continue with the launch tomorrow of a supermarket review service from Isabusters.com.
fields.body:
Growth in the investment supermarket sector looks set to continue with the launch tomorrow of a supermarket review service from Isabusters.com.

The advice and information website will rate investment supermarkets according to the number of services they have, how much customer support is on offer and how committed they are to e-commerce.

It will review supermarkets established by the likes of Fidelity, Egg, Virgin Money, Interactive Investor International and MoneyWorld and aims to give users enough information to make decisions by themselves.

Investment supermarkets, or fund supermarkets as they are also known, let you combine funds from different fund managers within one Isa, and switch easily between funds. Normally, you have to invest your annual £7,000 Isa allowance with one fund manager, although you can choose more than one fund from that manager.

If you don't use a supermarket, the only way to get round this rule is to use a self select Isa, which involves extra costs. Supermarkets let you bypass the rule because the supermarket provider effectively becomes the Isa provider.

Funds are also available at a discount to the price you would pay if buying from an adviser or direct from the fund manager, which will usually levy the full initial charge of up to 5.25% of the amount invested.

As such, supermarkets are similar to discount brokers: the main difference being that while brokers often cut the annual management charge as well as the initial charge, they don't let you mix and match different funds under the banner of one fund provider.

Technically speaking, Virgin Money, Interactive Investor International and MoneyWorld sit more comfortably in the discount broker basket because, while they sell funds with a discount on the initial charge, they don't let you mix and match. Instead, they will sell funds from a variety of vetted providers, often at a bigger discount than the mix and match supermarkets. Virgin Money, for example, guarantees no initial charge on any of the funds it sells.

This can be good if you know the fund you want to buy, but if you're not sure and would prefer to combine several funds in one ISA and spread the risk, supermarkets such as Egg's and Fidelity's are a better option.
