webTitle: Review: Elektra

fields.headline: Elektra
fields.standfirst: Baltimore Opera Company, Baltimore ***
fields.trailText: Baltimore Opera Company, Baltimore ***
fields.body:
The Baltimore Opera, founded 50 years ago this year by Rosa Ponselle, tends to be the operatic Cinderella of America's east coast. But what the company lacks in resources it makes up for in imagination - and Baltimore's seasons are often more challenging than those of the more glamorous Washington Opera run by Placido Domingo down the road.

Artistic ambition has been the hallmark of general director Michael Harrison's years in Baltimore, and the new production of Elektra there demonstrates the company's strengths and limitations. Merely to attempt Elektra is a statement of serious intent - for Elektra is a challenge.

Still, this production by Roberto Oswald was not a success. The Argentinian director produced a fine Norma in Baltimore two years ago and has an impressive Parsifal currently in Washington, but his half-hearted transposition of Strauss's opera into a 1920s mental asylum lacked coherence and conviction. The elemental Sophoclean myth constantly burst the bounds of what increasingly seemed an arbitrary setting.

In the orchestra pit, Christian Badea showed he has the measure of Strauss's most exciting score. Badea has been in charge of some fine things in Baltimore, including last season's Tannhauser directed by Werner Herzog. In Elektra he revealed the restraint this score contains. The Baltimore orchestra played with conviction and passion, but were sometimes challenged beyond their limits.

The irresistible curiosity of this production, though, lay in the casting of its Klytemnestra. To judge by the programme notes, the unwary might think that Renata Scotto's career began in 1992, rather than in 1953. Yet there is a certain truth in such discretion. After three decades as one of the great Italian lyric sopranos of her era, Scotto has enjoyed an Indian summer in some interesting German and French roles, and here she was, aged 67, making her debut in a part that another great singer of her generation, Christa Ludwig, also began singing late in her career.

One had to make allowances: her voice is greatly diminished from what it was. But the vocal art is something else, and the colouring, the attention to phrasing, the musicality and the sheer stage presence are amazingly intact. Everything Scotto sang compelled attention and respect even though the volume was often low. Badea was a very sensitive accompanist, holding the orchestra back as much as he dared. This was a fascinating masterclass in the victory of art over nature.

That Scotto did not overshadow Marilyn Zschau in the title role says something interesting about them both. As Covent Garden audiences know, Zschau has the equipment for Elektra, from the manic stamina to the piercing soprano top C that must cut through at climactic moments. But she also commands the dramatic expression that a fully rounded Elektra needs. Her scenes with Renate Behle's Chrysothomis - a patchy performance - and with the impressive Tom Fox as Orestes, were as compelling and disturbing as anyone could want.

webTitle: Review: Paul Motion Trio 2000

fields.headline: Paul Motian Trio 2000
fields.standfirst: Purcell Room, London *****
fields.trailText: Purcell Room, London *****
fields.body:
There will certainly be funkier, noisier, even more eclectic performances, and shows waving more explicitly accessible signposts at audiences during the upcoming week of the London jazz festival.

But it will be a big surprise if there's one with more group empathy, or a more remarkable display of sustained melodic invention on a saxophone than that displayed by Paul Motian's Trio on the opening weekend.

If Motian's delicate and intricate chamber-jazz appears to demand focused concentration, the audacity of the improvising and the variety and refinement of the sounds made the two sets pass as if the listener were suspended in a trance.

The trio was Motian on drums, Chris Potter on reeds and Marc Johnson on bass. Motian, a former partner of Keith Jarrett and the late Bill Evans, is a percussionist with an eccentrically personal signature, using space and fragmented patterns to imply rhythms as much as state them. Johnson, a regular Motian partner, is a bassist with a comparable intelligent delicacy - and Chris Potter has lately emerged as one of the most remarkable saxophone improvisers.

Motian's full percussion panoply was on display on Saturday, with tickling cymbal figures followed by exclamatory slams, softly whis-pering brushwork, and brief surges of swing.

But though this was a sublime group performance, it was really Potter's night. He won't ever get to be as famous as Michael Brecker (he doesn't go in for saxophone aerobics, warp-speed runs, explosive climaxes), but over the course of an hour-and- a-half he delivered an astonishing succession of solos - and he got better as the show went on.

A long, swerving tenor solo on a fast opener to the second half burst the usual boundaries of how far single improvised motifs could be extended, and Potter played a ballad of breathtaking fragility for the encore that confirmed how strong he was in the opposite dynamic direction.

Though the improvising was of a high standard, the written materials were almost as distinctive - and coupled with the meticulous accuracy of the playing, even at extremes of the sax and double-bass registers, they were crucial to the gig's remarkable consistency.

Johnson, a regular Motian partner, is a bassist with a comparable intelligent delicacy - and Chris Potter has lately emerged as one of the most remarkable saxophone improvisers. Motian's full percussion panoply was on display on Saturday, with tickling cymbal figures followed by exclamatory slams, softly whis-pering brushwork, and brief surges of swing. But though this was a sublime group performance, it was really Potter's night. He won't ever get to be as famous as Michael Brecker (he doesn't go in for saxophone aerobics, warp-speed runs, explosive climaxes), but over the course of an hour-and- a-half he delivered an astonishing succession of solos - and he got better as the show went on. A long, swerving tenor solo on a fast opener to the second half burst the usual boundaries of how far single improvised motifs could be extended, and Potter played a ballad of breathtaking fragility for the encore that confirmed how strong he was in the opposite dynamic direction. Though the improvising was of a high standard, the written materials were almost as distinctive - and coupled with the meticulous accuracy of the playing, even at extremes of the sax and double-bass registers, they were crucial to the gig's remarkable consistency.

webTitle: Review: Airto Moreira

fields.headline: Airto Moreira
fields.standfirst: Royal Festival Hall, London  ***
fields.trailText: Royal Festival Hall, London ***
fields.body:
This year's London jazz festival aims to pull together the cultures of the world with 21st- century fervour, and here it made a flying start with an exhilarating 16-course evening of multi-cultural African music, set alight with a whoosh of Brazilian fire courtesy of Airto Moreira.

The Master Drummers of Africa were formed by Lord Eric Sugumugu of Ghana in the late 1970s, re-established in 1995 and have been on a mission ever since to educate the world about "The Drum". Centre stage belonged for most of the concert to the Master Drummers; the master percussionist, Moreira, did not step in until the second half.

Nigeria boasts the talking drum, but what's in a name? Here, other varieties of percussion were just as colourfully noisy. Thus did the good ship African Glory set off from the Ivory Coast, sailing via Namibia, Sudan, Kenya and South Africa before venturing to the rhythmic reaches of countries such as Ethiopia and Cameroon in the second half.

First stop was a playful double act, turned into a classy solo by the lead drummer, who exchanged the large drum slung around his hips for a set of six smaller bongos clustered like grapes in a bunch. The tumult slowed and quietened to let him launch a diversity of tones, with only the briefest of raps for rhythmic backing.

Then the man from Algeria got the audience singing in call and response; later, a good proportion of us were on our feet too. The piece divided into complex rhythms and chants, enlivened by the dervish-whirling of its leader and by the wonderful, ringing voices of the drummers, but the whine of speaker feedback sharpened it occasionally to an unwelcome edge.

The mbira of Zimbabwe introduced a welcome melodic vibrancy, a visit to Marrakesh was haunting, and the pit-stop at the Congo amusing, mostly because the lead drummer adopted a flat-on-his-back position, presumably to attain more leverage.

When Moreira, a Latin veteran of groups such as Weather Report and Return to Forever, appeared to huge applause, he was worth the price of the ticket alone.

He struck up by rustling what sounded like a bag of seashells around his neck, adding in some trademark verbal scat and cat-calls, and establishing regularity with the whump of a big bass drum.

Moreira piled up mounds of sound and demolished them with an exquisite control of momentum. His instruments looked intriguing but his real tools are more intangible; echo, stillness, pitch and groove, pace and space. Under his fingers, sounds became more than pulse, texture or embellishment as he created his own continuum. Soon, too soon, the African drummers came back and set sail joyfully once more, with Moreira the master-mixer in their midst. He looked to be having a fine old time but the night, in volume at least, belonged to The Drum.

webTitle: Where's the bonus?

fields.headline: Where's the bonus?
fields.trailText: I have been working in an art gallery for eight months. When I started my boss told me there was a bonus scheme dependent on how many paintings I sold. So far I've sold over £7000 worth of work but seen no bonus.
fields.body:
The problem

I have been working in an art gallery for eight months. I do a six day week but I don't have a contract and I am unsure about sick pay and holidays.

The company itself has been operating for a year and a half. When I started working for them my boss (who is a lawyer) told me there was a bonus scheme getting introduced depending on how many paintings I sold. So far I've sold over £7000 worth of work and there is no bonus to be seen. What do you think about this?

The solution

What do I think? I think you have a pretty lousy employer who is taking you for a ride. But, perhaps I should be a bit more charitable since this is a new and small firm - maybe your boss is just ignorant (although as a lawyer, he or she should know better).

The fact is that you are entitled to a written contract and to your statutory working rights, which include holiday and sick pay. Your not having been given a contract has no bearing on your rights, which still apply. Moreover, if you now start demanding these rights, you cannot be sacked for doing so.

My advice would be to seek input from ACAS (number in your local phone book) in order to ascertain exactly how much holiday leave etc you are entitled to. Once you know what your rights are, you need to approach your boss and ask for a written contract in which at least your minimum rights are stated. Many employers offer more than basic statutory rights (for example, extra holiday) so you might want to negotiate for more. Be pleasant and cheerful in your approach - assertive but not aggressive nor apologetic.

Put your suggested contract in writing as an opening for discussion - as this is a starting point for negotiation, it is wise to pitch it a little higher than you really expect. If your boss balks at any element, gently remind him/her that these are your statutory employment rights and that you have sought advice.

As for your bonus scheme, in theory your boss has breached a verbal contract that can be just as binding as a written one.

However, it is obviously harder to prove and you will have to decide where you want to go with this. I would suggest including a bonus scheme in your draft contract and see what they say.

 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

webTitle: Review: Gladiators and Caesers

fields.headline: Gladiators and Caesars
fields.standfirst: British Museum, London ***
fields.trailText: British Museum, London ***
fields.body:
They looked like robots coming towards you with insect eyes, stabbing and chopping to the cheers of the crowd. Behind the helmets' eye holes, you might have glimpsed an expression, but probably not. There was something inhuman about ancient Roman gladiators.

As the colossal success of Ridley Scott's film Gladiator shows, we are still enthralled by the games held in the Roman empire 2,000 years ago. Few people read Cicero any more, but we can recognise our own addiction to spectacle in the Roman arena. The massive technology of entertainment, the efficient delivery of something grossly unedifying - that aspect of the ancient world is at least familiar to us.

Not as familiar, though, as this exhibition implies. Where Ridley Scott lavished on us tigers, women charioteers and Russell Crowe, the curators of this exhibition expect us to be satisfied with a niggardly series of lesser spectacles: boxers, wrestlers, even theatre. The games are set in a wider context of public entertainment, an approach that is gratuitously deflating. All cultures have public spectacle of some kind; they don't all have fights to the death between heavily armed men in specially constructed arenas.

The artefacts themselves, from all over Europe and north Africa, suggest the appalling magnificence of it. Gladiators were abject but, as ancient graffiti reveals, they could receive rock-star adulation. Images of gladiators appear on decorative objects from all over the empire: oil lamps, flasks, toys.

The armour is stunning. Helmets seem designed to transform a man into a vicious marionette. Ornate greaves (leg armour), stabbing swords, shields and weapons used by the different types of gladiator all added to an intensely stylised violence. Fights by pairs of gladiators were part of an elaborately stage-managed event encompassing processions, warm-up acts and music; their corpses would be dragged off by slaves dressed as the god Mercury, guide of the dead. We like to picture the gladiator as a complex human being, like Maximus or Kirk Douglas's Spartacus, but the Romans were in love with the image of a killing machine.

Rome's most barbaric activity generated its enduring symbol - the Colosseum. The highest achievements of Roman architecture were dedicated to making the murderous games splendid. The weakness of this exhibition is that it doesn't communicate the power of the games as a spectacle that haunts western civilisation.
Until January 21. Details: 020-7636 1555.
